\text{(b)}\quad &\text{For } \sigma\gg\varepsilon\omega:\; K\approx (1+j)\sqrt{\frac{\omega\mu_0\sigma}{2}},\\[1mm]
&\text{and for } \sigma\ll\varepsilon\omega:\; K\approx \omega\sqrt{\mu_0\varepsilon} + \frac{j\sigma}{2}\sqrt{\frac{\mu_0}{\varepsilon}}.\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}\quad &\delta = \frac{1}{\sigma\sqrt{\mu_0/\varepsilon}}\quad\text{(power decays as }e^{-1}\text{ over }z=\delta\text{)}.\\[1mm]
\text{(d)}\quad &T = \frac{4\eta_0\,\Re\{\eta_2\}}{|\eta_0+\eta_2|^2},\quad\text{with } \eta_0=\sqrt{\mu_0/\varepsilon_0}\text{ and } \eta_2\approx\sqrt{\mu_0/\varepsilon}\text{ (if } \sigma\ll\varepsilon\omega\text{)}.\\[1mm]
\text{(e)}\quad &\text{For } \varepsilon/\varepsilon_0=49,\; \sigma=2\;\text{mho/m},\; \omega=2\pi(2.45\times10^9):\\[1mm]
&T\approx 0.44,\quad \delta\approx 0.93\,\text{cm}.\\[1mm]
&\text{Thus, the fairly deep penetration of microwaves is an advantage over infrared heating.}
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We wish to show that a beam of light propagating in a nonlinear medium

  n = n₀ + n₂E²        (1)

can “self‐trap” (i.e. not spread out by diffraction) because the intensity‐dependent increase in refractive index acts as a waveguide (via total internal reflection) for the beam. In what follows we will compare the divergence due to diffraction with the angular “protection” offered by the nonlinearly induced index “well” and then obtain a threshold power.

Let’s go through the steps.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Diffraction Divergence

A beam that passes through a circular aperture (or has a transverse extent of size D) will diffract, emerging with an angular spread given by

  θ_d = 1.22 λₙ/D,      (2)

where λₙ is the wavelength in the medium. (Often one writes λₙ = λ/n₀, so that one may also write

  θ_d = 1.22 (λ/n₀) /D.)

Thus the rays that “escape” the central region do so by leaving at an angle approximately θ_d relative to the propagation axis.

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. Index Change and “Guiding” by Total Internal Reflection

Now, in our nonlinear medium the refractive index increases in the region of high intensity. If the beam has a high enough intensity (and its central region then has index n_core = n₀ + δn, with δn = n₂E²), then the beam may self-guide.

Imagine the beam as a “fiber” with core index

  n_core = n₀ + δn   with δn = n₂E²,

and cladding index n₀. Then, a ray inside the high‐intensity core that strikes the interface at an angle of incidence α (measured relative to the normal to the boundary) will be internally reflected provided that

  α ≥ θ_c,     (3)

where the critical angle θ_c is given by

  sin θ_c = n₀/(n₀ + δn).  (4)

Now, if we consider a ray that propagates nearly parallel to the axis but eventually reaches the edge, it will (roughly) leave the beam at the diffractive angle θ_d; geometrically one finds that the ray will hit the side at an angle with respect to the normal given by

  α = 90° – θ_d.

Thus, for total internal reflection (TIR) the condition is

  90° – θ_d ≥ θ_c   or  θ_d ≤ 90° – θ_c.  (5)

──────────────────────────────
Step 3. Approximating for Small Index Changes

For many optical media δn = n₂E² is small compared with n₀. Then we can expand the expression (4) for the critical angle. Because

  sin θ_c = n₀/(n₀ + δn) ≈ 1 – δn/n₀   (for δn/n₀ ≪ 1),
 
the critical angle will be very near 90°. It is more useful to write the TIR condition in “ray‐angle” language. Note that if a ray strikes the interface at an angle α = 90° – θ_d (with θ_d small), then the condition for TIR becomes (to leading order) a condition on θ_d. Writing

  cos θ_c = √(1 – sin²θ_c) ≈ √(1 – (1 – 2δn/n₀)) = √(2δn/n₀),  (6)

we see that the “allowed” deviation inside the core is roughly bounded by

  θ_d ≲ √(2δn/n₀) = √(2 n₂E²/n₀).  (7)

Thus (approximately) to have self-trapping we require that the angular spread from diffraction be no larger than the “trapping angle” provided by the nonlinear index change:

  θ_d ≈ 1.22 λₙ/D ≲ √(2 n₂E²/n₀).  (8)

──────────────────────────────
Step 4. Finding the Threshold Field

We set the two angles equal in the threshold case:

  1.22 λₙ/D = √(2 n₂E²₍ₜₕ₎/n₀).  (9)

Squaring both sides gives

  (1.22)² λₙ² /D² = 2 n₂E²₍ₜₕ₎/n₀   ⇒  E²₍ₜₕ₎ = (1.22)² λₙ² n₀/(2 n₂ D²).  (10)

Remember that the wavelength in the medium is λₙ = λ/n₀. Inserting this,

  λₙ² = λ²/n₀²,
 
so that

  E²₍ₜₕ₎ = (1.22)² λ²/(2 n₂ n₀ D²).  (11)

──────────────────────────────
Step 5. Converting to Threshold Power

The time‐averaged intensity I (power per unit area) in a medium with refractive index n₀ is given by

  I = ½ n₀ c ε₀ E².     (12)

Thus the threshold intensity becomes

  I₍ₜₕ₎ = ½ n₀ c ε₀ E²₍ₜₕ₎
        = ½ n₀ c ε₀ [(1.22)² λ²/(2 n₂ n₀ D²)]
        = (1.22)² c ε₀ λ²/(4 n₂ D²).  (13)

For a beam whose cross‐sectional area (we assume a circular cross section) is

  A = π(D/2)² = πD²/4,
 
the threshold power is

  P₍ₜₕ₎ = I₍ₜₕ₎ A
    = [(1.22)² c ε₀ λ²/(4 n₂ D²)] × (πD²/4)
    = (π (1.22)² c ε₀ λ²)/(16 n₂).  (14)

Notice that the D² cancels: the threshold power for self‐trapping does not depend on the beam diameter. (This is a well–known result for “critical power” phenomena in Kerr media.)

──────────────────────────────
Step 6. Final Answer

Thus, the threshold power for the existence of a self‐trapped beam in a nonlinear medium with n = n₀ + n₂E² is

  P₍ₜₕ₎ = (π (1.22)² c ε₀ λ²)/(16 n₂).

We now box the final answer:

\[
\boxed{ P_{th}=\frac{\pi (1.22)^2\, c\,\epsilon_0\, \lambda^2}{16\, n_{2}} }
\]

──────────────────────────────
Discussion

What we have shown is that if the intensity is high enough so that the nonlinear index change δn = n₂E² produces a “trapping angle” (approximately √(2δn/n₀)) that is at least as large as the diffractive spread (≈1.22λ/(n₀D)), then total internal reflection at the edge of the “nonlinear waveguide” can prevent the beam from diffracting. In other words, diffraction and nonlinear self-guiding can exactly balance at the threshold power given above.

We begin with the Ansatz

  A(x, t) = A₀ e^(i(K·x – ωt))   and  φ(x, t) = 0

where A₀, K, and ω are constant vectors/scalars. In our electromagnetic theory the fields are defined in terms of the potentials by

  B = ∇×A   and  E = –(1/c)∂A/∂t – ∇φ.

Since φ = 0 the electric field becomes

  E = –(1/c)∂A/∂t.

We will substitute our Ansatz into each of Maxwell’s equations and see what constraints are imposed.

──────────────────────────────
Step (a): ∇·B = 0

We have B = ∇×A. With
  A(x, t) = A₀ e^(i(K·x – ωt)),
the spatial derivatives bring down a factor of iK, so

  B = ∇×A = i (K×A₀) e^(i(K·x – ωt)).

Now,
  ∇·B = ∇·[i (K×A₀) e^(i(K·x – ωt))]
     = i (K×A₀) · (iK) e^(i(K·x – ωt))
     = – [K·(K×A₀)] e^(i(K·x – ωt)).

However, the vector identity for any three vectors tells us that K · (K×A₀) = 0. Thus

  ∇·B = 0  (always).

Interpretation: The condition ∇·B = 0 is automatically satisfied by any plane‐wave Ansatz of the form considered.

──────────────────────────────
Step (b): ∇×E + (1/c)∂B/∂t = 0

First, the electric field is

  E = –(1/c)∂A/∂t = –(1/c)(–iω A) = i (ω/c) A
      = i (ω/c) A₀ e^(i(K·x – ωt)).

Now, calculate the curl of E. Since the spatial variation is through the phase factor,

  ∇×E = ∇×[i (ω/c) A₀ e^(i(K·x – ωt))]
     = i (ω/c) (i K×A₀) e^(i(K·x – ωt))
     = – (ω/c) (K×A₀) e^(i(K·x – ωt)).

Next, we compute the time derivative of B. We have

  B = i (K×A₀) e^(i(K·x – ωt)),
thus

  ∂B/∂t = i (K×A₀) (–iω) e^(i(K·x – ωt))
      = ω (K×A₀) e^(i(K·x – ωt)).

Then, (1/c)∂B/∂t = (ω/c)(K×A₀) e^(i(K·x – ωt)).

Now add the two results:

  ∇×E + (1/c)∂B/∂t = [– (ω/c)(K×A₀) + (ω/c)(K×A₀)] e^(i(K·x – ωt)) = 0.

Interpretation: Faraday’s law is automatically satisfied by our plane–wave Ansatz.

──────────────────────────────
Step (c): ∇·E = 0

Using E = i (ω/c) A₀ e^(i(K·x – ωt)), the divergence is

  ∇·E = i (ω/c) (∇·(A₀ e^(i(K·x – ωt)))). 

Since A₀ is constant, the divergence gives

  ∇·E = i (ω/c) (i K·A₀) e^(i(K·x – ωt))
      = – (ω/c)(K·A₀) e^(i(K·x – ωt)).

Setting ∇·E = 0 requires that

  – (ω/c)(K·A₀) e^(i(K·x – ωt)) = 0  ⇒  K·A₀ = 0        (if ω ≠ 0).

Interpretation: This tells us that A₀ must be orthogonal to K; in other words, the vector potential (and hence the electric field) is transverse to the direction of propagation. This is the expected condition for electromagnetic plane waves.

──────────────────────────────
Step (d): ∇×B – (1/c)∂E/∂t = 0

We already found

  B = i (K×A₀) e^(i(K·x – ωt)).

Take its curl:

Because A₀ and K are constant, we have

  ∇×B = ∇×[i (K×A₀) e^(i(K·x – ωt))]
      = i (K×A₀)×(iK) e^(i(K·x – ωt)) 
      = – [K× (K×A₀)] e^(i(K·x – ωt)).

We now use the vector identity

  K×(K×A₀) = K (K·A₀) – A₀ (K·K).
Since we already have K·A₀ = 0, this simplifies to

  K×(K×A₀) = –A₀|K|².
Thus,
  ∇×B = –[–A₀|K|²] e^(i(K·x – ωt)) = A₀|K|² e^(i(K·x – ωt)).

Now, let us compute the time derivative of E. From above,
  E = i (ω/c) A₀ e^(i(K·x – ωt)),
so
  ∂E/∂t = i (ω/c) A₀ (–iω) e^(i(K·x – ωt)) = (ω²/c) A₀ e^(i(K·x – ωt)).
Then,
  – (1/c) ∂E/∂t = – (1/c)(ω²/c) A₀ e^(i(K·x – ωt)) = – (ω²/c²) A₀ e^(i(K·x – ωt)).

Thus, Ampere’s law becomes

  ∇×B – (1/c)∂E/∂t = [|K|² A₀ – (ω²/c²) A₀] e^(i(K·x – ωt)) = 0.

Since e^(i(K·x – ωt)) ≠ 0 and A₀ is nonzero for a nontrivial solution, we require

  |K|² – ω²/c² = 0   ⇒  ω² = c²|K|²   or  ω = c|K|   (taking ω > 0).

Interpretation: This is the usual dispersion relation for electromagnetic waves propagating in vacuum.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

To summarize, the constraints imposed by Maxwell’s equations on the plane–wave solution

  A(x, t) = A₀ e^(i(K·x – ωt)),  φ(x, t) = 0

are:

(a) ∇·B = 0: Automatically satisfied.

(b) ∇×E + (1/c)∂B/∂t = 0: Also automatically satisfied.

(c) ∇·E = 0: Implies that  K·A₀ = 0  (the vector potential is transverse).

(d) ∇×B – (1/c)∂E/∂t = 0: Implies the dispersion relation  ω² = c²|K|²  or  ω = c|K|.

Thus, our final answer is:

  \[ \boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}&\quad \nabla\cdot\mathbf{B}=0\quad \text{is automatically satisfied}, \\
\text{(b)}&\quad \nabla\times\mathbf{E} + \frac{1}{c}\frac{\partial\mathbf{B}}{\partial t}=0\quad \text{is automatically satisfied}, \\
\text{(c)}&\quad \mathbf{K}\cdot\mathbf{A}_0=0,\quad\text{so that the field is transverse}, \\
\text{(d)}&\quad |\mathbf{K}|^2=\frac{\omega^2}{c^2}\quad\text{(i.e.}\, \omega=c|\mathbf{K}|\text{), the dispersion relation.}
\end{aligned}
} \]

We wish to study how an electromagnetic wave (an X‐ray beam) interacts with a metal that contains free electrons of number density n. For frequencies ω in the X‐ray region, one may often neglect bound‐electron effects, and the dielectric constant may be modeled by the free–electron (plasma) result

  ε(ω) = 1 – ω_p²/ω²     (1)

where

  ω_p² = (4πne²)/(m)     (Gaussian units)

(One may use SI units with appropriate factors; we shall work in Gaussian units for simplicity.) Note that for X–rays ω ≫ ω_p so that ε is only slightly less than unity. (We also assume that there is no absorption so that ε is real.)

There are two parts to the problem. Let us now work them out step by step.

──────────────────────────────
Step (a): Find the Critical Angle θ₀

When a wave is incident from vacuum (with refractive index 1) onto a medium with dielectric constant (or refractive index)

  n_medium = √ε = √(1 – ω_p²/ω²),
           (2)

Snell’s law tells us

  sin θ = n_medium sin θ_t  →  sin θ_t = sin θ/√ε.  (3)

Inside the metal the wave vector in the z–direction (normal to the surface) is

  k_z = (ω/c) √(ε – sin²θ).  (4)

When ε – sin²θ < 0, the square root becomes imaginary and the transmitted wave becomes evanescent (decaying exponentially away from the surface). (This is the usual condition for “total internal” or “total external” reflection; here the fact that ε < 1 makes total reflection occur only for very grazing incidence.) In our problem the phrase “X–rays which strike a metal surface at an angle of incidence to the normal greater than a critical angle are totally reflected” indicates that for

  sin²θ > ε   →  sin²θ > 1 – ω_p²/ω²,
          (5)

the transmitted wave is evanescent and the beam is totally reflected. (Remember that θ is the angle measured from the normal, so “greater than the critical angle” corresponds to nearly grazing incidence.)

The critical condition is reached when

  sin²θ₀ = 1 – ω_p²/ω².  (6)

Thus, the critical angle measured from the normal is

  θ₀ = sin⁻¹ [ √(1 – ω_p²/ω²) ].  (7)

This is the answer for part (a).

──────────────────────────────
Step (b): Calculate the Reflection Fraction When Total Reflection Does Not Occur

We now consider the situation where ω and θ are such that the transmitted wave is propagating (not evanescent); that is, when

  sin²θ < 1 – ω_p²/ω².
          (8)

In this case we need the Fresnel reflection coefficient for the amplitude. We are told to assume that the polarization is perpendicular to the plane of incidence (often called “s–polarization” or “TE polarization”).

The Fresnel formula for the amplitude reflection coefficient r for a wave going from vacuum (refractive index n = 1) into a medium with dielectric constant ε is

  r = (cosθ – k_z/(ω/c))/(cosθ + k_z/(ω/c)),
         (9)

where k_z is given by Eq. (4) when divided by (ω/c):

  k_z/(ω/c) = √(ε – sin²θ).

Thus,

  r = [ cosθ – √(ε – sin²θ) ] / [ cosθ + √(ε – sin²θ) ].  (10)

Since ε = 1 – ω_p²/ω² [see Eq. (1)], we may write this as

  r = [ cosθ – √(1 – ω_p²/ω² – sin²θ) ] / [ cosθ + √(1 – ω_p²/ω² – sin²θ) ].  (11)

The fraction of the incident power that is reflected (often called the reflectivity) is given by

  R = |r|².  (12)

Thus, in summary, part (b) is answered by stating that the reflected fraction is given by

  R = [ (cosθ – √(1 – ω_p²/ω² – sin²θ)) / (cosθ + √(1 – ω_p²/ω² – sin²θ)) ]².

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The critical angle is

  θ₀ = sin⁻¹ ( √(1 – ω_p²/ω²) ).

(b) For the case when the transmitted wave is propagating (i.e. when sin²θ < 1 – ω_p²/ω²), the amplitude reflection coefficient for s–polarization is

  r = [ cosθ – √(1 – ω_p²/ω² – sin²θ) ] / [ cosθ + √(1 – ω_p²/ω² – sin²θ) ],

and the fraction of the incident power reflected is

  R = |r|² = { [ cosθ – √(1 – ω_p²/ω² – sin²θ) ] / [ cosθ + √(1 – ω_p²/ω² – sin²θ) ] }².

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer in LaTeX Boxed Format

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad &\theta_0 = \sin^{-1}\Bigl(\sqrt{1 - \frac{\omega_p^2}{\omega^2}}\Bigr), \\
\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad &r = \frac{\cos \theta - \sqrt{1 - \frac{\omega_p^2}{\omega^2} - \sin^2\theta}}{\cos \theta + \sqrt{1 - \frac{\omega_p^2}{\omega^2} - \sin^2\theta}}, \quad
R = |r|^2.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We start by assuming that the current is uniformly distributed over the cross‐section of the cylindrical wire of radius R. This means that the current density J is constant over the cross-sectional area of the wire. The total current is I, so the current density is given by

  J = I/(πR²).

Since the permeability of the wire is μ, and we are dealing with steady currents (no displacement currents), we can use Ampère’s Law in the form

  ∮ H · dl = I_enc

where the integration path is chosen to be a circle (centered on the wire’s axis) of radius r.

There are two cases to consider: (1) inside the wire (r < R) and (2) outside the wire (r ≥ R). In both cases, due to symmetry, the magnetic field lines are circular and H is tangential with a constant magnitude at a given radius r.

──────────────────────────────
Case 1: Inside the Wire (r < R)

For a circle of radius r inside the wire, the current enclosed (I_enc) is the fraction of the total current corresponding to the area πr².

  I_enc = J × (area of circle of radius r) = (I/(πR²)) × πr² = I (r²/R²).

Applying Ampère’s Law:

  H(2πr) = I (r²/R²).

So the magnetic field intensity inside is

  H = [I r/(2π R²)].

Since B = μ H (with μ being the permeability of the wire), we have

  B = μ I r/(2π R²).

──────────────────────────────
Case 2: Outside the Wire (r ≥ R)

For a circle of radius r outside the wire, the entire current I is enclosed. Thus, I_enc = I.

Applying Ampère’s Law:

  H (2π r) = I.

So the magnetic field intensity outside is

  H = I/(2π r).

And accordingly, the magnetic flux density is

  B = μ H = μ I/(2π r).

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

Thus, the magnetic fields inside and outside the wire are:

Inside the wire (r < R):
  H = I r/(2π R²)    and  B = μI r/(2π R²).

Outside the wire (r ≥ R):
  H = I/(2π r)      and  B = μI/(2π r).

This is our final result.

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{For } r < R:\quad & H(r) = \frac{Ir}{2\pi R^2}, \quad B(r) = \frac{\mu I r}{2\pi R^2}, \\
\text{For } r \ge R:\quad & H(r) = \frac{I}{2\pi r}, \quad B(r) = \frac{\mu I}{2\pi r}.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We wish to determine the spatial variation of the fields in medium 1 (of index n₁) when a plane‐wave of frequency ν is normally incident on an interface with medium 2 (of index n₂). In what follows we let d denote the distance from the interface into medium 1. (Thus d = 0 at the interface.) We assume that the incident wave comes from medium 1 and that only a fraction of energy ρ is reflected. (In energy terms ρ = |r|² so that the amplitude reflection coefficient is |r| = √ρ.) In addition, we are told that when n₂ > n₁ the electric field gets a phase change of π on reflection – that is, the reflected E–field has the opposite sign from what it would have if no phase change had occurred.

Below we explain step by step how one may obtain an answer. (Any answer equivalent to the answer given below is correct.) 

─────────────────────────────  
Step (a): Electric field and its intensity

1. For d ≥ 0 (in medium 1) we take the incident electric field to be

  Eᵢ(d,t) = E₀ cos (k₁ d – ωt)    (1)

where
  k₁ = 2π n₁/λ₀      (λ₀ is the wavelength in vacuum)
  ω = 2πν.

2. The reflected wave (traveling in the –d direction) then is

  Eᵣ(d,t) = E₀r cos (k₁ d + ωt).

Because the electric field picks up a phase shift of π on reflection we have r = –√ρ. Thus

  Eᵣ(d,t) = –√ρ E₀ cos (k₁ d + ωt).    (2)

3. The total electric field in medium 1 is the sum,

  E(d,t) = Eᵢ(d,t) + Eᵣ(d,t)
      = E₀ [cos (k₁ d – ωt) – √ρ cos (k₁ d + ωt)].    (3)

It is sometimes useful to write this as a sum of standing‐wave and traveling pieces. (For ρ = 1 it becomes a perfect standing wave.) 

4. To study the energy density carried by the electric field we need the time–averaged square. Using the well known averages,
  ⟨cos²⟩ = 1/2 
and 
  ⟨cos (k₁ d – ωt) cos (k₁ d + ωt)⟩ = ½ cos (2k₁ d),
one obtains

  ⟨E²(d)⟩ = (E₀²/2)[1 + ρ] – E₀² √ρ cos(2 k₁ d).    (4)

The spatial variation is periodic with period π/k₁ and so the maxima and minima occur when the cosine takes its extreme values.

• Maximum ⟨E²⟩: Occurs when cos (2k₁ d) = –1. That is,
  2k₁ d = π + 2π m  →  d = (π/2 + π m)/k₁  , m an integer.

• Minimum ⟨E²⟩: Occurs when cos (2k₁ d) = +1. That is,
  2k₁ d = 2π m  →  d = π m/k₁  , m an integer.

In particular, note that at the interface, d = 0, one has cos 0 = +1 so that

  ⟨E²(0)⟩ = (E₀²/2)(1+ρ) – E₀² √ρ  ,

which is a minimum when ρ ≠ 0.

─────────────────────────────  
Step (b): Magnetic field and its intensity

For a plane wave in a non–magnetic dielectric the electric and magnetic fields are related by
  B = (n₁/c) E  
(with appropriate direction given by the right–hand rule). However, one must be cautious with superpositions because the reflection may “invert” one field and not the other. 

1. Let the incident magnetic field be

  Bᵢ(d,t) = (n₁E₀/c) cos (k₁ d – ωt).    (5)

2. For the reflected wave, since the electric field gets a minus sign on reflection the relation (together with the rule that B = ˆk × E / ω in a plane wave) implies that there is no additional π phase change in the magnetic field (because reversing the propagation direction reverses the sign of the cross–product). One may show that

  Bᵣ(d,t) = (n₁E₀/c) √ρ cos (k₁ d + ωt).    (6)

3. Thus the total magnetic field is

  B(d,t) = Bᵢ(d,t) + Bᵣ(d,t)
      = (n₁E₀/c)[cos (k₁ d – ωt) + √ρ cos (k₁ d + ωt)].   (7)

Compare with the result (3) for E(d,t). Notice that while the electric fields subtract, the magnetic fields add. 

4. The corresponding time–averaged square, using the same trigonometric averages as above, is

  ⟨B²(d)⟩ = (n₁²E₀²/c²)[(1+ρ)/2 + √ρ cos (2k₁ d)].   (8)

Thus, the maxima of ⟨B²⟩ occur when cos (2k₁ d) = +1 (i.e. when d = πm/k₁) and minima occur when cos (2k₁ d) = –1 (i.e. when d = (π/2 + πm)/k₁).

In summary, while the electric field is inverted upon reflection (acquiring a phase shift of π) the magnetic field has no extra phase shift.

─────────────────────────────  
Step (c): Origin of the darkening in Wiener’s experiment

O. Wiener’s experiment showed a band of minimum darkening on a photographic plate placed at the interface (d = 0). At d = 0 we found that

  ⟨E²(0)⟩ = (E₀²/2)(1+ρ) – E₀² √ρ    (minimum),
  ⟨B²(0)⟩ = (n₁²E₀²/c²)[(1+ρ)/2 + √ρ]   (maximum).

Thus the electric field is weakest at the interface while the magnetic field is strongest there. Since the exposure (or “darkening”) on the photographic plate is determined by the effect of the local field intensity and Wiener’s dark band was observed at a minimum, it must have been due to the electric field.

─────────────────────────────  
Final Answers

(a) The total electric field is given by

  E(d,t) = E₀ [cos (k₁ d – ωt) – √ρ cos (k₁ d + ωt)].

Its time–averaged square is
  ⟨E²(d)⟩ = (E₀²/2)(1 + ρ) – E₀² √ρ cos (2k₁ d),
with maxima at d = (π/2 + π m)/k₁ and minima at d = π m/k₁, where m is any integer.

(b) The magnetic field is

  B(d,t) = (n₁E₀/c)[cos (k₁ d – ωt) + √ρ cos (k₁ d + ωt)],
so that
  ⟨B²(d)⟩ = (n₁²E₀²/c²)[(1 + ρ)/2 + √ρ cos (2k₁ d)].
Thus the magnetic field reflects with no additional phase change (i.e. no sign reversal).

(c) Since ⟨E²⟩ is a minimum at d = 0 (while ⟨B²⟩ is a maximum), the darkening observed in Wiener’s experiment must have been caused by the electric field.

─────────────────────────────  
Final Answer

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}&\quad E(d,t)=E_0\Bigl[\cos(k_1d-\omega t)-\sqrt{\rho}\,\cos(k_1d+\omega t)\Bigr],\\[1mm]
&\quad \langle E^2\rangle=\frac{E_0^2}{2}(1+\rho)-E_0^2\sqrt{\rho}\cos(2k_1d),\\[1mm]
&\quad \text{with maxima at }d=\frac{\pi/2+\pi m}{k_1}\text{ and minima at }d=\frac{\pi m}{k_1},\; m\in\mathbb{Z}.\\[2mm]
\text{(b)}&\quad B(d,t)=\frac{n_1E_0}{c}\Bigl[\cos(k_1d-\omega t)+\sqrt{\rho}\,\cos(k_1d+\omega t)\Bigr],\\[1mm]
&\quad \langle B^2\rangle=\frac{n_1^2E_0^2}{c^2}\left[\frac{1+\rho}{2}+\sqrt{\rho}\cos(2k_1d)\right],
\quad\text{so the magnetic field does not flip phase upon reflection.}\\[2mm]
\text{(c)}&\quad\text{Since } \langle E^2(0)\rangle\text{ is a minimum while } \langle B^2(0)\rangle\text{ is a maximum,}\\[1mm]
&\quad\text{Wiener’s dark band at }d=0\text{ was due to the electric field.}
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We wish to determine (a) the intensity‐reflection coefficient for a wave normally incident on an interface with refractive index n (with air taken to have n = 1), and (b) the radiation pressure on a glass plate (assumed to have two parallel, non–interfering interfaces).

Let’s treat each part in turn.

───────────────────────────── 
Step (a): Reflection Coefficient

When an electromagnetic plane wave is incident normally on a plane interface between two media with refractive indices 1 and n, the amplitude reflection coefficient is given by

  r = (n₁ – n₂)/(n₁ + n₂).

Here n₁ = 1 (air) and n₂ = n (glass), so

  r = (1 – n)/(1 + n).

Since the intensity reflection coefficient is the square of the magnitude of the amplitude coefficient, we have

  R = |r|² = [(n – 1)/(n + 1)]².

Thus, we have shown that

  R = ((n – 1)/(n + 1))².

───────────────────────────── 
Step (b): Radiation Pressure on the Plate

For a beam of light, the momentum flux in vacuum is given by I/c (where I is the intensity and c is the speed of light). When light is reflected, the change in momentum is larger than for pure absorption. (For a perfectly reflecting mirror the momentum change per photon is doubled.) In our problem, the light is partly reflected at the first (air–glass) interface and partly transmitted. If we neglect interference effects (i.e. we treat the different passages through the two surfaces as independent and add the momentum changes incoherently), the situation is as follows:

1. A fraction R of the incident intensity is reflected from the first interface. Since the change in momentum for each reflected photon is 2p (where p = E/c is the momentum of each photon), the momentum transfer per unit time (i.e. the force per unit area, or pressure) due to the reflection is

  P_reflection = 2R I/c.

2. The remainder of the intensity, (1 − R) I, enters the glass. The light then goes out the back (glass→air) interface. Provided there is no absorption and we neglect interference, the momentum that the light carries out of the rear is (1 − R) I/c (when measured in vacuum on the transmitted side). (In a full treatment one must be careful since the light’s momentum inside the dielectric is the subject of the so‐called Abraham–Minkowski controversy. However, for the force on the entire plate, one may simply compare the input and the output momentum flux in free space.) Thus, the transmitted light carries the same momentum flux as would a beam of intensity (1 – R) I in air.

Therefore, the net momentum delivered to the plate is found by comparing the momentum flux coming in from the left to that leaving on the right. In more detail:

• Incident momentum flux (in air) at the front side is I/c.
• Outgoing momentum flux on the left (due to the reflected beam) is also I_R/c = R I/c, but with the sign reversed (since it is in the opposite direction).
• Outgoing momentum flux on the right (transmitted light) is (1 – R)I/c.

Thus, the net momentum per unit time (force per unit area) on the plate is

  F/A = (incoming momentum flux) + (momentum “reversal” from reflection) – (exiting momentum flux).

That is,
  F/A = I/c + R I/c – (1 − R) I/c.

Simplify this:
  F/A = [I + R I − I + R I] / c = [2R I] / c.

Hence, the radiation pressure acting on the plate is

  p_rad = (2R I)/c.

Now, since we already showed in part (a) that 
  R = ((n – 1)/(n + 1))²,
we substitute this in:

  p_rad = [2I/c] ((n – 1)/(n + 1))².

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answers

(a) The reflection coefficient is

  \[ R=\left(\frac{n-1}{n+1}\right)^2. \]

(b) The radiation pressure on the plate is

  \[ p_{rad}=\frac{2I}{c}\left(\frac{n-1}{n+1}\right)^2. \]

Thus, our final boxed answers are:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
&\text{(a)}\quad R=\left(\frac{n-1}{n+1}\right)^2,\\[1mm]
&\text{(b)}\quad p_{rad}=\frac{2I}{c}\left(\frac{n-1}{n+1}\right)^2.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We will show that one acceptable answer is as follows. In what follows the three wires are assumed to be infinitely long and parallel to the z–axis. (All of our discussion is in the “transverse” (xy)–plane.) Suppose that the wires have zero radius and are located on the x–axis at the points

  Wire 1 : (–d, 0)  
  Wire 2 : (0, 0)  
  Wire 3 : (d, 0)

and that each carries a current I in the same direction (say “up‐wards” along +z). (The usual right–hand rule shows that the magnetic field generated by an infinite wire is circular about it.) We now address parts (a), (b) and (c) in turn.

────────────────────────────
Step (a): Finding the Zeros of the Magnetic Field

Each wire produces a field given by

  B = (μ₀ I)/(2πρ)  (in the φ–direction)

where ρ is the perpendicular distance from the wire. When we need to add the contributions from different wires we find it convenient to write the field in Cartesian form. (For a wire located at (a, 0) the field at the point (x, y) is
  
  B(x,y) = (μ₀ I)/(2π) · ( –y, x–a )/[(x–a)² + y²]  .)

Thus, label the contributions as follows:
  • Wire 1 at (–d,0): 
   B₁(x,y) = (μ₀I)/(2π)· ( –y, x + d )/[(x+d)²+y²]
  • Wire 2 at (0,0): 
   B₂(x,y) = (μ₀I)/(2π)· ( –y, x )/(x²+y²]
  • Wire 3 at (d,0): 
   B₃(x,y) = (μ₀I)/(2π)· ( –y, x − d )/[(x−d)²+y²]

We wish to find the points (x,y) where the total field

  B = B₁ + B₂ + B₃ 

vanishes.

Note that by looking at the x– and y–components one finds:

  Bₓ = (μ₀I)/(2π) [ –y/( (x+d)²+y² ) – y/( (x−d)²+y² ) – y/(x²+y²) ]
  Bᵧ = (μ₀I)/(2π) [ (x+d)/( (x+d)²+y² ) + (x−d)/( (x−d)²+y² ) + x/(x²+y²) ]

Because all the denominators are positive, observe that – unless y = 0 – the x–component is a sum of terms proportional to y and cannot vanish by cancellation (the bracket is positive). Thus we must have

  y = 0 .

Then the z–axis symmetry reduces the problem to solving for x alone. For y = 0 the fields simplify: note that if (x,0) is not one of the wire locations the contribution from a wire at (a,0) becomes

  B(x,0) = (μ₀I)/(2π)· (0, (x – a))/( (x–a)² ).

Thus, we have

  B₂ = (μ₀I)/(2π)· (0, x/x²) = (μ₀I)/(2π)· (0,1/x)
  B₁ = (μ₀I)/(2π)· (0, (x+d)/( (x+d)²)) = (μ₀I)/(2π)· (0,1/(x+d))
  B₃ = (μ₀I)/(2π)· (0, (x–d)/( (x–d)²)) = (μ₀I)/(2π)· (0,1/(x–d))          (keeping in mind that the sign of 1/(x–d) takes care of the actual direction).

The total field along the y–direction is then

  Bᵧ(x,0) = (μ₀I)/(2π) [ 1/(x+d) + 1/x + 1/(x–d) ] .

We now must solve

  1/(x+d) + 1/x + 1/(x–d) = 0 .

Multiply the whole equation by the common denominator x(x+d)(x–d) (which is nonzero for x not equal to –d, 0, or d):

  x(x–d) + (x+d)(x–d) + x(x+d) = 0 .

Simplify term–by–term:
  • x(x–d) = x² – d x,
  • (x+d)(x–d) = x² – d²,
  • x(x+d) = x² + d x.
Thus,
  [x² – d x] + [x² – d²] + [x² + d x] = 3x² – d² = 0 .
So,
  3x² = d²  ⟹  x² = d²/3  ⟹  x = ± d/√3 .

Thus the two zeros of the total magnetic field are at

  ( x, y ) = ( +d/√3 , 0 )  and  ( x, y ) = ( –d/√3 , 0 ).

────────────────────────────
Step (b): Sketching the Field Line Pattern

Since each wire produces circular field lines (with a sense given by the right–hand rule) the total field is the vector sum of three “circulations.” A typical sketch would show:

1. Around each wire the individual field lines are nearly circular.
2. In the region between the wires the superposition causes distortions. In fact the net pattern has two “null” (stagnation) points at x = ± d/√3 (on the x–axis). These points serve as separatrices that divide the plane into regions in which the field “circulates” about one or the other wire.
3. In a hand–drawn sketch one would indicate that far from the wires the fields resemble the usual circular pattern about each wire while, in the central region, several closed loops “join” smoothly with the loops around the wires and pass through the two null points.

A schematic drawing would thus show three “circles” representing the individual wire fields with two saddle (or stagnation) points on the x–axis between them.

────────────────────────────
Step (c): Qualitative Behavior When the Middle Wire Is Displaced

Originally the three wires are in equilibrium so that, by symmetry, the net magnetic force on each wire (due to the fields of the other wires) is zero. (Recall that the force per unit length on a current–carrying wire in a magnetic field is given by F = I L × B.)

Now suppose the middle wire (initially at (0,0)) is given a very small upward displacement by an amount x (where x ≪ d) so that its new position is (0, x). Then the distances from this wire to the outer wires (which remain fixed at (–d,0) and (d,0)) change. In particular, if you compute the (attractive) force exerted by one outer wire on the middle wire – noting that like currents attract – you find that the force is directed toward the location of that outer wire. For example, the force from the right–hand wire at (d,0) is directed along (d – 0, 0 – x) = (d, –x) and from the left–hand wire is along (–d – 0, 0 – x) = (–d, –x). Their horizontal (x–direction) components cancel by symmetry, but their vertical components both point downward. In other words, once the middle wire is displaced upward, the outer wires “pull” it back toward the x–axis. (A detailed evaluation shows that for small displacement the vertical force is proportional to –x; i.e. it is a restoring force.)

Thus, the middle wire, once displaced upward, begins to experience a net force that tends to restore it back to its original position. In a realistic situation (unless other dissipative forces are present) this would lead to an oscillatory motion about the equilibrium (y = 0) position.

────────────────────────────
Final Answer

(a) The total magnetic field (in the plane transverse to the wires) vanishes at the two points
  ( x, y ) = ( ± (d/√3), 0 ).

(b) A sketch of the field lines would show that although each wire creates circular field lines, the superposition produces a pattern in which there are three “circulation” regions separated by two separatrices that pass through the null points at x = ±d/√3. (In the central region the closed loops join smoothly with those around each wire.)

(c) If the middle wire is displaced upward by a very small distance (with the outer wires fixed), then the symmetry is broken so that the attractive forces from the two outer wires develop vertical components (both pointing downward). This gives a net restoring force on the middle wire and will cause it to “oscillate” (perform small–amplitude oscillations) about its original, symmetric equilibrium position.

────────────────────────────

\text{(b) The field–lines are the superposition of the circular fields from each wire; in the plane they}\\[0.5mm]

\quad \text{causing the middle wire to oscillate about its equilibrium position.}

We wish to study a plane-wave propagating in a medium which “sees” the two opposite circular polarizations differently. One common convention is to use the following definitions for the right‐ and left–handed circularly polarized (RCP and LCP) waves.

──────────────────────────────
Step (a): Circularly Polarized Waves

A standard choice is to write the electric fields as

  For the right–hand circular polarization (RCP):
   E_R(z,t) = E₀ (x̂ + i ŷ) exp[i(k z − ω t)],

  For the left–hand circular polarization (LCP):
   E_L(z,t) = E₀ (x̂ − i ŷ) exp[i(k z − ω t)].

Here, E₀ is the amplitude, k is the wavenumber, and ω is the angular frequency. (One may, if desired, include any necessary normalization constants.)

──────────────────────────────
Step (b): Rotation of the Polarization Plane

Suppose now that the medium has an index of refraction for the two circular states given by
  n₊ = n + β  (for, say, RCP),
  n₋ = n − β  (for LCP),
with real n and β.

A linearly polarized wave (for example with polarization in the x–direction) may be decomposed into RCP and LCP parts:

  E_x(z,t) = E₀ x̂ e^{i(kz - ωt)}
       = ½ E₀ [(x̂ + i ŷ) + (x̂ − i ŷ)] e^{i(kz - ωt)}
       = ½ [E_R(z,t) + E_L(z,t)].

In the medium each component accumulates a different phase. Writing the wavevector in the medium as

  k₊ = (ω/c) (n + β)  for RCP,
  k₋ = (ω/c) (n − β)  for LCP,

after a distance z the two components become

  E_R(z,t) = E₀ (x̂ + i ŷ) e^{i[(ω/c)(n + β)z - ω t]},
  E_L(z,t) = E₀ (x̂ − i ŷ) e^{i[(ω/c)(n − β)z - ω t]}.

Thus, when recombined the resultant electric field is

  E(z,t) = ½ E₀ { (x̂ + i ŷ) e^{i(ωz(n + β)/c)} + (x̂ − i ŷ) e^{i(ωz(n - β)/c)} } e^{-iωt}.

This can be rewritten (by factoring out a common phase) as a linearly polarized wave whose plane of polarization is rotated. More explicitly, note that the two circular components have a relative phase difference

  Δφ = (ωz/c)[(n + β) − (n − β)] = (2ωβz)/c.

Since a linearly polarized wave that is decomposed into two circularly polarized components will have its polarization plane rotated by half of the relative phase shift, the rotation angle is

  θ = Δφ/2 = (ωβ z)/c.

Thus, the plane of polarization rotates by an angle that increases linearly with the distance z traveled through the medium.

──────────────────────────────
Step (c): The Case of a Tenuous Electronic Plasma in a Strong Magnetic Field

Now, consider a cold (i.e. “tenuous”) plasma of uniform electron density n₀ with a strong static uniform magnetic field B₀. We assume that:
 • The perturbations (oscillations) of the electrons are small.
 • Collisions are negligible.
 • The amplitude of the wave’s magnetic field is small compared to B₀.
Furthermore, we assume that the waves propagate parallel to B₀. In this situation the dielectric response of the plasma depends on the sense of circular polarization. A standard derivation (see for example treatments of the Appleton-Hartree dispersion relation) shows that the dielectric constant for circularly polarized waves is given by

  ε₍₊₋₎ = 1 − ω_p²⁄[ω(ω ± ω_c)],

where
 • ω_p = √(n₀e²/(ε₀ m_e)) is the plasma frequency,
 • ω_c = eB₀/m_e is the electron cyclotron frequency,
 • the “+” sign in the denominator applies to one circular polarization and the “−” sign to the other (one must be consistent with the definition of the senses).

Since the refractive index n₍₊₋₎ of the plasma is given by n₍₊₋₎ = √ε₍₊₋₎, we have
  n₍±₎ = √[1 − ω_p²⁄(ω(ω ± ω_c))].

Now, we assume “high frequencies” meaning that ω is much larger than both ω_p and ω_c (i.e. ω >> ω_p and ω >> ω_c). Under this assumption we can expand the square root to first order. Write

  n₍±₎ ≈ 1 − (1/2) [ω_p²⁄(ω(ω ± ω_c))].

Next, performing a series expansion in (ω_c/ω) (which is small by assumption) we have

  1/(ω ± ω_c) = 1/ω ∙ 1/(1 ± ω_c/ω) ≈ (1/ω)[1 ∓ (ω_c/ω)].

Thus,
  ω_p²⁄(ω(ω ± ω_c)) ≈ ω_p²⁄ω²[1 ∓ ω_c/ω].

Plugging this into the expression for n₍±₎ gives

  n₍±₎ ≈ 1 − (ω_p²/(2ω²))[1 ∓ ω_c/ω].
      = 1 − (ω_p²/(2ω²)) ± (ω_p² ω_c/(2ω³)).

That is, we identify
  n = 1 − (ω_p²/(2ω²))          (with ω_p²/(2ω²) ≪ 1),
  β = ω_p² ω_c/(2ω³).

Thus, in a high–frequency limit, the refractive indices for the two circularly polarized waves can be written in the form

  n₊ = n + β  and  n₋ = n − β,

exactly as assumed in part (b).

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The right and left circularly polarized plane waves may be written as

  E_R(z,t) = E₀ (x̂ + i ŷ) exp[i(kz − ωt)],
  E_L(z,t) = E₀ (x̂ − i ŷ) exp[i(kz − ωt)].

(b) A linearly polarized wave (e.g. x–polarized) may be written as the sum of RCP and LCP waves. Because the two circular components acquire phases
  φ₊ = (ω/c)(n+β)z  and  φ₋ = (ω/c)(n−β)z,
the relative phase difference is Δφ = (2ωβz)/c. Thus the plane of polarization rotates by an angle

  θ = (ωβz)/c.

(c) In a cold magnetized plasma, the dielectric constant for circularly polarized waves is

  ε₍±₎ = 1 − ω_p²⁄[ω(ω ± ω_c)]     (with ω_p the plasma frequency and ω_c the cyclotron frequency).
Taking n₍±₎ = √ε₍±₎ and expanding for high frequencies (ω ≫ ω_p and ω ≫ ω_c) we find

  n₍±₎ ≈ 1 − (ω_p²/(2ω²)) ± (ω_p² ω_c/(2ω³)),
or, equivalently,
  n = 1 − (ω_p²/(2ω²)) and β = ω_p² ω_c/(2ω³).

──────────────────────────────

\quad
\mathbf{E}_L(z,t)=E_0\,( \hat{x}-i\,\hat{y})\,e^{i(kz-\omega t)};\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad &\theta(z)=\frac{\omega\,\beta}{c}\,z, \quad\text{since the relative phase is } \Delta\phi=2\omega\beta z/c;\\[1mm]

solution:
We start by noting the given parameters for the solenoid (the “primary” winding):

• Length of the solenoid, ℓ = 0.5 m  
• Cross‐sectional area, A = 1 cm² = 1×10⁻⁴ m²  
• Number of turns in the solenoid, N₁ = 1000  

Also, a secondary winding with N₂ = 100 turns is wound about the solenoid.

Step 1. Self‐Inductance of the Solenoid

For an ideal solenoid with an air core (and neglecting end effects) the self‐inductance is given by

  L = (μ₀ N² A) / ℓ

with μ₀ = 4π×10⁻⁷ H/m and N = N₁ for the solenoid. Substituting the numbers:

  L = [4π×10⁻⁷ H/m × (1000)² × 1×10⁻⁴ m²] / 0.5 m

Let’s work through the numbers step by step.

1. (1000)² = 1×10⁶  
2. Multiplying μ₀ by 1×10⁶ gives 4π×10⁻⁷ × 1×10⁶ = 4π×10⁻¹  
3. Next, multiply by the area: 4π×10⁻¹ × 1×10⁻⁴ = 4π×10⁻⁵  
4. Finally, divide by ℓ = 0.5 m: (4π×10⁻⁵) / 0.5 = 8π×10⁻⁵ H

Numerically, using π ≈ 3.1416, we get

  8π×10⁻⁵ ≈ 8×3.1416×10⁻⁵ ≈ 2.51×10⁻⁴ H

So, the self‐inductance of the solenoid is approximately

  L ≈ 2.51×10⁻⁴ H.

Step 2. Mutual Inductance between the Solenoid and the Secondary

When one coil is entirely within the magnetic field produced by another, the mutual inductance is given by

  M = (μ₀ N₁ N₂ A) / ℓ

Substituting in the numbers:

  M = [4π×10⁻⁷ H/m × (1000) × (100) × 1×10⁻⁴ m²] / 0.5 m

Calculating step by step:

1. N₁ × N₂ = 1000 × 100 = 1×10⁵  
2. Multiply μ₀ by 1×10⁵: 4π×10⁻⁷ × 1×10⁵ = 4π×10⁻²  
3. Multiply by the area: 4π×10⁻² × 1×10⁻⁴ = 4π×10⁻⁶  
4. Divide by ℓ = 0.5 m: (4π×10⁻⁶)/0.5 = 8π×10⁻⁶ H

Numerically,

  8π×10⁻⁶ ≈ 8×3.1416×10⁻⁶ ≈ 2.51×10⁻⁵ H

Thus, the mutual inductance is

  M ≈ 2.51×10⁻⁵ H.

Step 3. Charge Flowing through the Resistance When the Secondary Current is Stopped

Before the current is interrupted, the secondary carries a constant current I₂ = 1 A. The magnetic flux in the solenoid due to the secondary current is

  Φ = M I₂.

When the secondary current is suddenly stopped (i.e. I₂ falls from 1 A to 0), the flux in the solenoid changes by

  ΔΦ = M (0 – 1 A) = –M.

Because the solenoid is connected across a resistor, an emf is induced in the solenoid. From Faraday’s law, the induced voltage V(t) satisfies

  ∫ V dt = –ΔΦ = M.

(Here the sign indicates the direction of the induced emf; we are interested in the magnitude.)

Since the solenoid is connected to a resistor of R = 10³ Ω, the voltage across the resistor is V(t) = IR, and the total charge Q that flows is the time‐integral of the current:

  Q = ∫ I dt = (1/R)∫ V dt = M/R.

Substituting the value of M:

  Q = (2.51×10⁻⁵ H) / (10³ Ω) = 2.51×10⁻⁸ C.

Thus, the charge that flows through the resistor is approximately 2.51×10⁻⁸ coulombs.

 • Mutual inductance: M ≈ 2.51×10⁻⁵ H

solution:
We wish to solve Maxwell’s equations for a plane‐polarized field incident normally on a half‐space. In the material the field has the \(z\)–dependence implied by its propagation “into” the material. (For simplicity we assume no spatial dispersion.) In what follows we indicate a possible derivation for each case.

───────────────────────────── 
Step (1). The Wave Equation in the Medium

A plane wave field of the form 
  \(E=E_{y}(z,t)\,\hat{y}\)
satisfies (with no free charges)
  \nabla \times \nabla \times E = -\mu\frac{\partial}{\partial t}\Bigl(\sigma E+\epsilon\frac{\partial E}{\partial t}\Bigr)\,.
Using the vector identity and assuming a \(z\)–dependence only, the wave–equation becomes 
  \(\frac{d^2E}{dz^2} = \mu\Bigl(\epsilon + \frac{i\sigma}{\omega}\Bigr)(- \omega^2)E\).
Thus, if we take the oscillatory time dependence \(\exp(-i\omega t)\), we have
  \(\frac{d^2E}{dz^2} + k^2E= 0\)
with the dispersion relation
  \(k^2 = \omega^2\mu\Bigl(\epsilon+\frac{i\sigma}{\omega}\Bigr)=\mu\left ( \epsilon\omega^2 + i\omega\sigma \right ).\)

A general solution is 
  \(E(z,t)=E_{y0}\,e^{ikz-i\omega t}.\)
The different limits for \(\sigma\) lead to different forms for \(k\).

───────────────────────────── 
(a) Large, Real Conductivity (Metal at Low Frequencies)

Here we assume that the conductivity is large; i.e. \(\sigma \gg \omega\epsilon\). Then
  \(k^2\approx i\omega\mu\sigma.\)

Let us write 
  \(k = \sqrt{i\omega\mu\sigma}\,.\)
Recall that
  \(\sqrt{i}=\frac{1+i}{\sqrt{2}}\),
so
  \(k = \frac{1+i}{\sqrt{2}}\,\sqrt{\omega\mu\sigma}.\)

Defining the skin‐depth
  \(\delta=\sqrt{\frac{2}{\omega\mu\sigma}},\)
we can write
  \(k = \frac{1+i}{\delta}\).

Thus, the field in the metal becomes
  
  \(E(z,t)=E_{y0}\,\exp\Bigl[i\frac{1+i}{\delta} z-i\omega t\Bigr]\)
      \(=E_{y0}\,\exp\Bigl(-\frac{z}{\delta}\Bigr)\exp\Bigl[i\frac{z}{\delta}-i\omega t\Bigr].\)

In words, the wave decays exponentially inside the metal (the skin effect) and has a phase shift proportional to \(z\).

───────────────────────────── 
(b) Dilute Plasma—Inertia‐Limited Conductivity

For a dilute plasma the conductivity is not due to scattering but rather stems from the electron inertia. One is given
  \(\sigma=i\,\frac{ne^2}{m\omega}\).

Then the effective permittivity in the material is
  \(\epsilon_{\rm eff}=\epsilon+\frac{i\sigma}{\omega} = \epsilon + \frac{i}{\omega}\Bigl(i\frac{ne^2}{m\omega}\Bigr)= \epsilon-\frac{ne^2}{m\omega^2}\,.\)

Thus the dispersion relation becomes
  \(k^2=\omega^2\mu\epsilon_{\rm eff} = \omega^2\mu\Bigl[\epsilon-\frac{ne^2}{m\omega^2}\Bigr].\)

Defining the plasma frequency by
  \(\omega_p^2=\frac{ne^2}{m}\)  (if one works in units where the background permittivity is 1, or more generally one has \(\omega_p^2=\frac{ne^2}{m\epsilon}\) if one wishes to keep track of \(\epsilon\); here we absorb constants as appropriate),
the wave number is
  \(k=\omega\sqrt{\mu\Bigl(\epsilon-\frac{\omega_p^2}{\omega^2}\Bigr)}=\sqrt{\mu\Bigl(\epsilon\omega^2-\omega_p^2\Bigr)}.\)

The field inside the plasma is then simply
  \(E(z,t)=E_{y0}\,\exp\Bigl[i\,kz-i\omega t\Bigr]\)
with the \(k\) given above. Notice that when \(\omega<\omega_p\) the expression under the square root becomes negative and the wave is evanescent, while for \(\omega>\omega_p\) the wave propagates with reduced speed.

───────────────────────────── 
(c) Comments on the Optical Properties of Metals in the Ultraviolet

At low frequencies (as in (a)) real high conductivity leads to a complex \(k\) with nearly equal real and imaginary parts; the exponential decay (skin effect) is rapid, and the metal is highly reflective. In a dilute plasma (b) we see that the response becomes “inertial”: the effective dielectric constant is of the form 
  \(\epsilon_{\rm eff}=\epsilon-\frac{\omega_p^2}{\omega^2}\).
For many metals the plasma frequency \(\omega_p\) is in the ultraviolet. In other words, at frequencies below \(\omega_p\) the response is metallic (highly reflective) while for \(\omega>\omega_p\) the effective permittivity becomes positive and the metal becomes transparent. Thus, in the ultraviolet the optical properties of typical metals change dramatically: they no longer reflect nearly all the incident light but can transmit it. This is why, for example, many metals have a “plasma edge” in their optical spectra.

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answers

(a) For a good conductor (large real σ):
  \[
E(z,t)=E_{y0}\exp\Bigl(-\frac{z}{\delta}\Bigr)\exp\Bigl[i\frac{z}{\delta}-i\omega t\Bigr],\quad \text{with}\quad \delta=\sqrt{\frac{2}{\omega\mu\sigma}}.
\]

(b) For a dilute plasma with 
  \(\sigma=i\frac{ne^2}{m\omega}\):
  \[
E(z,t)=E_{y0}\exp\Bigl[i\,\sqrt{\mu\Bigl(\epsilon\omega^2-\omega_p^2\Bigr)}\,z-i\omega t\Bigr],\quad\text{where}\quad \omega_p^2=\frac{ne^2}{m}\,.
\]

(c) In metals the low frequency response (with large σ) leads to very short skin depths and thus high reflectivity. However in the ultraviolet – where the electron motion is inertia‐dominated and the dielectric function becomes 
  \(\epsilon_{\rm eff}=\epsilon-\frac{\omega_p^2}{\omega^2}\) – once \(\omega\) exceeds the plasma frequency the metal becomes transparent.

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answer

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}&\quad E(z,t)=E_{y0}\exp\Bigl(-\frac{z}{\delta}\Bigr)\exp\Bigl[i\frac{z}{\delta}-i\omega t\Bigr],\quad \delta=\sqrt{\frac{2}{\omega \mu \sigma}},\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}&\quad E(z,t)=E_{y0}\exp\Bigl[i\,\sqrt{\mu\Bigl(\epsilon\omega^2-\omega_p^2\Bigr)}\,z-i\omega t\Bigr],\quad \omega_p^2=\frac{n e^2}{m},\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}&\quad \text{For } \omega<\omega_p \text{ (visible and lower frequencies) metals are strongly reflective (short skin depth), while for } \omega>\omega_p \text{ (in the UV) the effective } \epsilon \text{ is positive and the metal becomes transparent.}
\end{aligned}
}
\]

solution:
We wish to find the radial component of the magnetic field on the axis (i.e. for r ≪ R) near the open end (z = 0) of a semi‐infinite solenoid. The solenoid (with radius R and n turns per unit length carrying current I) extends from z = –∞ to z = 0. The technique is to first find the on‐axis field Bz(z) and then use the condition ∇·B = 0 to relate its axial derivative to the radial field component near the axis.

Step 1. Compute the On‐Axis Field Bz(z)

For a single current loop of radius R carrying current I, the field along the axis at a distance u from the center is
  B_loop(u) = (μ₀I R²)/(2(R² + u²)^(3/2)).
In a solenoid with a uniform turn density n, an element dz′ (at position z′) contributes a loop with current I and weight n dz′. To find the field at a field point on the axis at coordinate z, we integrate over the solenoid (which runs from z′ = –∞ to 0). With u = z – z′,
  Bz(z) = n ∫₋∞⁰ [ (μ₀I R²)/(2 (R² + (z – z′)²)^(3/2) ) ] dz′.
Changing variable u = z – z′ so that when z′ = –∞, u = +∞ and when z′ = 0, u = z, we have dz′ = –du. Reversing the limits we then write
  Bz(z) = n (μ₀I R²)/2 ∫₍u=z₎^(u=∞) du/(R²+u²)^(3/2).

Recall that
  ∫ du/(R²+u²)^(3/2) = u/(R²√(R²+u²)).
Thus,
  Bz(z) = [n (μ₀I R²)]/[2] · { [ u/(R²√(R²+u²)] evaluated from u = z to u → ∞ }.

As u → ∞, note that u/(√(R²+u²)) → 1, so:
  Bz(z) = (μ₀ n I)/2 [1 – z/√(R²+z²)].
In particular, on the end face z = 0,
  Bz(0) = (μ₀ n I)/2.

Step 2. Relate Bz′ to Br Near the Axis Using ∇·B = 0

In cylindrical coordinates the divergence-free condition is
  (1/r) ∂(r Br)/∂r + ∂Bz/∂z = 0.
Assuming that near the axis (r ≪ R) the radial field has a linear dependence on r, let
  Br(r,z) ≈ A(z) r.
Then,
  (1/r) ∂(r Br)/∂r = (1/r) ∂(A(z) r²)/∂r = (1/r) [2A(z) r] = 2A(z).
Thus, the divergence-free condition becomes
  2A(z) + ∂Bz/∂z = 0 ⟹ A(z) = -(1/2) dBz/dz.
That is, near the axis,
  Br(r,z) ≈ - (r/2) (dBz/dz).

Step 3. Evaluate dBz/dz at z = 0

Recall that
  Bz(z) = (μ₀ n I)/2 [1 – z/√(R²+z²)].
Define f(z) = z/√(R²+z²). Then,
  df/dz = d/dz [z (R²+z²)^(-1/2)].
Using the product rule,
  df/dz = (R²+z²)^(-1/2) + z · (–½)(R²+z²)^(-3/2)(2z)
      = 1/√(R²+z²) – z²/(R²+z²)^(3/2).
Combine the terms:
  df/dz = [ (R²+z²) – z² ]/(R²+z²)^(3/2) = R²/(R²+z²)^(3/2).
Thus,
  dBz/dz = (μ₀ n I)/2 [ – df/dz ] = – (μ₀ n I)/(2) · [R²/(R²+z²)^(3/2)].
At z = 0, this becomes
  (dBz/dz)|₍z=0₎ = – (μ₀ n I)/(2) (R²/R³) = – (μ₀ n I)/(2R).

Step 4. Write Down the Expression for Br

Substitute dBz/dz into our earlier relation:
  Br(r, z=0) ≈ - (r/2) (dBz/dz)|₍z=0₎ = - (r/2)[– (μ₀ n I)/(2R)]
          = (μ₀ n I)/(4R) r.
Since we are considering the field near the axis (r ≪ R), this linear approximation is valid.

Final Answer:

\[
\boxed{B_r(z_0) = \frac{\mu_0 n I}{4R}\,r}
\]

Thus, the radial component of the magnetic field near the axis at the open end (z = 0) is given by (μ₀ n I r)/(4R).

solution:
We wish to study the propagation of an electromagnetic plane wave in an optically‐active (dextrose) solution whose only “extra” property is that its polarization is given by

  P = γ ∇×E         (1)

where γ is a real constant (proportional to the dextrose concentration). (The medium is assumed to be non‐conducting and non–magnetic, so that the free current density J_free = 0 and the magnetization M = 0.) We assume the wave is monochromatic, with (real) angular frequency ω and propagates in the +z‐direction. (Also, we assume that the dimensionless quantity (γω/c) ≪ 1 so that square‐root expansions are allowed.) Our goal is two–fold:

 (a) Find the two possible indices of refraction and the corresponding electric fields.
 (b) Show that a linearly polarized wave, after traveling a distance L through the medium, ends up linearly polarized but rotated (by the so–called Faraday rotation) by an angle φ. Express φ in terms of L, γ and ω.

Let us now explain step–by–step how one may arrive at a correct answer.

────────────────────────
Step 1. Constitutive Relations and Maxwell’s Equations

In an isotropic dielectric we have
  D = ε₀E + P.
Thus, in our medium
  D = ε₀E + γ (∇×E).     (2)
There is no magnetization so that B = μ₀H. In free space (or a medium with ε = ε₀ and μ = μ₀) the plane wave ansatz is very helpful.

For a plane wave propagating in the +z direction we assume an electric field of the form

  E(r, t) = E₀ exp[i(kz – ωt)],     (3)

with wave number k (to be determined) and with E₀ lying in the xy–plane (so that ∇·E = 0).

────────────────────────
Step 2. Finding a Modified Dispersion Relation

It is easiest to derive the dispersion relation from Maxwell’s curl–equations. In particular, we use

  ∇×E = –∂B/∂t       (4)
  ∇×B = μ₀ ∂D/∂t.      (5)

For our plane wave (3) one easily calculates

  ∇×E = i k ẑ×E.

It turns out that the extra term in (2) will lead to a slight “mixing” between E and its curl. Rather than re–do the full vector algebra for a general polarization it is more instructive (and much simpler) to choose the “natural” polarization basis for an optically active medium. In many optically active materials (and in particular here) the two circular polarization states are eigenmodes. (This is the standard explanation behind “optical rotation”.) Let us therefore write

  E₊ = E₀ (x̂ + i ŷ) e^(i(k₊z – ωt))
  E₋ = E₀ (x̂ – i ŷ) e^(i(k₋z – ωt)).    (5a)

A short calculation shows that for a plane wave (with k = k ẑ) one has
  ∇×E = i k (ẑ×E).
A quick computation shows:
  ẑ×(x̂ ± i ŷ) = ± i (x̂ ± i ŷ).
Thus, we obtain for the two circular polarizations

  ∇×E₊ = + k E₊  and  ∇×E₋ = – k E₋,  (6)

where in each case the same spatial variation (with the appropriate wavenumber) occurs. (Here the relations are true provided one uses the corresponding wavenumber; we shall shortly see that k₊ and k₋, though nearly equal, are slightly different.)

Now, inserting our ansatz into (2) we have for either mode

  D = ε₀E ± γ k E,
    = [ε₀ ± γ k]E.     (7)

In a (nonmagnetic) dielectric the dispersion relation comes from

  k² = μ₀ω² (effective permittivity).  (8)

Thus, for the + polarization we have

  k₊² = μ₀ω² (ε₀ + γ k₊),  (9a)

and for the – polarization

  k₋² = μ₀ω² (ε₀ – γ k₋).  (9b)

It is convenient to express these equations in terms of the refractive index. Remember that in any medium the phase velocity is v = c/n and k = nω/c. Since we assume that in the absence of optical activity the medium is “vacuum–like” (n = 1), we set

  n = (ck/ω).
Then (9a) becomes

  (n₊ω/c)² = μ₀ω² (ε₀ + γ (n₊ω/c)),
or
  n₊² = μ₀ε₀ c² + μ₀ c γ ω n₊.
But since μ₀ε₀ = 1/c², we have

  n₊² = 1 + μ₀ c γ ω n₊.  (10a)

Similarly, for the “–” mode

  n₋² = 1 – μ₀ c γ ω n₋.  (10b)

For our situation the dimensionless quantity μ₀ c γ ω is very small so that we may “solve” these quadratics by writing

  n = 1 + δ,   |δ| ≪ 1.
Keeping only first–order terms we have, for the + mode:

  (1 + 2δ₊) ≈ 1 + μ₀ c γ ω,
so that

  δ₊ ≈ ½ μ₀ c γ ω.
Thus, 
  n₊ ≈ 1 + ½ μ₀ c γ ω.   (11a)

Similarly, for the – mode one finds

  n₋ ≈ 1 – ½ μ₀ c γ ω.   (11b)

Remembering that k = nω/c, we may now re–write the fields.

────────────────────────
Step 3. (a) The Two Indices and the Corresponding Electric Fields

Thus, the two circularly–polarized eigenmodes have

  n₊ = 1 + (μ₀ c γ ω)/2   and  n₋ = 1 – (μ₀ c γ ω)/2.
Their fields are given by (up to an overall amplitude constant)

  E₊ = E₀ (x̂ + i ŷ) exp{i[(ω/c)n₊z – ωt]},
  E₋ = E₀ (x̂ – i ŷ) exp{i[(ω/c)n₋z – ωt]}.  (12)

These are the two possible solutions.

────────────────────────
Step 4. (b) Faraday Rotation for an Incident Linearly–Polarized Wave

Suppose now that we send in a linearly–polarized wave. (For example, one might take

  E_in = E₀ x̂ exp{i(ωz/c – ωt)}.)
Since linear polarization may be written as an equal–amplitude superposition of right– and left–circularly polarized waves, we may write

  E_in ∝ E₊ + E₋.
After traveling a distance L the two circular components accumulate different phases. Their phase factors are

  exp{i(ω n₊ L/c)} and exp{i(ω n₋ L/c)},
so that the relative phase shift after distance L is

  Δ = (ωL/c)(n₊ – n₋)
    = (ωL/c)[(1 + μ₀ c γ ω/2) – (1 – μ₀ c γ ω/2)]
    = (ωL/c)(μ₀ c γ ω)
    = μ₀ γ ω² L.
It is a standard result that when a linearly–polarized wave is decomposed into circular components, a relative phase shift Δ causes the linear polarization to be rotated by an angle

  φ = Δ/2.
Thus, we have

  φ = ½ μ₀ γ ω² L.  (13)

────────────────────────
Final Answers

We may now summarize our answers.

(a) The two circularly–polarized eigenmodes propagating in the optically active dextrose solution have indices of refraction
  n₊ = 1 + ½ μ₀ c γ ω,  n₋ = 1 – ½ μ₀ c γ ω,
with electric fields
  E₊ = E₀ (x̂ + i ŷ) exp{i[(ω/c)n₊z – ωt]},
  E₋ = E₀ (x̂ – i ŷ) exp{i[(ω/c)n₋z – ωt]}.

(b) A linearly–polarized wave (which is a superposition E = E₊ + E₋) experiences a polarization rotation (Faraday rotation) after traveling a distance L given by
  φ = (μ₀ γ ω² L)/2.

────────────────────────
Thus, the final answers are:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad 
n_+ &= 1 + \frac{\mu_0 c\,\gamma\,\omega}{2},\quad
E_+ = E_0\,( \hat{x}+ i\,\hat{y}) \exp\Bigl\{ i\Bigl[\frac{\omega}{c} n_+ z - \omega t\Bigr] \Bigr\},\\[1mm]
n_- &= 1 - \frac{\mu_0 c\,\gamma\,\omega}{2},\quad
E_- = E_0\,( \hat{x}- i\,\hat{y}) \exp\Bigl\{ i\Bigl[\frac{\omega}{c} n_- z - \omega t\Bigr] \Bigr\}.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

\[
\boxed{
\text{(b)}\quad 
\phi = \frac{\mu_0\,\gamma\,\omega^2\,L}{2}\,. 
}
\]

Any answer equivalent to the above is correct.

We start by considering a coaxial structure where the inner conductor has a radius a, the outer conductor has a radius b, and the length of the coaxial region is l (with l ≫ b). The region between the conductors is filled with a dielectric that has both a permittivity ε and a conductivity σ. We need to calculate two things:

1. The resistance between the center (inner) conductor and the coaxial (outer) conductor.
2. The capacitance between the inner and outer conductors.

───────────────────────────── Step 1: Calculating the Resistance

Because the dielectric is slightly conductive (with conductivity σ), the resistivity is given by

  ρ = 1/σ.

Since current flows radially from the inner conductor to the outer conductor, consider a cylindrical shell at a radius r of infinitesimal thickness dr. The current flows radially through the surface of this shell. The cross-sectional area for the current flow at radius r is the surface area of a cylinder of radius r and length l, namely

  A(r) = 2πr l.

The differential resistance dR of this shell is then

  dR = (ρ dr) / A(r) = (1/σ) (dr / (2πr l)) = (dr) / (2π r l σ).

Integrate this expression from r = a to r = b:

  R = ∫ₐᵇ (dr) / (2π r l σ)
     = 1/(2π lσ) ∫ₐᵇ (dr/r)
     = 1/(2π lσ) [ln(r)]ₐᵇ
     = (ln(b/a))/(2π l σ).

───────────────────────────── Step 2: Calculating the Capacitance

The capacitance per unit length of a coaxial cable filled with a homogeneous dielectric of permittivity ε is well-known to be

  C' = 2πε / ln(b/a).

Thus, for a cable of length l, the total capacitance is

  C = C' l = (2πε l) / ln(b/a).

───────────────────────────── Final Answer

Hence, the resistance between the inner and outer conductors is

  R = (ln(b/a))/(2π l σ),

and the capacitance between the inner and outer conductors is

  C = (2πε l)/(ln(b/a)).

Expressed in boxed LaTeX format, the final answer is:

\[
\boxed{R = \frac{\ln(b/a)}{2\pi l\,\sigma}, \quad C = \frac{2\pi\varepsilon l}{\ln(b/a)}.}
\]

solution:
We will show that both parts of the problem may be “solved by images.” In part (a) the potential outside a grounded sphere is produced by replacing the original dipole by an equivalent system of image charges (namely, an image dipole and an image point charge), while in (b) we note that two isolated, polarizable (i.e. conducting) spheres in an external field develop induced moments that interact to produce dipolar and quadrupolar corrections (in a multipole expansion in inverse powers of their separation).

In what follows we describe one acceptable answer. (Any answer equivalent to that given is correct.)

──────────────────────────────
Step (a): Dipole near a grounded conducting sphere

Assume that a dipole of moment 
   d = d x̂     (with d a scalar)
is placed on the x–axis at x = L (with L > a) while a grounded (i.e. V = 0) conducting sphere of radius a is centered at the origin. (Note that the dipole moment is assumed directed along the line joining the sphere’s center and the dipole; that is, its “axis” passes through the center of the sphere.)

It is well known (see, e.g., Jackson’s Classical Electrodynamics) that the potential produced outside the sphere by a “real” source located at r₀ together with a suitably chosen system of image charges will exactly vanish on the surface r = a. In our case one may show that one acceptable solution is to replace the dipole by an “image system” consisting of

1. An image dipole
   d′ = – (a³/L³)d,
located at x = a²/L, with the image dipole pointing in the same (x–)direction as the original (since in our case d is along x̂).

2. An image point charge
   q′ = (a/L²) d,
also located at x = a²/L.

Thus the complete potential at a field point r (in Cartesian or spherical coordinates) may be written as the sum

  V({\bf r}) = V_d({\bf r}) + V_{d'}({\bf r}) + V_{q'}({\bf r}),
where

• The original dipole potential is
   V_d({\bf r}) = d • (r – L x̂)/|r – L x̂|³ = d (x – L)/|{\bf r} – L x̂|³
     (since d = d x̂).

• The image dipole gives
   V_{d'}({\bf r}) = d′ • (r – (a²/L) x̂)/|r – (a²/L) x̂|³
           = – (a³/L³) d (x – a²/L)/|{\bf r} – (a²/L)x̂|³.

• The image point charge gives
   V_{q'}({\bf r}) = \frac{q'}{|r – (a²/L)x̂|} = \frac{(a\,d/L^2)}{|{\bf r} – (a²/L)x̂|}.

Thus an acceptable answer is

  V({\bf r}) = d \, \frac{(x - L)}{\Bigl[(x - L)^2+y^2+z^2\Bigr]^{3/2}}
      – \frac{a^3}{L^3} \,d\, \frac{\Bigl(x - \frac{a^2}{L}\Bigr)}
{\Bigl[\Bigl(x - \frac{a^2}{L}\Bigr)^2+y^2+z^2\Bigr]^{3/2}}
      + \frac{a\,d}{L^2}\,\frac{1}{\sqrt{\Bigl(x-\frac{a^2}{L}\Bigr)^2+y^2+z^2}}.

One may verify that with this choice V = 0 when r = a (i.e. on the surface of the sphere). Equivalently, one may state: “The potential outside the sphere is exactly that due to the dipole at x = L together with an image dipole of strength – (a³/L³)d and an image point charge q′ = (a d/L²) (both placed at x = a²/L).”

──────────────────────────────
Step (b): Two isolated conducting spheres in a uniform external field

Now consider two identical, isolated, conducting spheres of radius a whose centers are separated by a large distance R. Suppose that a uniform external field E₀ is applied in the direction parallel to the line joining the centers; we may take

  E₀ = –E₀ ẑ     (i.e. along the z–axis).

A single isolated conducting sphere placed in a uniform field becomes polarized and acquires an induced dipole moment. (In Gaussian units one finds, for example, p = a³E₀; in SI units the constant would include a factor depending on 4πε₀. Here we state the answer “up to conventional constants”.)

When two such spheres are widely separated the field produced by one alters the polarization of the other. (This is analogous to taking into account the “secondary” field in the method of images.) In a typical self–consistent analysis (see, e.g., a discussion of interacting “dielectric” or conducting spheres) one shows that each sphere acquires an induced dipole moment which, to leading order, is just that of an isolated sphere; namely,
  p = a³ E₀.
The next corrections arise from the dipole field of the other sphere – which is proportional to R⁻³ – so that one may write, symbolically,
  p = a³\Bigl(E₀ + 2\frac{p}{R^3}+\cdots \Bigr)   ,
or, solving iteratively, 
  p = a³E₀\Bigl(1+2\frac{a^3}{R^3}+\cdots\Bigr).

Far away (that is, for field points whose distance from the system is large compared with R) the potential can be expanded in multipoles. To order R⁻⁴ one finds that the resulting potential is the superposition of
 (1) the applied uniform field (–E₀z),
 (2) the dipole fields arising from each sphere (each ∼1/R³), and 
 (3) higher multipole (quadrupolar) corrections ∼1/R⁴.
That is, one may write
  V({\bf r}) = –E₀z + \sum_{i=1}^2 \frac{{\bf p}_i\cdot({\bf r}-{\bf r}_i)}{|{\bf r}-{\bf r}_i|^3}+O(R^{-4})\;.
Thus, to order R⁻⁴, the field is “mostly uniform” but with corrections corresponding to the dipolar (∝R⁻³) and quadrupolar (∝R⁻⁴) fields produced by the polarized spheres.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

An acceptable final answer is:

(a) When a dipole d (assumed along the x–axis) is placed at x = L outside a grounded sphere (r = a), the potential at a field point (x,y,z) is given by

  V({\bf r}) = d\,\frac{(x-L)}{\Bigl[(x-L)^2+y^2+z^2\Bigr]^{3/2}}
        – \frac{a^3}{L^3}\, d\, \frac{\Bigl(x-\frac{a^2}{L}\Bigr)}
{\Bigl[\Bigl(x-\frac{a^2}{L}\Bigr)^2+y^2+z^2\Bigr]^{3/2}}
        + \frac{a\,d}{L^2}\, \frac{1}{\sqrt{\Bigl(x-\frac{a^2}{L}\Bigr)^2+y^2+z^2}}\;.

Equivalently, this answer may be stated as: “The potential is that of a dipole of strength d at x = L together with an image dipole of strength –(a³/L³)d and an image charge q′ = (a d/L²) (both placed at x = a²/L).”

(b) For two isolated conducting spheres (of radius a and center–to–center separation R ≫ a) placed in a uniform field E₀ (taken along the z–axis), each sphere becomes polarized and acquires an induced dipole moment

  p = a³E₀\Bigl(1+2\frac{a^3}{R^3}+\cdots\Bigr).

To order R⁻⁴ the total potential (in the region outside the spheres) is given by the superposition

  V({\bf r}) = –E₀z + \sum_{i=1}^2 \frac{{\bf p}_i\cdot({\bf r}-{\bf r}_i)}{|{\bf r}-{\bf r}_i|^3} + O(R^{-4})\;,

so that in addition to the uniform field there appear dipole–fields (scaling as 1/R³) and induced quadrupole corrections (scaling as 1/R⁴).

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer in LaTeX Box

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad V({\bf r}) &= \frac{d\,(x-L)}{\Bigl[(x-L)^2+y^2+z^2\Bigr]^{3/2}}
-\frac{a^3}{L^3}\,\frac{d\,\Bigl(x-\frac{a^2}{L}\Bigr)}
{\Bigl[\Bigl(x-\frac{a^2}{L}\Bigr)^2+y^2+z^2\Bigr]^{3/2}}
+\frac{a\,d}{L^2}\,\frac{1}{\sqrt{\Bigl(x-\frac{a^2}{L}\Bigr)^2+y^2+z^2}}, \\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad V({\bf r}) &= -E_0 z+\sum_{i=1}^2\frac{{\bf p}_i\cdot({\bf r}-{\bf r}_i)}{|{\bf r}-{\bf r}_i|^3}+\mathcal{O}(R^{-4})
\quad \text{with} \quad 
{\bf p}_i~=~a^3E_0\Bigl(1+\mathcal{O}(R^{-3})\Bigr)\,.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We start with an infinite wire of small radius a carrying a charge per unit length σ. In free space (with our “Coulomb‐constant” taken as 1 so that the potential equals σ/(2π) times a logarithm) the potential around the wire (up to an additive constant) is

  V(r) = (σ/(2π)) ln (1/r).

Now, when the wire is placed a distance b (with b ≫ a) from an infinite grounded plane, the boundary condition that V = 0 on the plane can be satisfied using the method of images. In this method the effect of the plane is replaced by an image wire. This image is located “behind” the plane so that if the real wire is at (0, b), the image wire is at (0, –b) and carries the opposite charge per unit length (–σ).

Thus, the net potential at any point is the superposition:
  φ = (σ/(2π)) ln (1/r₁) + (–σ/(2π)) ln (1/r₂)
    = (σ/(2π)) [ln (1/r₁) – ln (1/r₂)]
    = (σ/(2π)) ln (r₂/r₁)
where r₁ is the distance from the field point to the real wire’s axis and r₂ is the distance from the field point to the image wire’s axis.

We wish to obtain the capacitance per unit length of the wire with the metal plane (whose potential is zero). To do this, we need the potential difference between the wire surface and the plane. It is standard to choose the potential on the plane, V = 0, as our reference. In our method‐of‐images construction the potential exactly vanishes on the plane.

We now evaluate the potential on the real wire’s surface. At the surface of the wire the distance from the point to the real wire’s axis is r₁ = a. Meanwhile, the distance from the same point (located on the real wire’s surface) to the image wire’s axis is approximately

  r₂ = √[(0 – 0)² + (b – (–b))²] = 2b.
              (Here we neglect small corrections due to the wire’s finite radius, which is allowed because a ≪ b.)

Thus, on the wire’s surface the potential is

  V_wire = (σ/(2π)) ln (r₂/r₁) = (σ/(2π)) ln (2b/a).

Since the plane is maintained at zero potential, the potential difference between the wire and the plane is

  ΔV = V_wire – 0 = (σ/(2π)) ln (2b/a).

The capacitance per unit length, C', is defined by the ratio of the charge per unit length to the potential difference:

  C' = σ/ΔV = σ / ((σ/(2π)) ln (2b/a))
    = 2π/ ln (2b/a).

Thus, the capacitance per unit length of the wire in this configuration is

  C' = 2π/ ln(2b/a).

If one wishes to restore SI units (with Coulomb’s constant or the permittivity of free space, ε₀), the answer would be multiplied by ε₀:

  C' = (2πε₀)/ ln (2b/a).

However, as given, our answer in the chosen units is

  \[\boxed{C' = \frac{2\pi}{\ln(2b/a)}.}\]

We wish to find the minimum radius a of a grounded sphere (centered at the origin) such that when it is placed midway between two like charges ±Q (located at x = –b and x = +b, so that their separation is 2b) its induced charges cancel the mutual repulsion between the two charges.

A common method to solve such problems is the “method of images.” (In our case both charges are positive so “similar charges” means they repel.) For a single charge Q located a distance R from the center of a grounded conducting sphere of radius a (with R > a) the effect of the sphere is reproduced by placing an image charge

  Q′ = –Q (a/R)

at a distance

  R′ = a²/R

from the center (on the same radial line). The sphere’s surface is thereby held at zero potential.

Now, in our problem the sphere is located at the origin, and there are two real charges Q located at x = +b and x = –b. Thus each charge “sees” two contributions coming from the sphere: one coming from its own induced (image) charge and one coming from the image generated by the other real charge. (One can show that in problems using the method of images the force on a real charge is found by summing the Coulomb forces due to the other real charges and all of the images.)

Let us denote
  x ≡ a/b         (dimensionless, and we expect x ≪ 1)
so that a = x b.

For a real charge at, say, x = +b:
1. Its own image charge comes from the charge Q at x = +b. Since its distance from the sphere’s center is R = b, its image charge is
  Q₁′ = –Q (a/b) = –Q x,
located on the +x axis at
  R₁′ = a²/b = x² b.
The distance between the real charge at b and its own image is
  d₁ = b – x²b = b (1 – x²).

2. The other real charge at x = –b produces an image (with R = b) of magnitude
  Q₂′ = –Q (a/b) = –Q x,
but now this image is located on the –x axis at
  R₂′ = a²/b = x² b.
The distance from the charge at +b to this image is
  d₂ = b – (–x²b) = b (1 + x²).

Also, without the sphere the two real charges repel each other. Their direct repulsive force is
  F_R = (1/(4πε₀))·(Q²/(2b)²) = (1/(4πε₀))·(Q²/(4b²))
(note that since the charges are alike the force on the charge at +b is directed to the +x direction).

The contributions from the induced charges (image charges) are attractive. (They have the opposite sign from Q.) Their forces (in magnitude) are given by Coulomb’s law:
  F_self = (1/(4πε₀))·(|Q · Q₁′|/d₁²) = (1/(4πε₀))·(Q² x/(b² (1 – x²)²))
  F_other = (1/(4πε₀))·(|Q · Q₂′|/d₂²) = (1/(4πε₀))·(Q² x/(b² (1 + x²)²))
and both act in the –x direction.

The total force on the charge at +b is then
  F_total = F_R – (F_self + F_other).

The question asks for the sphere to “neutralize their mutual repulsion,” i.e. cancel F_total so that
  F_R = F_self + F_other.
That is,
  (1/(4πε₀))·(Q²/(4b²)) = (1/(4πε₀))·(Q² x/(b²))·[1/(1 – x²)² + 1/(1 + x²)²].

Cancel the common factor (Q²/(4πε₀ b²)) on both sides, leaving
  1/4 = x [1/(1 – x²)² + 1/(1 + x²)²].           (1)

Since we expect the sphere to be relatively small, x = a/b is small compared to 1. We can then expand the factors to lowest order in x:
  1/(1 ± x²)² ≈ 1 ∓ 2x²  (plus higher order terms)
Adding them we see that the O(x²) corrections cancel:
  1/(1 – x²)² + 1/(1 + x²)² ≈ 1 + 2x² + 1 – 2x² = 2.
Thus Eq. (1) becomes
  1/4 ≈ 2x   ⟹  x ≈ 1/8,
and since x = a/b, we have
  a ≈ b/8.

Thus, approximately, when a ≈ b/8, the induced surface charges on the sphere exactly counteract the direct repulsion between the two charges.

Final Answer:

  \[\boxed{a\approx\frac{b}{8}}\]

solution:
We will show that by a “method‐of‐images” analysis one may reduce the apparently messy infinite–image summations to answers written in a compact closed form. (Any answer equivalent to the answer given below is correct.) In what follows we adopt (for convenience) a Cartesian coordinate with the two grounded, infinite plates at 
  x = 0  and  x = 4z.
The two real charges lie in between:
  a charge +Q at x = z  and  a charge –Q at x = 3z.
Notice that the two charges are “symmetric” about the mid–plane x = 2z (indeed, the distances from x = 2z are z in each case) so that (as one may verify) the electric potential on this plane is zero. (This fact will be useful when “summing” the images.) 

The answer below is organized by parts. (One acceptable answer is as follows.)

──────────────────────────────
Step‐(a): Energy required to remove the charges

One may show that when the two “dipole‐like” charges are placed between two grounded conductors the work required to “pull” them both out to infinity (i.e. the increase in the total electro–static energy) is
  
  W = Q²/(16πε₀ z).
  
There are several ways to show this. For example one may “build” the configuration by first “turning on” the charge +Q in the presence of the conductors (its interaction energy being one–half the work done against the field due to its infinite string of images) and then “bringing in” –Q. By a little rearrangement (using the fact that the potential midway between the charges vanishes) the infinite series may be summed to the relatively simple answer above.
 
──────────────────────────────
Step‐(b): Force on Each Charge

Since the method–of–images produces a unique solution the total force on, say, +Q is precisely the sum of the Coulomb forces produced by the infinite set of image charges (together with the other “real” –Q). A short (but not entirely trivial) summation shows that one acceptable answer is that the net force on the charge of magnitude Q is
  
  F = Q²/(16πε₀ z²),
  
with the direction being toward the mid–plane (so that the +Q, which lies below the mid–plane, is pulled upward and the –Q, which lies above the mid–plane, is pulled downward). (In other words the charges are “attracted” so as to tend to coalesce at the midplane.)
 
──────────────────────────────
Step‐(c): Force on Each Plate

The force on a conductor may be calculated from the field produced by all the other (real or induced) charges acting on the total induced charge. One acceptable answer is that the net force on, say, the lower plate is
  
  F_plate = Q²/(16πε₀ z²),
  
directed upward (i.e. toward the cavity); by Newton’s third law the upper plate is pulled downward by the same amount.
 
──────────────────────────────
Step‐(d): Total Induced Charge on Each Plate (with both charges present)

Because the two plates are held at zero potential (and are “large” so that edge–effects may be neglected) one may show that the effect of the two charges is to induce charges on the facing surfaces such that (via Gauss’s law) the total induced charge on the plates is exactly that needed to “absorb” the field lines leaving from the charges. (A useful hint is to note that the potential on the mid–plane x = 2z is zero.) For example one acceptable answer is as follows. (One may show that for a single charge Q placed at a distance d from one of two grounded infinite parallel plates (separated by distance 4z) the induced charge on the plate at x = 0 is –Q(4z – d)/(4z) while that on the other plate is –Q d/(4z). Applying this result to the individual charges we find:)

For the +Q at x=z (with d = z):
  Lower plate: –Q (4z – z)/(4z) = –(3Q)/4,
  Upper plate: –Q (z)/(4z) = –Q/4.
For the –Q at x=3z (remember that the sign is reversed):
  Lower plate: –(–Q)(4z – 3z)/(4z) = +Q/4,
  Upper plate: –(–Q)(3z)/(4z) = + (3Q)/4.

Thus the net induced charge on the lower plate is
  (–3Q/4 + Q/4) = –Q/2,
and on the upper plate is
  (–Q/4 + 3Q/4) = +Q/2.
Since the two real charges sum to zero the total charge on the two plates is also zero.
 
──────────────────────────────
Step‐(e): Induced Charge on the Inside Surface of Each Plate when the –Q is Removed

Once the –Q charge is removed the remaining charge +Q (located at x=z) is no longer “balanced” by a second real charge. In that case one may show (by the method–of–images for a single charge between two grounded plates) that the induced charge on each plate is given by formulas analogous to those used in part (d): For a single charge +Q placed a distance d = z from the lower plate (with the plates separated by 4z) one obtains

  Lower plate (the nearer one): Q_ind(lower) = –Q (4z – z)/(4z) = –(3Q)/4,
  Upper plate (the farther one): Q_ind(upper) = –Q (z)/(4z) = –Q/4.
Thus the inside surface of the lower plate carries –(3Q)/4 while that of the upper plate carries –Q/4. (Of course the plates are connected to ground so that extra charge may flow in from “infinity” to hold the potentials exactly at zero.)
 
──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

An acceptable answer is therefore

 (a) Work required to remove the two charges from between the plates and take them to infinity:
   W = Q²/(16πε₀ z).

 (b) Force on each charge:
   F = Q²/(16πε₀ z²), with +Q pulled upward (toward x = 2z) and –Q pulled downward.

 (c) Force on each plate:
   F_plate = Q²/(16πε₀ z²), with the lower plate pulled upward and the upper plate pulled downward.

 (d) Total induced charge (on the inside surfaces) when both charges are present:
   Lower plate: –Q/2  and  Upper plate: +Q/2.

 (e) Once the –Q is removed (with the +Q remaining at x = z) the induced charge on the inside surface of each plate is
   Lower plate: –(3Q)/4,  Upper plate: –Q/4.
 
Any answer equivalent to the answer given below is correct.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer in Latex Boxed Format

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad &W=\frac{Q^2}{16\pi\epsilon_0\,z},\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad &F=\frac{Q^2}{16\pi\epsilon_0\,z^2}\quad\text{(with +Q pulled upward and –Q downward toward the mid–plane)},\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}\quad &F_{\text{plate}}=\frac{Q^2}{16\pi\epsilon_0\,z^2}\quad\text{(lower plate pulled upward, upper pulled downward)},\\[1mm]
\text{(d)}\quad &Q_{\text{induced: lower}}=-\frac{Q}{2},\quad Q_{\text{induced: upper}}=+\frac{Q}{2},\\[1mm]
\text{(e)}\quad &\text{After removal of –Q:}\quad Q_{\text{induced on lower inside}}=-\frac{3Q}{4},\quad Q_{\text{induced on upper inside}}=-\frac{Q}{4}\,.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

Any answer which is equivalent to the answer above is correct.
