solution:
We wish to understand a situation in which a long cylinder of insulating material is “tagged” with a layer of mobile electrons so that initially the surface has a uniform charge density σ₀. Then an external uniform electric field Eₐ (directed, say, along the x‐axis) is turned on. Although the electrons are free to move along the surface, the rest of the cylinder is an insulator (in particular, we assume it does not polarize). We are to compare this “mobile‐charge layer” problem to the standard problem of a charged, conducting cylinder and then work out the induced change δσ(θ) in the surface charge density for a conducting cylinder. (Here the angle θ is measured around the cylinder so that cos θ is the projection along the field direction.)

Below we describe step by step the answers.

────────────────────────────
Step 1. (The Difference)

(a) In a standard electrostatic problem for a charged conductor the free charges rearrange so that the entire conductor (and hence its surface) is at the same potential. That is, the conductor “enforces” an equipotential boundary condition. In our present problem the only free charges are the electrons that have been sprayed onto the surface; the insulating material underneath does not supply additional mobile charges and does not polarize. Thus although the electrons can laterally redistribute, they must do so while preserving the total amount of charge on the surface. In a conductor, however, the free carriers can come in from the bulk (or leave it) so as to make the surface an equipotential.

Thus the two problems differ in that while a conducting cylinder is required to have a constant potential all over its surface, in our case the “mobile‐electron layer” is constrained to have a fixed (integrated) total charge and does not benefit from the extra “reservoir” of charge that a conductor possesses. As a result, the usual “conductor” solution for the surface charge density will apply only when the applied field is weak enough that the electrons can move around on the surface to “simulate” an equipotential surface. (One may say that for small Eₐ the electronic motion is fast enough to “screen” the normal component of the external field on the surface. However, if Eₐ is too large, the electrons will be completely pulled off (or be driven to one side) so that the solution is no longer given by the usual conductor calculation.)

────────────────────────────
Step 2. (The Conductor Calculation)

(b) Let us now calculate the induced charge density σ(θ) for a (charged) conducting cylinder. We assume:
• The cylinder is infinitely long (so we can use a two‐dimensional problem in the plane perpendicular to the axis).
• The cylinder has radius r.
• Initially the cylinder has a uniform surface charge density σ₀, so that its net charge per unit length is Q = 2πrσ₀.
• An external uniform field Eₐ is applied in the x-direction (i.e. along θ = 0).

Because the conductor must be an equipotential, the potential V (outside, r ≥ r) consists of the potential of the net charge Q, the applied field, and an induced dipole contribution. (There is no induced monopole since that contribution is already contained in Q.) In polar coordinates (r,θ) the general solution of Laplace’s equation that vanishes at infinity [apart from the logarithmic term due to Q] is

  V(r,θ) = – (Q⁄(2πε₀)) ln r – Eₐ r cosθ + A (cosθ)⁄r.

The constant A is determined by the requirement that the potential V is constant on r = r (we denote the radius by r; you may alternatively call it a). In other words, we require that on the cylinder’s surface the θ‑dependence vanishes:

  V(r,θ) |₍r₌r₎ = – (Q⁄(2πε₀)) ln r – Eₐ r cosθ + (A cosθ)⁄r = constant.

Since the only θ‑dependent pieces are the ones proportional to cosθ, these must cancel. Hence one must have

  – Eₐ r + (A⁄r) = 0 ⟹ A = r²Eₐ.

Thus the potential (outside) becomes

  V(r,θ) = – (Q⁄(2πε₀)) ln r – Eₐ r cosθ + (r²Eₐ cosθ)⁄r
        = – (Q⁄(2πε₀)) ln r – Eₐ r cosθ + Eₐ r cosθ = – (Q⁄(2πε₀)) ln r, 

when r is set equal to r (the cylinder’s surface). (That is, the contributions proportional to cosθ cancel, ensuring a constant potential on the surface.)

Now, to compute the surface charge density we use the condition that the charge density is given by

  σ(θ) = –ε₀ (∂V/∂r)_above,

since inside the conductor the electric field is zero (and the jump in the electric field is given by the surface charge). Differentiate V for r > r:

  V(r,θ) = – (Q⁄(2πε₀)) ln r – Eₐr cosθ + (r²Eₐ cosθ)/r 
            = – (Q⁄(2πε₀)) ln r – Eₐr cosθ + Eₐ (r cosθ).

But notice that in writing the potential outside we already combined the applied field and the induced dipole piece so that their sum satisfies the boundary condition on r = r. For r > r the derivative is taken from the full expression:
  d/dr[ – (Q⁄(2πε₀)) ln r ] = – (Q⁄(2πε₀))(1/r),
  d/dr[ – Eₐ r cosθ ] = – Eₐ cosθ,
  d/dr[ (r²Eₐ cosθ)/r ] = d/dr[ Eₐ r cosθ ] = Eₐ cosθ.
Thus, the derivative of the cosθ terms cancels exactly at r = r if taken a bit more carefully, but it turns out that the discontinuity in the radial derivative is solely due to the total potential produced by the Q and by the cosθ–dependent contributions. (A more careful calculation identifies the contribution of the induced dipole to the field jump.)

A simpler way is to note that since the only effect of the applied field is to redistribute the charges (while keeping the net charge Q fixed), the induced part of the surface charge density must be “dipolar.” It is well known for a charged conducting cylinder in an applied uniform field (see, for example, Jackson’s Classical Electrodynamics) that the final surface charge density is given by

  σ(θ) = Q⁄(2πr) + 2ε₀Eₐ cosθ.

Recalling that Q = 2πrσ₀, we obtain

  σ(θ) = σ₀ + 2ε₀Eₐ cosθ.

This is the answer for a charged conductor.

────────────────────────────
Step 3. (The Range of Applicability)

For the sprayed‐electron system on an insulating cylinder to behave as a conductor, the electrons must remain on the surface. In the answer above the net charge at angle θ is

  σ(θ) = σ₀ + 2ε₀Eₐ cosθ.

Since the electrons are the only free charges, it is necessary that the local charge density remains of the same sign everywhere (i.e. no “hole” is created where electrons have been completely removed). If we assume that initially the electrons give rise to a uniform σ₀ (say, negative if they are electrons), then the most “vulnerable” point is where cosθ = –1 (that is, in the direction opposite to the applied field). In order that there remain electrons even at that point, we must have

  σ₀ – 2ε₀Eₐ ≥ 0   (if σ₀ is positive)   or, if instead σ₀ is negative (as for electrons), we require that no spot reverses sign. In general, writing the condition in terms of magnitudes we must have

  2ε₀Eₐ < |σ₀|.

Thus the solution σ(θ) = σ₀ + 2ε₀Eₐ cosθ applies provided the applied field is weak enough that

  Eₐ < |σ₀|⁄(2ε₀).

For larger fields the assumption that the mobile electrons can rearrange to produce a conductor–like equipotential (while keeping the total charge fixed on the entire surface) will break down since some regions would be completely depleted of electrons.

────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The difference between the two cases is that for a charged conductor the free charges (including those in the bulk) rearrange so as to make the entire surface an equipotential, while an insulating cylinder with a sprayed-on mobile electron layer has only a fixed (total) amount of mobile charge on its surface and no extra charges in the bulk to polarize. Hence, the “conductor‐picture” applies only if Eₐ is sufficiently weak so that the electrons can move along the surface to approximate an equipotential. Otherwise, the charge distribution on the surface of the insulator will differ (for example, regions may run out of electrons).

(b) For a conducting cylinder with an initial uniform surface charge density σ₀ (so that Q = 2πrσ₀), the solution in an external uniform electric field Eₐ (taken to be in the x–direction) is

  σ(θ) = σ₀ + 2ε₀Eₐ cosθ.

This result is valid provided that the applied field is not so strong as to reverse the sign of σ(θ) at any point. In practice, one must have

  2ε₀Eₐ < |σ₀|   or  Eₐ < |σ₀|⁄(2ε₀).

────────────────────────────
Final Answer

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad&\text{For a charged conductor, free charges rearrange so that the entire surface is an equipotential. In contrast,}\\
&\text{an insulating cylinder with a sprayed-on layer of mobile electrons has a fixed total charge and no bulk}\\
&\text{polarization; hence its electrons can only redistribute on the surface. The solution for an equipotential surface}\\
&\text{applies (i.e. the conductor solution holds) provided the external field is weak enough that the electrons do}\\
&\text{not get completely removed from any portion of the surface.}\\[1ex]
\text{(b)}\quad&\sigma(\theta)=\sigma_0+2\epsilon_0E_a\cos\theta,\quad\text{with the condition }2\epsilon_0E_a<|\sigma_0|\text{ (i.e. }E_a<|\sigma_0|/(2\epsilon_0)\text{).}
\end{aligned}
}
\]

solution:
We wish to study the field

  B(x,y) = (B₀/(a)) (x x̂ – y ŷ),

and answer several questions about it. (In what follows the constant a is a length scale and B₀ may be a constant or a slowly varying function of time.) One acceptable answer is that

  (a) the field is both divergence‐free and curl‐free in free space,
  (b) its field lines are the hyperbolas given by xy = constant, i.e. a “quadrupole‐like” pattern that might be approximately produced by four “filamentary” (i.e. line) currents (two carrying current upward and two downward) located, for example, at positions (±R,0) and (0,±R),
  (c) the magnetic flux per unit “z–length” in the region between the origin and the field line whose closest approach is R is B₀R²/(2a),
  (d) a non‐relativistic observer moving with velocity v in the ẑ–direction will, by the Lorentz transformation to first order in v/c, see an electric field (equivalently, a potential difference) corresponding to an electric potential φ(x,y) = (B₀v/(a))xy (relative to the origin), and 
  (e) if B₀ is slowly varying in time so that B₀ = B₀(t), a stationary observer sees an induced electric field given by E(x,y) = –(xy/(a)) (dB₀/dt) ẑ.

Below we describe one step‐by–step solution.

───────────────────────────── 
Step (a): Verifying Maxwell’s equations

The field is 
  B(x,y) = (B₀/(a))(x, –y, 0).
Its divergence is

  ∇·B = ∂ₓ(B₀x/a) + ∂ᵧ(–B₀y/a) + ∂𝑧(0)
     = (B₀/a) – (B₀/a) = 0.
Also, since none of the components depend on z we have
  (∇×B)_z = ∂ₓ(–B₀y/a) – ∂ᵧ(B₀x/a) = 0 – 0 = 0.
And the other components vanish, so
  ∇×B = 0.
Thus the field obeys Maxwell’s equations in free space (no magnetic charges and, in current–free regions, ∇×B = μ₀J = 0).

───────────────────────────── 
Step (b): Sketching the field lines and filamentary currents

A field line obeys
  dx/Bₓ = dy/Bᵧ.
That is,
  dx/(B₀x/a) = dy/(–B₀y/a)  ⟹  dx/x = –dy/y.
Separating variables, d(ln|x|) = – d(ln|y|), and upon integration
  ln|x| + ln|y| = constant  ⟹  xy = constant.
Thus the field lines are the hyperbolas (or their pieces) given by xy = constant. (In particular, the “null” line through the origin is xy = 0, i.e. the x– and y–axes.)

A quadrupolar field such as this is commonly produced by a suitable arrangement of “filamentary” currents. For example one may approximate B by placing four long, thin wires (or current elements) along the z–direction at the positions (x,y) = (±R,0) and (0,±R) with currents chosen so that the resulting field in the vicinity of the origin sums to B ∝ (x, –y). (Any arrangement of two pairs of oppositely directed currents that produces a “quadrupole moment” is acceptable.) In a sketch one shows the hyperbolic field lines in the x–y plane and marks the four current filaments (all along ẑ) with arrows indicating the direction of current (two in the +ẑ and two in the –ẑ directions).

───────────────────────────── 
Step (c): Magnetic flux per unit z–length

When a magnetic field has no z–dependence one may speak of “flux per unit length” in the z–direction. A very convenient way to characterize the 2D magnetic configuration is to introduce a flux function ψ(x,y) defined so that
  Bₓ = ∂ᵧψ,  Bᵧ = –∂ₓψ.
For our field, one may check that
  ψ(x,y) = (B₀/(a)) x y
satisfies
  ∂ᵧψ = (B₀/(a)) x = Bₓ  and  –∂ₓψ = –(B₀/(a)) y = Bᵧ.
Since ψ is constant on field lines, its value is a “label” for a particular field line. In particular, the field line that passes closest to the origin (i.e. that has its minimum distance equal to R) will have its minimum (absolute) distance when |x| = |y|. Along this line, we have
  ψ = (B₀/(a)) x².
Taking x_min = R/√2 so that the distance from the origin is r = √(2) |x_min| = R we see that the corresponding constant is
  ψ = (B₀/(a)) (R²/2) = B₀R²/(2a).
(The flux “between” the ψ=0 field line (through the origin) and a given field line is just the difference in ψ.) Thus the magnetic flux (per unit z length) contained between the origin and the field line whose minimum distance from the origin is R is

  Φ = B₀R²/(2a).

───────────────────────────── 
Step (d): The electric potential seen by a moving observer

Now suppose an observer moves with a non‐relativistic velocity
  v = v ẑ.
In his frame (to first order in v/c) an electric field appears according to
  E′ = –v × B.
Since
  B = (B₀/(a)) (x  x̂ – y  ŷ)
we compute
  v × B = v ẑ × (B₀/(a))(x x̂ – y ŷ)
      = (B₀v/(a)) (ẑ × x x̂ – ẑ × y ŷ)
Recall that ẑ × x̂ = ŷ and ẑ × ŷ = –x̂ so that
  v × B = (B₀v/(a)) (x ŷ + y x̂).
Then
  E′ = –(B₀v/(a))(y x̂ + x ŷ).
Since this induced electric field is (for our non–relativistic observer) conservative, we may define a potential φ by
  E′ = –∇φ.
That is,
  ∂ₓφ = (B₀v/(a)) y  and  ∂ᵧφ = (B₀v/(a)) x.
A short calculation shows that a potential which satisfies these equations is
  φ(x,y) = (B₀v/(a)) x y,
with φ(0,0) = 0. (Any constant may be added.) Thus the observer moving with velocity v ẑ measures a potential difference
  φ(x,y) = (B₀v/(a))xy.

───────────────────────────── 
Step (e): The induced electric field when B₀ = B₀(t) slowly varies

If now the magnetic field is time–dependent because B₀ = B₀(t), then a stationary observer sees an induced electric field by Faraday’s law. (We assume that the time–variation is slow enough that we may ignore radiation.) One standard method is to choose a vector potential A which yields B by
  B = ∇×A.
A simple choice is to take
  A = (0, 0, A_z(x,y,t)),
with A_z chosen so that
  Bₓ = ∂ᵧA_z  and  Bᵧ = –∂ₓA_z.
Since Bₓ = (B₀(t)x/a) and Bᵧ = –(B₀(t)y/a), one may take
  A_z(x,y,t) = (B₀(t)/(a)) x y.
In a gauge in which the scalar potential vanishes, the induced electric field is given by
  E = –∂A/∂t = –(∂A_z/∂t) ẑ.
Thus
  E(x,y,t) = –(x y/(a)) (dB₀/dt) ẑ.
A quick check shows that the curl of this E is exactly what is required by Faraday’s law:
  (∇×E)_x = ∂ᵧE_z = –(x/a)(dB₀/dt),
  (∇×E)_y = –∂ₓE_z = (y/a)(dB₀/dt),
so that
  ∇×E = –(dB₀/dt)/a (x x̂ – y ŷ) = –∂B/∂t.
Thus the induced electric field is

  E(x,y,t) = –(x y/(a)) (dB₀/dt) ẑ.

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answers

We may now summarize our answers as follows:

(a) The field 
  B = (B₀/(a))(x x̂ – y ŷ)
satisfies
  ∇·B = 0  and  ∇×B = 0.

(b) The field lines are the curves
  xy = constant,
i.e. rectangular hyperbolas. (For example, one may approximate the field by placing four filamentary currents along the z–axis at (±R,0) and (0,±R) with alternating directions to yield the correct quadrupolar pattern.)

(c) The magnetic flux per unit length (in the z–direction) between the origin and the field line whose minimum distance from the origin is R is
  Φ = B₀R²/(2a).

(d) A non–relativistic observer moving with v = v ẑ measures an electric field
  E′ = –v × B = –(B₀v/(a))(y x̂ + x ŷ),
so that a potential difference given by
  φ(x,y) = (B₀v/(a)) x y
is measured (with φ(0,0)=0).

(e) When B₀ = B₀(t) slowly varies in time the induced electric field seen by a stationary observer is
  E(x,y,t) = –(x y/(a)) (dB₀/dt) ẑ.

We now give the final answers in boxed form.

───────────────────────────── 

\[
\boxed{
\begin{array}{rcl}
\text{(a)}\quad \nabla\cdot\mathbf{B} &=& 0,\quad \nabla\times\mathbf{B}=0;\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad \text{Field lines satisfy }xy&=&\mathrm{const}\,,
\text{ and can be approximated by four z–directed filamentary currents}\\[1mm]
&&\text{(located at, e.g., }( \pm R,0) \text{ and }(0,\pm R)\text{ with alternating directions).}\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}\quad \Phi &=& \dfrac{B_{0}R^{2}}{2a}\,;\\[1mm]
\text{(d)}\quad \phi(x,y) &=& \dfrac{B_{0}\,v}{a}\,xy\,;\\[1mm]
\text{(e)}\quad \mathbf{E}(x,y,t) &=& -\dfrac{x\,y}{a}\,\dfrac{dB_{0}}{dt}\,\hat{z}\,.
\end{array}
}
\]

Any answer equivalent to the above is correct.

solution:
We are given that an isolated soap bubble of radius R₁ = 1 cm is at a potential V₁ = 100 V. Being an isolated charged conductor means that the total charge Q on the bubble remains fixed even if its size changes. Thus, when the bubble collapses to a drop of radius R₂ = 1 mm, the charge Q is the same in both cases, although the capacitance and potential change.

Step 1. Determine the charge on the bubble.

For an isolated sphere (or spherical bubble) the self‐capacitance is given by

  C = 4πε₀R,

where ε₀ is the permittivity of free space (ε₀ ≈ 8.854×10⁻¹² F/m) and R is the radius in meters.

For the initial bubble:  
  R₁ = 1 cm = 0.01 m,  
  C₁ = 4πε₀(0.01 m).

Since the bubble is at a potential V₁ = 100 V, the charge is  
  Q = C₁ V₁ = (4πε₀ · 0.01) × 100 = 4πε₀.  
Thus the magnitude of the charge is Q = 4πε₀ (note that the units work out correctly).

Step 2. Write the expression for the electrostatic energy.

The energy stored in a charged conductor can be written as

  U = Q²/(2C).

Step 3. Compute the initial and final energies.

Initial energy, U₁:

  U₁ = Q²/(2C₁) = (4πε₀)²/(2 · (4πε₀·0.01)).

Simplify:
  U₁ = (4πε₀)/(2·0.01) = (4πε₀)/(0.02).

Final energy, U₂:

For the collapsed drop:  
  R₂ = 1 mm = 0.001 m,  
  C₂ = 4πε₀(0.001).

Thus,
  U₂ = Q²/(2C₂) = (4πε₀)²/(2 · (4πε₀·0.001))  
     = (4πε₀)/(2·0.001) = (4πε₀)/(0.002).

Step 4. Calculate the change in energy.

The change in energy is
  ΔU = U₂ − U₁  
     = (4πε₀)/(0.002) − (4πε₀)/(0.02).

Notice that
  (4πε₀)/(0.002) = (4πε₀) × 500 = 2000πε₀,  
  (4πε₀)/(0.02) = (4πε₀) × 50  = 200πε₀.

So,
  ΔU = 2000πε₀ − 200πε₀ = 1800πε₀.

Step 5. Numerical evaluation (optional).

Substitute ε₀ ≈ 8.854×10⁻¹² F/m:
  ΔU ≈ 1800 × π × 8.854×10⁻¹² J.

Taking π ≈ 3.1416,
  ΔU ≈ 1800 × 3.1416 × 8.854×10⁻¹²  
     ≈ 5654.88 × 8.854×10⁻¹²  
     ≈ 5.0×10⁻⁸ J.

Thus, the increase in the electrostatic energy when the bubble collapses is approximately 5.0×10⁻⁸ J.

Final Answer in LaTeX Boxed Format:

\[
\boxed{\Delta U = 1800 \pi \epsilon_0 \approx 5.0 \times 10^{-8}\, \text{J}}
\]

solution:
We begin with the situation in the lab frame where the fields are
  E = (0, E, 0) (in the y‐direction)
  B = (0, 0, B) (in the z‐direction)
and a particle of charge q and rest mass m is released from rest.

Below we describe one acceptable answer, working step by step.

──────────────────────────────
Step (a): Conditions for a frame with vanishing E or B

Under a Lorentz boost the components transform. For a boost at speed v along the x–axis the standard formulas give (here we use SI units; you may check with c’s restored when needed):

  E′y = γ (E – vB)           (1)
  B′z = γ (B – vE/c²)          (2)

Thus:

(1) To find a frame in which the electric field vanishes (E′ = 0) one requires
  γ (E – vB) = 0  ⟹ v = E/B.
But since v must be less than c, this boost exists provided that
  E/B < c  ⟹ E < cB.

(2) Similarly, to find a frame in which the magnetic field vanishes (B′ = 0) one requires 
  γ (B – vE/c²) = 0  ⟹ v = c²B/E.
Again, one must have v < c so that
  c²B/E < c  ⟹ E > cB.
Thus, a frame in which B′ = 0 exists provided that E exceeds cB.

Note that the other electromagnetic invariant, E·B, is zero in our situation; the only condition is on the combination E² and c²B².

──────────────────────────────
Step (b): Motion in the Lab Frame When a Frame with E′ = 0 Exists

Suppose that E < cB so that we can boost with
  v = E/B  (in the x–direction)
to a frame where the electric field is zero. (Call this the prime frame.)

Since the particle is at rest in the lab frame, after this boost its velocity is
  v′ = –v  (in the x–direction).
In the prime frame the only field is a (reduced) magnetic field B′ (whose exact magnitude is not needed for the qualitative discussion). A charged particle in a pure magnetic field undergoes uniform circular motion (with cyclotron frequency ω = qB′/(γ′m)). Therefore, in the prime frame the particle gyrates in a circle.

When we transform the (circular) motion back to the lab frame the effect is to “add back” the boost. The result is that the lab‐frame motion is the well–known E×B drift:
• A steady drift with velocity v₍d₎ = E×B/B². With E = (0, E, 0) and B = (0, 0, B) one obtains
  v₍d₎ = (E/B, 0, 0);
• Superimposed on this uniform motion is a “cyclotron gyration” (a circle about the drift center).
Thus the overall trajectory in the lab frame is a cycloid – that is, a combination of uniform drift along x (with speed E/B) and a circular orbit about a point which itself moves with the drift.

──────────────────────────────
Step (c): Momentum Versus Time in the Frame with B′ = 0

Now assume instead that E > cB so that one can boost with
  v = c²B/E  (in the x–direction)
to a frame in which the magnetic field vanishes. (Call this the “B = 0 frame”.) In that frame the only field is a uniform electric field. (Its y–component is given by E′y = γ (E – vB), but for our purpose we denote this simply by E′.) In a region with a constant electric field and no magnetic field the force is simply
  F = qE′,
acting in the y–direction.

Although one must be cautious with “constant force” in relativistic dynamics, one may show that if one uses the rapidity η defined by v = c tanh η and the relation
  p = m c sinh η,
then the equations of motion (with proper acceleration a₀ = qE′/m) imply that the rapidity increases linearly with proper time τ:
  η(τ) = (qE′/(m c))τ.
Moreover, the coordinate time t in the B = 0 frame is given by
  t = (m c)/(qE′) sinh η.
Thus, one easily finds that
  sinh η = (qE′t)/(m c)  ⟹  p(t) = m c sinh η = qE′t.
In other words, even though the velocity approaches c asymptotically, the relativistic momentum in the B = 0 frame increases linearly with the coordinate time t.

Note that if preferred one may write the answer in the equivalent hyperbolic form:
  p(t) = m c sinh( (qE′t)/(m c) ).
Since sinh(arcsinh (qE′t/(m c))) = (qE′t)/(m c), these forms are equivalent.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

An acceptable answer is as follows:

(a) A Lorentz frame exists in which
 (1) E = 0 if one boosts with velocity v = E/B (along the x–axis), provided that v < c, i.e. E < cB.
 (2) B = 0 if one boosts with velocity v = c²B/E (along the x–axis), which requires E > cB.
  (In our fields the invariant E·B = 0, so these conditions on E and B alone are necessary and sufficient.)

(b) If a boost with v = E/B exists (i.e. E < cB), then in that frame the field is purely magnetic and the particle (which was at rest in the lab) has initial velocity –E/B (in the –x direction). In a pure magnetic field the charged particle performs circular (cyclotron) motion. We start by noting that once the capacitor is disconnected from the charging circuit, the charge Q on the capacitor remains constant.

Step 1. Write the capacitance for a parallel-plate capacitor. For circular plates of radius r (with r ≫ d) we have:

  C = ε₀A/d,  with A = πr².

Thus, the capacitance is

  C = (ε₀πr²)/d.

Step 2. Determine the energy stored in the capacitor. For a capacitor, the energy stored is given by

  U = Q²/(2C).

Since Q is constant, we have

  U = Q²/(2C) = Q²/[2(ε₀πr²/d)] = (Q²d)/(2ε₀πr²).

Step 3. Calculate the initial and final energies. Let the initial distance be d and the final distance be d′. Then,

  U_initial = (Q²d)/(2ε₀πr²)  and  U_final = (Q²d′)/(2ε₀πr²).

The change in the stored energy when the plate separation is changed slowly is

  ΔU = U_final − U_initial = (Q²/(2ε₀πr²))(d′ − d).

Step 4. Relate the change in energy to the work performed. In a quasi-static process the work done by the external forces (the work done by slowly moving the plates) is equal to the change in the stored energy. Hence,

  W = ΔU = (Q²/(2ε₀πr²))(d′ − d).

Step 5. Express the result in terms of the initial potential V. Initially, when the capacitor is charged to a potential V (while connected to the circuit), the charge is

  Q = CV = (ε₀πr²/d)V.

Substitute this expression for Q back into the work expression:

  W = [((ε₀πr²V/d)²) / (2ε₀πr²)](d′ − d)
     = [(ε₀²π²r⁴V²/d²) / (2ε₀πr²)](d′ − d)
     = [ε₀πr²V²/(2d²)](d′ − d).

Thus, the work done by slowly changing the separation from d to d′ is

  W = (ε₀πr²V²(d′ − d))/(2d²).

Final Answer in boxed format:

  \[
\boxed{W = \frac{\epsilon_0 \pi r^2 V^2}{2d^2}(d' - d)}
\]

Step 1: Find the Surface Charge Density

The total charge Q is uniformly distributed over the surface of a sphere with radius r. Therefore, the surface charge density σ is given by

  σ = Q / (4πr²).

Step 2: Determine the Electric Field on the Surface

For a sphere with a uniform surface charge distribution, Gauss’ law tells us that the electric field just outside the surface is

  E₊ = σ / ε₀ = Q / (4πε₀r²).

However, on the inside of a conductor (or on the inner side of a charged shell) the electric field is zero. Thus, on the surface there is a discontinuity:
  E₊ – E₋ = σ/ε₀,
with E₋ = 0. 

A common prescription is to take the effective electric field acting on the surface charges as the average of the fields just outside and just inside. That is, we define the effective field E_eff to be

  E_eff = (E₊ + E₋) / 2 = (1/2) E₊ = (1/2) (Q / (4πε₀r²)).

Step 3: Calculate the Force on a Small Charge Element

Consider a small element of charge dq on the surface of the sphere. The only force on this charge element (due to the other charges) comes from the effective field E_eff produced by the rest of the charge. Therefore, the force on dq is

  dF = (dq)(E_eff).

Substituting the expression for E_eff we find

  dF = dq * (1/2) (Q / (4πε₀r²)).

This can be arranged as

  dF = (1/2) ( (1/4πε₀)(Q/r²) ) dq.

Step 4: Direction of the Force

Due to the spherical symmetry of the charge distribution, the non-radial (tangential) components of the force cancel each other out. Only the radial components survive, and they point outward. Thus, the force on dq is purely radial and outward.

Final Answer

The force on a small charge element dq on the sphere is given by

  dF = (1/2) (1/4πε₀)(Q/r²) dq.

In boxed LaTeX format, the final answer is:

\[
\boxed{dF = \frac{1}{2}\frac{1}{4\pi\varepsilon_0}\frac{Q}{r^2}\, dq.}
\]

solution:
We wish to find the self‐forces acting on electrons in a “beam”, that is, an ensemble of electrons distributed uniformly in a cylinder of radius a. (We assume that the beam is “long” so that edge effects may be ignored.) In what follows we denote by ρ or ρ₀ a “charge density” (by which we mean the charge per unit volume); one can always write ρ = –e n so that n is the number density and the minus sign indicates the electron’s charge. (For the purpose of “force‐magnitudes” we shall work with absolute values and omit minus signs when the context is clear.) We now describe how one may derive the answers.

────────────────────────────
Step (a): Electric field (and force) inside a uniformly charged cylinder

Inside a cylinder of radius a with uniform charge density ρ₀ the electric field may be found by Gauss’s law. Choose a coaxial cylindrical Gaussian surface of radius r (with r < a) and length L. Then the enclosed charge is

  Q_enc = ρ₀ · (area)·L = ρ₀ πr²L.

By symmetry the electric field points radially and has the same magnitude E(r) on the Gaussian surface. Gauss’s law gives
  ∮E·dA = E 2πr L = Q_enc/ε₀ = ρ₀ πr²L/ε₀.
Thus,
  E(r) = (ρ₀ r)/(2ε₀).

Since each electron of charge e sees the field produced by all the other electrons, it “feels” a repulsive force (directed radially outward) whose magnitude is

  F(r) = e E(r) = (e ρ₀ r)/(2ε₀).

That is our answer for part (a).

────────────────────────────
Step (b): What does a laboratory observer see when the beam is moving?

Now imagine the same cylindrical distribution—but now with “lab‐frame” charge density ρ (which need not equal ρ₀ because of Lorentz contraction in the longitudinal direction) moving with velocity v. In the lab frame two fields are present:
 • An electric field, which for r < a remains (by the same Gauss law applied “instantly” in the lab) 
  E(r) = (ρ r)/(2ε₀).
 • A magnetic field produced by the current density J = ρ v. (Its magnitude, by using the Ampère law in the steady‐state, is that of a “long straight wire” with the same r–dependence.) Specifically, one finds for r < a an azimuthal magnetic field 
  B(r) = (μ₀ ρ v r)/2.

Now an electron in the beam moves with velocity v (parallel to the axis) and therefore sees a Lorentz force that is the sum of the electric force and the magnetic force (using v × B): 
  F = –e [E + v × B].
A little thought on the directions shows that the v × B term is radially opposed to E. (Indeed, for an electron, the two forces act in opposite directions and tend to cancel.) In magnitude we have

  |F_lab(r)| = e [E – vB] = e [ (ρ r)/(2ε₀) – v (μ₀ ρ v r)/2 ] 
            = e (ρ r)/2 [ 1/ε₀ – μ₀ v² ].

But recalling that
  μ₀ε₀ = 1/c²   ⇒ μ₀ = 1/(ε₀ c²),
we obtain
  1/ε₀ – μ₀ v² = 1/ε₀ – v²/(ε₀ c²) = (1/ε₀)(1 – v²/c²).

Thus, the net force as seen in the lab is

  F_lab(r) = (e ρ r)/(2ε₀) (1 – v²/c²).

This is the answer for part (b).

────────────────────────────
Step (c): What would be seen in the beam’s rest frame, especially when v → c?

In the rest frame of the beam the electrons are (by definition) at rest so that there is no self–magnetic field. However, due to Lorentz contraction the “lab density” ρ is not the density in the beam frame. In fact, if ρ is the lab–density then the proper density (the density in the beam frame) is

  ρ' = ρ/γ,  with γ = 1/√(1–v²/c²).

Thus, the electric field in the beam frame is

  E'(r) = (ρ' r)/(2ε₀) = (ρ r)/(2ε₀γ).
And so the force on an electron is

  F'(r) = e E'(r) = (e ρ r)/(2ε₀γ).

How does this compare with the lab frame force? From part (b)
  F_lab = (e ρ r)/(2ε₀)(1 – v²/c²) = (e ρ r)/(2ε₀γ²),
since (1 – v²/c²) = 1/γ². Thus, we have the relation

  F'(r) = γ F_lab(r).

In words: Even though in the co–moving frame the electric field (and force) is larger than that seen in the lab, the (transverse) force measured in the lab is reduced by a factor γ. In the limit v → c (so that γ is very large) the lab observer sees the self–repulsion almost canceled (by nearly complete cancellation between the Coulomb repulsion and the attractive magnetic force) while the beam–frame force is larger by a factor of roughly γ. (One must keep in mind that forces perpendicular to the motion transform differently than forces parallel to the motion.)

────────────────────────────
Step (d): What magnetic gradient is required to “focus” the beam?

Suppose one wishes to confine the beam in (say) the x–direction. A quadrupole magnet (or another suitable focusing system) produces a transverse magnetic field whose magnitude grows linearly from the axis:
  B(x) ≈ B′ x,
where B′ = dB/dx is the gradient (in Tesla per meter). For a relativistic electron moving with velocity v, a magnetic field produces a force
  F_ext = e v B′ x     (in SI units)
directed (with the sign depending on the particular arrangement) to oppose the self–repulsion.

To “just hold” the beam from expanding we require this focusing force to cancel the net “space–charge” force. Taking the expression from part (b) and writing it (for small displacement x replacing r) we require

  e v B′x = (e ρ x)/(2 ε₀)(1 – v²/c²).

The factor x cancels and then we solve for the needed gradient:

  B′ = (ρ/(2 ε₀ v))(1 – v²/c²).

Now, if we replace the charge density by the number density via ρ = e n, then

  B′ = (e n/(2 ε₀ v))(1 – v²/c²).

Now we plug in the given numbers. We are given
  n = 2 × 10¹⁰ cm⁻³.
Since 1 cm⁻³ = 10⁶ m⁻³, 
  n = 2 × 10¹⁰ × 10⁶ = 2 × 10¹⁶ m⁻³.
Also, v = 0.99c = 0.99 × 3.0×10⁸ m/s ≈ 2.97×10⁸ m/s.
Furthermore, note that
  1 – v²/c² = 1 – (0.99)² ≈ 1 – 0.9801 = 0.0199.
The other constants are:
  e = 1.602×10⁻¹⁹ C  and  ε₀ = 8.854×10⁻¹² F/m.

Thus, the numerical value is

  B′ = (e n/(2 ε₀ v)) (1 – v²/c²)
     = [ (1.602×10⁻¹⁹ C)(2×10¹⁶ m⁻³) / (2×8.854×10⁻¹² F/m×2.97×10⁸ m/s) ] × 0.0199.

Let us compute the factors step–by–step.

1. Compute the numerator:
  e n = (1.602×10⁻¹⁹)(2×10¹⁶) = 3.204×10⁻³ C/m³.

2. Compute the denominator (before the factor 1–v²/c²):
  2 ε₀ v = 2×8.854×10⁻¹² F/m×2.97×10⁸ m/s.
First, 8.854×10⁻¹² × 2.97×10⁸ ≈ 2.63×10⁻³,
  Then multiplied by 2: 2×2.63×10⁻³ ≈ 5.26×10⁻³ (in SI units).

3. Thus, the fraction is
  (3.204×10⁻³)/(5.26×10⁻³) ≈ 0.609.
Multiplying by (1 – v²/c²) = 0.0199 gives
  B′ ≈ 0.609 × 0.0199 ≈ 0.0121 Tesla/m.

Thus the needed magnetic gradient is about 0.012 Tesla per meter.

────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The electric field inside the cylinder and the force on an electron at r < a are
  E(r) = (ρ₀ r)/(2ε₀)    and   F(r) = e (ρ₀ r)/(2ε₀).

(b) In the lab the net force (after cancellation between electric and magnetic forces) is
  F_lab(r) = (e ρ r)/(2ε₀) (1 – v²/c²).

(c) In the beam’s rest frame the pure electric force is
  F′(r) = e (ρ r)/(2ε₀γ)
with γ = 1/√(1–v²/c²). Hence, F_lab = F′/γ, so that at high speeds (v → c) the lab sees a very much reduced net force (by roughly a factor 1/γ²) because the magnetic attraction nearly cancels the Coulomb repulsion.

(d) To “just hold” the beam (i.e. to cancel the net space–charge force) one must have a transverse magnetic gradient
  dB/dx = (e n/(2ε₀ v)) (1 – v²/c²).
For n = 2×10¹⁰ cm⁻³ and v = 0.99c this works out to approximately 0.012 T/m.

────────────────────────────
Final Answer in Boxed Form

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad & F(r)=\frac{e\,\rho_{0}\,r}{2\epsilon_{0}},\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad & F_{\rm lab}(r)=\frac{e\,\rho\,r}{2\epsilon_{0}}\Bigl(1-\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}\Bigr),\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}\quad & F' (r)=\frac{e\,\rho\,r}{2\epsilon_{0}\,\gamma},\quad \text{so that}\quad F_{\rm lab}(r)=\frac{F'(r)}{\gamma},\\[1mm]
\text{(d)}\quad & \frac{dB}{dx}=\frac{e\,n}{2\epsilon_{0}\,v}\Bigl(1-\frac{v^{2}}{c^{2}}\Bigr)
\approx 0.012\, \text{T/m}.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We wish to find the current density from a negatively biased electrode (the “cathode”) at 0 V to an anode at V₀, separated by a distance d, where electrons are emitted from the cathode at rest and the only limitation is the space‐charge (i.e. collisions are neglected). This is the classical problem that leads to the Child–Langmuir law.

Step 1. Energy Considerations

An electron starting at rest at the cathode (x = 0) will gain kinetic energy as it moves in the electric potential φ(x). By energy conservation we have

  ½ m v² = e φ(x).

Thus, the speed of the electron at potential φ is

  v(x) = √(2eφ(x) / m).

Step 2. Current Density

The electrons form a steady current density j. At any point, the electron density n(x) is such that

  j = e n(x) v(x).

Thus, we can write

  n(x) = j / [e v(x)] = j / [e √(2eφ(x)/m)] = j / [e √(2eφ/m)].

Step 3. Poisson’s Equation

The space charge due to the electrons produces an electric potential φ(x). Poisson’s equation in one dimension is

  d²φ/dx² = –ρ/ε₀,

where ρ is the charge density. Since electrons carry a charge –e, we have

  ρ = –e n(x).

Thus,

  d²φ/dx² = e n(x) / ε₀ = j / [ε₀ √(2eφ/m)].

Step 4. Differential Equation for φ

We therefore obtain

  d²φ/dx² = (j / ε₀) √(m/(2e)) 1/√(φ).

Now, multiply both sides by dφ/dx:

  (d²φ/dx²)(dφ/dx) = (j / ε₀) √(m/(2e)) (1/√φ) (dφ/dx).

Notice that the left-hand side is the derivative of (dφ/dx)²/2:

  d/dx [ (dφ/dx)²/2 ] = (j / ε₀) √(m/(2e)) (1/√φ) (dφ/dx).

We now regard φ as the variable. Writing the derivative with respect to φ on the left gives

  d/dφ [(dφ/dx)²/2] = (j / ε₀) √(m/(2e)) (1/√φ).

Integrate from φ = 0 (at x = 0) to some general φ:

  [(dφ/dx)²/2] φ = 0 + (j / ε₀) √(m/(2e)) ∫₀^φ dφ'/√(φ').

But

  ∫₀^φ dφ'/√(φ') = 2√φ.

Thus,

  (dφ/dx)²/2 = (j / ε₀) √(m/(2e)) (2√φ)/1.

That is,

  (dφ/dx)² = 4 (j / ε₀) √(m/(2e)) √φ.

Step 5. Integrate Across the Gap

We now integrate from the cathode (x = 0 where φ = 0) to the anode (x = d where φ = V₀). For a given φ, we have

  dx = dφ / (dφ/dx).

Thus,

  d = ∫₀ᵛ₀ (dφ)/(dφ/dx) = ∫₀ᵛ₀ dφ / [ 2 √{ (j / ε₀)√(m/(2e)) √φ } ].

This can be rearranged as

  d = 1 / [2 √{ (j / ε₀) √(m/(2e)) }] ∫₀ᵛ₀ dφ / φ^(1/4).

The integral is

  ∫₀ᵛ₀ dφ / φ^(1/4) = (4/3) V₀^(3/4).

Thus,

  d = (1/(2)) (4/3) V₀^(3/4) / √{ (j / ε₀) √(m/(2e)) }.

Solving for the square root term:

  √{ (j / ε₀) √(m/(2e)) } = (2/3) V₀^(3/4)/d.

Now, square both sides:

  (j / ε₀) √(m/(2e)) = (4/9) V₀^(3/2)/d².

Solve for j:

  j = (4/9) ε₀ √(2e/m) V₀^(3/2)/d².

Step 6. Final Answer

Thus the space‐charge limited current density (the Child–Langmuir law) for this setup is

  j = (4/9) ε₀ √(2e/m) (V₀^(3/2))/(d²).

Final answer in boxed LaTeX:

  \[
\boxed{j = \frac{4}{9} \,\epsilon_0 \sqrt{\frac{2e}{m}}\, \frac{V_0^{3/2}}{d^2}}
\]

solution:
We wish to show that if a point charge q is moving at constant velocity v along the x‐axis, then the electric and magnetic fields in the laboratory frame are given by

  Eₓ = (q/χ) γ (x − vt),  Eᵧ = (q/χ) γ y,  E𝓏 = (q/χ) γ z,
  Bₓ = 0,  Bᵧ = −(q/χ) β γ z,  B𝓏 = (q/χ) β γ y,

where

  β = v/c,  γ = (1 − v²/c²)^(−1/2),
  χ = {γ² (x − vt)² + y² + z²}^(3/2).

One elegant way to obtain these fields is to start with the Coulomb field of the charge in its rest frame and then perform a Lorentz transformation to the laboratory (moving) frame.

────────────────────────
Step 1. Coulomb Field in the Rest Frame

In the rest frame of the charge (denoted by primed coordinates), the electromagnetic fields are very simple. The charge has no magnetic field and its electric field is given by Coulomb’s law:
  E′(r′) = (q / r′³) r′      (B′ = 0),
where
  r′² = x′² + y′² + z′².

────────────────────────
Step 2. Lorentz Transformation of Coordinates

Since the charge moves along the x‐axis with speed v, the Lorentz transformation from the lab coordinates (x, y, z, t) to the rest frame coordinates (x′, y′, z′, t′) is
  x′ = γ (x − vt),  y′ = y,  z′ = z,
  t′ = γ (t − vx/c²).

In particular, the spatial distance r′ in terms of lab coordinates becomes
  r′² = x′² + y′² + z′² = γ² (x − vt)² + y² + z².
For notational convenience, define
  χ′ = {γ² (x − vt)² + y² + z²}^(3/2).
(We will later denote this simply by χ.)

────────────────────────
Step 3. Field Transformation

Since the fields in the rest frame are known, we now use the standard field transformation formulas under a boost along the x‐axis. They are:

• For the electric field:
  Eₓ = E'ₓ,
  Eᵧ = γ (E'ᵧ),
  E𝓏 = γ (E'𝓏).

• For the magnetic field:
  Bₓ = B′ₓ = 0,
  Bᵧ = −γ β E'𝓏,
  B𝓏 = γ β E'ᵧ,
since in the rest frame B′ = 0 and the transformation “mixes” the fields.

Now, in the rest frame, the Coulomb field is given by
  E′ = (q / r′³) (x′, y, z),
so that
  E'ₓ = (q/ r′³)x′ = [q γ (x − vt)] / r′³,
  E'ᵧ = (q/ r′³)y,
  E'𝓏 = (q/ r′³)z.

But recall that r′³ = [γ² (x − vt)² + y² + z²]^(3/2) = χ. Therefore, we obtain

  Eₓ = E'ₓ = (q γ (x − vt)) / χ,
  Eᵧ = γ E'ᵧ = (q γ y) / χ,
  E𝓏 = γ E'𝓏 = (q γ z) / χ.

Similarly, the magnetic field components are

  Bₓ = 0,
  Bᵧ = −γ β E'𝓏 = −(q γ β z) / χ,
  B𝓏 = γ β E'ᵧ = (q γ β y) / χ.

We have arranged the expressions exactly as required.

────────────────────────
Final Answer

Thus, the electromagnetic field of a particle of charge q moving with constant velocity v along the x‐axis is

  Eₓ = (q/χ) γ (x − vt),  Bₓ = 0,
  Eᵧ = (q/χ) γ y,  Bᵧ = −(q/χ) β γ z,
  E𝓏 = (q/χ) γ z,  B𝓏 = (q/χ) β γ y,
with
  β = v/c,  γ = (1 − v²/c²)^(−1/2),
  χ = {γ² (x − vt)² + y² + z²}^(3/2).

────────────────────────
Final Answer in Boxed Form

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
E_x &= \frac{q}{\chi}\,\gamma\,(x - vt), \quad &B_x &= 0, \\
E_y &= \frac{q}{\chi}\,\gamma\,y, \quad &B_y &= -\frac{q}{\chi}\,\beta\,\gamma\,z, \\
E_z &= \frac{q}{\chi}\,\gamma\,z, \quad &B_z &= \frac{q}{\chi}\,\beta\,\gamma\,y, \\
\beta &= \frac{v}{c}, \quad \gamma &= \left(1 - \frac{v^2}{c^2}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}},\quad
\chi = \Bigl\{\gamma^2 (x - vt)^2 + y^2 + z^2\Bigr\}^{3/2}.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

solution:
We wish to find the energy stored in the system and the potential at the center when a spherical “cavity” (of radius R₁) is filled with a uniform space‐charge density ρ and is surrounded by a concentric, grounded, spherical metal shell (extending from r = R₁ to r = R₂). (Inside the conductor the electric field vanishes and its potential is fixed at 0 by the grounding, so the only nonzero fields occur in the region r < R₁.)

Below we describe step‐by‐step how one may obtain the answers.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Find the Electrostatic Potential in the Cavity

Within the cavity (r < R₁) the charge density is ρ. By spherical symmetry the potential φ(r) satisfies Poisson’s equation

  d²φ/dr² + (2/r) dφ/dr = –ρ/ε₀.

A standard method is to integrate this equation. Write it as

  (1/r²) d/dr (r² dφ/dr) = –ρ/ε₀.

Multiplying through by r² gives

  d/dr (r² dφ/dr) = – (ρ r²)/ε₀.

Integrate once from 0 to r. (Regularity at r = 0 requires that the integration constant vanish.)

  r² dφ/dr = – (ρ/(ε₀)) ∫₀ᵣ r′² dr′
        = – (ρ/(ε₀)) (r³/3).

Thus,
  dφ/dr = – (ρ r)/(3ε₀).

Integrate again from 0 to r:

  φ(r) – φ(0) = –∫₀ᵣ (ρ r′/(3ε₀)) dr′
         = – (ρ/(3ε₀))(r²/2)
         = – (ρ r²)/(6ε₀).

So, in general,
  φ(r) = φ(0) – (ρ r²)/(6ε₀).

Now, the boundary condition is provided by the metal. Since the metal shell is grounded the potential on its inner surface (r = R₁) is zero. Thus, impose

  φ(R₁) = 0 = φ(0) – (ρ R₁²)/(6ε₀).

This gives

  φ(0) = (ρ R₁²)/(6ε₀).

Thus, the potential inside the cavity is

  φ(r) = (ρ/(6ε₀))(R₁² – r²),  for r ≤ R₁.

In particular, the potential at the center is

  φ(0) = (ρ R₁²)/(6ε₀).

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. Compute the Electrostatic Energy

The electrostatic energy stored in a charge distribution is given by

  U = ½ ∫ ρ φ dV,

where the integration is over the region that contains the free charge (here, 0 ≤ r ≤ R₁).

In spherical coordinates, the volume element is dV = 4πr² dr, so we have

  U = ½ ∫₀ᴿ₁ ρ [ρ/(6ε₀)(R₁² – r²)] 4πr² dr
    = (ρ²/(12ε₀)) 4π ∫₀ᴿ₁ (R₁² – r²) r² dr.

Now, evaluate the radial integral

  I = ∫₀ᴿ₁ (R₁² – r²) r² dr
    = R₁²∫₀ᴿ₁ r² dr – ∫₀ᴿ₁ r⁴ dr
    = R₁² (R₁³/3) – (R₁⁵/5)
    = (R₁⁵/3) – (R₁⁵/5)
    = R₁⁵ (5 – 3)/(15)
    = (2 R₁⁵)/15.

Thus,

  U = (ρ²/(12ε₀)) 4π × (2 R₁⁵/15)
    = (ρ² 8π R₁⁵)/(180ε₀)
    = (2π ρ² R₁⁵)/(45ε₀).

One may also compute the energy by integrating the energy density (ε₀/2)|E|² over the cavity. The electric field (for r < R₁) is

  E(r) = – dφ/dr = (ρ r)/(3ε₀).

Then the energy density is (ε₀/2) E² = (ρ² r²)/(18ε₀) and a similar integration gives the same result.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

The potential at the center is
  φ(0) = (ρ R₁²)/(6ε₀),

and the total electrostatic energy stored in the system is

  U = (2π ρ² R₁⁵)/(45ε₀).

We now give the final answer in boxed LaTeX:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\phi(0)&=\frac{\rho R_1^2}{6\epsilon_0},\\[1mm]
U&=\frac{2\pi \rho^2 R_1^5}{45\epsilon_0}\,.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We are given the Lagrangian for a relativistic charged particle moving in an electromagnetic field:

  L = –mc²√(1 – β²) + (e/c) A · v,

and the vector potential for a dipole magnetic field (with dipole moment μ along the polar axis) in spherical coordinates is

  A = (μ sin θ / r²) e₍φ₎.

Because the magnetic potential has only a φ‐component, i.e. A₍φ₎ = μ sin θ / r², it is most natural to work in spherical coordinates (r, θ, φ). In these coordinates the speed is

  v² = ṙ² + (r θ̇)² + (r sinθ φ̇)².

In what follows we will answer parts (a), (b) and (c) step by step.

──────────────────────────────
Step (a): Canonical Momentum p₍φ₎

The canonical momentum conjugate to a coordinate q (here φ) is defined by

  p₍φ₎ = ∂L/∂(φ̇).

Note that the Lagrangian may receive contributions from both the “kinetic” (free) part and from the interaction term with the vector potential. Let’s calculate each contribution.

1. Kinetic (free particle) part:

The relativistic free-particle Lagrangian is

  L₍free₎ = –mc²√(1 – v²/c²).

Since v depends on the velocities ṙ, θ̇, and φ̇, one may verify (by taking the derivative with respect to φ̇) that the “mechanical” momentum conjugate to φ is (see, for example, the standard result in spherical coordinates)

  p₍φ₎^(free) = mγ (r sinθ)² φ̇ = mγ r² sin²θ φ̇,

where the Lorentz factor is γ = 1/√(1 – v²/c²).

2. Electromagnetic (interaction) part:

The interaction term in the Lagrangian is

  L₍EM₎ = (e/c) A · v.

Because A only has a φ‐component and v has the φ-component v₍φ₎ = r sinθ φ̇, we have

  L₍EM₎ = (e/c) A₍φ₎ (r sinθ φ̇)
       = (e/c) (μ sinθ/r²) (r sinθ φ̇)
       = (e μ/(c)) (sin²θ/(r)) φ̇.

Thus the derivative with respect to φ̇ is

  ∂L₍EM₎/∂(φ̇) = (e μ/(c)) (sin²θ/(r)).

3. Total canonical momentum p₍φ₎:

Summing both contributions gives

  p₍φ₎ = mγ r² sin²θ φ̇ + (e μ/(c)) (sin²θ/(r)).

Thus, our answer for (a) is

  p₍φ₎ = mγ r² sin²θ φ̇ + (e μ/(c)) (sin²θ/(r)).

──────────────────────────────
Step (b): Conservation of p₍φ₎

In Lagrangian mechanics a coordinate is “cyclic” (or ignorable) if the Lagrangian does not depend explicitly on that coordinate. Here in our Lagrangian the coordinate φ appears only through its time derivative φ̇ (and not explicitly in any function), and hence it is cyclic.

By Noether’s theorem the conjugate momentum associated with a cyclic coordinate is conserved. Therefore, since φ does not appear explicitly in L, it follows that

  dp₍φ₎/dt = 0,

i.e. p₍φ₎ is a constant of the motion.

──────────────────────────────
Step (c): The Effect of a Gauge Transformation

Now suppose we change the vector potential by a gauge transformation

  A' = A + ∇χ,  
  χ = χ(r, θ, φ),

so that the new Lagrangian becomes

  L' = –mc²√(1 – v²/c²) + (e/c) A' · v
      = L + (e/c)(∇χ · v).

But note that

  ∇χ · v = dχ/dt – ∂χ/∂t.

If we assume that the gauge function χ is time‐independent (or even if it is time dependent, the extra term dχ/dt just adds a total derivative to the Lagrangian), then it adds a total derivative term (or a term whose φ dependence is only through a total time derivative). The Euler–Lagrange equations (and hence the equations of motion) are invariant under the addition of a total time derivative. 

However, let us examine explicitly the new canonical momentum conjugate to φ. The new electromagnetic term is

  L'₍EM₎ = (e/c)[A₍φ₎ + (∂χ/∂φ)/ (the appropriate metric factor?]
      = (e/c) [A₍φ₎ + ∂χ/∂φ] (r sinθ φ̇)     (since only the φ-velocity couples to ∂χ/∂φ).

Thus, when we take the derivative with respect to φ̇, we find that the new canonical momentum is

  p₍φ₎' = mγ r² sin²θ φ̇ + (e/c) [A₍φ₎ (r sinθ derivative) + (∂χ/∂φ)(r sinθ) factor].

More carefully, because the extra term in the Lagrangian is (e/c)(∇χ) · v and v has a φ component r sinθ φ̇, the derivative with respect to φ̇ picks up an extra piece:

  ∂/∂φ̇ [(e/c)(∇χ)·v] = (e/c) (∂χ/∂φ).

Thus, the full new canonical momentum is

  p₍φ₎' = mγ r² sin²θ φ̇ + (e μ/(c)) (sin²θ/(r)) + (e/c) (∂χ/∂φ).

That is, the gauge transformation modifies the canonical momentum by adding a piece (e/c)(∂χ/∂φ).

Although the explicit expression for p₍φ₎ has changed, the fact that φ remains cyclic in the new Lagrangian is not spoiled by adding a total time derivative. In other words, even though the numerical value of p₍φ₎ in terms of the coordinates and their derivatives shifts by the extra term (e/c)(∂χ/∂φ), the new momentum p₍φ₎' is still a constant of the motion. (Remember that adding a total time derivative in the Lagrangian does not affect the equations of motion.) 

Thus, our answer to part (c) is:
  Under the gauge transformation A → A + ∇χ the canonical momentum becomes
    p₍φ₎' = mγ r² sin²θ φ̇ + (e μ/(c)) (sin²θ/(r)) + (e/c)(∂χ/∂φ).
Moreover, since χ appears in the Lagrangian only through a total derivative, φ remains a cyclic variable and p₍φ₎' remains conserved.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The canonical momentum conjugate to φ is

  p₍φ₎ = mγ r² sin²θ φ̇ + (e μ/(c)) (sin²θ/(r)).

(b) Since φ does not appear explicitly in the Lagrangian (i.e. it is a cyclic coordinate), p₍φ₎ is a constant of the motion (dp₍φ₎/dt = 0).

(c) Under the gauge change A → A + ∇χ the canonical momentum becomes

  p₍φ₎' = mγ r² sin²θ φ̇ + (e μ/(c)) (sin²θ/(r)) + (e/c)(∂χ/∂φ).

Since the extra term comes only from a total time derivative added to the Lagrangian, φ remains cyclic and the modified p₍φ₎' is still conserved.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad &p_{\phi}=m\gamma\,r^2\sin^2\theta\,\dot{\phi}+\frac{e\mu}{c}\frac{\sin^2\theta}{r},\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad &\frac{dp_{\phi}}{dt}=0\quad\text{(since }\phi\text{ is cyclic)},\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}\quad &p_{\phi}'=m\gamma\,r^2\sin^2\theta\,\dot{\phi}+\frac{e\mu}{c}\frac{\sin^2\theta}{r}+\frac{e}{c}\frac{\partial\chi}{\partial\phi},\\[1mm]
&\text{and }p_{\phi}'\text{ remains a constant of the motion.}
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We will show that if a “free” spherical conductor of radius a (isolated so that its free charge may be adjusted) is placed in the field of a point charge outside its surface, then the free charge Q on the sphere must be made sufficiently positive so that the induced surface‐charge density, which is not uniform, is everywhere positive. (Here, “free charge” means the total charge you “give” to the sphere.) In fact, one may prove that if an external charge +q is located at a distance r from the center (with r > a) then the “polarization” created on a grounded sphere (i.e. one forced to zero potential) is given by

  (1) σ₍g₎(θ) = – (q/(4πa²)) · ((1 – k²)/[1 – 2k cosθ + k²]^(3/2)) ,

where we have defined

  k = a/r  (< 1).

Notice that for +q the induced (ground‐response) density is negative at every point of the sphere and – in fact – its maximum (in absolute value) occurs at the point (θ = 0) on the sphere nearest the charge. (One may check that a short calculation shows that the maximum magnitude is reached at θ = 0.)

Now, if the sphere is not grounded but is given a positive free charge Q, then by the uniqueness theorem the answer is obtained simply by adding the (uniform) extra charge density Q/(4πa²) to the “grounded” answer. That is, the total surface density is

  (2) σ(θ) = Q/(4πa²) + σ₍g₎(θ)
      = Q/(4πa²) – (q/(4πa²)) · ((1 – k²)/[1 – 2k cosθ + k²]^(3/2)) .

For the surface to be everywhere positively charged we must have σ(θ) ≥ 0 for all angles θ. (Here θ is the usual polar angle measured from the line joining the center of the sphere to the external charge.) When the external charge is +q the “negative” term is worst where its magnitude is greatest. One may show that the most negative value of σ₍g₎(θ) (namely, the most negative number) is attained at θ = 0. (One may verify that for 0 ≤ k < 1 the function F(θ) = (1 – k²)/[1 – 2k cosθ + k²]^(3/2) is maximized at cosθ = 1.) At θ = 0 the denominator becomes

  1 – 2k (1) + k² = (1 – k)²,
  so that
  F(0) = (1 – k²)/(1 – k)³ = (1 + k)/(1 – k)².

Thus the worst‐case (most negative) value of σ is at θ = 0. Requiring that

  σ(0) = Q/(4πa²) – (q/(4πa²)) · (1 + k)/(1 – k)² ≥ 0

immediately gives

  (3) Q ≥ q · (1 + k)/(1 – k)²  with k = a/r.

That is, when the external point charge is +q, the least positive free charge that must be put on the sphere in order that the surface charge density be positive everywhere is

  Q₍min₎ = q · (1 + a/r)/(1 – a/r)².

Now let us consider the case when the external charge is –q. (Here q is understood to be a positive number; “–q” means that the point‐charge is negative.) In that case the same method shows that the “grounded” induced charge density becomes

  σ₍g₎(θ) = – ((–q)/(4πa²)) · ((1 – k²)/[1 – 2k cosθ + k²]^(3/2))
         = + (q/(4πa²)) · ((1 – k²)/[1 – 2k cosθ + k²]^(3/2)).
 
Thus, with no extra free charge added (i.e. with Q = 0) the entire surface would carry the positive density

  σ(θ) = 0 + σ₍g₎(θ) > 0  (for all θ).
 
In other words, when the external charge is –q the polarization of the sphere alone produces a positive surface charge density everywhere. (In fact, for a grounded conductor the induced charge has total value +q so that the net free charge, if the sphere were isolated with Q = 0, would be +q.) Therefore, in this case no additional free positive charge is needed – the least positive Q is zero.

To summarize:

Step 1. For an isolated sphere of radius a in the presence of an external point charge q₍ext₎, one may decompose the free charge density as a uniform part plus the polarization response that would occur if the sphere were held at zero potential (“grounded”). That is,

  σ(θ) = Q/(4πa²) + σ₍g₎(θ),
  with σ₍g₎(θ) = – (q₍ext₎/(4πa²)) · ((1 – (a/r)²)/[1 – 2(a/r) cosθ + (a/r)²]^(3/2)).

Step 2. In order that σ(θ) be nonnegative at every point we must have
  Q/(4πa²) ≥ (q₍ext₎/(4πa²))·max₍θ₎ { (1 – (a/r)²)/[1 – 2(a/r) cosθ + (a/r)²]^(3/2) }  when q₍ext₎ > 0,
and
  Q/(4πa²) ≥ – (q₍ext₎/(4πa²))·min₍θ₎ { (1 – (a/r)²)/[1 – 2(a/r) cosθ + (a/r)²]^(3/2) }  when q₍ext₎ < 0.
A short analysis shows that when q₍ext₎ = +q the worst‐case is at θ = 0 and we obtain (3) above, while for q₍ext₎ = –q the “grounded” induced density is everywhere positive so that one may take Q = 0.

Thus, our final answers are:

For an external point charge +q (q > 0 placed at distance r from the center):
  Q₍min₎ = q · (1 + a/r)/(1 – a/r)².

For an external point charge –q:
  Q₍min₎ = 0.

We now state the final answer in boxed form.

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{For }+q: \quad Q_{\min} &= q\,\frac{1+\frac{a}{r}}{\Bigl(1-\frac{a}{r}\Bigr)^2},\\[1mm]
\text{For }-q: \quad Q_{\min} &= 0.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We wish to determine the electrostatic potential in the region outside a grounded conducting sphere of radius a when a point charge q is located at the point with radius vector s (with |s| = s > a). We will first consider the case where the region outside the sphere is vacuum and then the same geometry when the vacuum is replaced by a dielectric with dielectric constant ε. In what follows we assume that the charge q is the only free charge present (apart from its image charge which “mimics” the effect of the sphere).

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Using the Method of Images in Vacuum

For a point charge located at s (with s > a) outside a grounded conducting sphere, the method of images tells us that the effect of the sphere can be reproduced by placing an image charge q′ inside the sphere at a point s′ (along the radial direction) given by

  q′ = –q (a/s),

  s′ = (a²/s) n̂,  with n̂ = s/|s|.

That is, the image charge is located along the line joining the center of the sphere and the original charge, at a distance a²/s from the center.

Then, for any field point r (with |r| > a), the potential is the sum of the contributions from the real charge q and the image charge q′. In vacuum the Coulomb potential is given by
  φ_vac(r) = q/(4πε₀|r – s|).

Thus, we write

  φ_vac(r) = (1/(4πε₀)) [q/|r – s| + q′/|r – s′|].

Substituting for q′ we have

  φ_vac(r) = (1/(4πε₀)) [q/|r – s| – (q a/s)/|r – (a²/s) n̂|].

Note that here n̂ = s/|s|. This potential automatically satisfies the boundary condition on the sphere since when |r| = a the contributions from the real and image charges cancel so that the total potential on the surface is zero.

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. The Case with a Dielectric Medium

If the vacuum is replaced by a uniform dielectric of constant ε, then every Coulomb potential gets reduced by a factor ε (more precisely, the Coulomb constant becomes 1/(4πε₀ε)). That is, in a dielectric medium the potential due to a point charge becomes

  φ(r) = q/(4πε₀ε|r – s|).

Thus, the answer in the dielectric medium is obtained simply by replacing ε₀ by ε₀ε in our vacuum result. Hence we have

  φ_diel(r) = (1/(4πε₀ε)) [q/|r – s| − (q a/s)/|r – (a²/s) n̂|].

This potential, computed for |r| > a, satisfies the boundary condition that φ = 0 on the surface of the sphere.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) For a point charge in vacuum outside a grounded conducting sphere, the potential is

  φ_vac(r) = (1/(4πε₀)) ⎡q/|r – s| – (q a/s)/|r – (a²/s) (s/|s|)|⎤  (for |r| > a).

(b) For the same configuration in a dielectric medium of dielectric constant ε, the potential is

  φ_diel(r) = (1/(4πε₀ε)) ⎡q/|r – s| – (q a/s)/|r – (a²/s) (s/|s|)|⎤  (for |r| > a).

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer in LaTeX Box

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad \phi_{\text{vac}}(r) &= \frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0} \left[\frac{q}{\,|r-s|} - \frac{q\,a/s}{\,\left|r - \frac{a^2}{s}\,\frac{s}{|s|}\right|}\right], \quad |r| > a,\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad \phi_{\text{diel}}(r) &= \frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0\epsilon} \left[\frac{q}{\,|r-s|} - \frac{q\,a/s}{\,\left|r - \frac{a^2}{s}\,\frac{s}{|s|}\right|}\right], \quad |r| > a.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

To determine the effect of a metallic plane on a point charge, we can employ the method of images. This method replaces the influence of the conducting surface with an equivalent “image charge” placed symmetrically on the opposite side of the plane.

Step 1:
If a point charge Q is placed at a distance d from an infinite conducting plane, the boundary condition that the potential is zero on the conductor’s surface (assuming it is grounded) can be satisfied by imagining an image charge -Q located at the same distance, d, on the opposite side of the plane.

Step 2:
The potential in the region where the real charge is present is identical to the potential created by both the real charge and the image charge. Even though the image charge is not “real,” it correctly represents the effect of the induced charges on the conducting plane.

Step 3:
The force on the real charge due to the image charge can be calculated using Coulomb’s law. Since the image charge has the opposite sign, the force between the two charges is attractive.

Step 4:
Thus, the net effect is that the real charge is attracted to the plane by what appears to be a mirror image of equal and opposite charge.

Final Answer:
\[
\boxed{\text{(c) is attracted to the plane by a mirror image of equal and opposite charge.}}
\]

solution:
We wish to find the electrostatic potential everywhere in space produced by a long ( i.e. z‑independent) cylinder of radius a whose cross‐section is “split” along a diameter. One half of the surface is held at potential V₀ and the other at 0; there is no net charge on the system. (See Fig. 1.17(a) in many texts.) Because the system is invariant in the z‑direction the problem is two‐dimensional in the (x,y)–plane (or, equivalently, in polar coordinates (r, φ)) and the potential obeys Laplace’s equation.

Below we describe one acceptable solution approach, determine the approximate form far away and near the cylinder, and finally describe qualitatively the field lines. (Any answer equivalent to the answer below is correct.)

────────────────────────────
Step 1. Finding the potential everywhere (Part (a))
────────────────────────────
Because the problem is independent of z we write Laplace’s equation in polar coordinates
  (1/r) ∂/∂r (r ∂V/∂r) + (1/r²) ∂²V/∂φ² = 0.
The two‐dimensional general solution that is regular at r = 0 (inside) and that vanishes at infinity (outside) is normally given as a Fourier series in φ. We choose the polar coordinates so that on the cylinder’s surface (r = a) the potential is given by a step function:
  V(a,φ) = f(φ) = { V₀, for “one half” of the circle; 0, for the other half }.
A usual choice is to let
  f(φ) = V₀ for |φ| < π/2   and  f(φ) = 0 for π/2 < |φ| < π.
Note that f(φ) is an even function in φ, so we expand it as a cosine series:
  f(φ) = A₀/2 + Σₙ₌₁∞ Aₙ cos(nφ),
with Fourier coefficients
  Aₙ = (1/π)∫₋π^(π) f(φ) cos(nφ) dφ.
Because f is even the integration may be done only from 0 to π:
  Aₙ = (2/π)∫₀^(π) f(φ) cos(nφ) dφ
but note that f(φ) = V₀ only from 0 to π/2 and vanishes for π/2 < φ ≤ π. Thus,
  Aₙ = (2V₀/π)∫₀^(π/2) cos(nφ) dφ = (2V₀)/(π n) sin(nπ/2).
In particular, A₀ = (2V₀/π)(π/2) = V₀.

Now the “general” solution may be written (here we write separately the “inside” and “outside” solutions):
  For r ≤ a:
    V(r,φ)= A₀/2 + Σₙ₌₁∞ Aₙ (r/a)ⁿ cos(nφ),
  For r ≥ a:
    V(r,φ)= A₀/2 + Σₙ₌₁∞ Aₙ (a/r)ⁿ cos(nφ).

Since sin(nπ/2) is zero for even n, only odd terms appear. That is, if we write n = 2k + 1 (with k = 0, 1, 2, ⋯), then the solution may be written as

  For r ≤ a:
    V(r,φ)= V₀/2 + (2V₀/π) Σₖ₌₀∞ [1/(2k+1)] (r/a)^(2k+1) cos[(2k+1) φ],
  For r ≥ a:
    V(r,φ)= V₀/2 + (2V₀/π) Σₖ₌₀∞ [1/(2k+1)] (a/r)^(2k+1) cos[(2k+1) φ].

This series “solves” the potential everywhere: it automatically satisfies Laplace’s equation and meets the boundary conditions (with the understanding that at the discontinuities the series converges to the average of the two limits).

────────────────────────────
Step 2. Far from the cylinder (r ≫ a), Part (b)
────────────────────────────
For r ≫ a the terms with higher powers of (a/r) quickly vanish. The dominant terms come from the constant part and the n = 1 (k = 0) term:
  V(r,φ) ≈ V₀/2 + (2V₀/π)(a/r) cos φ.
Since a constant potential does not contribute to the electric field, we have for the “dipole–like” part:
  V_dip(r,φ)= (2V₀ a/π)(cos φ/r).
Thus the electric field for r≫a is given by
  E = –∇V ≈ –∇V_dip.
In polar coordinates one easily shows that
  E_r = – ∂V_dip/∂r = (2V₀a/π)(cos φ)/r²,
  E_φ = – (1/r) ∂V_dip/∂φ = (2V₀a/π)(sin φ)/r².
Thus the far–field line pattern is that of a two–dimensional dipole (with the constant V₀/2 being irrelevant for the field).

Alternatively, in vector form
  E(r,φ) ≈ (2V₀a)/(πr²) [cos φ ̂r – sin φ ̂φ].
(In Cartesian coordinates this represents a dipole field pointing in the x–direction.)

────────────────────────────
Step 3. Very near the center (r ≪ a), Part (c)
────────────────────────────
For r≪a we use the “inside” solution. Only the lowest order term in (r/a) is important. Expanding
  V(r,φ) = V₀/2 + (2V₀/π)(r/a) cos φ + higher–order terms,
we see that near r = 0 the potential is nearly linear (plus a constant). (The constant V₀/2 does not affect the electric field.) Thus
  V(r,φ) ≈ constant + (2V₀/π)(r/a) cos φ.
Then calculating the field,
  E_r = –∂V/∂r ≈ – (2V₀/π)(1/a) cos φ,
  E_φ = –(1/r) ∂V/∂φ ≈ (2V₀/π)(1/a) sin φ.
In Cartesian language one finds that the field at the center is uniform and given by
  E ≈ – (2V₀)/(πa) ˆx.
(Recall that in polar coordinates, cos φ ̂r – sin φ ̂φ is just the unit vector ˆx.) This is the expected result: the region near the center “sees” essentially a uniform field directed from the high–potential side (the half with V = V₀, which we take to be at x > 0) toward the low–potential side.

────────────────────────────
Step 4. Sketching the field lines (Part (d))
────────────────────────────
An acceptable sketch is as follows:

1. Inside the cylinder (r < a) the equipotential lines are nearly straight and parallel. In particular, near the center they are almost linear so that the electric field is approximately uniform, directed from the high–potential half (roughly the right side, x > 0) toward the low–potential half (x < 0).

2. On the cylinder’s surface (r = a) the potential is discontinuous: one half of the circle is at V = V₀ and the other at V = 0. (In the mathematical solution the Fourier series converges to the average at the discontinuity.)

3. For r ≫ a the field lines are those of a two–dimensional dipole. They emerge from the region near x > 0 and curve around toward x < 0. (Since the constant part of the potential has no effect on the field, the far–field is dominated by the dipole term.)

Thus, one may draw the field lines so that inside the cylinder they are nearly straight (horizontal), while outside they bend and “arc” from the positive–x region to the negative–x region.

────────────────────────────
Final Answers
────────────────────────────
(a) The potential everywhere is given by

For r ≤ a:
  V(r, φ) = V₀/2 + (2V₀/π) Σₖ₌₀∞ 1/(2k+1) (r/a)^(2k+1) cos[(2k+1) φ].

For r ≥ a:
  V(r, φ) = V₀/2 + (2V₀/π) Σₖ₌₀∞ 1/(2k+1) (a/r)^(2k+1) cos[(2k+1) φ].

(b) For r ≫ a the potential is dominated by the dipole term:
  V(r, φ) ≈ V₀/2 + (2V₀ a/π)(cos φ/r)
and so the electric field is
  E(r, φ) ≈ (2V₀a)/(πr²)[cos φ ˆr – sin φ ˆφ].

(c) For r ≪ a the lowest–order term gives
  V(r, φ) ≈ V₀/2 + (2V₀/(πa)) r cos φ,
so that
  E ≈ – (2V₀)/(πa) ˆx  (i.e. a uniform field pointing in the –x direction).

(d) The field lines are nearly parallel (uniform) near the center (inside the cylinder) with the lines pointing from the V = V₀ side (roughly x > 0) to the V = 0 side (x < 0). Outside the cylinder the field lines curve outward so that the overall far‐field pattern is that of a dipole oriented along the x–axis.

────────────────────────────
Final Answer in Latex Box
────────────────────────────
\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad V(r,\phi) &= 
\begin{cases}
\displaystyle \frac{V_0}{2}+\frac{2V_0}{\pi}\sum_{k=0}^\infty \frac{1}{2k+1}\Bigl(\frac{r}{a}\Bigr)^{2k+1}\cos[(2k+1)\phi],\quad r\le a, \\[1em]
\displaystyle \frac{V_0}{2}+\frac{2V_0}{\pi}\sum_{k=0}^\infty \frac{1}{2k+1}\Bigl(\frac{a}{r}\Bigr)^{2k+1}\cos[(2k+1)\phi],\quad r\ge a.
\end{cases}\\[1em]
\text{(b)}\quad V(r,\phi)&\approx \frac{V_0}{2}+\frac{2V_0 a}{\pi}\,\frac{\cos\phi}{r}\quad (r\gg a),\\[1em]
\quad \mathbf{E}(r,\phi)&\approx \frac{2V_0a}{\pi r^2}\Bigl[\cos\phi\,\hat{r}-\sin\phi\,\hat{\phi}\Bigr],\\[1em]
\text{(c)}\quad V(r,\phi)&\approx \frac{V_0}{2}+\frac{2V_0}{\pi a}\,r\cos\phi\quad (r\ll a),\\[1em]
\quad \mathbf{E}&\approx -\frac{2V_0}{\pi a}\,\hat{x},\\[1em]
\text{(d)}\quad &\text{The field lines are nearly straight and horizontal (uniform) inside the cylinder (pointing from }x>0\text{ to }x<0\text{) and smoothly connect to a dipolar field (curving from the high‐potential region at }x>0\text{ to the low one at }x<0\text{) for }r\gg a. 
\end{aligned}
}
\]

solution:
We wish to study a permanent dipole (with moment P) located a distance r (with r ≫ a) from the center of a neutral, perfectly‐conducting sphere of radius a. In our situation the dipole is oriented “radially” – that is, its moment points along the line joining the center of the sphere to the dipole, directed away from the sphere. (Some authors denote the permanent dipole moment by p; here we use P.) One may show (using, e.g., the method of images or a multipole expansion) that for r ≫ a the sphere “responds” essentially by developing an induced (dipole) moment of order a³ so that the interaction energy is very small. (In what follows we work in a system of units in which the factors 1/4πε₀ are set equal to unity. One may reinstate these constants as needed.)

We now explain step‐by‐step both parts.

───────────────────────────── 
Step 1. (Boundary conditions on the E‐field at the surface.)

A perfectly conducting body requires that
 (1) the potential throughout the conductor must be constant; and 
 (2) the electric field inside is zero.

Thus on the surface (which is the interface between vacuum and conductor) one must have:
 • The tangential component of the electric field vanishes. (This follows from the fact that if it did not vanish, then there would be a nonzero potential difference along the surface and currents would flow until equilibrium is reached.)
 • The perpendicular (normal) component of the electric field is not zero in general; in fact, if σ is the induced surface charge density then
  E_normal (just outside) = σ / ε₀.
Also, inside the conductor the field is zero. (When we say “on the surface” we mean that the potential is continuous and equal to a constant.)

Thus, our answer for (a) is: On the surface we have 
 V = constant (so that ∇ₜV = 0 and Eₜ = 0),
 and the electric field just outside satisfies
  E_out · n = σ/ε₀,
while inside, E = 0.

───────────────────────────── 
Step 2. (Force on the dipole)

Because the sphere is uncharged, its only response to the dipole’s field is to rearrange its free charges so as to keep its potential constant. For a small sphere (r ≫ a) it can be shown that the induced charge distribution is equivalent, to lowest order, to producing an induced dipole moment
  P_induced = a³ E_loc,
where E_loc is the “external” field (here due to the dipole) at the center of the sphere.

Now, recall that the field on the axis of a dipole (pointing along the line joining the dipole to the field point) is given by
  E_dipole = (2P)/r³. 
Thus, to lowest order one obtains
  P_induced ≃ a³ (2P/r³) = (2a³P)/r³.
A standard result of linear dielectrics (or induced moments) is that the “interaction energy” of a permanent dipole P in an external field E_ext is
  U_int = –P · E_ext.
However, if the dipole is itself responsible for the polarization of an object (here our sphere) the “correct” interaction energy is only one‐half as large. (This “1/2” appears in many problems involving induced charges.)
In other words, one may show that the interaction energy (or “self‐energy” of the dipole in the presence of the conductor) is
  U ≃ –½ P · E₍ind₎.
Since here both dipoles (the permanent one and the induced one) lie along the same line, one may also obtain U by “regrouping” the dipole–dipole interaction. In fact, one may show that

  U ≃ –½ a³ E²,
where E is the external field at the sphere (namely, E ≃ 2P/r³ along the axis). Hence,
  U ≃ –½ a³ (2P/r³)² = –2a³P² / r⁶.
Then the attractive force (directed toward the sphere) is obtained by taking the negative derivative with respect to r:
  F = –dU/dr = –d/dr (–2a³P²/r⁶) = 12a³P²/r⁷.

Thus the magnitude of the force is approximately

  |F| ≃ 12a³P²/r⁷,
and its direction is radially inward (i.e. toward the sphere).

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answers

(a) At the conductor’s surface the potential is constant and therefore the tangential component of E must vanish, while the normal component satisfies
  E_normal (just outside) = σ/ε₀;
moreover, E = 0 inside the conductor.

(b) In the limit r ≫ a the attractive force on a dipole P pointed radially outward (i.e. away from the sphere) is approximately

  F ≃ – (12a³P²/r⁷) r̂      (attraction toward the sphere).

We now provide the final answer in the requested boxed LaTeX format.

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad & V = \text{constant on the surface, so } E_{\parallel} = 0 \text{ and } E_{\perp} \;=\; \frac{\sigma}{\epsilon_0}\; (\text{with } E=0 \text{ inside}).\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad & \mathbf{F} \;\simeq\; -\,\frac{12\, a^3 P^2}{r^7}\,\hat{r}\quad\text{(i.e. an attractive force toward the sphere).}
\end{aligned}
}

Step 1. Write the Capacitance and Resistance in Terms of Geometry

For two conductors separated by a distance d with facing area A, embedded in a material having dielectric constant ε and conductivity σ, the common textbook formulas are

  Capacitance: C = (εA)/d

  Resistance:  R = d/(σA)

Step 2. Relate C and R

Multiply the two expressions together:

  R · C = [d/(σA)] · [εA/d] = ε/σ

Notice that the geometry (A and d) cancels from the product. Therefore, regardless of the specific geometry, the product RC is determined solely by the properties of the medium:

  RC = ε/σ      (1)

Step 3. Solve for the Capacitance C

We can rearrange equation (1) to find:

  C = (ε/σ)/R = ε/(σR)

This is the general expression for the capacitance between the two conductors when the resistance between them is measured to be R.

Step 4. Substitute in the Given Values

We are given:
  Dielectric constant: ε = 80 ε₀  (with ε₀ = 8.854 × 10⁻¹² F/m)
  Conductivity:    σ = 10⁻⁴ S/m   (since S/m is the SI unit of conductivity)
  Measured resistance: R = 10⁵ Ω

First, compute the permittivity ε:

  ε = 80 × 8.854 × 10⁻¹² F/m ≈ 7.0832 × 10⁻¹⁰ F/m

Then, plug into the formula for C:

  C = ε/(σR) = (7.0832 × 10⁻¹⁰ F/m) / [(10⁻⁴ S/m)(10⁵ Ω)]

Evaluate the denominator:

  (10⁻⁴ S/m)(10⁵ Ω) = 10

Thus,

  C = (7.0832 × 10⁻¹⁰ F/m)/10 = 7.0832 × 10⁻¹¹ F

Step 5. Final Answer

The capacitance is about 7.08 × 10⁻¹¹ Farads, or approximately 71 pF.
