We will show step‐by–step how one obtains the following answers. In what follows we assume the particle is non–relativistic so that only the lowest–order (“dipole”) radiation need be kept. (Any answer equivalent to the answers below is correct.)

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. The general result

For a non–relativistic point charge e with instantaneous acceleration a(t) the electric “radiation” field at large distances (in the radiation zone) is proportional to

  E_rad ∝ n′×(n′×a)
       (1)

where n′ is the unit vector from the charge to the observer. (Throughout we set n′ as the “observer direction”.) Then the instantaneous power radiated per unit solid angle is given by
   
  dP/dΩ = (e²/(4πc³)) |n′×(n′×a)|².
       (2)

It is sometimes preferable to write the acceleration in “dimensionless” form. Defining β = v/c so that a = d(βc)/dt = c dβ/dt we may also write
   
  dP/dΩ = (e²c/(4π)) |n′×(n′×dβ/dt)|².
       (2a)

This is our answer (a).

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. (a) General answer in terms of β and its time derivative

Thus, (a) one acceptable answer is

  
  dP/dΩ = (e²c/(4π)) | n′×( n′× (dβ/dt)) |².
       (Answer a)
  
or, equivalently, writing a = c dβ/dt,
  
  dP/dΩ = (e²/(4π c³)) | n′×(n′×a) |².

──────────────────────────────
Step 3. (b) Oscillation along z

Suppose the particle oscillates along the z–axis:
  
  z(t) = a cos(ω₀t). 
  
Then the velocity and acceleration are:
  
  v_z(t) = –a ω₀ sin(ω₀t), a_z(t) = –a ω₀² cos(ω₀t).
  
Thus the acceleration vector is
  
  a(t) = (0, 0, –a ω₀² cos(ω₀t)).
  
Take the observer direction n′ = (sinθ cosφ, sinθ sinφ, cosθ). We now compute (using the vector identity n′×(n′×a)=a–n′(n′⋅a)):
  
  n′⋅a = –a ω₀² cos(ω₀t) cosθ,
  
so that
  
  n′×(n′×a) = a – n′ (n′⋅a)
          = (0,0,–a ω₀² cos(ω₀t)) + a ω₀² cos(ω₀t) cosθ n′.
  
Its magnitude is
  
  |n′×(n′×a)| = a ω₀² |cos(ω₀t)| √(1 – cos²θ)
         = a ω₀² |cos(ω₀t)| sinθ.
  
Squaring and plugging into Eq. (2),
  
  |n′×(n′×a)|² = a² ω₀⁴ cos²(ω₀t) sin²θ.
  
The time–averaged value over one period of cos²(ω₀t) is 1/2. Hence the time–averaged differential power is
  
  ⟨dP/dΩ⟩ = (e²/(4π c³)) (a² ω₀⁴ sin²θ)/(2)
        = (e² a² ω₀⁴ sin²θ)/(8π c³).
       (Answer b)

It is sometimes convenient to note that if we define a “dimensionless acceleration” by writing dβ/dt = a ω₀² cos(ω₀t)/c then the same answer follows.

──────────────────────────────
Step 4. (c) Circular motion in the xy–plane

Now suppose the particle moves in a circle of radius R in the xy–plane with constant angular frequency ω₀. Then the particle’s position is, e.g.,
  
  x(t)=R cos(ω₀t), y(t)=R sin(ω₀t), z(t)=0.
  
Its acceleration is centripetal:
  
  a(t) = –ω₀²R (cos(ω₀t), sin(ω₀t), 0).
  
Again, take the observer direction n′ = (sinθ cosφ, sinθ sinφ, cosθ). The instantaneous value of n′⋅a is
  
  n′⋅a = –ω₀² R [ sinθ cosφ cos(ω₀t) + sinθ sinφ sin(ω₀t) ]
      = –ω₀² R sinθ cos(ω₀t – φ).
  
Thus
  
  (n′⋅a)² = ω₀⁴ R² sin²θ cos²(ω₀t – φ).
  
Since |a|² = ω₀⁴ R², we have, using 
  
  |n′×(n′×a)|² = |a|² – (n′⋅a)²
      = ω₀⁴ R² [1 – sin²θ cos²(ω₀t – φ)].
  
Upon time averaging the “rotating” quantity cos²(ω₀t – φ) over a full cycle we get 1/2 (note: the angular phase φ is constant for a given observer, but the time–average over t eliminates the t–dependence). Hence,
  
  ⟨|n′×(n′×a)|²⟩ = ω₀⁴ R² [1 – sin²θ/2].
  
Thus the time–averaged differential power is 
  
  ⟨dP/dΩ⟩ = (e²/(4π c³)) ω₀⁴ R² (1 – sin²θ/2).
        = (e² ω₀⁴ R²/(4π c³)) (1 – ½ sin²θ).
       (Answer c)

──────────────────────────────
Step 5. (d) Sketching the angular distributions

• For the linear oscillation along z (part (b)): The instantaneous radiation pattern is that of an oscillating electric dipole. After time–averaging, the angular distribution goes as sin²θ (with θ measured from the z–axis). Thus the radiation is zero along the z–axis (θ = 0, π) and maximum in the “equatorial” plane (θ = π/2).

• For the circular motion in the xy–plane (part (c)): The time–averaged pattern is proportional to 1 – (1/2) sin²θ. Thus the radiation is maximum along the z–axis (θ = 0, π) and smaller in the plane (θ = π/2; in fact, one finds ⟨dP/dΩ⟩(π/2) is half the value at θ = 0).

A schematic sketch would show a “doughnut” (or dipole) pattern for (b) and an “oblate” pattern, peaked along the z direction, for (c).

──────────────────────────────
Step 6. (e) Qualitative changes in the relativistic case

When the particle’s speed becomes relativistic, the radiation is no longer emitted in a symmetric dipole pattern. Instead, due to Lorentz–boosting the radiation is highly “beamed” in the direction of the instantaneous velocity. (In fact, the radiation is confined to a narrow cone about the particle's instantaneous velocity with an opening angle ~1/γ where γ = (1–v²/c²)^(–1/2).) Also, additional effects occur (such as “aberration” and frequency shifts) and the overall radiated power increases according to the full Liénard formula. In short, the angular distribution is much more anisotropic in the relativistic case.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) For an arbitrary non–relativistic motion,
  
  \[
  \frac{dP}{d\Omega} = \frac{e^2 c}{4 \pi} \Bigl|\mathbf{n}'\times\Bigl(\mathbf{n}'\times\frac{d\beta}{dt}\Bigr)\Bigr|^2
  \]
    or equivalently,
  \[
  \frac{dP}{d\Omega} = \frac{e^2}{4 \pi c^3} \Bigl|\mathbf{n}'\times\Bigl(\mathbf{n}'\times\mathbf{a}\Bigr)\Bigr|^2.
  \]

(b) For oscillatory motion along z given by z(t)=a cos(ω₀t),
  
  \[
  \Bigl\langle\frac{dP}{d\Omega}\Bigr\rangle = \frac{e^2 a^2 \omega_0^4}{8 \pi c^3}\sin^2\theta.
  \]

(c) For circular motion of radius R in the xy–plane with angular frequency ω₀,
  
  \[
  \Bigl\langle\frac{dP}{d\Omega}\Bigr\rangle = \frac{e^2 \omega_0^4 R^2}{4 \pi c^3}\Bigl(1 - \frac{1}{2}\sin^2\theta\Bigr).
  \]

(d) The sketches of the angular distributions are as follows:
  • For (b) the radiation has a dipole pattern (∝ sin²θ), so it vanishes along the oscillation axis (θ = 0, π) and peaks in the equatorial plane (θ = π/2).
  • For (c) the radiation is maximum along the z–axis (θ = 0, π) and reduced in the plane (θ = π/2).

(e) In the relativistic case the radiation becomes strongly beamed in the direction of motion (with typical opening angle ~1/γ). Consequently, the angular distribution is highly anisotropic, and not given simply by the dipole patterns above. (Also, the total radiated power is increased.)

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad &\frac{dP}{d\Omega}=\frac{e^2c}{4\pi}\Biggl|\mathbf{n}'\times\Bigl(\mathbf{n}'\times\frac{d\beta}{dt}\Bigr)\Biggr|^2\;=\;\frac{e^2}{4\pi c^3}\Bigl|\mathbf{n}'\times(\mathbf{n}'\times\mathbf{a})\Bigr|^2,\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad &\Bigl\langle\frac{dP}{d\Omega}\Bigr\rangle=\frac{e^2a^2\omega_0^4}{8\pi c^3}\sin^2\theta,\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}\quad &\Bigl\langle\frac{dP}{d\Omega}\Bigr\rangle=\frac{e^2\omega_0^4R^2}{4\pi c^3}\Bigl(1-\frac{1}{2}\sin^2\theta\Bigr),\\[1mm]
\text{(d)}\quad &\text{(b) shows a dipole pattern (zero along }z\text{) while (c) is peaked along the }z\text{–axis.}\\[1mm]
\text{(e)}\quad &\text{For relativistic motion the radiation is confined to a narrow cone (angle }\sim1/\gamma\text{) about the velocity.}
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We will show that if you “do the math” in the two cases – (a) when the two positrons are separated along the beam (i.e. the velocity) direction and (b) when they are separated transverse to the beam – you obtain answers that can be written in “Coulomb‐law form” in the rest frame with extra factors of γ (the usual Lorentz–factor) appearing when one transforms to the laboratory frame. (Any answer reconciling these effects is acceptable.) Below is one acceptable solution.

─────────────────────────────  
Step 1. Write the answers in the beam (rest) frame

Let the charges be q = e (positron charge), and assume that in their rest frame the distance between the two is d. (We choose coordinates so that the beam is along the x–axis.)

(a) Longitudinal separation (one positron directly ahead of the other):

• In the rest frame the field of e₂ on e₁ is purely Coulomb:
  E′ = (e/(4πε₀)) (1/d²) 𝑥̂                    [1]
  B′ = 0.
• The Lorentz force then is
  F′ = e E′ = e²/(4πε₀ d²) 𝑥̂.
• And the acceleration (using Newton’s law in this frame) is
  a′ = F′/m = e²/(4πε₀ m d²) 𝑥̂.

(b) Transverse (side‐by–side) separation:

Now assume the charges are separated by d in the y–direction.

• In the rest frame the electric field is
  E′ = (e/(4πε₀)) (1/d²) 𝑦̂                    [2]
  B′ = 0.
• Thus the force is
  F′ = e E′ = e²/(4πε₀ d²) 𝑦̂,
• And the acceleration is
  a′ = e²/(4πε₀ m d²) 𝑦̂.

─────────────────────────────  
Step 2. Transform to the Laboratory Frame

Now the beam’s laboratory frame is one in which both charges are moving with speed v (with γ = 1/√(1–β²), β = v/c) along the x–axis. In transforming we must remember two things: (i) the fields of a moving charge are not isotropic and (ii) distances parallel to the boost contract.

─────────────────────────────  
Case (a): Longitudinal (along the beam)

1. The separation along x contracts. That is, if the “rest–frame” separation is d then the lab sees
  d_lab = d/γ.
2. On the other hand, the well–known field of a charge moving with constant velocity (the “Lienard–Wiechert field”) gives, for an observation along the direction of motion,
  E₍∥₎ = (e/(4πε₀)) (1–β²)/(r²) = (e/(4πε₀)) (1/γ²)/(r²).
 Since for the longitudinal case the lab distance is r = d/γ, we have
  E_lab = (e/(4πε₀)) (1/γ²)/((d/γ)²) = e/(4πε₀ d²).
 Thus in the lab frame the electric field “comes out” with the same numerical value as in the rest frame:
  E_lab = (e/(4πε₀ d²)) 𝑥̂.
3. Also, when the observation point lies along the velocity the magnetic field vanishes (v and E are parallel). Hence,
  B_lab = 0.
4. The Lorentz force is then
  F_lab = e E_lab = e²/(4πε₀ d²) 𝑥̂.
5. However, note that the transformation of the “equation of motion” is different because the effective mass for acceleration along the direction of motion increases by a factor γ³. (This is a standard result: if F∥ = dp/dt then one finds a∥ = F∥/(γ³ m).) Therefore the acceleration observed in the lab is
  a_lab = F_lab/(γ³ m) = e²/(4πε₀ γ³ m d²) 𝑥̂.
  Intuition: Although the electric field “recovers” its rest–frame magnitude (because the contraction of d cancels the 1/γ² from the moving–charge field), the particle’s inertia in a longitudinal force is enhanced by γ³ so that the acceleration is much smaller.

─────────────────────────────  
Case (b): Transverse (side–by–side)

1. For the transverse separation the distance d is not contracted (only lengths parallel to v contract). So,
  d_lab = d.
2. The moving charge produces an electric field which is enhanced transverse to the velocity by a factor γ:
  E_lab = (e/(4πε₀)) (γ/d²) 𝑦̂.
3. It also produces a magnetic field given by
  B_lab = (1/c²) (v×E_lab),
 so with v = v 𝑥̂ and E_lab = (eγ/(4πε₀ d²)) 𝑦̂ the cross product gives
  B_lab = (e v γ/(4πε₀ c² d²)) 𝑧̂.
4. The total Lorentz force on a charge moving with velocity v is
  F_lab = e [E_lab + v×B_lab].
 Let us compute the second term:
  v×B_lab = v 𝑥̂ × (e v γ/(4πε₀ c² d²) 𝑧̂)
      = e v² γ/(4πε₀ c² d²) (𝑥̂×𝑧̂)
      = – e v² γ/(4πε₀ c² d²) 𝑦̂    (since 𝑥̂×𝑧̂ = –𝑦̂).
5. Hence,
  F_lab = e [ (eγ/(4πε₀ d²)) 𝑦̂ – (e v² γ/(4πε₀ c² d²)) 𝑦̂ ]
     = e²γ/(4πε₀ d²)[1 – v²/c²] 𝑦̂ = e²γ/(4πε₀ d²)(1/γ²) 𝑦̂,
     = e²/(4πε₀ γ d²) 𝑦̂.
6. For forces transverse to the velocity the effective inertial mass is increased by a factor γ (so that a = F/(γ m)). Thus,
  a_lab = F_lab/(γ m) = e²/(4πε₀ γ² m d²) 𝑦̂.
  Intuition: Here the transverse electric field is boosted by γ, but a nearly canceling magnetic effect (∝ v²/c²) reduces the net force by 1/γ relative to the rest force. In addition, the transverse “mass” is enhanced by γ, so that the acceleration is reduced by a factor 1/γ².

─────────────────────────────  
Final Answers

(a) Two positrons separated longitudinally (one ahead of the other):

1. In the beam (rest) frame:
  
  E′ = (e/(4πε₀)) (𝑥̂/d²),
  B′ = 0,
  F′ = eE′ = e²/(4πε₀ d²) 𝑥̂,
  a′ = F′/m = e²/(4πε₀ m d²) 𝑥̂.

2. In the laboratory frame:
  
  The separation is d_lab = d/γ. The moving–charge field for an observation in the longitudinal direction gives
   E_lab = (e/(4πε₀)) (𝑥̂/d²),
   B_lab = 0.
  Thus,
   F_lab = eE_lab = e²/(4πε₀ d²) 𝑥̂,
   a_lab = F_lab/(γ³ m) = e²/(4πε₀ γ³ m d²) 𝑥̂.

An intuitive explanation is that although length contraction makes d_lab smaller (which would tend to enhance the Coulomb field), the fact that the “longitudinal” field of a moving charge is reduced by 1/γ² exactly cancels that, leaving the force unchanged; however, the inertia for acceleration along the beam is increased by γ³, so the acceleration is smaller by 1/γ³.

(b) Two positrons separated transversely (side‐by–side):

1. In the beam (rest) frame:
  
  E′ = (e/(4πε₀)) (𝑦̂/d²),
  B′ = 0,
  F′ = eE′ = e²/(4πε₀ d²) 𝑦̂,
  a′ = F′/m = e²/(4πε₀ m d²) 𝑦̂.

2. In the laboratory frame:
  
  Since there is no contraction transverse to v, d_lab = d. The moving–charge fields give:
   E_lab = (e/(4πε₀)) (γ 𝑦̂/d²),
   B_lab = (eγ v/(4πε₀ c² d²)) 𝑧̂.
  Then the Lorentz force on a charge moving with v is
   F_lab = e[E_lab + v×B_lab] = e²/(4πε₀ γ d²) 𝑦̂,
  and the transverse acceleration (recall the “transverse mass” is γm) is
   a_lab = F_lab/(γ m) = e²/(4πε₀ γ² m d²) 𝑦̂.
  Intuitively, although the transverse electric field is enhanced by γ, a “magnetic” force of nearly equal magnitude (but opposite in sign) partially cancels the force so that the net force is down by 1/γ relative to the rest–frame force; furthermore the increased transverse inertia (by γ) leads to an acceleration that is smaller by 1/γ².

─────────────────────────────  
Final Answer in LaTeX Boxed Format

\[
\boxed{
\begin{array}{rcl}
\textbf{(a)}\quad\text{Longitudinal separation:} &&\\[1mm]
\text{In the beam frame:}&&
\begin{cases}
\mathbf{E}'=\dfrac{e}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\dfrac{\hat{x}}{d^2},\\[1mm]
\mathbf{B}'=0,\\[1mm]
\mathbf{F}'=e\mathbf{E}'=\dfrac{e^2}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\dfrac{\hat{x}}{d^2},\\[1mm]
\mathbf{a}'=\mathbf{F}'/m=\dfrac{e^2}{4\pi\epsilon_0 m}\dfrac{\hat{x}}{d^2};
\end{cases} \\[2mm]
\text{In the lab frame (with }d_{\mathrm{lab}}=d/\gamma\text{):}&&
\begin{cases}
\mathbf{E}=\dfrac{e}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\dfrac{\hat{x}}{d^2},\\[1mm]
\mathbf{B}=0,\\[1mm]
\mathbf{F}=e\mathbf{E}=\dfrac{e^2}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\dfrac{\hat{x}}{d^2},\\[1mm]
\mathbf{a}=\mathbf{F}/(\gamma^3 m)=\dfrac{e^2}{4\pi\epsilon_0\,\gamma^3 m}\dfrac{\hat{x}}{d^2}.
\end{cases} \\[3mm]
\textbf{(b)}\quad\text{Transverse (side–by–side) separation:} &&\\[1mm]
\text{In the beam frame:}&&
\begin{cases}
\mathbf{E}'=\dfrac{e}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\dfrac{\hat{y}}{d^2},\\[1mm]
\mathbf{B}'=0,\\[1mm]
\mathbf{F}'=\dfrac{e^2}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\dfrac{\hat{y}}{d^2},\\[1mm]
\mathbf{a}'=\dfrac{e^2}{4\pi\epsilon_0 m}\dfrac{\hat{y}}{d^2};
\end{cases} \\[2mm]
\text{In the lab frame (with }d_{\mathrm{lab}}=d\text{):}&&
\begin{cases}
\mathbf{E}=\dfrac{e\gamma}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\dfrac{\hat{y}}{d^2},\\[1mm]
\mathbf{B}=\dfrac{e\gamma v}{4\pi\epsilon_0c^2}\dfrac{\hat{z}}{d^2},\\[1mm]
\mathbf{F}=e\Bigl[\mathbf{E}+\mathbf{v}\times\mathbf{B}\Bigr]
=\dfrac{e^2}{4\pi\epsilon_0\,\gamma}\dfrac{\hat{y}}{d^2},\\[1mm]
\mathbf{a}=\mathbf{F}/(\gamma m)
=\dfrac{e^2}{4\pi\epsilon_0\,\gamma^2 m}\dfrac{\hat{y}}{d^2}.
\end{cases}
\end{array}
}
\]

This solution shows that in the lab frame the “longitudinal” force is unchanged (apart from the effect of the increased inertia, which appears as a factor of 1/γ³ in the acceleration) while the “transverse” force is reduced by 1/γ (and the acceleration by 1/γ²) – exactly as one would expect from the Lorentz–transformation properties of the fields and forces.

We start by noting that the particle, initially at rest, is acted on by a constant electric field E (in the laboratory frame) so that it experiences a constant force

  F = eE.

In special relativity, the momentum of a particle is given by

  p = mγv      (1)

and its rate of change is given by

  dp/dt = F.

Since F is constant and the particle starts from rest, by integrating (1) we obtain

  p = eE · t,
      (2)

where t is the time duration over which the force acts.

We now answer each part step by step.

─────────────────────────────

Step (a): Momentum at the End of the Acceleration

From relation (2) above, after an acceleration time t the particle has acquired a momentum

  p = eEt.

─────────────────────────────

Step (b): The Velocity of the Particle

The relativistic momentum is given by (1), and we can write the Lorentz factor γ in terms of p by noting that

  γ = √[1 + (p/(mc))²].

Substitute the result (2) into the above expression:

  γ = √[1 + (eEt/(mc))²].

Now, using (1) we have

  mγv = eEt   ⟹  v = eEt/(mγ).

Thus, substituting for γ we obtain

  v = [eE t] / [m √(1 + (eE t/(mc))²)].

It is sometimes more illuminating to express v in terms of c by writing

  v = c · [(eEt/(mc))] / √(1 + (eEt/(mc))²).

─────────────────────────────

Step (c): Lifetime Measured by a Stationary Observer

In the rest frame of the particle, its proper lifetime is τ. In the laboratory frame, time dilation tells us that the lifetime is increased by the Lorentz factor γ. That is,

  τ_lab = γτ.

Inserting the expression for γ we found earlier, we have

  τ_lab = τ √[1 + (eE t/(mc))²].

─────────────────────────────

Final Answers:

  (a) The momentum of the particle at time t is:
    p = eEt.

  (b) The velocity of the particle at time t is:
    v = [eE t] / [m√(1+(eE t/(mc))²)] = c · (eEt/(mc))/√(1+(eEt/(mc))²).

  (c) The lifetime measured by the stationary observer is:
    τ_lab = τ √(1+(eE t/(mc))²).

\text{(c)}\quad & \tau_{\text{lab}} = \tau\,\sqrt{1+\left(\frac{eEt}{mc}\right)^2}.

}

We wish to find the electric field in three regions and to “set up” (i.e. write as integrals) an expression for the potential of the inner sphere. In the problem we have two conductors: 

• A solid conducting sphere of radius r₁ carrying a charge +Q.  
• A surrounding “hollow” (i.e. shell) conductor with inner radius r₂ and outer radius r₃.  

Because conductors are equipotentials and because of Gauss’s law the induced charges on the surfaces of the outer shell will arrange themselves so that the field in the conductors is zero. (In particular, if the outer sphere is not given any extra charge – it is neutral in total – then it will acquire an induced charge –Q on its inner surface (at r = r₂) and +Q on its outer surface (at r = r₃).)

Below we use Gauss’s law to obtain the fields in the various regions.

────────────────────────────
Step 1. Find the Electric Field Using Gauss’s Law

Recall Gauss’s law in integral form:
  ∮ E · dA = Q_enc/ε₀.

We must consider three spatial regions.

(a) Field outside the outer sphere (r > r₃):

For a Gaussian sphere of radius r > r₃ (which encloses everything) the enclosed charge is
  Q_enc = Q (from the inner sphere) + (– Q on the inner surface of the shell) + (+ Q on the outer surface) = Q.
Thus, by symmetry,
  E( r ) · 4πr² = Q/ε₀  ⟹  E(r) = Q/(4πε₀ r²)   (directed radially outward).

────────────────────────────
(b) Field “between” the spheres.

Notice that there are two “between” regions to consider:
 (1) The cavity inside the outer conductor (i.e. r₁ < r < r₂) and 
 (2) The material of the conductor itself (r₂ < r < r₃).

Inside any conductor at electrostatic equilibrium the electric field is zero. Thus, for r₂ < r < r₃ we have:
  E = 0.

Now, for the cavity region (which is that region between the inner sphere and the inner surface of the shell, r₁ < r < r₂) choose a Gaussian sphere of radius r with r₁ < r < r₂. This Gaussian surface encloses only the inner sphere’s charge (its entire charge + Q); the induced charge on the inner surface of the outer sphere resides exactly at r = r₂ and is not enclosed when r < r₂. Therefore,
  ∮ E · dA = E(r) 4πr² = Q/ε₀  ⟹  E(r) = Q/(4πε₀ r²)   (radially outward).

So, the answers are:
  For r₁ < r < r₂ (the cavity): E = Q/(4πε₀ r²) (radial).
  For r₂ < r < r₃ (inside the conductor): E = 0.
  For r > r₃: E = Q/(4πε₀ r²).

────────────────────────────
(c) Setting up an Expression for the Potential of the Inner Sphere

We wish to write the potential of the inner sphere, V(r₁), as the line integral of the electric field taken (say) from infinity to r₁, with the convention V(∞) = 0. Because of the different regions where the expression for E is different, our integration must take into account these regions.

A convenient radial integration path goes:
 from r = ∞ to r = r₃ (outside the outer sphere), then 
 from r = r₃ to r = r₂ (through the outer conductor), and finally 
 from r = r₂ to r = r₁ (in the cavity between the spheres).

The potential difference is defined by
  V(b) – V(a) = – ∫ₐᵇ E · dr.
Since our path is radial and E is along the radial direction, the integrals become quite simple.

(i) Region 1: From r = ∞ to r = r₃.
 For r > r₃, we have E(r) = Q/(4πε₀ r²). Thus,
  V(r₃) – V(∞) = – ∫₍∞₎^(r₃) [Q/(4πε₀ r²)] dr
 Since V(∞)=0,
  V(r₃) = Q/(4πε₀) [1/r₃].

(ii) Region 2: Through the conductor from r = r₃ to r = r₂.
 In the conductor the field is zero so there is no potential drop:
  V(r₂) = V(r₃).

(iii) Region 3: From r = r₂ to r = r₁ (in the cavity).
 Here again, E(r) = Q/(4πε₀ r²). Thus,
  V(r₁) – V(r₂) = – ∫₍r₂₎^(r₁) [Q/(4πε₀ r²)] dr
        = Q/(4πε₀) [1/r₁ – 1/r₂].

Thus, the potential of the inner sphere is
  V(r₁) = V(r₃) + (V(r₁) – V(r₂))
      = (Q/(4πε₀) [1/r₃]) + (Q/(4πε₀)[1/r₁ – 1/r₂])
      = Q/(4πε₀) [1/r₁ – 1/r₂ + 1/r₃].

We do not have to evaluate the integrals further since they have been written in integral form.

────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) Outside the outer sphere (r > r₃):
  E(r) = Q/(4πε₀ r²)  (radially outward).

(b) Between the spheres, there are two cases:
  For the cavity, r₁ < r < r₂:
   E(r) = Q/(4πε₀ r²)  (radially outward);
  For the material of the outer conductor, r₂ < r < r₃:
   E(r) = 0.

(c) An expression for the potential of the inner sphere is given by

  V(r₁) = ∫₍∞₎^(r₃) (Q/(4πε₀ r²)) dr + ∫₍r₃₎^(r₂) (0) dr + ∫₍r₂₎^(r₁) (Q/(4πε₀ r²)) dr,
which simplifies to

  V(r₁) = Q/(4πε₀) [1/r₃ + (1/r₁ – 1/r₂)].

────────────────────────────
Final Answer in Latex

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad &E(r) = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_0\,r^2}\quad \text{for } r > r_3,\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad &
E(r) =
\begin{cases}
\frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_0\,r^2}, & r_1 < r < r_2,\\[1mm]
0, & r_2 < r < r_3,
\end{cases}\\[2mm]
\text{(c)}\quad &
V(r_1) = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\Bigl[\frac{1}{r_3} + \frac{1}{r_1} - \frac{1}{r_2}\Bigr].
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We wish to study what happens to the fields and charge/current when we “boost” from a frame in which the wire is neutral to one in which the currents and charges are seen moving at different speeds. In the “lab‐frame” (frame A) the infinitely long, perfectly conducting wire (of circular cross‐section of radius r) carries a steady current i but is electrically neutral. (All observers agree that the rest frame of the positive “lattice” has zero proper charge density and the conduction electrons, though moving at high speed U, are arranged with just the right density so that overall the wire is neutral.) An observer B, moving along the wire with speed v (along the z–axis, say) will, however, see a different mixture of electric and magnetic fields and a nonzero net charge density. One acceptable answer is obtained by “boosting” the A–fields. (Any answer equivalent to the one below is correct.)

Below we explain step‐by‐step.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Fields in A–

In frame A the wire is neutral so that, in our chosen units,
  E = 0,
and by Ampère’s law the magnetic field is the familiar one outside a long straight wire:
  B = (μ₀i)/(2πr) φ̂        (with φ̂ the azimuthal unit vector).

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. Lorentz transforming the fields

The standard formulas for a boost along the z–axis (with speed v) are (for fields perpendicular to the boost):

  E'⊥ = γ (E⊥ + v × B),
  B'⊥ = γ (B⊥ – (v/c²)× E).

Since E = 0 in A we immediately have
  E' = γ (v × B),
and
  B' = γ B
(there is no “parallel” component in our situation).

The velocity v points in the +z–direction. At a point at distance r (with cylindrical coordinates (r, φ, z)) the magnetic field in A is  
  B = (μ₀ i)/(2πr) φ̂.  
Now, using the right–hand rule in cylindrical coordinates the cross product is
  v × B = v ẑ × ( (μ₀ i)/(2πr) φ̂ ) = (μ₀ i v)/(2πr) (ẑ × φ̂).
One may show that ẑ × φ̂ = –r̂ so that 
  E' = –γ (μ₀ i v)/(2πr) r̂.       (1)

Likewise,
  B' = γ (μ₀ i)/(2πr) φ̂.         (2)

Thus, in the B–frame there appears an electric field directed radially (with a minus sign meaning “inward” if we define r̂ as the outward radial unit vector) along with a “boosted” magnetic field.

──────────────────────────────
Step 3. Finding the charge density implied by E′

In electrostatics a line charge density λ produces an electric field
  E(r) = λ/(2πε₀ r)  r̂.

Comparing with (1) we identify
  |E'| = γ (μ₀ i v)/(2πr) = |λ'|/(2πε₀ r).

Thus, equating the magnitudes,
  λ' = γ μ₀ ε₀ i v = γ (i v)/c²,
since μ₀ε₀ = 1/c². (Notice that here the sign is dictated by the direction of the field; since our E′ in (1) is inward, we have a negative line density for i > 0.) Hence, writing explicitly,
  λ' = –γ (i v)/c².

If one wishes, one may also speak of the volume charge density ρ′ by dividing by the cross–sectional area A of the wire:
  ρ' = λ'/A = –γ (i v)/(c² A).

──────────────────────────────
Step 4. Velocities of the ions and electrons as seen by B

In frame A we have
• Ions (the fixed “lattice”) are at rest.
• Electrons move (say) with speed U (to produce a current i). (For a positive current i flowing in the +z direction, the electrons must be moving in the –z direction; here we choose U as a positive number so that in A the electron velocity is uₑ = –U ẑ.)

Now, the velocity transformation along the z–axis is, for an object with velocity u in A,
  u' = (u – v)/(1 – uv/c²).

Thus,
(a) For the ions (u_i = 0) we obtain
  u'_i = (0 – v)/(1 – 0) = –v    (i.e. the ions move in the –z direction with speed v as seen by B).

(b) For the electrons (uₑ = –U) we have
  u'_e = (–U – v)/(1 + (Uv)/c²)  ,
so that in B the electrons are moving in the negative z–direction with speed
  |u'_e| = (U + v)/(1 + (Uv)/c²).

──────────────────────────────
Step 5. Interpretation

In A the wire is neutral (the positive ionic and negative electronic charge densities cancel exactly). But in B the two charge streams are moving with different speeds, and thus “experience” different Lorentz contractions. In particular the moving lattice (ions) is now moving with speed v (and is therefore Lorentz–contracted by the usual γ factor) whereas the electrons, having a different speed according to (4b), contract by a different factor. The difference in the two Lorentz factors produces a net charge density in B which is precisely that needed to give rise to the electric field (1) seen by B. (This is simply another manifestation of the “relativity of charge” and the unification of electric and magnetic fields.)

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

We now summarize our answers.

(a) In observer B’s frame the wire’s fields are
  E′(r) = –γ (μ₀ i v)/(2πr) r̂  and  B′(r) = γ (μ₀ i)/(2πr) φ̂.

(b) By comparing E′ with the field of a line charge one deduces that the net linear charge density is
  λ′ = –γ (i v)/c²  (or equivalently a volume density ρ′ = –γ (i v)/(c²A)).

(c) In B’s frame the ions (which are at rest in A) move with speed –v, while the electrons (which in A move with speed –U) have speed
  u′ₑ = (–U – v)/(1 + (Uv)/c²).

(d) The appearance of a net charge density in B (even though the wire is neutral in A) is due to relativistic length contraction – the electrons and ions are Lorentz contracted by different amounts in B’s frame.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer in LaTeX Boxed Format

\[
\boxed{
\begin{array}{rcl}
\textbf{(a)}\quad E'(r) &=& -\gamma\,\dfrac{\mu_0 i\,v}{2\pi\,r}\,\hat{r},\qquad
B'(r) \;=\; \gamma\,\dfrac{\mu_0 i}{2\pi\,r}\,\hat{\varphi}, \\[2mm]
\textbf{(b)}\quad \lambda' &=& -\gamma\,\dfrac{i\,v}{c^2}\quad\mbox{(so that } \rho' = -\gamma\,\dfrac{i\,v}{c^2A}\mbox{)}, \\[2mm]
\textbf{(c)}\quad u_i' &=& -v, \qquad 
u_e' \;=\; \dfrac{-U-v}{\,1+\dfrac{Uv}{c^2}\,}, \\[2mm]
\textbf{(d)}\quad \mbox{The net charge density in }B\mbox{'s frame arises because the ions and electrons,}\\[1mm]
&& \mbox{which were balanced (neutral) in }A\mbox{, are Lorentz–contracted by different amounts in }B\mbox{'s frame.}
\end{array}
}
\]

Any answer equivalent to the one above is correct.

We start by noting that the geometry is spherically symmetric, so the electric field has only a radial component. However, the twist is that the conductivity of the material between the spheres is not constant but depends on the local electric field according to

  σ = K E,

where K is a constant.

Step 1. Determine the local current density

In a region with a local electric field E(r), Ohm’s law (in its differential form) gives the current density as

  J(r) = σ E(r).

Substituting the given relation for σ, we obtain

  J(r) = (K E(r)) E(r) = K [E(r)]².

Step 2. Express the total current in radial geometry

Because of spherical symmetry, the total current I passing through a spherical shell of radius r is given by the current density multiplied by the area of the sphere:

  I = J(r) · 4πr².

Substitute the expression for J(r):

  I = 4πr² K [E(r)]²   (1)

Since I is constant (steady state), we can solve for E(r):

  [E(r)]² = I/(4πK r²)
  E(r) = √[I/(4πK)] / r.   (2)

Step 3. Relate the potential difference V to the electric field

The potential difference V between the inner sphere (radius a) and the outer sphere (inner radius b) is obtained by integrating the electric field from r = a to r = b:

  V = ∫[a to b] E(r) dr.

Substitute our expression (2) for E(r):

  V = ∫[a to b]  √[I/(4πK)] / r dr
  = √[I/(4πK)] ∫[a to b] (1/r) dr
  = √[I/(4πK)] ln(b/a).   (3)

Step 4. Solve for the current I

Solving equation (3) for √[I/(4πK)] gives:

  √[I/(4πK)] = V / ln(b/a).

Squaring both sides we get:

  I/(4πK) = [V / ln(b/a)]².

Thus,

  I = 4πK [V / ln(b/a)]²
  I = (4πK V²) / [ln(b/a)]².   (4)

Final Answer:

\[
\boxed{I = \frac{4\pi K V^2}{\left[\ln\left(\dfrac{b}{a}\right)\right]^2}}
\]

solution:
We wish to find the magnetic field required to keep an ultra‐relativistic electron (with energy E ≫ mc²) in a circular orbit of radius R, and then estimate the fractional energy loss per orbit when the electron radiates (synchrotron emission). (Any answer equivalent to the answer below is correct.)

In what follows we present one acceptable solution in SI units (with the final answers also given in Gauss for the magnetic field in part (a)). (One must be a bit careful since many texts on synchrotron radiation use Gaussian units; just be sure to use a self–consistent system.)

────────────────────────────
Step 1. (a) Finding the Required Field

An electron of (relativistic) momentum
  p = γ m v 
moves in a magnetic field B where the Lorentz force provides the required centripetal force. In SI one has

  e v B = p v/R        [since the magnetic force is perpendicular to v, and so gives the “centripetal force”]

But more directly the well–known “cyclotron radius” for a relativistic particle is

  R = p/(eB).

For ultra–relativistic motion we have v ≃ c and the total energy is E ≃ γ mc². Since (in any relativistic treatment) p = γ m v and here v ≃ c we have

  p ≃ E/c.

Thus the condition R = p/(eB) becomes

  R = (E/c)/(eB)
  ⇒ B = E/(e c R).

This is our analytical answer. (In SI units, E must be in Joules, e in Coulombs, c in m/s, and R in m. In SI the field comes out in Tesla; to convert to Gauss use 1 Tesla = 10⁴ Gauss.)

Now let us compute the number. We are given:
  R = 30 m,
  E = 2.5×10⁹ eV.

First, convert the energy to Joules. Since
  1 eV = 1.602×10⁻¹⁹ J,
we have
  E = 2.5×10⁹ eV ≃ 2.5×10⁹ × 1.602×10⁻¹⁹ J ≃ 4.005×10⁻¹⁰ J.

Next, use the following constants:
  e = 1.602×10⁻¹⁹ C,
  c = 3.00×10⁸ m/s.

Thus,
  B = E/(e c R)
    = (4.005×10⁻¹⁰ J) / [ (1.602×10⁻¹⁹ C)(3.00×10⁸ m/s)(30 m) ].

Let us compute the denominator:
  e c R = 1.602×10⁻¹⁹ × 3.00×10⁸ × 30 
       = 1.602×3.00×30 ×10^(–19+8) 
       = (1.602×90) ×10^(–11)
       ≃ 144.18×10⁻¹¹ = 1.4418×10⁻⁹ (in SI units).

Thus,
  B ≃ (4.005×10⁻¹⁰)/(1.4418×10⁻⁹) ≃ 0.2777 Tesla.

In Gauss, 
  B ≃ 0.2777 × 10⁴ Gauss ≃ 2777 Gauss.

────────────────────────────
Step 2. (b) Fractional Energy Loss per Revolution

Although we have assumed that the electron does not lose energy (so that its orbit is circular), in fact an accelerated charge radiates. (For synchrotron radiation one must use the relativistic Larmor–formula.) In Gaussian units (which are often most convenient for radiation problems) the instantaneous power radiated from a charge moving with acceleration perpendicular to its velocity is

  P = (2 e² γ⁴ a²)/(3 c³).

For circular motion the (magnitude of the) acceleration is

  a = v²/R ≃ c²/R  (for v ≃ c).

Thus
  P = (2 e² γ⁴ c⁴)/(3 c³ R²) = (2 e² γ⁴ c)/(3 R²).

Now, the time to complete one revolution is approximately

  T = 2πR/c.

So the energy loss per revolution is

  ΔE = P T = [(2 e² γ⁴ c)/(3 R²)] (2πR/c) = (4π e² γ⁴)/(3 R).

It is best to express this answer in a “dimensionless” form by dividing by the total energy E. Recall that for an ultra–relativistic electron,

  γ = E/(m c²).

Thus
  ΔE/E = (4π e² γ⁴)/(3 R E) = [ (4π e²)/(3 R) ] [E⁴/(m⁴ c⁸)] (1/E)
    = (4π e² E³)/(3 m⁴ c⁸ R).

This is the desired analytical expression.

It is common (and instructive) to rewrite the combination e²/(m c²) as the “classical electron radius” (in Gaussian units)

  r_e = e²/(m c²).

Then note that
  (e²/(m⁴ c⁸)) E³ = (e²/(m c²)) (E/(m c²))³ = r_e (E/(mc²))³.
Thus an equivalent answer is

  ΔE/E = (4π/3)(r_e/R) (E/(mc²))³.

Let us now evaluate this numerically. (We shall use the well–known value in SI for the classical electron radius as
  r_e ≃ 2.818×10⁻¹⁵ m,
but it is easier to use a standard synchrotron–radiation formula.)

Using:
  E = 2.5×10⁹ eV,
  mc² = 0.511×10⁶ eV    (so that γ = E/(mc²) ≃ 2.5×10⁹ / 0.511×10⁶ ≃ 4893),
  R = 30 m,
  r_e = 2.818×10⁻¹⁵ m,
we have

  ΔE/E = (4π/3) (r_e/R) (γ)³
    = (4π/3) (2.818×10⁻¹⁵/30) (4893³).

Now, 4893³ ≃ (4.893×10³)³. Compute
  (4.893×10³)³ = 4.893³×10⁹.
A quick calculation shows 4.893³ ≃ 117 (approximately).

Thus,
  γ³ ≃ 1.17×10¹¹.

Also,
  r_e/R = 2.818×10⁻¹⁵/30 ≃ 9.393×10⁻¹⁷.

Now,
  (4π/3) ≃ 4.18879.

Therefore,
  ΔE/E ≃ 4.18879 × (9.393×10⁻¹⁷) × (1.17×10¹¹)
      ≃ 4.18879 × (1.099×10⁻⁵)
      ≃ 4.60×10⁻⁵.

Thus, the fractional energy loss per revolution is about 4.6×10⁻⁵ (that is, about 0.005% of the particle’s energy per turn).

────────────────────────────
Final Answers

An acceptable answer is:

(a) The magnetic field needed is 
  B = E/(e c R).
Numerically, with E = 2.5×10⁹ eV and R = 30 m, one finds
  B ≃ 0.28 Tesla ≃ 2.8×10³ Gauss.

(b) If the energy loss per turn is small (ΔE ≪ E) the fractional energy loss is given by
  ΔE/E = (4π e² E³)/(3 m⁴ c⁸ R)
or equivalently,
  ΔE/E = (4π/3)(r_e/R)(E/(mc²))³,  with r_e = e²/(mc²).
Numerically, this gives
  ΔE/E ≃ 4.6×10⁻⁵ per revolution.

────────────────────────────

\[

\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad B &= \frac{E}{e\,c\,R}\quad\Longrightarrow\quad B\simeq 0.28\,\text{T}\simeq 2.8\times10^3\,\text{Gauss},\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad \frac{\Delta E}{E} &= \frac{4\pi\,e^2\,E^3}{3\,m^4 c^8\,R}
=\frac{4\pi}{3}\frac{r_e}{R}\Bigl(\frac{E}{mc^2}\Bigr)^3
\simeq 4.6\times10^{-5}\,.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We start with a parallel‐plate capacitor having area A = 0.2 m² and an initial separation d = 1 cm = 0.01 m. The capacitor is charged to an initial potential V₁ = 1000 V and then disconnected from the battery. Because it is isolated, the charge Q remains constant during any mechanical change, even though the capacitance will change.

Step 1. Find the Initial Capacitance (C₁)

The capacitance of a parallel‐plate capacitor is given by

  C = ε₀A/d

where ε₀ = 8.9 × 10⁻¹² C²/(N·m²).

Thus, the initial capacitance is

  C₁ = (8.9×10⁻¹²)(0.2) / 0.01 = (1.78×10⁻¹²) / 0.01 = 1.78×10⁻¹⁰ F.

Step 2. Determine the Initial Charge (Q)

Since the battery charges the capacitor to 1000 V, the initial charge is

  Q = C₁V₁ = (1.78×10⁻¹⁰ F)(1000 V) = 1.78×10⁻⁷ C.

Step 3. Change in the Capacitance When the Plate Separation is Doubled

When the plates are pulled apart so that the new separation is d₂ = 2d = 0.02 m, the new capacitance is

  C₂ = ε₀A/d₂ = (8.9×10⁻¹²)(0.2)/0.02 = C₁/2 = 1.78×10⁻¹⁰ /2 = 8.9×10⁻¹¹ F.

Step 4. Calculate the Energy Stored in the Capacitor Before and After

For an isolated capacitor (constant Q), the energy stored is

  E = Q²/(2C).

Initial energy:
  E₁ = Q²/(2C₁).

Final energy:
  E₂ = Q²/(2C₂).

Since C₂ = C₁/2, we see that

  E₂ = Q²/(2 (C₁/2)) = Q²/C₁ = 2 × (Q²/(2C₁)) = 2E₁.

Thus, the stored energy doubles. The extra energy is

  ΔE = E₂ – E₁ = E₁.

Now, let’s calculate E₁:

  E₁ = ½ C₁V₁²
    = 0.5 × (1.78×10⁻¹⁰ F) × (1000 V)²
    = 0.5 × (1.78×10⁻¹⁰) × 1×10⁶
    = 0.5 × 1.78×10⁻⁴
    = 8.9×10⁻⁵ J.

Thus, the work done (the extra energy required) is

  W = ΔE = 8.9×10⁻⁵ J.

Step 5. Find the Final Voltage (V₂)

Since the charge Q remains constant and the final capacitance is C₂, the final voltage is

  V₂ = Q/C₂.

We already found
  Q = C₁V₁, and C₂ = C₁/2.

Thus:

  V₂ = (C₁V₁)/(C₁/2) = 2V₁ = 2×1000 V = 2000 V.

Final Answer:

\[
\boxed{W \approx 8.9\times10^{-5}\,\text{J} \quad \text{and} \quad V_f \approx 2000\,\text{V}}
\]

We begin with a plane electromagnetic wave propagating in the x‑direction in vacuum. In our chosen gauge the scalar potential (ϕ) is identically zero so that the only nonzero potential is the vector potential A. Moreover, we are given that the vector potential is of the form

  A = A(x – ct)

with A = 0 sufficiently far away (so that any constants of integration may be fixed by the boundary conditions).

Below we work through the solution for parts (a) and (b) step by step.

────────────────────────────
Step 1. (a) Show that Aₓ = 0.

Recall that the Lorenz gauge condition, in the absence of the scalar potential (ϕ = 0), reduces to

  ∇·A = 0.

Now, since A is a function of the variable (x – ct) only, the derivatives with respect to y and z vanish and we have

  ∇·A = ∂Aₓ/∂x.

Thus the gauge condition becomes

  ∂Aₓ/∂x = 0.

This tells us that Aₓ can depend only on time; however, because A itself is a function only of (x – ct) (and not an independent function of time), it can only be a constant. In other words, Aₓ must be independent of both x and time. Now, applying the boundary condition that the vector potential goes to zero for sufficiently large values of (x – ct) (i.e. where the wave is not present), we conclude that the constant must be zero. Hence

  Aₓ = 0.

────────────────────────────
Step 2. (b) Show that p₍⊥₎ = –e A where p₍⊥₎ is the particle momentum in the y–z plane.

For a charged particle in an electromagnetic field, the relativistic Lagrangian (in units where c remains explicit) is given by

  L = –mc²√(1 – v²/c²) + e v · A.

The canonical momentum is obtained by differentiating the Lagrangian with respect to the velocity:

  p = ∂L/∂v = mγv + e A,

where γ = 1/√(1 - v²/c²).

Since the vector potential A has only transverse components (Aₓ = 0 as shown in part (a) and A = [0, A_y(x – ct), A_z(x – ct)]), the Lagrangian does not depend explicitly on the transverse coordinates y or z. This means that the transverse components of the canonical momentum are cyclic variables and their corresponding momenta are conserved. Denote the transverse canonical momentum by p₍⊥₎ = (p_y, p_z). Thus,

  d/dt (p_y) = 0 and d/dt (p_z) = 0.

By definition, the transverse canonical momenta are

  p_y = mγ v_y + e A_y,
  p_z = mγ v_z + e A_z.

Now, since the particle is initially at rest it follows that

  p_y(0) = 0 and A_y(0) = 0   (when the particle is far from the pulse)
  p_z(0) = 0 and A_z(0) = 0.

Thus, by the conservation of the canonical momentum, we have

  mγ v_y + e A_y = 0 ⟹ p_y = –e A_y,
  mγ v_z + e A_z = 0 ⟹ p_z = –e A_z.

In vector notation for the transverse components we then have

  p₍⊥₎ = –e A.

────────────────────────────
Final Answer

Thus, we have shown that

(a) Aₓ = 0,

and

(b) p₍⊥₎ = –e A.

Expressed in the final boxed answer we have

  \[\boxed{A_{x}=0 \quad \text{and} \quad \mathbf{p}_{\perp}=-e\,\mathbf{A}}\]

We wish to find the electric field both inside and outside a dielectric sphere of radius R and dielectric constant ε when it is placed in a uniform external field E₀ directed along the z‐axis. (We assume the surrounding medium is free space with dielectric constant ε₀.) Because there are no free charges in the problem, the electric potential φ satisfies Laplace’s equation. Moreover, from the symmetry of the problem the potential (in spherical coordinates) will depend on r and the polar angle θ (measured from the z‐axis) only.

Step 1. Write the general solution

For problems with axial symmetry the general solution of Laplace’s equation in spherical coordinates (with no φ-dependence) is
  φ(r,θ) = Σ (Aₗ rˡ + Bₗ r^(–(l+1))) Pₗ(cosθ)
For our problem only the l = 1 term is needed. Thus we write

• Outside (r > R): 
  φ_out(r,θ) = –E₀ r cosθ + (B cosθ)/r².
Here the term –E₀r cosθ corresponds to the applied uniform field (with φ → −E₀z where z = r cosθ) and the second term represents the field produced by the polarization of the sphere.
 
• Inside (r < R):
  φ_in(r,θ) = –A r cosθ.
There is no singular (1/r^2) term within the sphere since the potential must remain finite at r = 0.

Step 2. Apply Boundary Conditions at r = R

We must require that:
 (a) The potential is continuous:
  φ_in(R,θ) = φ_out(R,θ)
 (b) The radial component of the displacement field D = ε₀E (outside) and D = εε₀E (inside) is continuous across the boundary:
  εε₀ E_r^(in)(R,θ) = ε₀ E_r^(out)(R,θ).

Let’s determine the radial field components (recall that E = –∇φ).

First, find the derivatives:

For φ_in = –A r cosθ,
  ∂φ_in/∂r = –A cosθ,
so that
  E_r^(in) = –∂φ_in/∂r = A cosθ.

For φ_out = –E₀ r cosθ + (B cosθ)/r²,
we have
  ∂φ_out/∂r = –E₀ cosθ – (–2B cosθ)/r³ = –E₀ cosθ – 2B cosθ/r³.
Thus,
  E_r^(out) = –∂φ_out/∂r = E₀ cosθ + 2B cosθ/r³.
At r = R, this becomes
  E_r^(out)(R,θ) = E₀ cosθ + (2B cosθ)/R³.

Now apply the boundary conditions:

(a) Continuity of potential at r = R:
  –A R cosθ = –E₀ R cosθ + (B cosθ)/R².
Divide by cosθ (which is valid for all θ ≠ π/2, and the result must hold for all θ):
  –A R = –E₀ R + (B)/R²  →  B = R³(E₀ – A).

(b) Continuity of the normal (radial) component of the displacement field:
Inside, D_r^(in) = εε₀ E_r^(in) = εε₀ A cosθ.
Outside, D_r^(out) = ε₀ E_r^(out) = ε₀ [E₀ cosθ + 2B cosθ/R³].
Setting these equal (and canceling ε₀ cosθ) gives:
  ε A = E₀ + (2B)/R³.
But from above, B = R³ (E₀ – A). Substituting,
  ε A = E₀ + 2(E₀ – A)
     = 3E₀ – 2A.
Bringing like terms together,
  A (ε + 2) = 3E₀  →  A = 3E₀/(ε + 2).

Then from the previous relation,
  B = R³ (E₀ – A) = R³[E₀ – 3E₀/(ε + 2)]
     = R³E₀[( (ε+2) – 3)/(ε+2)] = R³E₀ (ε – 1)/(ε+2).

Step 3. Write the final potentials and fields

Thus, the potential inside the sphere is
  φ_in = –(3E₀/(ε+2)) r cosθ,
and the electric field inside (by taking E = –∇φ) is uniform:
  E_in = (3E₀/(ε+2)) ẑ.
It is interesting to note that the magnitude of the field is reduced (or enhanced) by the factor 3/(ε+2) relative to the applied field, depending on the value of ε.

Outside the sphere the potential is
  φ_out = –E₀ r cosθ + [R³E₀ (ε–1)/(ε+2)] (cosθ/r²).
Thus the external electric field is the superposition of the applied uniform field and the field of an induced dipole. In fact, the induced dipole moment may be identified with
  p = 4πε₀ R³ [ (ε–1)/(ε+2)] E₀.
Then one may write the additional dipole potential as
  φ_dip(r,θ) = (1/(4πε₀)) (p·r)/(r³),
which is equivalent, after some slight algebra, to the term we obtained.

So, summarizing the results:

• Inside the sphere (r < R):
  φ_in = –(3E₀/(ε+2)) r cosθ  and  E_in = (3E₀/(ε+2)) ẑ.

• Outside the sphere (r > R):
  φ_out = –E₀ r cosθ + [R³E₀ (ε–1)/(ε+2)] cosθ/r²,
and so the electric field is given by
  E_out = –∇φ_out,
or, equivalently, one may write
  E_out = E₀ ẑ + (E₀ R³(ε–1)/(ε+2)) [ (3 cosθ (r̂)/r³ – ẑ/r³) ].

It is common to recognize that the induced dipole moment is
  p = 4πε₀ R³ [ (ε–1)/(ε+2)] E₀,
so the external field can be seen as the sum of the applied uniform field and the dipole field.

Final Answer in LaTeX boxed form:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{For } r<R:&\\[1mm]
\phi_{\rm in}(r,\theta)&=-\frac{3E_0}{\varepsilon+2}\,r\cos\theta,\\[1mm]
\vec{E}_{\rm in}&=-\nabla\phi_{\rm in}=\frac{3E_0}{\varepsilon+2}\,\hat{z}.
\end{aligned}
\quad
\begin{aligned}
\text{For } r>R:&\\[1mm]
\phi_{\rm out}(r,\theta)&=-E_0r\cos\theta+\frac{E_0R^3(\varepsilon-1)}{(\varepsilon+2)}\frac{\cos\theta}{r^2},\\[1mm]
\vec{E}_{\rm out}&=-\nabla\phi_{\rm out}
=E_0\hat{z}+\frac{E_0R^3(\varepsilon-1)}{(\varepsilon+2)}\frac{1}{r^3}\Bigl(3\cos\theta\,\hat{r}-\hat{z}\Bigr).
\end{aligned}
}
\]

Any answer equivalent to the one above is correct.

We start by noting that when a dielectric sphere (with dielectric constant ε) is placed in a uniform electric field E₀ (taken to be along the z‐axis), it becomes polarized. One may show (by solving Laplace’s equation with the appropriate boundary conditions at the surface of the sphere) that the polarization produces an induced surface charge given by

  σ(θ) = [(ε – ε₀)/(ε + 2ε₀)]·3ε₀E₀ cos θ,  (1)

where θ is the polar angle measured from the direction of E₀.

Let us now consider what happens when the sphere is rotated at an angular velocity ω about the z‐axis (i.e. the direction of E₀). One might worry that by moving the charges on the surface one is creating a “current” and hence a magnetic field. (In many situations a rotating charged body yields a magnetic dipole moment!) However, the situation here is more subtle.

Step 1. The surface charge distribution in (1) is static in the body of the sphere; it is “frozen in” by the polarization and is in one‐to‐one correspondence with the direction of the applied E₀. Because σ(θ) depends only on the polar angle θ and not on the azimuthal angle φ, the charge distribution is axially symmetric about the z‑axis.

Step 2. When the sphere is rotated about the z‑axis, each point on the sphere (and hence the bound charge at that point) is moving. One might compute a surface current density

  K(θ) = σ(θ) v = σ(θ) (ωR sin θ)  (2)

which flows in the φ‑direction. (Here v is the speed of the surface charge at radius R and polar angle θ.) Although there is local motion of charges (and thus a current), the key point is that the overall pattern of σ(θ) remains fixed in the laboratory frame because the rotation is about the symmetry axis. The surface charge pattern, being proportional to cos θ, is independent of φ. Thus every “ring” of current at a fixed θ is exactly balanced by its counterpart 180° away in θ. In fact, if one computes the net magnetic dipole moment m from the surface currents by the formula

  m = ½ ∮ (r × K) dA,
  
one finds, after an integration over the sphere, that the contributions symmetrically cancel, yielding a zero net magnetic moment.

Step 3. It turns out that although there are circulating bound currents, the symmetry of the problem guarantees that no net magnetic field is produced. (One way to see this is to note that the rotating sphere still has an electric dipole moment which does not change in time. It is, in this sense, “stationary,” and no steady magnetic field appears from a static dipole.) In other words, the distribution of currents is such that when one calculates the magnetic field (for example, the field far from the sphere), everything cancels out.

Thus, even though the surface charges are in motion, no net magnetic field is generated by rotating the sphere around the direction of E₀.

Final Answer: 
 – The induced surface charge density is
  σ(θ) = [(ε – ε₀)/(ε + 2ε₀)]·3ε₀E₀ cos θ.
 – When the sphere is rotated about the E₀ direction the moving charges produce an axially symmetric current pattern (with no azimuthal variation), so that all contributions to a net magnetic field cancel. Therefore, no magnetic field is produced.

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\sigma(\theta) &= \frac{\varepsilon - \varepsilon_0}{\varepsilon + 2 \varepsilon_0} 3\varepsilon_0 E_0 \cos\theta,\\[1mm]
\text{and no magnetic field is produced upon rotation about the } &E_0\text{ direction.}
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We begin by noting that the usual Coulomb potential

  V_Coulomb = (q₁q₂)/r

satisfies Poisson’s equation

  ∇²φ = –4πρ        (in cgs units)

when φ is the electric potential due to charge density ρ.

If instead the potential between two point charges is given by

  V_Yukawa = (q₁q₂ e^(–Kr))/r

this is the familiar Yukawa potential which arises in theories with a finite-range (or massive mediator) interaction. In such cases the potential does not satisfy the usual Poisson’s equation. Instead, one finds it satisfies a modified equation, often written as

  (∇² – K²)φ = –4πρ.

Let’s explain this result step by step:

1. For a point charge, in the Coulomb case the Green’s function is proportional to 1/r, which is the solution to ∇²(1/r) = –4πδ(r).

2. When the potential is given by exp(–Kr)/r, you can show (by direct computation or using properties of Yukawa-type functions) that the corresponding Green's function satisfies

  (∇² – K²)(e^(–Kr)/r) = –4πδ(r).

Thus if we take this function as the potential due to a point source, the generalized equation becomes

  (∇² – K²)φ = –4πρ.

This replacement of Poisson’s equation with the Helmholtz equation (also called the “screened Poisson equation”) is the theoretical basis for our new potential.

Now, how might we test for a nonvanishing K experimentally? The idea is to design a null experiment whereby the classical Coulomb (unscreened) electric field is expected to vanish, but if K ≠ 0 (even if very small), the modifications would lead to a small nonzero field.

Conceptual Experimental Design:

Consider a symmetric configuration such as a charged spherical shell. In classical electrostatics (with K = 0) the electric field inside a hollow conductor is zero – this is the well-known result of Gauss’s law and the shell theorem.

The Theoretical Basis:
 • In the standard case, a spherical shell of charge produces no electric field in its interior.
 • However, when the potential takes the Yukawa form, the field inside is no longer guaranteed to vanish since the “screening” coming from the term –K²φ breaks the exact cancellation. Mathematically, the solution of (∇² – K²)φ = 0 inside the shell is not just a constant but may involve spatial variations depending on the boundary conditions.
 • Thus, by measuring the electric field (or potential gradient) inside a precisely manufactured spherical shell charged to a known value, one can search for deviations from zero.

The Null Experiment:
 1. Prepare a spherical conducting shell and charge it uniformly.
 2. Using an extremely sensitive electrometer or potential probe, measure the electric field or potential gradient at various points inside the shell.
 3. In the absence of a Yukawa modification (K = 0), the measured field should be exactly zero. Any nonzero residual measured field would indicate a deviation from standard Coulomb behavior, hinting at a nonvanishing K.

Thus, if one observes a slight but measurable field inside the shell, this would be evidence for the modified potential and imply that (∇² – K²)φ = –4πρ is the correct governing equation.

Final Answer:

 The replacement for Poisson’s equation is
  (∇² – K²)φ = –4πρ,
and one suitable null experiment is to measure the electric field inside a uniformly charged spherical shell – any deviation from zero indicates a nonvanishing K.

\[
\boxed{(\nabla^2 - K^2)\phi = -4\pi\rho \quad \text{with a null experiment based on measuring deviations from zero field inside a charged spherical shell.}}
\]

We start by considering the effect of inserting a dielectric into a charged, isolated capacitor. The capacitor is isolated, which means that the charge Q on the plates remains constant when the dielectric is partially inserted.

Step 1: Energy stored in a capacitor  
The energy stored in a capacitor is given by  
  U = Q²/(2C),  
where C is the capacitance.

Step 2: Effect of inserting a dielectric  
A dielectric increases the capacitance. When a dielectric (with dielectric constant κ > 1) is inserted, the effective capacitance of the capacitor increases as more of the dielectric fills the gap between the plates.

Step 3: Energy change due to dielectric insertion  
Since Q is constant, an increase in capacitance C results in a decrease in stored energy U. In other words, inserting the dielectric lowers the system’s energy:
  dC/dx > 0  ⇒  dU/dx = -Q²/(2C²) (dC/dx) < 0.
This decrease in energy means that the system is driven to pull the dielectric further in to lower its energy even more.

Step 4: Force on the dielectric  
The force on the dielectric is given by  
  F = -dU/dx.  
Since dU/dx is negative (energy decreases as more dielectric is inserted), F becomes positive, indicating that the force is directed so as to pull the dielectric further into the capacitor.

Final Answer:  
The dielectric is pulled into the capacitor.

We wish to analyze the Compton scattering process where a photon with energy E (and momentum p = E/c) collides with an electron at rest (mass m_e) and is scattered. We will now write down the conservation laws and then analyze the special case of 180° (back‐scattering).

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Conservation Equations

(a) Conservation of Energy:

Before collision the energy is the photon energy plus the electron’s rest energy:
  E + m_ec²

After collision the energies are the scattered photon energy E′ and the electron’s energy, which (since the electron recoils) is given by the relativistic expression:
  E′ + √[(p_e c)² + (m_ec²)²]
Thus,
  E + m_ec² = E′ + √[(p_e c)² + (m_ec²)²].  (1)

(b) Conservation of Momentum:

It is simplest to choose the x–axis along the initial photon direction. Initially, the photon (of momentum E/c) is moving along x, while the electron is at rest. After scattering, suppose the photon is scattered at an angle θ relative to the x–axis, with momentum E′/c, and the electron recoils with momentum p_e at an angle φ.

Thus, the momentum components satisfy:

  In the x–direction:
   E/c = (E′/c) cosθ + p_e cosφ  (2)

  In the y–direction:
   0 = (E′/c) sinθ – p_e sinφ  (3)

These two equations represent the vector conservation of momentum.

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. Case of 180° Back-Scattering

For back–scattering, the photon is scattered exactly backward so that θ = 180°. Here, cos(180°) = –1 and sin(180°) = 0. While the algebra from Eqs. (1–3) can be carried out in full generality, it is standard to introduce the Compton wavelength shift formula. (Though the derivation uses the above conservation laws, the final formula is well known.) 

For Compton scattering the wavelength shift is given by:
  Δλ = λ′ – λ = (h/(m_ec)) (1 – cosθ).

Since the energy of a photon is related to its wavelength by E = hc/λ, one may show that this shift can be recast in the energy form:
  1/E′ – 1/E = (1 – cosθ)/(m_ec²).

For θ = 180° we have 1 – cosθ = 1 – (–1) = 2, so that
  1/E′ – 1/E = 2/(m_ec²).

Solve for E′:
  1/E′ = 1/E + 2/(m_ec²),
  E′ = E / [1 + (2E/(m_ec²))].  (4)

This result tells us that the energy of the scattered photon in the back–scattering case is reduced relative to the incident photon energy by the factor in the denominator. Note that the assumption that the recoiling electron is moving “approximately at the speed of light” would arise if E ≫ m_ec². In that limit, the final photon energy becomes much smaller, consistent with a very energetic electron.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

(a) The conservation laws are

  Energy:
   E + m_ec² = E′ + √[(p_e c)² + (m_ec²)²].

  Momentum (choosing the x–axis along the initial photon direction):
   x–component: E/c = (E′/c) cosθ + p_e cosφ,
   y–component: 0 = (E′/c) sinθ – p_e sinφ.

(b) For 180° back–scattering (θ = 180°) the scattered photon’s energy is
  E′ = E / [1 + 2E/(m_ec²)].

Thus, our final result is:
        
  \[\boxed{E'=\frac{E}{1+\frac{2E}{m_ec^2}}}\]

We wish to find the frequency of the reflected wave in the laboratory frame when the medium (and hence its surface) is moving with speed v along the positive z‑axis. The incident wave has its electric field given (in the lab frame) as

  Eₓ(z, t) = Re{ Eₓ⁰ exp[i(kz – ω t)] }    (1)

with k = ω/c (since the wave in free space obeys the dispersion relation ω = c k).

Because the surface is moving, we must take into account the Doppler effect during reflection. One standard way to analyze the problem is to Lorentz transform to the rest frame of the moving surface, compute the reflection (which, for a good “mirror”, does not change the frequency in the mirror’s frame), and then transform back to the lab frame. Let us outline the necessary steps.

Step 1. Transform the incident wave to the rest frame of the medium.

In the lab frame the wave four‐vector is
  (k^μ) = (ω/c, 0, 0, k),
with k = ω/c (since z is the direction of propagation). The Lorentz transformation (for a boost along the z‑axis with β = v/c and γ = 1/√(1 – β²)) gives the frequency in the rest frame of the moving surface as

  ω′ = γ (ω – v k).

Since k = ω/c we obtain

  ω′ = γ ω (1 – v/c) = ω γ (1 – β).    (2)

Step 2. Reflection in the rest frame of the surface.

In the rest frame, when the wave reflects off the mirror-like surface, the frequency remains the same (i.e. ω′ is unchanged) but the wave vector reverses direction. Specifically, the reflected wave in the mirror frame has four-wave vector

  (k′₍r₎)^μ = (ω′/c, 0, 0, -ω′/c).

Step 3. Transform the reflected wave back to the lab frame.

We now Lorentz transform back to the lab (stationary) frame. Under a Lorentz boost along the z‑axis, the frequency transforms as

  ω_r = γ (ω′ + v k′_z).

For the reflected wave, k′_z = –ω′/c. Hence

  ω_r = γ (ω′ – v (ω′/c)) = γ ω′ (1 – v/c) = ω′ γ (1 – β).    (3)

Now substitute ω′ from (2):

  ω_r = [ω γ (1 – β)] [γ (1 – β)] = ω γ² (1 – β)².

Recall that γ² = 1/(1 – β²); hence

  ω_r = ω (1 – β)²/(1 – β²).

We can simplify this expression using

  1 – β² = (1 – β)(1 + β).

Thus

  ω_r = ω (1 – β)²/[(1 – β)(1 + β)] = ω (1 – β)/(1 + β).   (4)

Thus the frequency of the reflected wave, as seen by the stationary observer, is

  ω_r = ω (1 – v/c)/(1 + v/c).

Remarks:
• If v = 0 then ω_r = ω, as one would expect.
• For v ≪ c, the frequency shift to first order is ω_r ≈ ω (1 – 2v/c).

The index of refraction n of the medium does not affect this Doppler shift because the reflection occurs at the surface and the transformation is dictated solely by the speed of the moving boundary relative to the observer.

Final Answer:

\[
\boxed{\omega_{\text{reflected}} = \omega\,\frac{1-\frac{v}{c}}{1+\frac{v}{c}}}
\]

solution:
We wish to study an infinitely long cylinder of radius R whose material is “permanently polarized” so that the polarization at every point is

  P = a r⃗    (1)

with a > 0 and where r⃗ is the two‐dimensional “radial” vector in the (x,y) plane. (We shall always take the axis of the cylinder to be the z‑axis.) In addition the cylinder is set into rotation about its axis with angular velocity

  ω,    (2)

assumed “non‐relativistic” (so that ωR ≪ c). In what follows we find, step by step, the electric field E, the magnetic field B, and the net electromagnetic energy per unit length before and after spinning.

───────────────────────────── 
Step 1. The Electric Field 
───────────────────────────── 
A permanent polarization produces bound charges. In any polarized dielectric one defines

  ρ_b = –∇·P   and  σ_b = P·n⃗   (3)

where n⃗ is the outward normal on the surface.

Since (in cylindrical coordinates) the polarization is 
  P = a r 𝑟̂   (4)
(with P only in the r‑direction) the divergence is
  ∇·P = (1/r)∂(rP_r)/∂r = (1/r) d/dr (a r^2) = 2a,  (5)
so that
  ρ_b = –2a     (for r < R).  (6)

At the curved (side) surface (r = R) the outward unit normal is n⃗ = r̂ so that
  σ_b = P(R)·r̂ = aR.   (7)

Because the cylinder is infinitely long there are no “end‐caps” and no other charges appear.

Now, by symmetry the E–field must be radial and depend only on r. One may apply Gauss’s law for the electric field:
  ∮E·dA = (1/ε₀)Q_enc.  (8)

• For r < R choose a cylindrical Gaussian surface of radius r and length L. The enclosed charge is
  Q_enc = ρ_b (area) = (–2a)(π r² L),
so that
  E(r) (2π r L) = (–2a π r² L)/ε₀  ⟹  
  E(r) = –(a r/ε₀).  (9)
Thus, inside the cylinder the electric field is
  E = –(a/ε₀) r 𝑟̂   for r < R.

• For r > R the Gaussian surface encloses both the entire volume charge (–2a over the circular cross–section of area πR²) and the surface charge along r = R (with total charge σ_b·(surface area) = aR · (2πR L) = 2πaR²L). Hence
  Q_enc = (–2a πR² L) + (2πaR² L) = 0.
Thus,
  E = 0   for r > R.

───────────────────────────── 
Step 2. The Magnetic Field 
───────────────────────────── 
When the cylinder rotates, every charged “bit” of the dielectric moves with the local velocity

  v = ω × r⃗.  (10)

Since the cylinder rotates about z, a point at position (r,φ) (with r < R) has velocity
  v = ω r 𝜙̂.  (11)

Thus both the volume and surface bound charges are moving. (They remain “bound” to the material, but in motion they create currents.) In our non‐relativistic treatment we assume the moving charge “simply” produces a current density given by

  J = ρ_b v,   in the bulk (r < R),
  K = σ_b v,   on the surface (r = R).  (12)

So we obtain:

• For r < R (volume current)
  J(r) = (–2a) [ωr 𝜙̂] = –2a ω r 𝜙̂.

• On the surface (r = R)
  K = σ_b v = (aR)[ωR 𝜙̂] = a ω R² 𝜙̂.

The net effect of these circulating currents is to “build up” a magnetic dipole moment. (Although there is no free “magnetization” given at the outset, the motion of bound charges is equivalent to a magnetization M_eff.) One common method is to compute the magnetic moment per unit length. In general one may write

  (magnetic moment)_z per unit length = (1/2)∫(r (J_φ)) dA  (13)

where the integration is over the cross–section. (The “z”–component is picked out by the vector product.) Let us calculate the contributions.

(a) Volume contribution: In cylindrical coordinates the infinitesimal area element is dA = 2πr dr, so
  m_z^(vol) = (1/2)∫_0^R r [J_φ(r)] (2πr dr).
Here J_φ(r) = –2a ω r so that
  m_z^(vol) = (1/2)∫_0^R r [–2a ω r] (2π r dr)
      = –2πaω ∫_0^R r³ dr
      = –2πaω (R⁴/4) = –(π a ω R⁴)/2.  (14)

(b) Surface contribution: The magnetic moment per unit length from a surface current flowing around a loop is given by
  m_z^(surf) = (1/2) R [K] (circumference),
i.e.,
  m_z^(surf) = (1/2) R (a ω R²) (2πR) = π a ω R⁴.  (15)

Thus the total magnetic moment per unit length is
  m_z = m_z^(vol) + m_z^(surf) = –(πaω R⁴)/2 + (πaω R⁴) = (πaω R⁴)/2.  (16)

It is often useful to express the net effect as that of a uniform “effective magnetization” given by
  M_eff = m_z / (area) = [(πaωR⁴)/2] / (π R²) = (aωR²)/2.  (17)

For an infinitely long cylinder uniformly magnetized along its (z)–axis, the magnetostatics is well known. (In fact, the demagnetizing factor along the z–axis is zero when the cylinder is infinite.) Thus one immediately concludes that the magnetic induction in the interior is given by

  B = μ₀ M_eff = (μ₀ a ω R²)/2   (in the z–direction)
or
  B = (μ₀ a ω R²/2) ẑ   for r < R.

Furthermore, it is a standard result that for a uniformly magnetized infinite cylinder the stray (dipolar) fields vanish outside (since the only “magnetic charges” would reside on the ends, which here are sent to infinity). Hence we take

  B = 0   for r > R.

───────────────────────────── 
Step 3. The Energy Stored in the Fields 
───────────────────────────── 
The electromagnetic energy per unit volume in the fields is (in SI units)

  u_E = (ε₀/2)E²,  and   u_B = B²/(2μ₀).  (18)

(i) Before the cylinder is spun the magnetic field is zero so only the (electric) energy stored in E matters. We found that only the region r < R has a nonzero field:
  E = –(a/ε₀) r   (so that |E| = a r/ε₀).
Thus the electric energy per unit length is
  Uₑ = ∫_0^R (ε₀/2) (a²r²/ε₀²) (2πr dr)
      = (a²/(2ε₀)) (2π) ∫_0^R r³ dr
      = (πa²/(ε₀)) (R⁴/4)
      = (π a² R⁴)/(4 ε₀).  (19)

(ii) When the cylinder is spinning the fields are the superposition of the unaltered electric field (since in the non‐relativistic limit the static polarization gives the same E‐field) and the new magnetic field which is nonzero inside. (There is no magnetic field outside.) We already found that
  B = (μ₀aω R²)/2 ẑ for r < R.
Thus the magnetic energy density is

  u_B = B²/(2μ₀) = [μ₀²a²ω²R⁴/(4)]/(2μ₀) = (μ₀ a² ω² R⁴)/(8).
Since B is uniform in the interior the magnetic energy per unit length is

  U_B = (μ₀ a² ω² R⁴)/(8) × (area) with area = πR²,
so that
  U_B = (π μ₀ a² ω² R⁶)/(8).  (20)

Thus the total field energy per unit length when spinning is

  U_total = Uₑ + U_B = (π a² R⁴)/(4 ε₀) + (π μ₀ a² ω² R⁶)/(8).

Finally, one may ask: where did the extra energy come from? In short, when one spins up the cylinder an external “torque” must do work to overcome the electromagnetic “back‐reaction” (the extra magnetic energy stored in the process). That extra energy appears in the new B–field.

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answers 
───────────────────────────── 
We now summarize our results.

(a) The electric field is
  for r < R:  E = –(a r/ε₀)𝑟̂,
  for r > R:  E = 0.

(b) The magnetic field (due to the moving bound charges) is
  for r < R:  B = (μ₀ a ω R²/2) ẑ,
  for r > R:  B = 0.

(c) The electromagnetic energy per unit length is

  (i) Before spinning (only the E–field):
    Uₑ = (π a² R⁴)/(4ε₀).

  (ii) While spinning (electric plus magnetic energies):
    U_total = (π a² R⁴)/(4ε₀) + (π μ₀ a² ω² R⁶)/(8).

The extra energy in (ii) comes from the work done by the external agent (the applied torque) in setting the cylinder into rotation.

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answer in LaTeX Boxed Form
───────────────────────────── 

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad & E(r)=\begin{cases}
-\dfrac{a}{\epsilon_0}\,r\,\hat{r}, & r<R,\\[1mm]
0, & r>R,
\end{cases}\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad & B(r)=\begin{cases}
\dfrac{\mu_0\,a\,\omega R^2}{2}\,\hat{z}, & r<R,\\[1mm]
0, & r>R,
\end{cases}\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}\quad & \text{(i) } U_E=\dfrac{\pi a^2 R^4}{4\epsilon_0},\\[1mm]
& \text{(ii) } U_{\rm total}=\dfrac{\pi a^2 R^4}{4\epsilon_0}+\dfrac{\pi\mu_0\,a^2\omega^2R^6}{8}.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

Any answer equivalent to the one above is correct.

We wish to know the “pull‐apart” force between the two halves when a charged conducting sphere (of radius R and total charge Q) is “cut” into two hemispheres. (In practice the two halves repel one another, and an external force of equal magnitude is needed to keep them together.) One standard way to attack this problem is through the concept of electrostatic pressure (or “tension”) on a charged surface.

Step 1. Electrostatic pressure on a conductor

For a charged conductor the electric field just outside is perpendicular to the surface and has magnitude

  E = σ/ε₀

where σ is the surface charge density. (Inside a conductor E = 0.) However, one must be a little careful in computing the force on a “piece” of the conductor. In fact, one may show that the net force per unit area (or pressure) that the other charges exert on a given patch is

  P = σ²/(4ε₀).

One way to understand this is the following:
 • If one considered the field produced by an infinite charged plane (with surface charge σ) one would get E = σ/(2ε₀) on either side.
 • For a small patch of a conductor the field produced by all of the other charges is then the average of the field “just outside” (i.e. half of σ/ε₀) so that effectively the field acting on the charges on the patch is E_ext = σ/(2ε₀).
 • The force per unit area on that patch is then (½)(σE_ext) = σ²/(4ε₀). (The factor ½ is needed because a charged element does not act on itself.)

Step 2. Apply to the flat “cut‐face”

When the sphere is intact the charge Q is spread uniformly over its outer surface. For a sphere the total area is 4πR² so that
  σ = Q/(4πR²).

When the sphere is “cut” into hemispheres the two halves (if they were simply separated, with the same charge distribution as before) would “pull” on one another. It turns out that the net repulsive force between the two halves comes solely from the interaction across the flat, circular cut. (The curved surfaces—with their charge distribution—are self-contained.)

We now consider that flat circular face (of radius R, area A = πR²). Using the pressure we found earlier, the force is given by

  F = (pressure) × (area) = (σ²/(4ε₀)) × (πR²).

Step 3. Substitute σ

Substitute σ = Q/(4πR²) into the above expression:

  F = [1/(4ε₀)] · (Q²/(16π²R⁴)) · (πR²)
     = Q²/(64π ε₀ R²).

Thus, the force necessary to hold the two halves together is

  F = Q²/(64π ε₀ R²).

Step 4. Final Answer in boxed LaTeX

We now write the final answer in boxed LaTeX as requested:

  \[
  \boxed{\frac{Q^2}{64\pi\epsilon_0 R^2}}
  \]

This is the required force that must be applied to counteract the electrostatic repulsion between the two hemispheres of the sphere.

We start by writing the relation between the potential difference V and the charge per unit length λ for an air‐spaced coaxial cable. For radii a (inner conductor) and b (outer conductor), Gauss’s law gives the electric field

  E(r) = λ/(2πϵ₀r)  for a < r < b.

Integrating the electric field from r = a to r = b yields the potential difference

  V = ∫ₐᵇ (λ/(2πϵ₀r)) dr = (λ/(2πϵ₀)) ln(b/a).

Thus, the charge per unit length is

  λ = (2πϵ₀V) / ln(b/a).

(a) Calculating the Charge per Meter

The given dimensions are:
  Inner conductor diameter = 0.5 cm → a = 0.25 cm = 0.0025 m,
  Outer conductor diameter = 1.5 cm → b = 0.75 cm = 0.0075 m,
  V = 8000 V,
  ϵ₀ = 8.854 × 10⁻¹² F/m.

The ratio of the radii is

  b/a = 0.0075/0.0025 = 3  and  ln(b/a) = ln 3 ≈ 1.0986.

Now substitute into the formula:

  λ = (2π × 8.854×10⁻¹² F/m × 8000 V) / 1.0986.

First, compute the numerator:

  2π×8.854×10⁻¹² ≈ 2 × 3.1416 × 8.854×10⁻¹² ≈ 5.56×10⁻¹¹,
  Multiplying by 8000 V: 5.56×10⁻¹¹ × 8000 ≈ 4.448×10⁻⁷ C/m.

Then, dividing by ln3:

  λ ≈ (4.448×10⁻⁷ C/m) / 1.0986 ≈ 4.05×10⁻⁷ C/m.

(b) Calculating the Electric Field at r = 1 cm

We use the expression for the electric field in the region a < r < b:

  E(r) = λ/(2πϵ₀r).

Substitute r = 1 cm = 0.01 m and the computed λ:

  E(1 cm) = (4.05×10⁻⁷ C/m) / (2π×8.854×10⁻¹² F/m × 0.01 m).

Compute the denominator:

  2π×8.854×10⁻¹² × 0.01 = 6.2832 × 8.854×10⁻¹² × 0.01 ≈ 5.557×10⁻¹³.

Thus,

  E(1 cm) ≈ (4.05×10⁻⁷) / (5.557×10⁻¹³) ≈ 7.29×10⁵ V/m.

Final Answer:

  (a) The charge per meter on the inner conductor is approximately 4.05×10⁻⁷ C/m.
  (b) The electric field intensity at r = 1 cm is approximately 7.29×10⁵ V/m.

\text{(b) } E(1\,\text{cm}) &\approx 7.29 \times 10^5 \, \text{V/m}.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

Step 1: Maxwell's equation ∇·B = 0 implies that there is no magnetic charge in any region. When we integrate this equation over a pillbox that straddles the boundary between the two media, the only contribution is from the normal components of B. This directly leads to the boundary condition that the normal component of B is continuous across the interface.

Step 2: In contrast, the field H is related to B by B = μH (in linear media) and in general, the relation may involve additional magnetization terms. When there is a discontinuity in the magnetization (or permeability), the normal component of H is generally not continuous. Only if there is no surface current or magnetization, the tangential component of H would be continuous. Therefore, the statement about the normal component of H being continuous is not generally true.

Step 3: Concerning the tangential component of B, it is not necessarily continuous, because the boundary condition derived from Faraday’s law (in magnetostatics, implying that ∇×E = 0) pertains to the electric field and tells us that the tangential component of E is continuous (if there is no changing magnetic flux). For B, the curl equation relates to H and may have a jump if there is a surface current present. Thus, the statement about the tangential component of B being continuous is in general not correct.

We will show one way to “design‐by‐calculation” an electromagnet producing a field B = 10,000 gauss (i.e. 1 tesla) in a 0.1‐m gap whose pole faces are 1 m by 2 m (area A = 2 m²). We assume that a high‐µ iron yoke is used so that nearly all of the “magnetic reluctance” is in the gap. (Any answer that gives results equivalent to what follows is acceptable.) 

• Step 1. Determine the mmf (magnetomotive force) required

In a magnetic circuit the dominant drop is in the air gap. In the gap the magnetic field intensity is

  H = B/µ₀     (µ₀ = 4π×10^(–7) H/m).

Thus with B = 1 T,
  H = 1/(4π×10^(–7)) ≃ 7.96×10^5 A/m.

Since the gap has length g = 0.1 m the total mmf needed is

  NI = H·g ≃ 7.96×10^5 A/m × 0.1 m ≃ 80,000 A‐turns.

• Step 2. Choosing the maximum current density

We wish to “use as little copper as possible”. That is achieved if we run the coil at its maximum “engineering” current density. We are given
  Jₘₐₓ = 1000 A/cm².
Remember that 1 A/cm² = 10⁴ A/m², so

  Jₘₐₓ = 1000 × 10⁴ A/m² = 1×10⁷ A/m².

Now, if a current I is chosen in the conductor, then the cross‐sectional area of the copper needed in that “wire” is

  A_wire = I/Jₘₐₓ.

The design must supply NI = 80,000 A‐turns. If we use N turns running at current I then
  N = 80,000/I.

Suppose the coil is wound “around” the pole pieces. (For example, if the pole face is 1×2 m, a “winding” loop that roughly goes around the pole may have an average length L_turn of about 6 m – e.g. the perimeter of a 1 m×2 m rectangle.) With this assumption the total length of copper is

  L_total = N · L_turn = (80,000/I)·L_turn.

Since each turn has a cross‐section A_wire = I/Jₘₐₓ, the total volume of copper is

  V = N·L_turn · A_wire = (80,000/I)·L_turn · (I/Jₘₐₓ) = (80,000·L_turn)/Jₘₐₓ.

Notice that I cancels! (This is typical: if you use the maximum allowed current density the total copper cross‐section is “pinned” by the mmf requirement.) Putting in the numbers with L_turn = 6 m,

  V = (80,000 × 6) / (1×10⁷) = 480,000/1×10⁷ = 0.048 m³.

Now, the density of copper is given as 8 g/cm³. In SI units 1 g/cm³ = 1000 kg/m³ so

  ρ_cu = 8×1000 = 8000 kg/m³.

Thus the mass of copper required is

  m_cu = ρ_cu · V = 8000 kg/m³ × 0.048 m³ = 384 kg.

• Step 3. Determine the electrical “loss” (power consumption)

The electrical resistivity of copper is given as 2×10^(–6) ohm‐cm. Convert this to ohm–m:
  ρ = 2×10^(–6) ohm‐cm × (1 m/100 cm) = 2×10^(–8) ohm‐m.

Let’s now compute the resistance of one turn. Each turn (of length L_turn) is a long “wire” of cross‐section A_wire = I/Jₘₐₓ. Its resistance is

  r_turn = ρ · (L_turn/A_wire) = ρ · (L_turn/(I/Jₘₐₓ)) = ρ · L_turn · (Jₘₐₓ/I).

Because the turns are connected in series the total resistance is

  R_total = N · r_turn = (80,000/I) · [ρ L_turn (Jₘₐₓ/I)]
       = 80,000 · ρ · L_turn · Jₘₐₓ / I².

Now the power dissipated in the coil is

  P = I² · R_total = I² · (80,000 ρ L_turn Jₘₐₓ/I²) = 80,000 · ρ L_turn Jₘₐₓ.

That is independent of I provided we run at the maximum allowable J. Now plug in the numbers:

  P = 80,000 × (2×10^(–8) ohm‐m) × 6 m × (1×10⁷ A/m²).

Compute step‐by‐step:
  2×10^(–8) × 1×10⁷ = 0.2,
  0.2 × 6 = 1.2,
  1.2 × 80,000 = 96,000 W.

Thus the coil will “waste” about 96 kW in resistive losses.

• Step 4. Calculate the attraction force between the poles

In a gap the energy density (magnetic pressure) is

  p = B²/(2µ₀).

This pressure, acting over the pole face area A, produces an attractive force

  F = p · A = (B²/(2µ₀)) · A.

Here B = 1 T, µ₀ = 4π×10^(–7) H/m, and A = 2 m². Then

  F = (1/(2×4π×10^(–7))) × 2 = (1/(8π×10^(–7)))×2.

First compute 8π×10^(–7): 
  8π ≃ 25.13, so 8π×10^(–7) ≃ 2.513×10^(–6).

Then,
  F = 2/(2.513×10^(–6)) ≃ 7.96×10⁵ N.

That is just under 8×10^5 newtons of force between the poles.

• Summary of our “magnet design” results

– Required mmf:  NI ≃ 80,000 A‐turns.

We start by modeling the Earth’s magnetic field as if it were produced by a magnetic dipole at the center of the Earth. For a dipole, the magnetic field along its axis (the “pole”) at a distance r is given by

  B = (μ₀/4π)·(2m/r³),

where m is the magnetic dipole moment. At the surface (r = R), this becomes

  B = (μ₀/4π)·(2m/R³).

We are given:
 • B = 0.8 gauss = 0.8 × 10⁻⁴ T = 8 × 10⁻⁵ T,
 • R = 6 × 10⁶ m, and
 • μ₀ = 4π × 10⁻⁷ H/m.

To solve for m, rearrange the dipole field equation:

  m = (B R³ (4π))/(2 μ₀).

Plugging in the values:

  m = (8×10⁻⁵ T × (6×10⁶ m)³ × (4π)) / (2×4π×10⁻⁷ H/m).

Notice that the factors of 4π in the numerator and denominator cancel out:

  m = (8×10⁻⁵ T × (6×10⁶ m)³) / (2×10⁻⁷).

Now calculate (6×10⁶)³ first:

  (6×10⁶)³ = 6³ × (10⁶)³ = 216 × 10¹⁸ = 2.16×10²⁰ m³.

Substitute this back in:

  m = (8×10⁻⁵ × 2.16×10²⁰) / (2×10⁻⁷).

Multiply the numerator:

  8×10⁻⁵ × 2.16×10²⁰ = 17.28×10¹⁵ = 1.728×10¹⁶.

Then, divide by 2×10⁻⁷:

  m = 1.728×10¹⁶ / (2×10⁻⁷)
    = (1.728 / 2) ×10¹⁶ ×10⁷
    = 0.864 ×10²³
    = 8.64×10²² A·m².

Thus, the estimated magnetic dipole moment of the Earth (assuming a small current loop at its center) is

  m ≈ 8.64 × 10²² A·m².

Finally, we box the final answer:

  \[\boxed{8.64 \times 10^{22} \, \text{A} \cdot \text{m}^2}\]
