We are given a long cylindrical conductor that carries a total current I. The conductor is not magnetic (so μ = μ₀) and is hollow in the center (for r < a) with the conducting annulus extending from r = a to r = b. The current density J is uniform over the cross-sectional area of the conductor, that is,

  J = I⁄[π(b² – a²)].

Our goal is to determine the magnetic field B as a function of the radial coordinate r for three cases: (a) for r < a (inside the hollow), (b) for a < r < b (within the conductor), and (c) for r > b (outside the conductor).

We will use Ampère’s Law which states:

  ∮ B · dl = μ₀ I_enc,

where I_enc is the current enclosed by the Amperian loop.

Step 1. Choose an Amperian loop:  
Since the situation is cylindrically symmetric, we choose a circular loop of radius r (with r as specified in each region). The magnetic field B will be tangential to the loop and its magnitude will be constant along the loop. Hence, the line integral is

  ∮ B · dl = B · (2πr).

Now, let’s address each region.

─────────────────────────────  
(a) Region: r < a (Inside the Hollow)

For r < a, note that the Amperian loop lies completely within the hollow region of the conductor where there is no current. Hence,

  I_enc = 0.

Thus Ampère’s Law gives:

  B (2πr) = μ₀·0  ⇒  B = 0.

─────────────────────────────  
(b) Region: a < r < b (Within the Conductor)

For a loop of radius r such that a < r < b, part of the current is enclosed. The enclosed current I_enc is the current density times the area of the conductor that lies between r = a and r = r. That is,

  I_enc = J × [Area from a to r] = J · [π(r² – a²)].

Substitute J = I⁄[π(b² – a²)]:

  I_enc = I · (r² – a²)/(b² – a²).

Now, applying Ampère’s Law:

  B (2πr) = μ₀ I_enc = μ₀ I (r² – a²)/(b² – a²).

Hence, the magnetic field is

  B = [μ₀ I (r² – a²)] / [2πr (b² – a²)].

─────────────────────────────  
(c) Region: r > b (Outside the Conductor)

For r > b, the entire current I is enclosed in the Amperian loop. Therefore,

  I_enc = I.

Again, applying Ampère’s Law:

  B (2πr) = μ₀ I  ⇒  B = μ₀ I/(2πr).

─────────────────────────────

Thus, the magnetic field as a function of r is given by:

  For r < a:      B = 0,
  For a < r < b:  B = [μ₀ I (r² – a²)] / [2πr (b² – a²)],
  For r > b:     B = μ₀ I/(2πr).

\displaystyle \frac{\mu_0 I}{2\pi r}, & \text{for } r > b.
\end{cases}
}

We wish to find an electric field E that “matches” the given magnetic field

  B(x, y, t) = B₀ e^(ax) ẑ sin(ky – ωt)    (1)

(with constant B₀ and real constant a) so that the vacuum Maxwell equations (in Gaussian units) are satisfied. In what follows we will (i) use the two “curl” equations (Faraday’s law and Ampère’s law) to determine a possible E, (ii) find the dispersion relation (and hence the speed of propagation) and (iii) comment on the physical realization of such a field.

────────────────────────────
Step (a): Find E

The two curl equations in vacuum (with no charges or currents) are

  Faraday’s law:
    ∇×E = – (1/c) ∂B/∂t,

  Ampère’s law:
    ∇×B = (1/c) ∂E/∂t.

Since B in (1) is along ẑ and its phase depends on y and t (the combination w = ky – ωt), it is natural to try an E which lies in the x–y plane. (Indeed, for a “plane‐wave” with propagation along ŷ the electric and magnetic fields are mutually transverse; here the extra factor e^(ax) in B introduces an x–dependence in the amplitude but does not affect the phase.) Thus, we write

  E(x,y,t) = Eₓ(x,y,t) ˆx + E_y(x,y,t) ŷ    (2)

Our strategy is to assume a form in which the x–dependence factors as e^(ax) and the common phase is the same as for B; that is, we look for solutions of the form

  Eₓ(x,y,t) = Eₓ₀ e^(ax) f₁(ky – ωt),
  E_y(x,y,t) = E_y₀ e^(ax) f₂(ky – ωt).

Because the time derivatives of sin(ky – ωt) give cos(ky – ωt) (and vice‐versa) we try the choices

  Eₓ(x,y,t) = A e^(ax) sin(ky – ωt),
  E_y(x,y,t) = F e^(ax) cos(ky – ωt).    (3)

We now determine the two amplitudes A and F by substituting into Maxwell’s equations.

────────────────────────────
(1) Using Ampère’s law

We first compute ∇×B. Our magnetic field is given by 
  B = (0, 0, B_z)  with B_z = B₀ e^(ax) sin(ky – ωt).

Since B has only a z–component,
  (∇×B)_x = ∂B_z/∂y – ∂B_y/∂z = ∂B_z/∂y,
  (∇×B)_y = ∂B_x/∂z – ∂B_z/∂x = – ∂B_z/∂x,
  (∇×B)_z = ∂B_y/∂x – ∂B_x/∂y = 0.
Thus,
  (∇×B)_x = k B₀ e^(ax) cos(ky – ωt),
  (∇×B)_y = – a B₀ e^(ax) sin(ky – ωt).    (4)

On the other hand, (1/c) ∂E/∂t gives the components
  (1/c) ∂Eₓ/∂t  in the x–direction, and (1/c) ∂E_y/∂t  in the y–direction.
Using the ansatz (3):
  ∂Eₓ/∂t = A e^(ax) cos(ky – ωt) (–ω) = – ω A e^(ax) cos(ky – ωt),
so that
  (1/c) ∂Eₓ/∂t = – (ω A)/(c) e^(ax) cos(ky – ωt).

Similarly,
  ∂E_y/∂t = F e^(ax) (– sin(ky – ωt)) (–ω)? 
But note: actually, differentiate E_y = F e^(ax) cos(ky – ωt); then
  ∂E_y/∂t = – ω F e^(ax) sin(ky – ωt).

Ampère’s law, ∇×B = (1/c) ∂E/∂t, then tells us that
  x–component: k B₀ e^(ax) cos(ky – ωt) = (1/c) ∂Eₓ/∂t = – (ω A)/(c) e^(ax) cos(ky – ωt). 
Thus,
  – (ω A)/(c) = k B₀  or  A = – (c k B₀)/ω.    (5)

Similarly, comparing the y–components, Ampère’s law gives
  – a B₀ e^(ax) sin(ky – ωt) = (1/c) ∂E_y/∂t = – (ω F)/(c) e^(ax) sin(ky – ωt).
Canceling the common factors,
  (ω F)/(c) = a B₀  or  F = (a c B₀)/ω.    (6)

────────────────────────────
(2) Using Faraday’s law

We also must have 
  ∇×E = – (1/c) ∂B/∂t.
Since E = (Eₓ, E_y, 0), its curl has only a z–component:
  (∇×E)_z = ∂E_y/∂x – ∂Eₓ/∂y.

First, note that
  Eₓ = A e^(ax) sin(ky – ωt) with A given by (5),
  E_y = F e^(ax) cos(ky – ωt) with F given by (6).
Thus,
  ∂E_y/∂x = a F e^(ax) cos(ky – ωt),
and
  ∂Eₓ/∂y = A e^(ax) cos(ky – ωt) k.
Therefore,
  (∇×E)_z = [a F – k A] e^(ax) cos(ky – ωt).    (7)

Now compute the time derivative of B_z:
  B_z = B₀ e^(ax) sin(ky – ωt) implies ∂B_z/∂t = – ω B₀ e^(ax) cos(ky – ωt).
Thus, Faraday’s law requires
  (∇×E)_z = – (1/c) (–ω B₀ e^(ax) cos(ky – ωt)) = (ω B₀)/(c) e^(ax) cos(ky – ωt).    (8)

Substitute F and A from (5) and (6) into (7):
  a F – k A = a (a c B₀/ω) – k [– (c k B₀)/ω] = (c B₀/ω)(a² + k²).
Thus, (7) becomes
  (∇×E)_z = (c B₀/ω)(a² + k²) e^(ax) cos(ky – ωt).
Comparing with (8) we must have
  (c B₀/ω)(a² + k²) = (ω B₀)/c  ⟹  a² + k² = ω²/c².    (9)

This last equation is nothing but the dispersion relation (and also the condition for the wave equation to be satisfied by B). In effect, our ansatz is consistent provided
  ω² = c² (a² + k²).    (10)

────────────────────────────
Thus a valid solution for the electric field is

  Eₓ(x,y,t) = – (c k B₀/ω) e^(ax) sin(ky – ωt),
  E_y(x,y,t) =  (a c B₀/ω) e^(ax) cos(ky – ωt),   E_z = 0.    (11)

It is easy to check that with (10) the remaining Maxwell equations are also satisfied.

────────────────────────────
Step (b): Speed of Propagation

Recall that the given magnetic field has phase

  w = ky – ωt.

Thus the phase fronts (constant w) travel in the y–direction with speed v_phase = ω/k. However, the dispersion relation (10) tells us that

  ω² = c² (a² + k²)  or  ω = c √(a² + k²).
This implies that
  v_phase = ω/k = c √(1 + (a/k)²).
In a pure plane wave, one usually obtains v_phase = c, but here the extra transverse e^(ax) factor (which does not affect the phase) makes the phase velocity along y exceed c. (This is a well‐known phenomenon in “evanescent” or “guided” waves; however, the signal or energy velocity will remain ≤ c.) In fact, if one now computes the group velocity from (10) by writing
  ω = ω(k) = c√(a²+k²)
one obtains
  v_group = dω/dk = c²k/ω = c² / v_phase.
Thus one finds that physically the energy and signals travel with group velocity v_group < c. (Remember that in vacuum electromagnetic signals do not propagate faster than c.)

One “speed of propagation” that is often meant is the “signal” or “energy” velocity and in a source‐free region of vacuum this is c. (Also note that if a is not equal to zero the field is not a simple homogeneous plane wave but a “guided” or “evanescent” one in the x–direction.) In any event, the dispersion relation (10) must hold.

For purposes of our answer we may state that the dispersion relation is
  ω² = c² (a² + k²),
so that the natural speed that enters is c.

────────────────────────────
Step (c): Physical Realizability

The field (1) has an amplitude modulation e^(ax) in the x–direction even though its phase is that of a plane wave traveling in the y–direction. (In many textbooks one meets such fields as “nonuniform plane waves”.) In free space a “plane‐wave” solution must have a uniform amplitude. What is going on here?

A field with an exponential factor like e^(ax) (with a a nonzero real number) is often encountered in problems involving evanescent fields (for example, in total internal reflection, or as guided modes in a waveguide). When a is real the factor e^(ax) either grows (if a > 0) without bound or decays (if a < 0) in x. Of course, over all space such a solution is non‐physical (since it would either have infinite energy or vanish in one half–space), but in a restricted region (for example, inside a waveguide or in the “frustrated” region near a totally reflecting interface) such fields may be produced. In other words, the answer to “is it possible to generate such a field?” is “Yes, provided one uses the appropriate boundary conditions.” For example, one may obtain such an exponentially “modulated” field by exciting a suitable mode in a waveguide or by launching an evanescent wave at an interface. (In free space, without boundaries the simple plane–wave fields have uniform amplitude.)

────────────────────────────
Final Answer

Thus one acceptable answer is:

(a) A possible electric field is

  E(x,y,t) = – (c k B₀/ω) e^(ax) sin(ky – ωt) ˆx + (a c B₀/ω) e^(ax) cos(ky – ωt) ŷ.

(b) The dispersion relation is

  ω² = c²(a² + k²)  so that (defining the “propagation speed” as the one appearing in the dispersion relation) the field “propagates” with speed c.

(c) Such a field may be generated provided one has the proper boundary conditions. In practice, an exponential variation in the transverse (x) direction is characteristic of evanescent or guided waves (for example, in a waveguide or via total internal reflection). Hence, while a “uniform” free–space plane wave has no x–dependence, fields of the type (1) can be produced in situations where the source (or the geometry) forces an exponential amplitude modulation.

────────────────────────────
Final Answer in Boxed LaTeX

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad \mathbf{E}(x,y,t) &= -\frac{c\,k\,B_0}{\omega}\,e^{ax}\sin(ky-\omega t)\,\hat{x}
+\frac{a\,c\,B_0}{\omega}\,e^{ax}\cos(ky-\omega t)\,\hat{y},\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad \omega^2 &= c^2\,(a^2+k^2),\quad\text{so that the natural speed is }c,\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}\quad &\text{Such fields (with exponential modulation in }x\text{) arise as evanescent or guided modes,}\\
&\text{and can be generated by appropriate sources (e.g. in a waveguide or via total internal reflection).}
\end{aligned}
}
\]

solution:
We wish to study how a harmonic electromagnetic field interacts with free electrons present in a medium. In what follows we assume that the fields vary in time as

  E(r, t) = E(r) e^(–iωt).

Also, we assume that the free electrons do not interact with each other so that their motion in the field is independent.

──────────────────────────────
Step (a): Find the induced current density j

The electrons of charge –e and mass m obey the classical equation of motion under the force provided by the electric field:

  m (dv/dt) = –e E.

For a time‐harmonic field (with E ∝ e^(–iωt)) we have d/dt → –iω and therefore

  –iω m v = –e E ⟹ v = e E/(i m ω).

Since the current density is given by

  j = (charge density) × (velocity)
    = –nₑ e v    (the minus sign appears because the electrons are negatively charged),

we substitute for v to obtain

  j = –nₑ e [e E/(i m ω)] = –(nₑ e²/(i m ω)) E.

It is sometimes more convenient to write the factor 1/i as –i so that

  j = i (nₑ e²/(m ω)) E.

Thus, an acceptable answer for (a) is

  j = –(nₑ e²/(i m ω)) E   (or equivalently j = i nₑ e²/(m ω) E).

──────────────────────────────
Step (b): Write the differential equations for the spatial dependence of the wave

We now work with Maxwell’s equations in the frequency domain. In a nonconducting medium the Maxwell’s curl equations are

  (1) ∇ × E = iω B,
  (2) ∇ × B = μ₀ (j – iω ε E).

In our case, there is also the current density we found in part (a). Inserting

  j = –(nₑ e²/(i m ω)) E
    = i (nₑ e²/(m ω)) E   [since –1/i = i],

into (2) gives

  ∇ × B = μ₀ [i (nₑ e²/(m ω)) E – iω ε E]
       = –i μ₀ [ωε – (nₑ e²/(m ω))] E.

To derive a wave equation we take the curl of (1):

  ∇ × (∇ × E) = iω (∇ × B).

Using the vector identity

  ∇ × (∇ × E) = ∇(∇ · E) – ∇²E,

and assuming that there are no free charges in the medium (so that ∇ · E = 0), we obtain

  –∇²E = iω (∇ × B).

Now substitute the expression we got for ∇ × B:

  –∇²E = iω [ –i μ₀ (ωε – (nₑ e²/(m ω))) E ]
      = ω μ₀ (ωε – [nₑ e²/(m ω)]) E
      = μ₀ [ω²ε – nₑ e²/m] E.

Thus, we obtain the Helmholtz (wave‐) equation for E:

  ∇²E + μ₀ [ω²ε – nₑ e²/m] E = 0.

A similar equation holds for B. In other words, for a wave varying as exp(–iωt) the spatial dependence of E (or B) must satisfy

  ∇²E + k² E = 0  with k² = μ₀ (ω²ε – (nₑ e²/m)).

──────────────────────────────
Step (c): Determine the condition under which the electromagnetic waves propagate indefinitely

For a wave to propagate indefinitely (i.e. without being exponentially damped or evanescent), the wavenumber k must be real. From the wave equation we require

  k² = μ₀ (ω²ε – (nₑ e²/m)) > 0.
 
Since μ₀ is positive, the necessary and sufficient condition is

  ω²ε – (nₑ e²/m) > 0   ⟹  ω²ε > nₑ e²/m.

In many problems the medium is vacuum (or a dielectric with constant ε₀), in which case one defines the plasma frequency ωₚ by

  ωₚ² = nₑ e²/(m ε₀).

Then, when ε = ε₀, the propagation condition becomes

  ω² > ωₚ²  ⟹  ω > ωₚ.

Thus, electromagnetic waves will propagate (without attenuation) only if the angular frequency of the wave is high enough to overcome the “inertia” of the free electrons.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

(a) The induced current density is
  j = –(nₑ e²/(i m ω)) E      (or equivalently j = i (nₑ e²/(m ω)) E).

(b) Maxwell’s equations lead to the spatial wave equation
  ∇²E + μ₀ [ω²ε – nₑ e²/m] E = 0.

(c) For indefinite (undamped) propagation we must have
  ω²ε > nₑ e²/m,
so that (in vacuum, when ε = ε₀) the propagation condition is ω > ωₚ, with ωₚ² = nₑ e²/(m ε₀).

The final boxed answer is:

\[ \boxed{
\begin{array}{rcl}
\text{(a)}\quad j &=& -\dfrac{n_e e^2}{i m \omega} E \quad \text{(i.e., } j = i\,\dfrac{n_e e^2}{m \omega}\,E \text{)}; \\
\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad \nabla^2E + \mu_0\Bigl(\omega^2\epsilon - \dfrac{n_e e^2}{m}\Bigr)E &=& 0;\\[1mm]
\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}\quad \text{Waves propagate if} \quad \omega^2\epsilon &>& \dfrac{n_e e^2}{m}\,,
\end{array}
} \] 

which for ε = ε₀ gives the familiar condition ω > ωₚ, with ωₚ² = n_e e²/(m ε₀).

solution:
We wish to see whether the given wave

  E = (0, E₀ e^(i(Kz – ωt)), 0)

can “live” in a medium containing free electrons of number density n. (All other charges are fixed.) In such a situation the free electrons are accelerated by the wave’s electric field; if we finally neglect the magnetic force acting on them, then their velocity is determined solely by

  m (d²r/dt²) = –e E.

In what follows we work in the phasor picture (using the time‐dependence e^(i(Kz – ωt))) and with SI units. We now proceed step‐by‐step.

───────────────────────────── 
Step (a). Maxwell’s Equations in the Medium

In a medium the Maxwell equations in differential form are

  (i) Gauss’ law for E:  ∇·E = ρ/ε₀,
  (ii) Gauss’ law for B:  ∇·B = 0,
  (iii) Faraday’s law:  ∇×E = –∂B/∂t,
  (iv) Ampère–Maxwell law: ∇×B = μ₀ J + μ₀ε₀ ∂E/∂t.

Because the free electrons are the only mobile charges (all others are fixed) and the medium is overall neutral (in equilibrium), the charge density ρ induced by the wave is taken to vanish; however, the electrons’ motion produces a current density J. (In part (b) we will see that the current is determined by the electron’s equation of motion.) Finally, the electrons obey

  m (d²r/dt²) = –e E.

Thus one may summarize part (a) by writing

  ∇·E = 0,  ∇·B = 0,
  ∇×E = –∂B/∂t,
  ∇×B = μ₀ J + μ₀ε₀ ∂E/∂t,
  with J = –n e v  and  m d²r/dt² = –e E.
───────────────────────────── 
Step (b). Consistency of the Wave and a Requirement on ω

Let us first find the current density J. Since the electric field is (in the phasor representation)
  E = ŷ E₀ e^(i(Kz – ωt)),
the electron’s equation of motion is

  m (d²r/dt²) = –e E.
Assuming a phasor solution r = r₀ e^(–iωt) (the space–dependent factor is not essential here), we have
  –ω² m r₀ = –e E ⟹ r₀ = eE/(m ω²).
Then the velocity is

  v = dr/dt = –iω r = –iω (eE/(m ω²)) = –i eE/(mω).
Thus the current density (for electrons of density n) is

  J = –n e v = –n e (–i eE/(mω)) = i (n e²/(mω)) E.
Now we substitute this into Ampère’s law. In phasor notation the time-derivative becomes multiplication by –iω so that Ampère’s law becomes

  ∇×B = μ₀ (i (n e²/(mω)) E) – iω μ₀ε₀ E.
For a plane wave varying as e^(i(Kz – ωt)), take (for example) the curl in the y– and z–directions. In order for the spatial derivatives on the left-hand side to produce a factor of iK, one must have
  iK (… E) = –iω μ₀ε₀ (1 – (n e²/(mω²ε₀) )) E.
That is, one obtains the dispersion relation (after some algebra)
  K² = ω² μ₀ε₀ (1 – ω_p²/ω²),
where we have defined the usual plasma frequency by

  ω_p² = n e²/(m ε₀).
Thus, in order that K be real (a requirement for a propagating wave) we must have ω² > ω_p². (In other words, the electrons can follow the field only if the driving frequency is high enough.) This is exactly what we wish to show in part (b).
───────────────────────────── 
Step (c). Finding the Magnetic Field and the Wavelength

For the given electric field we now find the corresponding magnetic field by using Faraday’s law

  ∇×E = –∂B/∂t.
Since

  E = (0, E₀ e^(i(Kz – ωt)), 0),
its only nonzero spatial derivative is with respect to z. (In Cartesian coordinates the x–component of ∇×E is)
  (∇×E)_x = ∂E_z/∂y – ∂E_y/∂z.
Since E_z = 0 and ∂E_y/∂z = iK E₀ e^(i(Kz – ωt)), we have

  (∇×E)_x = –iK E₀ e^(i(Kz – ωt)),
while the other components vanish.

On the right side we have
  –∂B/∂t = iω B e^(i(Kz – ωt))
if we assume that B has the same space–time dependence. (It is natural to seek a solution in which B is perpendicular to both E and the propagation direction z; with E along y we choose B along x.) Thus let

  B = B₀ x̂ e^(i(Kz – ωt)).
Then Faraday’s law requires

  –iK E₀ = –∂B_x/∂t = iω B₀ ⟹ B₀ = –(K/ω) E₀.
Thus the magnetic field is

  B = –(K/ω) E₀ x̂ e^(i(Kz – ωt)).
Finally, since the dispersion relation is

  K = ω√(μ₀ε₀(1 – ω_p²/ω²)) = (ω/c) √(1 – ω_p²/ω²)
(with c = 1/√(μ₀ε₀)), the wavelength is

  λ = 2π/K = (2πc/ω) / √(1 – ω_p²/ω²).
───────────────────────────── 
Final Answer

(a) Maxwell’s equations (in SI units) are

  ∇·E = 0,  ∇·B = 0,
  ∇×E = –∂B/∂t,
  ∇×B = μ₀ J + μ₀ε₀ ∂E/∂t,
with the electron current given by
  J = –n e v  and  m (d²r/dt²) = –e E.

(b) In the phasor representation the electron acceleration causes a current J = i (n e²/(mω)) E. Substitution into Ampère’s law results in the dispersion relation

  K² = ω² μ₀ε₀ (1 – ω_p²/ω²),  with ω_p² = n e²/(m ε₀).
Thus a propagating (“plane‐wave”) solution requires that

  ω² > ω_p².

(c) For the given electric field E = ŷ E₀ e^(i(Kz – ωt)), Faraday’s law yields

  B = –(K/ω) x̂ E₀ e^(i(Kz – ωt)).
Also, since K = (ω/c) √(1 – ω_p²/ω²), the wavelength is

  λ = 2π/K = (2π c/ω)/√(1 – ω_p²/ω²).

Thus, an electromagnetic wave with the given electric field can propagate in the free‐electron medium only if ω² > ω_p². Its associated magnetic field is perpendicular to both E and the propagation direction and has the amplitude given above.

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answer in Boxed Form

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
&\text{(a) Maxwell's equations are:} \\
&\quad \nabla\cdot E = 0,\quad \nabla\cdot B = 0,\\[1mm]
&\quad \nabla\times E = -\frac{\partial B}{\partial t},\\[1mm]
&\quad \nabla\times B = \mu_0\left(J + \varepsilon_0\frac{\partial E}{\partial t}\right),\quad \text{with }J = -ne\,v\text{ and } m\frac{d^2r}{dt^2}=-eE.\\[2mm]
&\text{(b) With }E_y = E_0e^{i(Kz-\omega t)}\text{ and the electron response }v=-\frac{ieE}{m\omega},\\[1mm]
&\quad \quad J = i\frac{ne^2}{m\omega}E,\\[1mm]
&\quad \text{Amp\`ere's law leads to } K^2=\omega^2\mu_0\varepsilon_0\left(1-\frac{\omega_p^2}{\omega^2}\right),\quad\omega_p^2=\frac{ne^2}{m\varepsilon_0},\\[1mm]
&\quad \text{so that a propagating wave exists only if } \omega^2>\omega_p^2.\\[2mm]
&\text{(c) The magnetic field is found from Faraday's law:}\\[1mm]
&\quad B=-\frac{K}{\omega}E_0\,x\,e^{i(Kz-\omega t)},\\[1mm]
&\quad \text{with }K=\frac{\omega}{c}\sqrt{1-\frac{\omega_p^2}{\omega^2}},\text{ so that } \lambda=\frac{2\pi}{K} = \frac{2\pi c}{\omega\sqrt{1-\omega_p^2/\omega^2}}.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

solution:
We wish to show that in the frequency–domain the potentials may be written as

  (1) φ₍ω₎(r) = (1/(4πε₀)) ∫ d³r′ ρ₍ω₎(r′) e^(iK|r–r′|)/|r–r′|,

  (2) A₍ω₎(r) = (μ₀/(4π)) ∫ d³r′ J₍ω₎(r′) e^(iK|r–r′|)/|r–r′|   (K = |ω|/c).

In what follows we explain how the conservation law is expressed in frequency–domain, and then we obtain the usual far–zone (or “radiation zone”) approximations for the electric and magnetic fields, finishing with the particular case when the current density is “radial”, namely

  (3) J₍ω₎(r) = r f(r).

We now present the complete step–by–step solution.

────────────────────────────
Step 1. Charge–Current Conservation in Frequency Domain

In the time–domain the conservation law (continuity equation) reads

  ∂ρ(r,t)/∂t + ∇⋅J(r,t) = 0.

Taking the temporal Fourier transform (with the convention
  f₍ω₎ ≡ ∫ dt f(t)e^(iωt) )
one obtains that the time derivative contributes a factor –iω. Hence, in the frequency representation the continuity equation becomes

  –iω ρ₍ω₎(r) + ∇⋅J₍ω₎(r) = 0.

Sometimes one sees it in the equivalent form

  ∇⋅J₍ω₎(r) = iω ρ₍ω₎(r).

This is the charge–current conservation law expressed in terms of ρ₍ω₎ and J₍ω₎.

────────────────────────────
Step 2. Far–Zone Expressions for the Fields

In the radiation zone (r → ∞) the Green’s function

  e^(iK|r–r′|)/|r–r′|
 
may be approximated by expanding |r – r′| when r′ is “small” compared to r. In fact, writing

  |r – r′| = r – r̂⋅r′ + O((r′/r)²)
 
we have

  e^(iK|r–r′|)/|r–r′| ≈ e^(iKr)/r · e^(–iK r̂⋅r′).

Thus the potentials become

  A₍ω₎(r) ≈ (μ₀/(4π)) e^(iKr)/r ∫ d³r′ J₍ω₎(r′) e^(–iK r̂⋅r′),

and a similar result holds for φ₍ω₎(r). (In most practical situations for radiation only the transverse part of A₍ω₎ is important.)

The magnetic field is given by

  B₍ω₎ = ∇×A₍ω₎.

In the far zone the spatial variation is dominated by the phase factor e^(iKr); therefore we may write

  ∇×A₍ω₎ ≈ (iK) (r̂×A₍ω₎).

Thus we obtain

  B₍ω₎(r) ≈ iK (r̂×A₍ω₎(r))
       = iK (μ₀/(4π)) e^(iKr)/r [r̂× ∫ d³r′ J₍ω₎(r′) e^(–iK r̂⋅r′)].

Next, the electric field in the frequency–domain is given by

  E₍ω₎ = iω A₍ω₎ – ∇φ₍ω₎.

A careful calculation (or, equivalently, an appeal to the fact that in a radiating plane wave the electric and magnetic fields are transverse and related by the impedance of free space) shows that in the far zone one obtains the standard relation

  E₍ω₎(r) ≈ c B₍ω₎(r) × r̂         (with c = 1/√(ε₀μ₀)).

Thus, summarizing, the radiation fields in the far zone are

  (4) B₍ω₎(r) ≈ (iK μ₀/(4π)) e^(iKr)/r [r̂× F(r̂)],
  (5) E₍ω₎(r) ≈ c (r̂×B₍ω₎(r)),

where we have defined the “angular spectrum” (or effective current) by

  F(r̂) = ∫ d³r′ J₍ω₎(r′) e^(–iK r̂⋅r′).

────────────────────────────
Step 3. Special Case: Radial Current Density J₍ω₎(r) = r f(r)

Now suppose that the current density has the form

  J₍ω₎(r) = r f(r),
         i.e. it points in the radial direction at every point.

Then the angular (or “radiation‐”) integral becomes

  F(r̂) = ∫ d³r′ r′ f(|r′|) e^(–iK r̂⋅r′).

It is most convenient to introduce spherical coordinates for r′ so that r′ = r′ n̂ (with n̂ a unit vector in the direction of r′) and d³r′ = r′² dr′ dΩ. Then

  F(r̂) = ∫₀^∞ dr′ r′³ f(r′) ∫ dΩ n̂ e^(–iK r′ (r̂⋅n̂)).

But note that if f(r′) is a spherically symmetric function (i.e. it depends only on r′), then the angular integral

  ∫ dΩ n̂ e^(–iK r′ cosθ)
 
(where we have aligned r̂ with the z–axis) vanishes by symmetry. (Indeed, the x– and y–components vanish by symmetry and the z–component involves an odd function cosθ over the interval 0 to π.) Therefore we find

  F(r̂) = 0.

It then follows that

  A₍ω₎(r) ∼ e^(iKr)/r · F(r̂) = 0   → No radiation vector potential,
  B₍ω₎(r) ∼ r̂×A₍ω₎(r) = 0,
  E₍ω₎(r) ∼ r̂×B₍ω₎(r) = 0.

Thus, for a purely “radial” current density of the form J₍ω₎(r) = r f(r), there is no radiated field in the far zone.

────────────────────────────
Final Answer

1) In the frequency–domain the law of charge–current conservation is expressed as

  –iω ρ₍ω₎(r) + ∇⋅J₍ω₎(r) = 0.

2) In the far zone (r → ∞) the vector potential is approximated by

  A₍ω₎(r) ≈ (μ₀/(4π)) (e^(iKr)/r) ∫ d³r′ J₍ω₎(r′) e^(–iK r̂⋅r′),
  and hence the magnetic field is
   B₍ω₎(r) ≈ iK (μ₀/(4π)) (e^(iKr)/r) [r̂× ∫ d³r′ J₍ω₎(r′) e^(–iK r̂⋅r′)],
  while the electric field in the radiation zone satisfies
   E₍ω₎(r) ≈ c (r̂×B₍ω₎(r)).
  (Here c = 1/√(ε₀μ₀).)

3) For a current density of the form

  J₍ω₎(r) = r f(r),
  the angular integral ∫ d³r′ r′ f(r′) e^(–iK r̂⋅r′) vanishes by symmetry. Consequently, in the far zone one finds

  A₍ω₎(r) = 0, B₍ω₎(r) = 0, and E₍ω₎(r) = 0.

────────────────────────────

solution:
We wish to find the electric field and potential at the point P which is the center of a small spherical “hole” (of radius R₂) that has been cut out from a uniformly charged sphere (of radius R₁ with uniform charge density ρ). One may “remove” the cavity by the method of superposition. In other words, we may think of the actual charge distribution as the superposition of

  (1) a complete sphere with uniform charge density ρ, and  
  (2) a “negative” sphere of the same density –ρ (filling exactly the volume of the cavity) placed at the proper location.

The center P of the cavity is displaced by a vector a from the center O of the full sphere.

Below is a step‐by‐step solution.

───────────────────────────── 
Step 1. Field from a Uniformly Charged Sphere

For a sphere of uniform charge density ρ and radius R₁ the electric field inside (r ≤ R₁) is given by

  E_full(r) = (ρ/(3ε₀)) r         (1)

where r is the vector from the center O of the sphere. In our application the point P is located at r = a (the vector from O to P). Hence, the contribution from the full sphere is

  E_full(P) = (ρ/(3ε₀)) a.         (2)

───────────────────────────── 
Step 2. Field from the “Negative” Sphere (the Cavity)

We now “add” a sphere of radius R₂ and uniform density –ρ (i.e. the same density but negative) whose center is located at the same point as the cavity (point P). What is its contribution to the field at P? In a uniformly charged sphere the electric field at any point inside is given by the vector (ρ/(3ε₀)) times the displacement from the sphere’s own center. But when the field is evaluated at the center of that sphere the displacement is zero. Therefore, the field at P due to the negative sphere is

  E_negative(P) = (–ρ/(3ε₀))·0 = 0.  (3)

───────────────────────────── 
Step 3. Total Electric Field at the Center of the Cavity

Using superposition the total field at P is just the sum of (2) and (3):

  E_total(P) = E_full(P) + E_negative(P) = (ρ/(3ε₀)) a.    (4)

Thus the field at the center of the hollow is proportional to the displacement a (directed from the center of the full sphere toward the cavity’s center).

───────────────────────────── 
Step 4. Potential from a Uniformly Charged Sphere

The potential inside a uniformly charged sphere (with the usual condition φ(∞) = 0) is obtained by integrating the field. One standard result is

  φ_full(r) = (ρ/(6ε₀)) (3R₁² – r²)   for r ≤ R₁.   (5)

At the point P (r = |a|) the full-sphere contribution is

  φ_full(P) = (ρ/(6ε₀)) (3R₁² – a²).  (6)

───────────────────────────── 
Step 5. Potential due to the “Negative” Sphere

Similarly, the potential inside a uniformly charged sphere (of radius R₂ and density ρ) is given by the analogous form. Then the potential at its center (r = 0 relative to its own center) is

  φ_negative(P) = (ρ/(6ε₀)) (3R₂² – 0²) = (ρ/(6ε₀)) 3R₂².

However, since this sphere is “negative” (i.e. its density is –ρ), its contribution to the potential is

  φ_negative(P) = – (ρ/(6ε₀)) 3R₂².  (7)

───────────────────────────── 
Step 6. Total Potential at the Center of the Cavity

By superposition, the total potential at P is the sum of the two contributions (6) and (7):

  φ_total(P) = φ_full(P) + φ_negative(P)
        = (ρ/(6ε₀)) (3R₁² – a²) – (ρ/(6ε₀)) 3R₂²
        = (ρ/(6ε₀)) (3R₁² – a² – 3R₂²).    (8)

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answers

(a) The electric field at the center of the cavity is

  E = (ρ/(3ε₀)) a        (vector directed from the full sphere’s center to the cavity’s center). 

(b) The electric potential at that point is

  φ = (ρ/(6ε₀)) (3R₁² – a² – 3R₂²). 

Thus, in our boxed final answer we have

  \[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{E}\Bigl|_{P} &= \frac{\rho}{3\epsilon_0}\,\mathbf{a},\\[1mm]
\phi\Bigl|_{P} &= \frac{\rho}{6\epsilon_0}\Bigl(3R_1^2 - a^2 - 3R_2^2\Bigr).
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We wish to find the force acting on a single ion in an infinite beam of charged ions that has a constant circular cross‐section of radius R. The beam has a uniformly distributed charge per unit length q (units: C/m) and all the ions are moving with speed v along the z‐axis. We will assume that the ion we wish to examine is located at a distance r from the beam’s axis with r < R.

Because the beam is infinite and has cylindrical symmetry, we can use Gauss’ law and Ampère’s law to find the electric and magnetic fields, respectively, at a distance r from the center (ignoring the field produced by the ion itself).

Step 1. Determine the Electric Field Inside the Beam

The beam has a uniform linear charge density q and a circular cross‐section of radius R. Thus the charge per unit area (surface charge density in the cross section) is

  σ = q/(πR²).

Now, consider a cylindrical Gaussian surface of radius r (with r < R) and unit length along the beam. By symmetry the electric field E at distance r is radially outward and constant over the curved surface. Gauss’ law gives

  ∮E⋅dA = E × (2πr·1) = (1/ε₀) × (charge enclosed).

The charge enclosed in the unit length is

  q_enc = σ (πr²) = (q/(πR²)) (πr²) = q (r²/R²).

Thus, Gauss’ law yields

  E (2πr) = (1/ε₀)[q (r²/R²)],

so that

  E = (q r)/(2π ε₀ R²).

Its direction is radially outward.

Step 2. Determine the Magnetic Field Inside the Beam

Since the ions are moving with velocity v along the z‐axis, they constitute a current. The current per unit length comes from the charged beam and is given by

  I = q v   (since q is the charge per unit length).

For r < R, by symmetry the magnetic field B will be azimuthal (i.e. in the ϕ‑direction). Using Ampère’s law along a circle of radius r, we have

  ∮B⋅dl = B (2πr) = μ₀ (current enclosed).

The current enclosed in the circle of radius r is a fraction of the total current proportional to the fraction of the cross‐section,

  I_enc = I (πr²)/(πR²) = I (r²/R²) = q v (r²/R²).

Thus Ampère’s law gives

  B (2πr) = μ₀ (q v r²)/(R²),

or

  B = (μ₀ q v r)/(2π R²).

Its direction is given by the right‐hand rule (circulating around the z‑axis in the ϕ direction).

Step 3. Calculate the Lorentz Force on the Ion

A single ion (assumed to have charge e) within the beam experiences a Lorentz force given by

  F = e (E + v × B).

We have determined that the electric field is radial and given by

  E = (q r)/(2π ε₀ R²) r̂.

Next, we need to find the magnetic force. The ion’s velocity is along z, i.e. v = v ẑ, while B is in the ϕ direction, i.e. B = (μ₀ q v r)/(2π R²) ϕ̂. Thus, the magnetic force is

  F_mag = e (v ẑ × B ϕ̂).

Recall that in cylindrical coordinates the cross product ẑ × ϕ̂ = –r̂. (To picture this, if the current is upward the magnetic field circles the beam and a positively charged ion moving upward will feel a magnetic force pointing radially inward.) Therefore, its magnitude is

  |F_mag| = e v B = e v (μ₀ q v r)/(2π R²) = e (μ₀ q v² r)/(2π R²).

Thus, its direction is opposite to that of the electric force (which is radially outward). Combining, the net force F is

  F = e E + e (v × B)
    = e (E – vB) r̂
    = e [ (q r)/(2π ε₀ R²) – ( (μ₀ q v² r)/(2π R²) ) ] r̂.

Factor out common factors:

  F = e (q r)/(2π R²) [1/ε₀ – μ₀ v²] r̂.

Step 4. Expressing in terms of v²/c²

We recall the electromagnetic relation

  c² = 1/(ε₀ μ₀)   or equivalently  μ₀ = 1/(ε₀ c²).

Thus,

  1/ε₀ – μ₀ v² = 1/ε₀ – (v²/(ε₀ c²)) = (1/ε₀)(1 – v²/c²).

Substitute back into the force expression:

  F = e (q r)/(2π R²) (1/ε₀)(1 – v²/c²) r̂
    = (e q r)/(2π ε₀ R²) (1 – v²/c²) r̂.

Final Answer:

The net force on a single beam ion (of charge e) located at radius r is therefore

  F = (e q r)/(2π ε₀ R²) (1 – v²/c²) in the radial direction.

In boxed LaTeX format, the final answer is

  \[\boxed{F = \frac{e\,q\,r}{2\pi \epsilon_0 R^2}\left(1-\frac{v^2}{c^2}\right) \, \hat{r}}\]

solution:
We wish to find the surface charge density on a perfectly conducting sphere of radius R moving with constant velocity

  v = v eₓ   (with v ≪ c)

through a uniform magnetic field

  B = B e_y.

Because the sphere is a perfect conductor, any motional “electric” forces will be exactly canceled inside the conductor by the buildup of surface charges. In the laboratory frame the electric field is zero; however, because the sphere is moving the charges “feel” a motional electromotive force. It is therefore simplest to analyze the problem in the rest frame of the sphere.

Step 1. Change to the Sphere’s Rest Frame

The electromagnetic field transforms under a Lorentz boost. To lowest order in v/c one may use the non‐relativistic approximation. In the lab frame we have E = 0; then in the sphere’s rest frame the electric field becomes

  E′ = E + v × B = v × B.

Since v = v eₓ and B = B e_y, we have

  v × B = vB (eₓ × e_y) = vB e_z.

Thus, in the sphere’s rest frame the exterior uniform field is

  E′ = vB e_z,  or equivalently E₀ = vB in the +z direction.

Now, because the conductor is a perfect conductor the electric field inside must vanish. Consequently, the moving sphere develops surface charges so that the total electric field (the sum of the applied field and the field due to the induced charges) cancels inside.

It is a standard electrostatics problem to find the induced charge distribution on a conducting sphere placed in a uniform electric field. However, note the sign: Although the field in the sphere’s rest frame is E₀ = vB e_z, the conductor must set up an electric potential to cancel this field. This is identical to the standard problem of a conducting sphere in an external uniform electric field, except that our field is “effective” and originates from the motion.

Step 2. Solve the Potential Problem

Let φ be the electrostatic potential in the sphere’s rest frame. Since the sphere is a conductor the potential inside is constant (which we may take as zero) and the potential outside must satisfy Laplace’s equation. A well known solution for a sphere in a uniform external field E₀ pointing in the z direction is

  φ(r,θ) = –E₀ r cosθ + E₀ (R³/r²) cosθ  for r ≥ R,

where θ is the polar angle measured from the +z axis. Notice that when r = R the two terms cancel, φ(R,θ) = 0, as required by the conductor’s equipotential condition.

Here our effective uniform field is E₀ = vB (pointing along +z). Thus the potential outside the sphere is

  φ(r,θ) = –(vB) r cosθ + (vB)(R³/r²) cosθ  (for r ≥ R).

Step 3. Find the Surface Charge Density

The surface charge density σ is determined from the discontinuity of the electric field at the surface. In particular, if n̂ is the outward normal, Gauss’s law tells us

  σ = ε₀ (E_out · n̂ – E_in · n̂).

Since the electric field inside the conductor is zero (E_in = 0), we get

  σ = ε₀ (E_out · n̂).

But the electric field is related to the potential by

  E = –∇φ.

On the surface (r = R) the outward normal is e_r so that

  E_r = –∂φ/∂r evaluated at r = R.

Let us differentiate φ(r,θ):

  φ(r,θ) = vB cosθ [–r + (R³/r²)].

Differentiate with respect to r:
  d/dr (–r) = –1,
  d/dr (R³/r²) = –2R³/r³.
Thus,
  ∂φ/∂r = vB cosθ ( –1 – 2R³/r³).

Evaluating at r = R:
  ∂φ/∂r |_(r=R) = vB cosθ (–1 – 2) = –3 vB cosθ.

Therefore, the radial electric field just outside is
  E_r = – (∂φ/∂r) = 3 vB cosθ.

Now by Gauss’s law, the surface charge density is
  σ = ε₀ E_r = 3 ε₀ vB cosθ.

But take care with the sign. Let us reexamine the physical situation: in the sphere’s rest frame, E′ = vB e_z. In a conductor placed in an external electric field, the induced charges arrange so that the field inside is zero. For an external field E₀ in the +z direction, it is known that the solution yields

  σ(θ) = 3 ε₀ E₀ cosθ.

Substituting E₀ = vB, one finds 
  σ(θ) = 3 ε₀ vB cosθ.

However, note that in going back to the lab frame the signs remain the same to lowest order, and the interpretation of the locations of positive and negative induced charges must be consistent with the effective motional field. Recall that in the lab frame the motional electric field experienced by the charges is given by

  E_mot = –v × B = –vB e_z.

Thus, if one were to analyze the problem in the lab frame, the induced charges would be such that the total effective field inside the sphere cancels; that is, the induced potential would be equivalent to applying an external field of –vB e_z. In this case the induced surface charge density would be

  σ(θ) = 3ε₀ (–vB) cosθ = –3 ε₀ vB cosθ.

The point is this: One must be careful with the sign convention. In the sphere’s rest frame we “see” an external field E′ = vB e_z, but this is not the field acting on the charges inside the conductor—instead, the conductor must produce an induced potential so that the net field is zero. One can either work entirely in the sphere’s rest frame or in the lab frame. A careful treatment shows that the actual induced surface charge density (as measured in the lab frame) is given by

  σ(θ) = –3 ε₀ vB cosθ.

Physical interpretation:
• At the “north pole” (θ = 0, i.e. along +z) the surface charge density is negative: σ = –3 ε₀ vB.
• At the “south pole” (θ = π, i.e. along –z) the surface charge density is positive: σ = +3 ε₀ vB.
This is exactly what one expects if the net motional field is E_mot = – v × B = –vB e_z (i.e. pointing in the –z direction) in the lab frame.

Step 4. Final Answer

Thus the induced surface charge density on the conducting sphere, to lowest order in v/c, is

  σ(θ) = – 3 ε₀ vB cosθ.

Final Answer in Latex boxed format:

  \[\boxed{\sigma(\theta) = -3\,\epsilon_0\,v\,B\,\cos\theta}\]

solution:
We wish to find the electric field E and the electrostatic potential V everywhere in space for a uniformly charged sphere of radius R that carries a total charge Q. The charge density is

  ρ = Q/(volume) = Q/( (4/3)πR³ ).

We determine the fields by applying Gauss’s law and then find the potential by integrating the electric field, taking V(∞) = 0.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Find the Electric Field

Case 1: For r ≥ R (Outside the sphere)

For a spherical Gaussian surface of radius r ≥ R, all the charge Q is enclosed. By Gauss’s law,
  ∮ E · dA = Q_enc/ε₀      (1)

Since the field is radial and constant in magnitude over the surface,
  E(r) · 4πr² = Q/ε₀
  ⇒ E(r) = Q/(4πε₀r²)      (2)

Thus, for r ≥ R:
  E_out(r) = (1/(4πε₀)) (Q/r²), directed radially outward.

Case 2: For r < R (Inside the sphere)

A spherical Gaussian surface of radius r (with r < R) encloses only part of the charge. The enclosed charge is
  Q_enc = ρ · (volume of sphere of radius r) = [Q/(4/3 π R³)] · (4/3 π r³) = Q (r³/R³).

Using Gauss’s law,
  E(r) · 4πr² = Q_enc/ε₀ = Q(r³/R³)/ε₀
  ⇒ E(r) = Q r/(4πε₀ R³)    (3)

Thus, for r < R:
  E_in(r) = (1/(4πε₀)) (Q r/R³), directed radially outward.

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. Find the Electrostatic Potential

We define the potential by the relation
  V(b) - V(a) = -∫ₐᵇ E · dl.
It is conventional to choose V(∞) = 0.

Case 1: For r ≥ R (Outside the sphere)

The electric field is that of a point charge, so the potential is found by integrating from infinity to r:
  V(r) = -∫∞ʳ (Q/(4πε₀ r′²)) dr′
     = -[Q/(4πε₀)] ( -1/r′ ) |∞ʳ
     = Q/(4πε₀ r).

Thus, for r ≥ R:
  V_out(r) = Q/(4πε₀ r).

Case 2: For r < R (Inside the sphere)

For points inside the sphere, we must integrate in two parts:
  (a) from infinity to R (outside the sphere),
  (b) from R to r (inside the sphere).

We already have V(R) from the outside result:
  V(R) = Q/(4πε₀ R).

Now, for r < R, choose the radial path (with dl = dr′). The potential difference from R to r inside is
  V(r) - V(R) = -∫Rʳ E_in(r′) dr′
Since inside E_in(r′) = (1/(4πε₀)) (Q r′/R³), we have
  V(r) - V(R) = -∫Rʳ (Q/(4πε₀)) (r′/R³) dr′.

Calculate the integral:
  ∫_R^r r′ dr′ = [r′²/2]_R^r = (r² - R²)/2.
Thus,
  V(r) - V(R) = - (Q/(4πε₀ R³)) · (r² - R²)/2.
Rearrange to write V(r):
  V(r) = V(R) + (Q/(4πε₀ R³)) · (R² - r²)/(2)
     = Q/(4πε₀ R) + (Q/(8πε₀ R³)) (R² - r²).

It is often convenient to combine the terms:
  Multiply Q/(4πε₀ R) by 2R²/2R² so that we have a common denominator:
  V(r) = Q/(8πε₀ R³) [2R² + (R² - r²)]
     = Q/(8πε₀ R³) [3R² - r²].

Thus, for r < R:
  V_in(r) = (Q/(8πε₀ R³)) (3R² - r²).

Alternatively, one can write the same result as:
  V_in(r) = Q/(4πε₀) · (3R² - r²)/(2R³).

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

The electric field is given by:

  For r ≥ R:
    E(r) = (1/(4πε₀)) (Q/r²) (radially outward).

  For r < R:
    E(r) = (1/(4πε₀)) (Q r/R³) (radially outward).

And the electrostatic potential (with V(∞) = 0) is:

  For r ≥ R:
    V(r) = Q/(4πε₀ r).

  For r < R:
    V(r) = Q/(4πε₀) (3R² - r²)/(2R³).

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer in Latex Boxed Format

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
 \text{For } r\ge R:\quad &E(r) = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_0\,r^2},\quad V(r) = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_0\,r},\\[1mm]
 \text{For } r< R:\quad &E(r) = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\,\frac{r}{R^3},\quad V(r) = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\,\frac{3R^2 - r^2}{2R^3}.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We wish to find the electric field E and the potential ϕ for a uniformly charged sphere of radius R and constant charge density ρ. The total charge is

  Q = ρ · (4πR³/3).

We will use Gauss’s law to find the electric field first and then obtain the potential by integration, using the condition ϕ → 0 as r → ∞.

───────────────────────────── Step 1. Electric Field via Gauss’s Law

Gauss’s law states that

  ∮ E · dA = Q_enc/ε₀.

Because of spherical symmetry the electric field is radial. We analyze two regions:

1. Outside the sphere (r ≥ R):

  Take a spherical Gaussian surface of radius r. The enclosed charge is Q, so:
    E(r) · 4πr² = Q/ε₀  ⟹  E(r) = Q/(4πε₀ r²).
  Thus, for r ≥ R:
    E_out(r) = (Q/(4πε₀ r²)) r̂.

2. Inside the sphere (r < R):

  For a Gaussian sphere of radius r (< R) the enclosed charge is
    Q_enc = ρ · (4πr³/3).
  Then Gauss’s law gives:
    E(r) · 4πr² = (ρ·(4πr³/3))/ε₀  ⟹  E(r) = ρr/(3ε₀).
  In terms of Q, since ρ = Q/(4πR³/3) = 3Q/(4πR³), we can also write
    E(r) = (Q r)/(4πε₀R³).
  Thus, for r < R:
    E_in(r) = (ρr/(3ε₀)) r̂ = (Q r)/(4πε₀R³) r̂.

───────────────────────────── Step 2. Electric Potential

The potential is given by

  ϕ(r) = -∫₍∞₎^r E · dr′,

with the boundary condition ϕ(∞) = 0. The integration must be done in parts depending on whether r is inside or outside the sphere.

A. For r ≥ R, the entire integration is performed in a region where the field is given by the external form:

  ϕ(r) = -∫₍∞₎^r [Q/(4πε₀ (r′)²)] dr′
      = -[Q/(4πε₀)] ∫₍∞₎^r (1/(r′)²) dr′.
  The integral ∫ (1/(r′)²) dr′ = -1/r′, so:

  ϕ(r) = -[Q/(4πε₀)] [(-1/r + 0)] = Q/(4πε₀r).

Thus, for r ≥ R:

  ϕ_out(r) = Q/(4πε₀ r).

B. For r < R, the potential is found by first going from infinity to R (where r ≥ R, and we already know the potential) and then from R to r (inside the sphere):

  ϕ(r) = ϕ(R) - ∫₍R₎^r E_in(r′) dr′.
  But we have
    ϕ(R) = Q/(4πε₀R)
  and for the inner region:
    E_in(r') = ρr'/(3ε₀).

Thus,
  ϕ(r) = Q/(4πε₀R) - ∫₍R₎^r [ρr′/(3ε₀)] dr′.

Evaluate the integral:
  ∫₍R₎^r r′ dr′ = [r′²/2]₍R₎^r = (r² - R²)/2.
So,
  ϕ(r) = Q/(4πε₀R) - [ρ/(3ε₀)]·[(r² - R²)/2]
      = Q/(4πε₀R) - [ρ (r² - R²)]/(6ε₀).

It is sometimes preferable to express the answer entirely in terms of Q and R. Recall that
  ρ = 3Q/(4πR³).
Substitute this into the expression:
  ϕ(r) = Q/(4πε₀R) - [ (3Q/(4πR³)) (r² - R²)]/(6ε₀)
      = Q/(4πε₀R) - [Q (r² - R²)]/(8πε₀R³).

It is then common to rewrite the potential in the form:
  ϕ(r) = Q/(4πε₀R) [ 1 - (r² - R²)/(2R²) ]
      = Q/(4πε₀R) [ (3/2) - (r²/(2R²)) ].

Thus, for r < R:
  ϕ_in(r) = Q/(4πε₀R) [ (3/2) - (r²/(2R²)) ].

───────────────────────────── Final Answers

(a) The electric field is given by

  r ≥ R: E(r) = (Q/(4πε₀ r²)) r̂,
  r < R: E(r) = (ρ r/(3ε₀)) r̂ = (Q r/(4πε₀ R³)) r̂.

(b) The electric potential is

  r ≥ R: ϕ(r) = Q/(4πε₀ r),
  r < R: ϕ(r) = Q/(4πε₀R) [ (3/2) - (r²/(2R²)) ].

───────────────────────────── Final Answer

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad &\mathbf{E}(r) =
\begin{cases}
\displaystyle \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_0\,r^2}\,\hat{r}, & r\ge R, \\[1mm]
\displaystyle \frac{Q\,r}{4\pi\epsilon_0\,R^3}\,\hat{r}, & r< R,
\end{cases} \\
\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad &\phi(r)=
\begin{cases}
\displaystyle \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_0\,r}, & r\ge R, \\[1mm]
\displaystyle \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_0\,R} \left[\frac{3}{2} - \frac{r^2}{2R^2}\right], & r< R.
\end{cases}
\end{aligned}
}
\]

solution:
We start from a hydrogen‐atom–like model: a light particle (mass m and charge q) orbits a fixed heavy particle (charge –q) in a circular orbit of radius R. Because the particle is accelerating, it radiates energy. The loss of energy causes the orbit to shrink. In classical electrodynamics the radiated power (Larmor formula) is

  P = (q²a²)/(6π ε₀ c³)

where a is the magnitude of the acceleration. For our circular orbit the centripetal acceleration is

  a = v²/R.

But Newton’s second law for circular motion tells us

  m v²/R = F = k_e (q²/R²),

with the Coulomb constant k_e = 1/(4π ε₀). Thus

  v² = (k_e q²)/(m R)

and

  a = v²/R = k_e q²/(m R²).

Substitute a into the Larmor formula:

  P = (q²/(6π ε₀ c³)) · (k_e² q⁴/(m² R⁴))
    = (k_e² q⁶)/(6π ε₀ c³ m² R⁴).

Since k_e = 1/(4π ε₀), one has k_e² = 1/(16π² ε₀²), so

  P = (q⁶)/(6π ε₀ c³ m² R⁴) · 1/(16π² ε₀²)
    = q⁶/(96 π³ ε₀³ c³ m² R⁴).

The total (mechanical) energy of the orbit in a Coulomb potential is

  E = K + U = (½ mv²) – (k_e q²/R).

For a circular orbit one finds from the virial theorem that K = –½ U so that

  E = – (k_e q²)/(2R).

As the particle radiates, its energy decreases. We assume the energy loss is entirely due to radiation, so that

  dE/dt = –P.

But E is a function of R so that

  dE/dt = (dE/dR)(dR/dt).

Since

  E(R) = – (k_e q²)/(2R),  dE/dR = (k_e q²)/(2R²).

Thus

  (k_e q²)/(2R²) (dR/dt) = –P
    ⇒ dR/dt = –[2R²/(k_e q²)] P.

Now substitute for P:

  dR/dt = –[2R²/(k_e q²)] · [q⁶/(96 π³ ε₀³ c³ m² R⁴)]
       = –[2q⁶/(96 π³ ε₀³ c³ m² k_e q²)] · (1/R²)
       = –[q⁴/(48 π³ ε₀³ c³ m² k_e)] · 1/R².

Since k_e = 1/(4π ε₀), we have 1/k_e = 4π ε₀, so

  dR/dt = –[q⁴/(48 π³ ε₀³ c³ m²)]·(4π ε₀)/R²
    = –[4π ε₀ q⁴/(48 π³ ε₀³ c³ m²)]·(1/R²)
    = –[q⁴/(12 π² ε₀² c³ m²)]·(1/R²).

Thus, the differential equation for R(t) is

  dR/dt = –A/R²   with A = q⁴/(12 π² ε₀² c³ m²).

We now wish to know the time T required for the radius to shrink from R (initial) to R/2. Separating variables,

  dR/dt = –A/R²  ⟹ R² dR = –A dt.

Integrate both sides: when t = 0, R = R, and at t = T, R = R/2. Thus

  ∫[R to R/2] R² dR = –A ∫[0 to T] dt.

First, compute the integral on the left:

  ∫[R/2 to R] R² dR = [R³/3] evaluated from R/2 to R
            = (R³/3) – ((R/2)³/3)
            = (R³/3) – (R³/(24))
            = R³ (1/3 – 1/24) = R³ ((8 – 1)/24)
            = (7R³)/(24).

Thus,

  (7R³)/(24) = A T    ⟹ T = (7R³)/(24 A).

Now substitute back for A:

  T = (7R³)/(24) · [12 π² ε₀² c³ m²/q⁴]
    = (7R³ 12 π² ε₀² c³ m²)/(24 q⁴)
    = (7 π² ε₀² c³ m² R³)/(2 q⁴).

Thus, the time required for the radius to decay from R to R/2 is

  T = (7 π² ε₀² c³ m² R³)/(2 q⁴).

Finally, we box the result:

  \[\boxed{\frac{7\pi^2\epsilon_0^2 c^3 m^2 R^3}{2q^4}}\]

solution:
We wish to calculate the work done by an external agent in moving a charge q from infinity to the center of a hollow conducting spherical shell. (We shall neglect the “self‐energy” of bringing an isolated point charge in; we are computing the interaction energy that is assembled during the process.)

In the final state the initially neutral conductor has rearranged its free charges so that:
 – a total charge –q is induced on the inner surface (which, since the cavity is spherical, is distributed uniformly on the spherical surface of radius R), and 
 – a charge +q appears on the outer surface (distributed uniformly on the spherical surface of radius R + t, where t is the shell’s thickness).

A basic fact about a uniformly charged spherical shell is that the potential inside it (i.e. at all points inside the shell) is constant and equal to that at its (spherical) surface. (We take the usual constant in Coulomb’s Law as k = 1/(4πε₀).)

Thus, the potentials at the center of the sphere due to the two induced charge distributions are as follows:

1. The inner surface (charge –q uniformly on a spherical surface of radius R) produces at the center a potential 
  V_inner = (k × (–q))/R = –(kq)/R.
2. The outer surface (charge +q uniformly on a spherical surface of radius R + t) produces at the center a potential 
  V_outer = (k × (+q))/(R+t) = kq/(R+t).

Note that the free charge q that we brought in also “sees” these potentials due to the induced charges. (One may show, via a careful assembly of the charge, that the relevant work done to bring the charge from infinity is one‐half the “interaction energy”, namely ½ qV, where V is the potential at the location of the q due only to the induced charges.)

Thus the net induced potential at the center is
  V_ind = V_inner + V_outer = –(kq)/R + kq/(R+t).

Then the work done by the external agent is given by

  W = ½·q·V_ind
    = ½·q·[ –(kq)/R + kq/(R+t) ]
    = (kq²/2) [1/(R+t) – 1/R].

Recalling that k = 1/(4πε₀), we may write

  W = (q²/(8πε₀)) [ 1/(R+t) – 1/R ].

A few comments are in order:
 • Notice that if the shell were infinitely thin (t = 0) the potential from the two surfaces would cancel (since then R + t = R) and the work would be zero. Indeed, when a very thin closed conductor has no separate “internal” and “external” surfaces (when the hole is not there) the field inside is zero and there is no net work required.
 • If t > 0 then clearly 1/(R+t) < 1/R. Thus the bracket is negative, meaning that the work done by the external agent is negative. (Physically, this means that the induced charges set up an attractive force which would do positive work on the charge. To insert the charge slowly, the agent must “control” the motion, and ends up doing “negative work” – that is, energy is actually released by the system.)

Thus, our final answer is

  W = (q²/(8πε₀)) [ 1/(R+t) – 1/R ].

In boxed form our final answer is

  \[
  \boxed{W =\frac{q^2}{8\pi\varepsilon_0}\left(\frac{1}{R+t}-\frac{1}{R}\right)}
  \]

solution:
We wish to find the interaction energy (or potential energy) of a point charge q located in vacuum at a distance x from a flat interface with a semi‐infinite dielectric medium, where the dielectric constant is K. (The “distance x” means the point charge is at a distance x from the interface; we imagine the dielectric fills, say, z < 0 while the charge is at z = x > 0.)

Step 1. Using the Method of Images

For many problems involving interfaces between media, one may use an image–charge method to represent the effect of the boundary. In the case of a charge q in vacuum (permittivity ε₀) near a dielectric (permittivity ε = Kε₀) the potential in the region of the charge (i.e. in the vacuum) is given by the same potential as the combination of:
 • The real charge q at z = x,
 • An image charge q′ placed at the mirror point z = –x.

The magnitude of the image charge is given by

  q′ = (1 – K)/(1 + K) q.

Note that when K = 1 (i.e. when the dielectric constant is the same as the vacuum), q′ = 0 and there is no interface effect. On the other hand, for K → ∞ (a perfect conductor) q′ → –q, which is the familiar image–charge for a grounded conducting plane.

Step 2. Calculating the Interaction Energy

The interaction energy of a charge with induced charges (or with its image) is given by one half the product of the charge times the potential at its location due to the image charge. (The factor ½ is needed so that we do not count the “self‐interaction” energy twice.) Thus

  U = ½ · q · V_image,

where V_image is the potential at the location of the real charge (at z = x) due to q′ located at z = –x.

Since the potential in vacuum of a point charge is given by

  V = q/(4πε₀ r),
  
the distance between q at (0, 0, x) and q′ at (0, 0, –x) is

  r = 2x.

Thus

  V_image = q′/(4πε₀ (2x)) = q′/(8πε₀ x).

So the interaction energy becomes

  U = ½ · (q · q′/(8πε₀ x)) = (q · q′)/(16πε₀ x).

Now substitute the expression for q′:

  U = (q/(16πε₀ x)) · [ (1 – K)/(1 + K) q ] = (q²/(16πε₀ x)) · (1 – K)/(1 + K).

Step 3. Final Answer

Thus, the potential energy of the point charge is

  U =  (q²/(16πε₀ x)) · ((1 – K)/(1 + K)).

In boxed LaTeX form, the answer is:

  \[
\boxed{U = \frac{q^2}{16\pi \varepsilon_0 x}\,\frac{1-K}{1+K}}
\]

solution:
We wish to hold in equilibrium a configuration in which the “upper” half‐space (z > 0) is filled with a linear dielectric of constant ε₁ and the “lower” half‐space (z < 0) with one of constant ε₂, while two point charges are present:
  • a charge –q located at (0, 0, a) (in the z > 0 region),
  • a charge +q located at (0, 0, –a) (in the z < 0 region).

Because the dielectric constant is different on either side of the interface the usual Coulomb law must be modified by the boundary conditions at z = 0. In fact, the standard method‐of‐images solution (see, e.g., Jackson’s Classical Electrodynamics) tells us that when a point charge is located in one dielectric, the potential in that region is given by a “real” charge and an “image” charge (which mimics the effect of polarization induced at the boundary). Moreover, when a charge lies in the “other” medium the potential seen in our region of interest (here, z > 0) is “transmitted” in a way that is equivalent to having an effective charge of a modified strength.

Let us now “build up” the field that the –q charge feels. (When computing a force by the method of images one must be careful to omit the spurious “self‐force” coming from the image corresponding to a given charge’s own field. However, when one is computing the force on a charge due to the induced surface “charge” – which in the method‐of‐images solution appears as an image charge – it is correct to include the interaction between the real charge and the other “images”.)

Step 1. Contribution from the dielectric interface induced by a charge in the same region

A point charge Q located in medium 1 (z > 0) produces a potential in that medium that is exactly reproduced by a “real” charge Q at the physical position and by an image charge Q₁ᵢ placed at the mirror point (0, 0, –a) with
  Q₁ᵢ = Q × ( (ε₁ – ε₂)/(ε₁ + ε₂) ).
In our problem the charge in medium 1 is –q. Thus there is an image (which is a mathematical tool giving the effect of the polarization of the interface) with
  (–q)₁ᵢ = –q · ( (ε₁ – ε₂)/(ε₁ + ε₂) ).
This image is “located” at (0, 0, –a) and, when calculating forces on the real charge –q, its contribution must be included (even though it is “self‐like” the procedure is standard in such problems).

Step 2. Contribution from the charge in the other medium

A charge located in medium 2 (z < 0) affects the region z > 0 in a “transmitted” way. The standard result (which may be derived by matching boundary conditions on the potential and displacement fields at z = 0) is that the field in medium 1 from a point charge Q in medium 2 is equivalent to that produced by a “transmission image” located at the same position as the real charge, but with an “effective” charge
  Q₂ₜ = Q × ( 2ε₁/(ε₁ + ε₂) ).
In our problem this charge is +q at (0, 0, –a), so its contribution in medium 1 is equivalent to having an effective charge
  q₂ₜ = (2ε₁/(ε₁ + ε₂))·q,
also at (0, 0, –a).

Step 3. Combining the Contributions

Thus, as seen in medium 1 the effective charges (all “located” at (0,0,–a)) that act on our real charge –q at (0,0,a) are:
  (i) Its own image:  –q · ( (ε₁ – ε₂)/(ε₁ + ε₂) ),
  (ii) The transmitted image for the charge +q:  (2ε₁q/(ε₁ + ε₂)).
Their sum is:
  Q_eff = [2ε₁q – q (ε₁ – ε₂)]/(ε₁ + ε₂) 
      = [(2ε₁ – ε₁ + ε₂)q]/(ε₁ + ε₂)
      = ((ε₁ + ε₂)q)/(ε₁ + ε₂)
      = q.
That is, surprisingly (or elegantly), the two contributions “combine” so that as far as the field in z > 0 is concerned the effective charge at the mirror point (0,0,–a) is exactly +q.

Step 4. Compute the Force

Now the real charge –q is at (0,0,a) while the effective charge q is at (0,0,–a). They lie along the z axis and are separated by a distance
  R = (a – (–a)) = 2a.
In medium 1 the Coulomb law tells us that the electric field of a point charge q is given by
  E = (1/(4π ε₁)) (q/R²) (in the radial direction from the charge).
Thus the electric field at (0,0,a) due to the effective charge q at (0,0,–a) is
  E_eff = (1/(4π ε₁))·(q/(2a)²)·ẑ 
      = (1/(4π ε₁))·(q/(4a²))·ẑ 
      = (q/(16π ε₁ a²))·ẑ.
Since the real charge is –q, the force on it is
  F = (–q) E_eff
    = –q (q/(16π ε₁a²)) ẑ
    = – (q²/(16π ε₁a²)) ẑ.
That is, the force (due to the other charge plus the induced charges on the interface) on –q points in the –z direction (downward).

Step 5. What Must Be Done

To hold the –q charge fixed at (0, 0, a) (i.e. to counteract the downward force) one must apply an equal and opposite (upward) force. Thus, the external force required is
  F_ext = + (q²/(16π ε₁a²)) ẑ.

Final Answer in a Box:

  We then have

    boxed{ F_ext = + \frac{q^2}{16\pi\,\epsilon_1\,a^2}\,\hat z . }

Thus, the force one must exert (directed upward) on the negative charge to hold it at rest is

\[
\boxed{\vec{F}_{\rm applied} = \frac{q^2}{16 \pi \epsilon_1 a^2}\,\hat{z}}
\]

solution:
We will solve the problem using the method of images. The idea is to replace the influence of the grounded infinite plane by an image charge of equal magnitude but opposite sign placed symmetrically with respect to the plane. Suppose the plane lies in the z = 0 plane and the real charge q = 2 μC is located at z = +a (with a = 10 cm = 0.1 m). Then, place an image charge −q at z = −a. With this setup, we now answer each part.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. (a) Total Induced Charge

The induced surface charge density on the plane is such that the potential on the plane becomes zero. One can show (by integrating the induced charge density) that the total induced charge on the plane is equal to the negative of the real charge. Thus,
  Q_ind = −q = −2 μC.

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. (b) Force on the Charge q

The force on the real charge is due solely to the electric field produced by the image charge. The separation between the charge q (at z = +a) and the image charge (at z = −a) is 2a. By Coulomb’s law the magnitude of the force is

  F = (1/(4πε₀))·(q²/(2a)²) = (1/(4πε₀))·(q²/(4a²)).

Inserting q = 2×10⁻⁶ C and a = 0.1 m, and with 1/(4πε₀) ≈ 9×10⁹ N·m²/C², we have

  F = (9×10⁹)·((2×10⁻⁶)²/(4×(0.1)²)).
  Compute (2×10⁻⁶)² = 4×10⁻¹² and (0.1)² = 0.01; then
  F = (9×10⁹)·(4×10⁻¹²/(4×0.01))
    = (9×10⁹)·(4×10⁻¹²/0.04)
    = (9×10⁹)·(1×10⁻¹⁰)
    = 0.9 N.

The force is attractive; it pulls the positive charge toward the plane (i.e. in the −z direction).

──────────────────────────────
Step 3. (c) Work Required to Remove the Charge

To slowly remove the charge to infinity, we must do work against the attractive force. The potential at the location of the charge q due to the image charge is

  φ_image = (1/(4πε₀))·(−q/(2a)).

However, when computing the interaction energy for systems where the field is produced by several charges, one must remember to include a factor of ½ (to avoid double counting interactions). Hence the potential energy of the system (taking the real charge interacting with the image charge) is

  U = (1/2)·q·φ_image = (1/2)·q·[−q/(4πε₀ (2a))]
    = −q²/(16πε₀a).

When the charge is at infinity the interaction energy is zero. Thus, the work required to remove the charge (i.e. to bring the energy from U to zero) is

  W = −U = q²/(16πε₀a).

Let’s plug in the numbers:
  q² = (2×10⁻⁶ C)² = 4×10⁻¹² C²,
  a = 0.1 m,
  and 1/(4πε₀) = 9×10⁹ N·m²/C².

Then,
  16πε₀a = 16π×8.854×10⁻¹² F/m × 0.1 m.
A quick estimate gives a denominator of roughly 4.45×10⁻¹¹. Therefore,

  W ≈ (4×10⁻¹²)/(4.45×10⁻¹¹) ≈ 0.09 J.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

Now we summarize our answers:

 (a) The total induced charge on the sheet is  Q_ind = −2 μC.

 (b) The force on the charge is  F = (q²/(4πε₀·4a²)) ≈ 0.9 N (directed toward the plane).

 (c) The work required to move the charge from a distance a to infinity is  W = q²/(16πε₀a) ≈ 0.09 J.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer in Latex Box

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
&\text{(a) } Q_{\text{ind}} = -2\,\mu C, \\
&\text{(b) } F = \frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\frac{q^2}{(2a)^2} \approx 0.9\,\text{N},\quad \text{(directed toward the plane)}, \\
&\text{(c) } W = \frac{q^2}{16\pi\epsilon_0 a} \approx 0.09\,\text{J}.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We will show that one acceptable answer is to choose the radius of the sphere as
  a = d/8
so that when the sphere is grounded the two charges (located at x = –d and x = +d) “feel” no net force. Then if the same sphere is instead held at a constant potential V the extra field (which comes in as a monopole term) produces on each charge a force of magnitude

  F = (QV)/(8d)
directed away from the center of the sphere.

In the remainder of the answer we describe one way to arrive at these results.

──────────────────────────────
Step‐by‐step explanation

Let the two equal point–charges Q lie on the x–axis at positions x = –d and x = +d. A sphere (a conductor) of radius a is centered at the origin. (We assume a < d so that the charges lie outside the sphere.) The problem is studied in two parts.

──────────────────────────────
Part (a): Grounded sphere and zero net force

1. When the sphere is grounded the electric potential on its surface is forced to be zero. In the presence of an external point charge a “method of images” is available. (Because our system is linear, if there are more than one external charges the solution is obtained by superposition.) In the case of one external charge Q at a distance r₀ from the center (with r₀ > a) the potential outside the sphere (r ≥ a) may be obtained by “replacing” the induced surface charge by an image charge
  Q′ = –(a/r₀)Q
located at a point r′ = (a²/r₀) along the line joining the center with the charge. (One may consult a textbook for details.)

2. In our problem there are two charges (at –d and +d) so that by linearity the full potential for r ≥ a is the sum of the two “ground–sphere” solutions. (That is, each external charge “sees” its own image and the image due to the other charge.) Thus one may represent the effect of the conducting sphere by “placing” inside the sphere two image charges:
  For the charge at x = +d, an image Q₂′ = –(a/d)Q at x = a²/d.
  For the charge at x = –d, an image Q₁′ = –(a/d)Q at x = –a²/d.

3. Although the method of images is used to reproduce the correct potential for r ≥ a, the key point is that the electric field in the region of the two external charges is exactly that produced by the two “real” charges Q and the two image charges. (In computing the force on, say, the charge at x = +d one omits its own “self–field”.)

4. Now, choose one of the charges – say the one at x = +d. Its full force is the sum of three contributions:
  (a) The repulsion from the other real charge Q at x = –d. The separation is 2d so that by Coulomb’s law this gives a force of magnitude
    F₁ = kQ²/(2d)² = kQ²/(4d²)
directed to the right (i.e. away from the charge at –d).

  (b) The force from the image charge Q₁′ = –(a/d)Q at x = –a²/d. Its separation from the charge at x = +d is
    R₁ = d + (a²/d) = (d² + a²)/d.
Since the image is negative, the result is an attractive force of magnitude
    F₂ = k Q [aQ/d] / R₁² = k a Q²/d / [(d²+a²)²/d²] = k a Q² d/(d²+a²)²,
directed to the left (toward the negative x–direction).

  (c) The force from the image charge associated with the charge at +d itself, Q₂′ = –(a/d)Q, which is located at x = a²/d. Its separation from the external charge (at x = +d) is
    R₂ = d – (a²/d) = (d² – a²)/d.
Again, being negative, the force is attractive. Its magnitude is
    F₃ = k Q [aQ/d] / R₂² = k a Q²/d / [(d²–a²)²/d²] = k a Q² d/(d²–a²)²,
directed to the left.

5. So the net force on the charge at x = +d is
  F_net = [F₁ (to the right)] – [F₂ + F₃ (to the left)].
Setting F_net = 0 gives
  kQ²/(4d²) = k a Q² d/(d²+a²)² + k a Q² d/(d²–a²)².
Canceling the common factor kQ² and multiplying through by d² we obtain
  1/4 = x [1/(1+x²)² + 1/(1–x²)²],
with the substitution x = a/d.

6. One now finds (by a short numerical search, say) that the solution of
  1/4 = x [1/(1+x²)² + 1/(1–x²)²]
is
  x = 1/8.
That is, a/d = 1/8 or a = d/8.

Thus, if the sphere is grounded the induced charges produce exactly the right extra forces to cancel the repulsion between the two Q’s provided that the sphere has radius

  a = d/8.

──────────────────────────────
Part (b): Sphere at a potential V

When the sphere is held at zero potential the solution has the form we have just discussed. Now suppose the sphere is instead raised to a constant potential V (by “charging it up” ). Because the Laplace equation is linear one may write the solution as
  Φ_total = Φ_grounded + Φ_extra,
where Φ_grounded is the potential we obtained with the sphere grounded (i.e. with zero potential on its surface) and Φ_extra is a solution of Laplace’s equation which is chosen so that the total potential on the surface is V. (Also, one is free to add any constant since its gradient is zero.)

A very convenient choice is to take
  Φ_extra = V,
i.e. simply add a constant V everywhere. (Since the electric field is –∇Φ, the extra constant does not produce any additional field and hence does not alter the induced “image‐charges” that produced our cancellation in part (a).) However, one must be a little careful: if we simply add a constant then though the potential on the sphere becomes V, the potential everywhere is raised by V but the electric field (and so the forces) remain exactly as in the grounded case.

But here the change in “charge on the sphere” (by charging it to potential V) is equivalent to adding a harmonic “monopole” solution that does contribute to the electric field. In fact, an alternative (and indeed standard) way to produce a solution which is V on the sphere is to add the potential of a point charge at the origin that produces a “monopole” potential. (In our problem since the sphere is a conductor the net field outside is in fact the superposition of the solution with a grounded sphere plus the potential due to a charge placed at the center whose value is adjusted so that the sphere attains the potential V.)

In practice one shows that the extra potential outside may be written as a monopole term:
  Φ_monopole = V (a/r).
One easily checks that on the surface (r = a) Φ_monopole = V. (Notice that if V is constant, then its gradient is zero; however, the monopole term V(a/r) is not constant and produces an extra field.) Thus the complete potential is
  Φ_total = Φ_grounded + V(a/r).

Since the force on any external charge is given by –q∇Φ, the contribution coming from the added constant is nil; the only extra force comes from the monopole portion V(a/r). (This is the field that must be added in order to “charge up” the sphere, and which is responsible for the fact that the sphere now has extra net charge.) In particular, at the location of either external charge (which is at a distance r = d from the origin) the extra potential gives an electric field
  E_extra = –d/dr [V(a/r)] = V a/r².
At r = d this is
  E_extra = V a/(d²).
Since all the other contributions (the mutual repulsion of the two charges and the effect of the induced charges that was arranged to cancel it in part (a)) cancel when a = d/8, the net force on, say, the charge at x = +d is now entirely due to the monopole term:
  F = Q E_extra = Q [V a/(d²)].
Using a = d/8 we obtain
  F = QV/(8d).

Note that the extra force is directed radially outward (i.e. away from the sphere’s center) at x = +d (and radially inward at x = –d) so that in both cases the force pushes the charges away from the center.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

Thus an acceptable answer is:

(a) In order that the forces on the two charges cancel when the sphere is grounded, one must have 
  a = d/8.

(b) When the sphere (of radius a = d/8) is instead held at a potential V, each charge Q experiences an extra force
  F = QV/(8d)
directed radially outward from the sphere.

We now give the final answer in the requested boxed LaTeX format:

\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)} \quad & a = \frac{d}{8} \,,\\[1mm]
\text{(b)} \quad & F = \frac{QV}{8d} \quad \text{(directed radially outward from the sphere’s center)}\,.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We wish to calculate the time required for the electron’s orbit to decay from an initial radius r₀ (the Bohr radius) down to zero under the continuous loss of energy by radiation. We assume that during each revolution the energy loss is small compared to the total energy so that we may treat the orbit as nearly circular at all times.

Step 1. Obtain the energy in a circular orbit

In a Coulomb potential the balance of centripetal and Coulomb forces gives

   mₑv²/r = e²/(4πε₀r²)

so that

   v = √(e²/(4πε₀ mₑ r)).

For such a circular orbit the kinetic energy is

   K = ½ mₑv² = e²/(8πε₀r).

The potential energy of the electron is

   U = −e²/(4πε₀r).

Thus the total energy is

   E(r) = K + U = −e²/(8πε₀r).

Step 2. Find the power radiated

A charged particle undergoing acceleration radiates energy according to the Larmor formula:

   P = (e²a²)/(6πε₀c³).

For circular motion the acceleration is centripetal, given by

   a = v²/r.

Using the balance equation already found,

   v² = e²/(4πε₀ mₑ r),

thus

   a = e²/(4πε₀ mₑ r²).

Then

   a² = e⁴/(16π²ε₀²mₑ²r⁴).

Substitute this into the Larmor formula:

   P = (e²/(6πε₀c³))·(e⁴/(16π²ε₀²mₑ²r⁴))
    = e⁶/(96π³ε₀³ mₑ²c³ r⁴).

Step 3. Relate energy loss to the rate of change of the orbit radius

The rate of energy loss is the power:
   dE/dt = −P.

Since

   E(r) = −e²/(8πε₀r),

its derivative with respect to r is

   dE/dr = e²/(8πε₀r²).

By the chain rule,
   dE/dt = (dE/dr)(dr/dt).

Thus,
   (e²/(8πε₀r²)) (dr/dt) = − e⁶/(96π³ε₀³ mₑ²c³ r⁴).

We can now solve for dr/dt:
   dr/dt = − [e⁶/(96π³ε₀³ mₑ²c³r⁴)]·[8πε₀r²/e²].

Simplify the constants step by step:
  – The constants e⁶/e² give e⁴.
  – 8πε₀ divided by 96π³ε₀³ gives (8/(96))·(1/π²)·(1/ε₀²) = (1/12)·(1/(π²ε₀²)).
  – The r dependence: r²/r⁴ = 1/r².

Thus we obtain
   dr/dt = – [e⁴/(12π²ε₀² mₑ²c³)] (1/r²).

Let
   C = e⁴/(12π²ε₀² mₑ²c³).

Hence,
   dr/dt = – C/r².

Step 4. Integrate to find the decay time

We want to determine T for the radius to shrink from r = r₀ at t = 0 to r = 0. Rewrite the differential equation:

   dr/dt = – C/r² ⟹ dt = – (r²/C) dr.

Now integrate both sides:
   T = ∫₀ᵀ dt = –(1/C) ∫ᵣ₀⁰ r² dr.

Changing the limits (or equivalently taking the absolute value) gives:

   T = (1/C) ∫₀^(r₀) r² dr = (1/C) [r³/3]₀^(r₀) = r₀³/(3C).

Now substitute back for C:

   T = [r₀³/(3)] · [12π²ε₀² mₑ²c³/e⁴] 
    = (12/(3)) (π²ε₀² mₑ²c³ r₀³/e⁴)
    = (4π²ε₀² mₑ²c³ r₀³)/e⁴.

Thus, the time it takes for the orbit to decay from the Bohr radius to zero is

   T = (4π²ε₀² mₑ²c³ r₀³)/e⁴.

Step 5. Final Answer

We box the final answer as follows:

   \[
\boxed{T = \frac{4\pi^2 \epsilon_0^2 m_e^2 c^3 r_0^3}{e^4}}
\]

This completes our derivation.

We start by noting that a point charge q is placed at the center of a spherical conducting shell with inner radius a and outer radius b. The conductor is in equilibrium, and its outer surface carries a uniform charge density σ. (Thus, the total free charge on the outer surface is Q_outer = σ(4πb²).)

Because the electric field inside a conductor in electrostatic equilibrium must be zero, any Gaussian surface lying within the conducting material (a < r < b) must enclose zero net charge. Hence, the charge induced on the inner surface must cancel the point charge q. That is,

  Q_inner + q = 0  ⟹  Q_inner = –q.

Now, let us determine the electric field E(r) in the three regions: (i) inside the cavity (r < a), (ii) within the conductor (a < r < b), and (iii) outside the shell (r > b).

────────────────────────────
Step 1. For r < a (Inside the Cavity):

Here the only charge enclosed by a spherical Gaussian surface of radius r (< a) is the point charge q at the center. By Gauss’ law,

  ∮ E · dA = E(r) · 4πr² = q/ε₀.

Thus,

  E(r) = q/(4πε₀ r²)    (for r < a).

This electric field is directed radially outward (if q > 0).

────────────────────────────
Step 2. For a < r < b (Within the Conductor):

In a conductor in electrostatic equilibrium, the electric field is zero. Hence,

  E(r) = 0          (for a < r < b).

────────────────────────────
Step 3. For r > b (Outside the Shell):

A spherical Gaussian surface of radius r > b encloses:
 • the point charge q,
 • the induced charge on the inner surface Q_inner = –q,
 • the uniformly distributed free charge on the outer surface Q_outer = σ(4πb²).

Therefore, the total enclosed charge is

  q + (–q) + σ(4πb²) = σ(4πb²).

Again by Gauss’ law,

  ∮ E · dA = E(r) · 4πr² = [σ(4πb²)]/ε₀.

Thus, solving for E(r),

  E(r) = σ(4πb²)/(4πε₀ r²) = (σ b²)/(ε₀ r²)    (for r > b).

This field is also directed radially outward.

────────────────────────────
Final Answers:

1. The electric field E(r) is given by

  For r < a:  E(r) = q/(4πε₀ r²) r̂,
  For a ≤ r ≤ b: E(r) = 0,
  For r > b:  E(r) = (σ b²)/(ε₀ r²) r̂.

2. The charge induced on the inner surface is

  Q_inner = –q.

────────────────────────────

0, & a \le r \le b,\\[2mm]
\displaystyle \frac{\sigma\,b^2}{\epsilon_0\,r^2}\,\hat{r}, & r > b,
\end{cases}\\[2mm]
Q_{\text{inner}} &= -q.
\end{aligned}
}

The total charge Q is uniformly distributed over the volume of the sphere of radius R, so the volume charge density ρ is given by

Step 2: Determine the electric field outside the sphere (r ≥ R).
For a spherical Gaussian surface of radius r > R, the entire charge Q is enclosed. Gauss's law states
  ∮ E · dA = Q_enc / ε₀.
Due to spherical symmetry, the electric field has constant magnitude E(r) on the Gaussian surface, and the flux is
  E(r) (4πr²) = Q / ε₀,
so
  E(r) = Q / (4πε₀ r²).

Step 3: Determine the electric field inside the sphere (r < R).
For a Gaussian surface of radius r < R, the enclosed charge is only a fraction of Q. Since the charge is uniformly distributed,

Then Gauss's law gives:
  E(r)(4πr²) = [Q (r³ / R³)] / ε₀,
which leads to
  E(r) = Q (r³ / R³) / (4πε₀ r²) = (Qr)/(4πε₀ R³).

Step 4: Summarize the results.
The electric field is:
 • Outside the sphere (r ≥ R): E = Q / (4πε₀ r²),
 • Inside the sphere (r < R): E = (Qr)/(4πε₀ R³).

}
