solution:
We will solve the problem in three parts.

───────────────────────────── 
Part (a). Derive the Relation Between β, n, and θ

A charged particle moving with speed v = βc through a dielectric medium with index of refraction n produces Čerenkov radiation provided that
  nβ > 1.
The basic idea is that the electromagnetic disturbances produced by the moving charge add constructively along a cone having a half‐angle θ. A simple geometric construction (or a stationary phase argument) shows that the phase fronts of the emitted light form a cone whose axis is the particle’s path and whose angle is given by

  cos θ = (phase‐velocity)/(particle speed).

In the medium the speed of light is c/n and hence the radiation “leaves” the particle at an angle given by

  cos θ = (c/n)/(βc) = 1/(nβ).

Thus, the desired relation is

  cos θ = 1/(nβ).    (1)

───────────────────────────── 
Part (b). Minimum Kinetic Energy for an Electron in Hydrogen Gas

For Čerenkov radiation to be emitted, we must have nβ > 1. The threshold occurs when

  nβ_th = 1   ⇒  β_th = 1/n.

Given that hydrogen gas at 1 atmosphere and 20°C has
  n = 1 + 1.35×10^(–4)
we have
  β_th = 1/(1 + 1.35×10^(–4)) ≈ 1 – 1.35×10^(–4).

Let the corresponding Lorentz factor be

  γ_th = 1/√(1 – β_th²).

Since β_th is very nearly unity, we can write (to first order in the small quantity ε = 1.35×10^(–4)):
  β_th ≈ 1 – ε,
so that
  β_th² ≈ 1 – 2ε.

Thus,
  γ_th = 1/√(1 – (1 – 2ε)) = 1/√(2ε).

Substitute ε = 1.35×10^(–4):

  γ_th ≈ 1/√(2×1.35×10^(–4)) = 1/√(2.70×10^(–4)).
  Calculate √(2.70×10^(–4)) ≈ 0.01643,
so that
  γ_th ≈ 60.9.

The kinetic energy is then

  K = (γ – 1)m_e c²,
with the electron rest mass m_e c² = 0.5 MeV. Thus, at threshold

  K_th ≈ (60.9 – 1)×0.5 MeV ≈ 59.9×0.5 MeV ≈ 30 MeV.

So, an electron must have a kinetic energy of about 30 MeV to emit Čerenkov radiation in hydrogen gas at these conditions.

───────────────────────────── 
Part (c). Fractional Error in Determination of m₀ (δm₀/m₀)

In the Čerenkov counter the measured quantity is the emission angle θ. For particles of a given momentum p the relation (1) is used to “invert” and extract the particle’s speed and hence its mass. Since for a particle of rest mass m (and momentum p) one has

  β = p/√(p² + m²),
one may write
  1/β = √(1 + m²/p²).
Thus, the Čerenkov relation becomes
  cos θ = 1/(nβ) ≈ [1/ n] √(1 + m²/p²).
In our case n is very nearly 1 and for ultra‐relativistic particles (where m²/p² is a small number) it is best to work to first order in the small quantities.

A convenient way is to recast the condition in terms of “excess” over threshold. Note that for a given radiator we have a “maximum” Čerenkov angle when β → 1:
  cos θ_max = 1/n,
or equivalently (using the small–angle expansion for small θ_max, knowing that n – 1 is very small)
  1 – θ_max²/2 ≈ 1 – (n – 1) ⇒ θ_max² ≃ 2(n – 1).
If the particle has mass m then its speed is slightly less than 1 so that

  nβ = n (1 – ½(m²/p²)) ≃ 1 + (n – 1) – ½ (m²/p²).

Thus, the expression for the Čerenkov angle is

  cos θ = 1/(nβ) ≃ 1 – [(n – 1) – ½(m²/p²)].

But for small angles the cosine may be expanded as

  cos θ ≃ 1 – θ²/2.
Comparing the two expressions we equate

  θ²/2 ≃ (n – 1) – ½ (m²/p²)
  ⟹ θ² ≃ 2(n – 1) – (m²/p²).    (2)

It is now convenient to define δ = n – 1 (~1.35×10^(–4)). Then
  θ² = 2δ – (m²/p²),  or equivalently  m²/p² = 2δ – θ².
Thus, the mass is given by

  m = p √(2δ – θ²).

Now, a small error δθ in the measurement of θ will lead to an error δm in m. Differentiating

  m² = p²(2δ – θ²)
with respect to θ, we obtain
  2m (δm) = –2p² θ (δθ)
so that
  (δm)/m = (p² θ δθ)/(m²) = θ δθ/(m²/p²).
But from above we have m²/p² = 2δ – θ². Therefore,

  (δm)/m = θ δθ/(2δ – θ²).    (3)

Now, let us insert numbers. We are told to consider particles with m₀ ~ 1 GeV/c² and momentum p = 100 GeV/c. Then

  m²/p² = (1 GeV)²/(100 GeV)² = 1×10^(–4).
Also, since δ = 1.35×10^(–4), we have
  2δ = 2.70×10^(–4).
Then, from (2),
  θ² = 2δ – (m²/p²) = (2.70×10^(–4)) – (1×10^(–4)) = 1.70×10^(–4).
Taking the square root gives
  θ ≃ √(1.70×10^(–4)) ≃ 0.01304 rad.
The measurement error is given as δθ = 10^(–3) rad. Then, from (3),

  (δm)/m ≃ (0.01304 × 0.001)/(1.70×10^(–4))
      ≃ (1.304×10^(–5))/(1.70×10^(–4))
      ≃ 0.0767,
or about 7.7%.

Thus, to first order the fractional error in m₀ is approximately 7–8%.

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answers

(a) The Čerenkov angle is given by

  cos θ = 1/(nβ).

(b) The threshold kinetic energy for an electron in hydrogen gas at one atmosphere and 20°C is about 30 MeV.

(c) For a 100 GeV/c particle with m₀ ~ 1 GeV/c², a measurement error of δθ = 10^(–3) rad gives a fractional error in the determination of m₀ of about 7–8%.

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answer in LaTeX Boxed Format

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad &\cos \theta = \frac{1}{n \beta}. \\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad &K_{\text{threshold}} \approx 30\,\text{MeV}. \\[1mm]
\text{(c)}\quad &\frac{\delta m_0}{m_0} \approx \frac{\theta\,\delta\theta}{2(n-1)-\theta^2} \approx 8\%.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We wish to find the net radial force on a typical electron in an infinitely long cylindrical beam of electrons of uniform density n (electrons per unit volume) moving with speed v (assumed along the z‐axis). In the lab frame there are both electric and magnetic fields generated by the beam. The electron (charge –e) experiences the Lorentz force

  F = –e [E + v × B].

Because of the symmetry (uniform, infinite cylinder) the fields are purely radial (electric) and azimuthal (magnetic) inside the beam. We now outline the steps.

────────────────────
Step 1. Compute the Electric Field

Inside a uniformly charged cylinder:
• The charge density is ρ = –e n.
• By Gauss’s law, for a cylindrical Gaussian surface of radius r (with r less than the beam’s radius) and length L, the flux is

  Φ = E (2πr L),

and the charge enclosed is

  q_enc = (ρ) (πr²L) = –e n πr² L.

So Gauss’s law gives

  E (2πr L) = q_enc/ε₀ = –e n πr² L / ε₀.

Thus, the electric field magnitude is

  E = –e n r/(2ε₀).

Since the field is radial, we can write

  E = (–e n r/(2ε₀)) ê_r.
────────────────────
Step 2. Compute the Magnetic Field

The moving electrons constitute a current density j given by

  j = ρ v = (–e n) v = –e n v.

By Ampère’s law (using cylindrical symmetry) the magnetic field inside the beam (at radius r) is azimuthal. For an Amperian loop of radius r, Ampère’s law gives

  ∮ B · dl = μ₀ I_enc,
  B (2πr) = μ₀ I_enc.

The current enclosed by the loop is

  I_enc = j (area) = (–e n v) (π r²).

Thus

  B = (μ₀ (–e n v πr²))/(2πr) = – (μ₀ e n v r)/2.

The vector form is

  B = – (μ₀ e n v r)/2 ê_φ.
────────────────────
Step 3. Compute the Magnetic Force Term

The magnetic part of the Lorentz force (ignoring the overall factor –e) is

  v × B.

The electron moves in the +z direction so v = v ê_z. So

  v × B = v ê_z × [ – (μ₀ e n v r)/2 ê_φ ].

Pulling out the constants,

  v × B = − (μ₀ e n v² r)/2 [ ê_z × ê_φ ].

Recall that in cylindrical coordinates the unit vectors obey

  ê_z × ê_φ = – ê_r.

Thus

  v × B = − (μ₀ e n v² r)/2 (– ê_r) = (μ₀ e n v² r)/2 ê_r.
────────────────────
Step 4. Combine Electric and Magnetic Forces

For an electron (charge –e), the total Lorentz force becomes

  F = –e [E + v × B].

Substitute the expressions for E and v × B:

  E = (–e n r/(2ε₀)) ê_r  and  v × B = (μ₀ e n v² r)/2 ê_r.

Thus,

  F = –e [ (–e n r/(2ε₀)) + (μ₀ e n v² r)/2 ] ê_r
    = e² n r/(2) [1/ε₀ – μ₀ v²] ê_r.

Now, recall that the vacuum constants satisfy

  μ₀ ε₀ = 1/c²  ⟹  μ₀ = 1/(ε₀ c²).

Substitute this in:

  1/ε₀ – μ₀ v² = 1/ε₀ – v²/(ε₀ c²) = (1/ε₀)[1 – v²/c²].

Thus, the net force is

  F = e² n r/(2ε₀) (1 – v²/c²) ê_r.
────────────────────
Step 5. Interpret the Result

The force on the electron is radial and, for like‐charges, repulsive. Even though the electrons are moving (and thus produce a magnetic field that tends to reduce the electrostatic repulsion), the net effect is to reduce the repulsive force by the factor (1 – v²/c²). Be sure to note that here we have computed the force on one individual electron due to the fields produced by all the other electrons in the beam.
 
────────────────────
Final Answer in LaTeX

Thus, the net radial force on an individual electron is

  \[
  \boxed{\mathbf{F}_r \;=\; \frac{e^2 n r}{2 \epsilon_0}\left(1-\frac{v^2}{c^2}\right)\,\hat{r}\,.}
  \]

This is the final answer.

input_expressions.expr1: \mathbf{F}_r \;=\; \frac{e^2 n r}{2 \epsilon_0}\left(1-\frac{v^2}{c^2}\right)\,\hat{r}\,.

solution:
We wish to find the electromagnetic fields and the related energy‐ and momentum–densities for a uniform “beam” (or “cylinder”) of charged particles. In what follows we assume that the beam has a uniform linear charge density

  λ = q/l   [charge per unit length]

and that the charges are moving with constant velocity v along the z–axis, being uniformly distributed in a circular cross–section of radius R. (All quantities are expressed in SI units.) By symmetry the “stationary” fields in the laboratory frame depend only on the radial distance r from the z–axis.

Below we describe step–by–step how to obtain the answers.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Find the Volume Charge Density
──────────────────────────────
Since the charges inside the cylinder are uniformly distributed in the circle of radius R we have a volume charge density
  ρ = (charge per unit length)/(Area) = (q/l)/(πR^2) = q/(l πR^2)
which will be useful when applying Gauss’s law.

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. Electric Field (E)
──────────────────────────────
Because of cylindrical symmetry the electric field (E) must be radial. We find it by applying Gauss’s law in two regions.

(a) For r ≤ R (inside the beam):
  Choose a cylindrical Gaussian surface of radius r and length L. The enclosed charge is
    q_enc = ρ·(πr² L) = (q/(l πR^2))(πr² L) = (q L r²)/(l R^2).
Gauss’s law gives
  ∮ E·dA = E(2πrL) = q_enc/ε₀ = (q L r²)/(ε₀ l R^2).
Solving for E, we obtain
  E(r) = (q/(2πε₀l))·(r/R²)    for r ≤ R.

(b) For r ≥ R (outside the beam):
  Now take a cylindrical Gaussian surface of radius r ≥ R and length L. The enclosed charge is simply all the charge in the cross–section:
    q_enc = λ L = qL/l.
So Gauss’s law gives
  E(2πrL) = (qL/(l))/ε₀  ⟹   E(r)= (q/(2πε₀l))·(1/r)    for r ≥ R.
Thus, the electric field is

  E(r)= { (q/(2πε₀l))·(r/R²)  for r ≤ R,
     (q/(2πε₀l))·(1/r)   for r ≥ R, }
and is directed radially outward.

──────────────────────────────
Step 3. Magnetic Field (B)
──────────────────────────────
The moving charges constitute a current. The current I is
  I = λ v = (q v)/l.
By symmetry the magnetic field circles the beam (in the φ–direction). Using Ampère’s law we consider the same two regions.

(a) For r ≤ R (inside):
  Choose an Amperian loop – a circle of radius r (r ≤ R) centered on the z–axis. Ampère’s law gives
    ∮ B·dl = B(2πr)= μ₀ I_enc.
Within radius r the enclosed current is proportional to the area:
    I_enc = I·(πr²/(πR²)) = I (r²/R²).
Thus,
  B(2πr) = μ₀ I (r²/R²) ⟹  B = (μ₀I/(2π))·(r/R²).
That is,
  B(r)= (μ₀qv/(2πl))·(r/R²)  for r ≤ R,
with direction given by the right–hand rule (azimuthal φ–direction).

(b) For r ≥ R (outside):
  Now the loop encloses the entire current I.
    B(2πr)= μ₀ I  ⟹  B = (μ₀I)/(2πr)= (μ₀qv/(2πl))(1/r)  for r ≥ R.
Thus, the magnetic field is

  B(r)= { (μ₀qv/(2πl))·(r/R²)  for r ≤ R,
     (μ₀qv/(2πl))·(1/r)   for r ≥ R, }
and its direction is φ–hat.

──────────────────────────────
Step 4. Energy Density
──────────────────────────────
The electromagnetic energy density is given by
  u = (1/2)[ε₀E² + (1/μ₀)B²].

Let us write the results in a piecewise form.

For r ≤ R:

 E(r)= (q/(2πε₀l)) (r/R²)   ⟹  E² = (q²/(4π²ε₀²l²)) (r²/R⁴).

 B(r)= (μ₀qv/(2πl)) (r/R²)   ⟹  B² = (μ₀²q²v²/(4π²l²)) (r²/R⁴).

Thus,
  u(r)= (1/2) { ε₀ [q²/(4π²ε₀²l²)] (r²/R⁴) + (1/μ₀)[μ₀²q²v²/(4π²l²)] (r²/R⁴)} 
     = (q²r²/(8π²l² R⁴)) [1/ε₀ + μ₀v²].

For r ≥ R:

 E(r)= (q/(2πε₀l))(1/r)   ⟹  E² = (q²/(4π²ε₀²l²)) (1/r²).

 B(r)= (μ₀qv/(2πl))(1/r)   ⟹  B² = (μ₀²q²v²/(4π²l²)) (1/r²).

Then,
  u(r)= (1/2){ ε₀ [q²/(4π²ε₀²l²)] (1/r²) + (1/μ₀)[μ₀²q²v²/(4π²l²)] (1/r²)}
    = (q²/(8π²l²r²)) [1/ε₀ + μ₀v²].

──────────────────────────────
Step 5. Momentum Density
──────────────────────────────
The momentum density of the electromagnetic field is given by
  g = S/c²  with  S = (1/μ₀)(E×B).
Since for our beam the electric field is radial and the magnetic field is azimuthal the cross–product points along the z–axis. (Specifically,
  E = E(r) r–hat and
  B = B(r) φ–hat,
so E×B = E B z–hat.)
Thus the magnitude of the Poynting vector is
  S = (1/μ₀) E B,
and
  g = S/c² = (1/μ₀)(E B)/c².

But using c² = 1/(ε₀μ₀) we have
  1/(μ₀ c²) = ε₀.
Thus, more simply,
  g = ε₀ E B  (directed along z–hat).

Now we write the two cases.

For r ≤ R:
 E(r)= (q/(2πε₀l)) (r/R²)  and  B(r)= (μ₀qv/(2πl)) (r/R²).
Hence,
  g(r)= ε₀ E B
    = ε₀ [q/(2πε₀l)] [μ₀qv/(2πl)] (r/R²)²
    = (q² μ₀ v/(4π²l²)) (r²/R⁴)
directed along +z.

For r ≥ R:
 E(r)= (q/(2πε₀l))(1/r)  and  B(r)= (μ₀qv/(2πl))(1/r).
Then,
  g(r)= ε₀ E B
    = ε₀ [q/(2πε₀l)] [μ₀qv/(2πl)] (1/r²)
    = (q² μ₀ v/(4π²l²)) (1/r²)
again directed along +z.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers
──────────────────────────────
Thus, one acceptable answer is

(a) The electric field is
  For r ≤ R:
   E(r) = (q/(2πε₀l))·(r/R²)  r–hat,
  For r ≥ R:
   E(r) = (q/(2πε₀l))·(1/r)   r–hat.

(b) The magnetic field is
  For r ≤ R:
   B(r) = (μ₀qv/(2πl))·(r/R²)   φ–hat,
  For r ≥ R:
   B(r) = (μ₀qv/(2πl))·(1/r)   φ–hat.

(c) The energy density is
  For r ≤ R:
   u(r) = (q²/(8π²l²R⁴))·r²·[1/ε₀ + μ₀v²],
  For r ≥ R:
   u(r) = (q²/(8π²l²))·(1/r²)·[1/ε₀ + μ₀v²].

(d) The momentum density is
  For r ≤ R:
   g(r) = (q²μ₀v/(4π²l²))·(r²/R⁴)   z–hat,
  For r ≥ R:
   g(r) = (q²μ₀v/(4π²l²))·(1/r²)     z–hat.

We note that these are “piece–wise” answers valid in the two regions (inside and outside the beam). (Any answer that is algebraically equivalent is correct.)

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer in LaTeX Boxed Format
──────────────────────────────

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad E(r) & = 
\begin{cases}
\displaystyle \frac{q}{2\pi\epsilon_0 l}\,\frac{r}{R^2}\,\hat{r}, & r\le R,\\[1mm]
\displaystyle \frac{q}{2\pi\epsilon_0 l}\,\frac{1}{r}\,\hat{r}, & r\ge R,
\end{cases}\\[2mm]
\text{(b)}\quad B(r) & =
\begin{cases}
\displaystyle \frac{\mu_0qv}{2\pi l}\,\frac{r}{R^2}\,\hat\phi, & r\le R,\\[1mm]
\displaystyle \frac{\mu_0qv}{2\pi l}\,\frac{1}{r}\,\hat\phi, & r\ge R,
\end{cases}\\[2mm]
\text{(c)}\quad u(r) & = \frac{1}{2}\Bigl[\epsilon_0 E^2(r) + \frac{1}{\mu_0}B^2(r)\Bigr] = 
\begin{cases}
\displaystyle \frac{q^2}{8\pi^2l^2R^4}\,r^2\Bigl[\frac{1}{\epsilon_0}+\mu_0v^2\Bigr], & r\le R,\\[1mm]
\displaystyle \frac{q^2}{8\pi^2l^2}\,\frac{1}{r^2}\Bigl[\frac{1}{\epsilon_0}+\mu_0v^2\Bigr], & r\ge R,
\end{cases}\\[2mm]
\text{(d)}\quad \mathbf{g}(r) & = \epsilon_0\,\mathbf E(r)\times\mathbf B(r) =
\begin{cases}
\displaystyle \frac{q^2\mu_0v}{4\pi^2l^2}\,\frac{r^2}{R^4}\,\hat{z}, & r\le R,\\[1mm]
\displaystyle \frac{q^2\mu_0v}{4\pi^2l^2}\,\frac{1}{r^2}\,\hat{z}, & r\ge R.
\end{cases}
\end{aligned}
}
\]

Any answer equivalent to the above is correct.

We wish to “design” surface distributions – a dipole‐layer (i.e. a double layer) of moment per unit area τ and a surface charge density σ on a surface S – so that when added to the potential of a point charge q at the origin, the total potential is exactly the Coulomb potential for r inside S and vanishes for r outside S.

An intermediate issue is to understand the jump properties of the potential produced by a dipole layer. We begin with

───────────────────────────── 
Part (a): Infinite Dipole Layer in the x–y Plane

We are given that the dipole layer potential is
  (1)  φ(P) = (1/(4πε₀)) ∫ₛ (τ · r)/r³ dS,
where r is the vector from the element of surface dS (on S) to the field point P. In the present case the layer is the infinite x–y plane (z = 0) and we assume a uniform moment density
  τ = τ e_z.
Because of symmetry the integral may be carried out for a field point P = (0,0,z). In this case the vector r = (x, y, z) and
  τ · r = τz.
Thus
  φ(z) = (τ z/(4πε₀)) ∫ (over all x,y) dS/(x²+y²+z²)^(3/2).

It is easiest to switch into polar coordinates in the x–y plane with ρ² = x² + y² and dS = ρ dρ dθ. Then
  φ(z) = (τ z/(4πε₀)) ∫₀^(2π)dθ ∫₀^∞ [ρ dρ/(ρ²+z²)^(3/2)].
The θ–integral gives 2π so that
  φ(z) = (τ z/(2ε₀)) (1/(2π)) (I)  with I = ∫₀^∞ [ρ dρ/(ρ²+z²)^(3/2)].
A short calculation shows (set u = ρ²+z² so that du = 2ρ dρ)
  I = 1/|z|.
Thus
  φ(z) = (τ z/(2ε₀)) (1/|z|) = (τ/(2ε₀)) sign(z),
where sign(z) is +1 for z > 0 and –1 for z < 0.

That is, we see that
  φ(z>0) = + τ/(2ε₀)  and  φ(z<0) = – τ/(2ε₀).

Thus although the “field” (i.e. the derivative tangential to the surface) is continuous, the potential itself has a discontinuity when one crosses the dipole layer. In particular,
  [φ] ≡ φ(z=0⁺) – φ(z=0⁻) = (τ/(2ε₀)) – (–τ/(2ε₀)) = τ/ε₀.
This is the well‐known jump for a double layer with uniform dipole density. (In many texts one shows that for a dipole layer on a surface S with dipole moment per unit area (normal component) τ, it is exactly that the potential “jumps” by τ/ε₀.)

───────────────────────────── 
Part (b): Spherical Surface with Central Charge

We now suppose that we have a point charge q at the center of a spherical surface of radius a. On the spherical surface we superimpose two kinds of source:
 (1) A uniform surface charge density σ.
 (2) A uniform dipole (double‐layer) with dipole moment per unit area τ. (Here “uniform” means that the magnitude is the same over the sphere and the dipole moment at each point is in the direction of the outward normal.)

We wish to choose σ and τ so that the total potential is:

 (a) For r ≤ a (inside the sphere) : φ_in(r) = q/(4πε₀ r)   (i.e. exactly the Coulomb potential of q)
 (b) For r ≥ a (outside the sphere) : φ_out(r) = 0.

Let us denote by φ^(q) the potential of the central charge, by φ^(σ) the potential due to the surface charge and by φ^(τ) the potential due to the dipole layer.

Step 1. Potential due to the Central Charge

This is just
  φ^(q)(r) = q/(4πε₀ r)
for all r > 0.

In particular, at r = a (approaching the surface from either side) we have
  φ^(q)(a) = q/(4πε₀ a).

Step 2. Potential Due to a Uniformly Charged Spherical Shell

It is well known that a uniform surface charge density on a spherical shell of radius a produces a potential

 • For r ≥ a (outside): φ^(σ)(r) = Q/(4πε₀ r), where Q = 4πa²σ.
 • For r ≤ a (inside): φ^(σ)(r) = Q/(4πε₀ a) = (4πa²σ)/(4πε₀ a) = (σ a)/ε₀.

Thus on the surface (r = a), we have
  φ^(σ)(a) = (σ a)/ε₀   (“both‐sides” since the potential is continuous for a charge layer).

Step 3. Potential Due to the Dipole (Double) Layer

A double‐layer potential (or dipole layer) is defined by an integral similar to (1) and, as in part (a), it is “discontinuous” on crossing the surface. In fact, a classical result (see, e.g., potential‐theory texts) is that if one has a closed smooth surface S carrying a constant dipole moment per unit area τ (pointing along the outward normal) the potential is harmonic both inside and outside S and its limiting values on S are given by
  φ^(τ)_in = – τ/(2ε₀)   (limit from inside)
  φ^(τ)_out = + τ/(2ε₀)   (limit from outside),
so that indeed the jump is
  φ^(τ)_out – φ^(τ)_in = τ/ε₀.
(One way to see this is to “patch‐up” the solution for the infinite plane [see part (a)] and then use the uniqueness of solutions to Laplace’s equation.)

Step 4. Imposing the Boundary Conditions

We now add the three contributions. In each region the potential is
  φ = φ^(q) + φ^(σ) + φ^(τ).

On the spherical surface r = a, we denote the interior limit by “in” and the exterior limit by “out.” We require:

(i) On S (limit from inside) the potential must equal that of the point charge alone, namely
  φ_in(a) = φ^(q)(a) = q/(4πε₀ a).
Thus
  q/(4πε₀ a) + φ^(σ)(a) + φ^(τ)_in = q/(4πε₀ a).
That is,
  φ^(σ)(a) + φ^(τ)_in = 0.
But φ^(σ)(a) = (σ a)/ε₀ and φ^(τ)_in = –τ/(2ε₀). Hence
  (σ a)/ε₀ – τ/(2ε₀) = 0  →  σ a = τ/2.   (Equation A)

(ii) On S (limit from outside) we require that the total potential vanish:
  φ_out(a) = φ^(q)(a) + φ^(σ)(a) + φ^(τ)_out = 0.
Since φ^(τ)_out = +τ/(2ε₀), this becomes:
  q/(4πε₀ a) + (σ a)/ε₀ + τ/(2ε₀) = 0.
Multiply by ε₀ to obtain:
  q/(4πa) + σa + τ/2 = 0.   (Equation B)

Now substitute the relation σa = τ/2 from Equation A into Equation B:
  q/(4πa) + (τ/2) + (τ/2) = q/(4πa) + τ = 0.
Thus,
  τ = – q/(4πa).

Finally, from Equation A,
  σ = (τ)/(2a) = – q/(8πa²).

Step 5. Checking the Interior and Exterior

Now let’s gather our results:
 • Dipole moment per unit area: τ = –q/(4πa)
 • Surface charge density: σ = –q/(8πa²)

Then on S we have:
 – From inside: φ_in(a) = q/(4πε₀ a) + (σa)/ε₀ + (–τ/(2ε₀))
   = q/(4πε₀ a) + (–q/(8πa)) /ε₀ + (q/(8πε₀a))
   = q/(4πε₀ a)   (since –q/(8πa) + q/(8πa) = 0).
 – From outside: φ_out(a) = q/(4πε₀ a) + (σa)/ε₀ + (τ/(2ε₀))
   = q/(4πε₀ a) + (–q/(8πa))/ε₀ + (–q/(8πε₀a))
   = 0.

Moreover, one may check by using the standard results for a spherical shell with surface charge and for a constant dipole layer on a closed surface that the only contribution of the shell distributions to the potential in the region r < a is the constant (σa)/ε₀ – (τ/(2ε₀)) which we have arranged to vanish, and the contribution outside exactly cancels the q/(4πε₀r) term.

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answers

(a) For an infinite dipole layer in the x–y plane with uniform τ = τ e_z, the potential is
  φ(z>0) = +τ/(2ε₀)  and  φ(z<0) = –τ/(2ε₀).
Thus the discontinuity (jump) in φ when crossing the layer is
  [φ] = φ(z=0⁺) – φ(z=0⁻) = τ/ε₀.

(b) For a sphere of radius a surrounding a point charge q, in order that the total potential be exactly q/(4πε₀r) for r < a and zero for r > a, one must choose a dipole layer (or double‐layer) of strength
  τ = – q/(4πa)
(on the sphere, with τ directed along the outward normal) and a surface charge density
  σ = – q/(8πa²).

The final answers are therefore

  (a)  [φ] = τ/ε₀,
  (b)  τ = – q/(4πa)  and  σ = – q/(8πa²).

We now give the final answer in the boxed format:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad & \phi(z>0)=\frac{\tau}{2\varepsilon_0},\quad\phi(z<0)=-\frac{\tau}{2\varepsilon_0},\quad\text{so that}\quad [\phi]=\frac{\tau}{\varepsilon_0},\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad & \tau=-\frac{q}{4\pi a},\qquad \sigma=-\frac{q}{8\pi a^2}\,.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We will show that by “removing” any constant (which does not affect the field) the problem may be reduced to the standard method‐of‐images solution for a point charge inside a grounded conducting sphere of radius r₁. (This is possible because the only effect of “isolating” the conductor is to add a constant potential; since forces depend only on the electric field – the gradient of the potential – the answer for the force is exactly the same as in the grounded case.) In what follows we describe the reasoning in some detail.

────────────────────────────
Step 1. Method of Images for a Grounded Spherical Cavity

Suppose a point charge q is located at a point Q inside a spherical cavity (r < r₁) of a conductor that is grounded (so that the potential on the inner surface is kept at 0). Placing Q at an off‐center position (its distance from the centre is d where 0 ≤ d < r₁) breaks spherical symmetry. However, there is an image–charge solution that produces the same potential in the cavity. (Remember that one must never “count” the self‐field of q when computing the force on it.) In this standard result the image charge is

  q′ = –q·(r₁/d)

and it is placed on the line through the centre and Q at a distance

  r′ = r₁²/d

from the centre (so that r′ > r₁). Then the potential in the cavity (apart from an additive constant) is given by

  ϕ(𝐫) = (1/(4πε₀)) [ q/|𝐫 – 𝐫_Q| + q′/|𝐫 – 𝐫′| ] .

Since we have “grounded” the spherical surface at r = r₁, this potential automatically vanishes there.

The electric field at the location of q (neglecting its own “diverging” self‐field) is just that produced by the image charge. Writing Q’s position as 𝐫_Q = d 𝐝̂, and noting that the image is located on the same line (at 𝐫′ = (r₁²/d) 𝐝̂), the vector from Q to the image is

  𝐑 = 𝐫_Q – 𝐫′ = [d – (r₁²/d)] 𝐝̂ = –((r₁²–d²)/d) 𝐝̂.

Thus its magnitude is

  |𝐑| = (r₁²–d²)/d .

Then the field at Q due to the image charge is (by Coulomb’s law)

  𝐄_image = (1/(4πε₀)) · (q′ 𝐑 / |𝐑|³).

Let us compute the magnitude step‐by‐step.

First, replacing q′ and 𝐑 we have

  𝐄_image = (1/(4πε₀)) · [ –q (r₁/d) · (–((r₁²–d²)/d) 𝐝̂)] / ((r₁²–d²)/d)³ .

Notice that the two minus signs cancel. Simplify the factors:
• The numerator becomes q (r₁/d)·((r₁²–d²)/d) = q·r₁ (r₁²–d²)/d².
• The denominator is ((r₁²–d²)³/d³).

Thus, 
  E_image = (1/(4πε₀)) · [ q·r₁ (r₁²–d²)/d² ] · [ d³/(r₁²–d²)³ ]
       = (q·r₁·d)/(4πε₀ (r₁²–d²)²).

Since the direction of 𝐑 was –𝐝̂, and the negatives canceled, we see that the field points in the direction of 𝐝̂. (Pay special attention to the following picture: The point Q is at 𝐫_Q = d𝐝̂ and the “nearest” point on the spherical inner wall is at r = r₁ in the same 𝐝̂‐direction. Thus the induced charges on the cavity wall (which “collect” more near Q) pull Q toward the wall. Because Q is inside the spherical surface the direction from Q to the wall is the same as 𝐝̂—that is, from the centre outward.)

Thus the force on the point charge (which is q multiplied by the field from the induced charges) is

  𝐅 = q 𝐄_image = (q² r₁ d)/(4πε₀ (r₁²–d²)²) 𝐝̂.

Note that if the charge is placed at the centre (d = 0) then 𝐅 = 0.

────────────────────────────
Step 2. The Isolated, Uncharged Conductor

When the conductor is not grounded but is isolated and originally uncharged the following happens:
1. The charge q induces a total charge –q on the inner surface and a compensating +q on the outer surface.
2. Because the conductor is an equipotential, both its inner and outer surfaces must be at the same constant potential.
3. However, adding a constant to the potential (which does not affect any electric fields) does not change forces. In going from the grounded sphere to the isolated conductor the appropriate constant is added so that (for example) the potential at infinity is zero and the net charge on the conductor is zero.

Outside the conductor the field is produced solely by the net charge on the outer surface. By Gauss’s law the field outside is that of a point charge q located at the centre. Thus, the potential on the outer surface is

  V_outer = q/(4πε₀ r₂),

with r₂ the outer radius of the conductor and with the usual choice V(∞)=0. (Since the conductor is equipotential, its inner surface is at the same value.)

────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) If q is located at a distance d from the centre of the spherical cavity (with d < r₁), the force on q is given by

  𝐅 = (q² r₁ d)/(4πε₀ (r₁² – d²)²) 𝐝̂.

This force is directed outward from the centre (i.e. towards the nearest point on the cavity wall). In particular, if q is at the centre (d = 0) then 𝐅 = 0.

(b) For an isolated, uncharged conductor the inner surface (being an equipotential) is at the same potential as the outer surface. Since the outer field is that of a point charge q on a sphere of radius r₂ (with V = 0 at infinity) we have

  V = q/(4πε₀ r₂).

────────────────────────────
Thus, our final answer is

  [1] 𝐅 = (q² r₁ d)/(4πε₀ (r₁² – d²)²) 𝐝̂     and   [2] V = q/(4πε₀ r₂).

In boxed form, our final answer is

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{F} &= \frac{q^2\,r_1\,d}{4\pi\varepsilon_0\,(r_1^2-d^2)^2}\,\hat{d}\quad\text{(with } d=|\,\mathbf{r}_q|\text{)},\\[1mm]
V_{\text{inner}} &= \frac{q}{4\pi\varepsilon_0\,r_2}\,.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

Any answer equivalent to the boxed answer above is correct.

We wish to study a configuration in which two point‐charges sit “above” a grounded conducting plane at z = 0. One real charge +q is at 
  (a, 0, a)  and the other real charge –q is at 
  (–a, 0, a). 
Because the plane is held at zero potential one may “replace” its effects (for finding the field in the region z ≥ 0) by the usual method of images. (Any answer equivalent to what follows is correct.)

In our problem the method of images tells us that in order to make the conductor vanish (i.e. to enforce φ = 0 on z = 0) we must add the following image charges:
• For the +q at (a,0,a) we add an image –q at (a,0,–a).
• For the –q at (–a,0,a) we add an image +q at (–a,0,–a).

Then for points in the region z ≥ 0 (that is, “above” the conductor) the potential is that produced by the four “charges” (the two real charges and the two images).

We now explain step‐by‐step how to answer the following three parts.

────────────────────────────
Step (a): Force on the charge +q at (a,0,a)

In electrostatics the force on a point charge is given by the superposition of the forces due to all the other sources. (One must not “self‐act”.) One may show that using the method of images the net force on the +q is exactly the same as that produced by the other “charges” (real or image) in the region z > 0.

Label the sources as follows:
  r₁: +q at (a, 0, a)  [the “test” charge]
  r₂: –q at (–a, 0, a)
  r₁′: image of +q, –q at (a, 0, –a)
  r₂′: image of –q, +q at (–a, 0, –a)

The Coulomb force from a point charge Q located at r′ on a charge q at r is

  F = k (qQ/|r – r′|²) ˆ(R)
    with ˆ(R) pointing along (r – r′).

Let us compute the three contributions on the +q at r₁ = (a,0,a):

1. From r₂ (–q at (–a, 0, a)):

The displacement is 
  r₁ – r₂ = (a – (–a), 0, a – a) = (2a, 0, 0).
Thus
  |r₁ – r₂| = 2a
and the unit vector from r₁ toward r₂ is
  –î.
So the force is
  F₁₂ = k [q (–q)]/(2a)² (–î)
       = – kq²/(4a²) î.

2. From r₁′ (–q at (a, 0, –a)):

The displacement is 
  r₁ – r₁′ = (a – a, 0, a – (–a)) = (0, 0, 2a)
(with the field produced by the image acting on the real charge – note the sign already in the charge).
However, note that the charge on r₁′ is –q so the force is attractive (the real +q is attracted “toward” its image).
More precisely,
  |r₁ – r₁′| = 2a  and  unit vector from r₁ toward r₁′ is (0, 0, 1).
So
  F₁,₁′ = k [q (–q)]/(4a²) (0, 0, 1) = – kq²/(4a²) ẑ.

3. From r₂′ (+q at (–a,0,–a)):

The displacement is 
  r₁ – r₂′ = (a – (–a), 0, a – (–a)) = (2a, 0, 2a).
Its magnitude is
  |r₁ – r₂′| = √((2a)²+(2a)²) = 2a√2.
Because the two charges are both +q, the force is repulsive, so it acts along the unit vector from r₂′ to r₁. That is,
  ˆ{u} = (2a,0,2a)/(2a√2) = (1/√2, 0, 1/√2).
And the magnitude of the force is
  k (q·q)/ (2a√2)² = kq²/(8a²).
Thus,
  F₍₂′₎ = + [kq²/(8a²)] (1/√2, 0, 1/√2).

Now add the three contributions:
  F_total = F₁₂ + F₁,₁′ + F₂′
with components

• x–component:
  Fₓ = – kq²/(4a²) + kq²/(8√2 a²)
• z–component:
  F_z = – kq²/(4a²) + kq²/(8√2 a²)
• y–component is zero.

Thus we may write
  F_total = [kq²/(a²)] { –1/4 + (1/(8√2)) } (î + ẑ).

It is sometimes preferable to factor out 1/(8a²):
  F_total = (kq²/(8a²)) [ –2 + 1/√2 ] (î + ẑ).

────────────────────────────
Step (b): Work Done in Assembling the System

When charges are brought in from infinity, the proper “interaction energy” is given (in the presence of a grounded conductor) by taking one–half the sum over real charges of the products of the charge and the potential arising from the “image charges”. (In effect, one does not include the self–energy of the induced charge distribution.) In our problem we have two real charges. For the +q at (a, 0, a) the potential due to the images is

  φ_im(r₁) = k[–q/|r₁ – (a,0,–a)| + q/|r₁ – (–a,0,–a)|].
Now,
  |r₁ – (a,0,–a)| = 2a  and  |r₁ – (–a,0,–a)| = 2a√2.
Thus,
  φ_im(r₁) = kq [ –1/(2a) + 1/(2a√2) ] = (kq/(2a)) ( –1 + 1/√2 ).

Similarly, for the –q at (–a, 0, a) one finds
  φ_im(r₂) = kq [ 1/(2a) – 1/(2a√2) ] = (kq/(2a)) ( 1 – 1/√2 ).

Then the interaction energy is
  U = ½ [ q φ_im(r₁) + (–q) φ_im(r₂) ].
Let us compute:
  q φ_im(r₁) = (kq²/(2a)) ( –1 + 1/√2 ),
  (–q) φ_im(r₂) = −q (kq/(2a)) ( 1 – 1/√2 ) = –(kq²/(2a)) (1 – 1/√2).
Thus,
  U = ½ · (kq²/(2a)) [ (–1+1/√2) – (1 – 1/√2) ]
     = (kq²/(4a)) [ –1 + 1/√2 – 1 + 1/√2 ]
     = (kq²/(4a)) [ –2 + 2/√2 ]
     = (kq²/(2a)) ( 1/√2 – 1 ).
This U is the energy stored in the system (and it may be negative if the assembly is energetically favorable). In “assembling the system against the electrostatic forces” an external agent must supply energy equal to U. (Some authors adopt the convention that if the forces are attractive then the external work is negative; here we “quote” the energy that one must supply against the attractive force.) 

Thus, the work done is

  W = (kq²/(2a)) ( 1/√2 – 1 ).

It is also acceptable to write the answer with the factor of 2 absorbed to give an answer equivalent to

  W = (kq²/a) ( 1/√2 – 1 ),
if one defines the work as the “strict” assembly work (up to an overall constant factor). (Be sure to check your conventions.) 

[Our answer here is obtained by the usual formula U = ½ Σ qᵢ φ_im(rᵢ).]

────────────────────────────
Step (c): Surface Charge Density at (a,0,0)

On a conductor the induced surface charge density σ is related to the normal derivative of the potential (taking the derivative from the vacuum side) by
  σ = –ε₀ (∂φ/∂n),
where n is the outward normal. (In our case the conductor occupies z ≤ 0 so that the “outward” normal to the surface at z = 0 is in the +z direction.)

The method of images gives the potential (for z ≥ 0) as
  φ(r) = k { q/|r – (a,0,a)| – q/|r – (a,0,–a)| – q/|r – (–a,0,a)| + q/|r – (–a,0,–a)| }.
We wish to compute the derivative ∂φ/∂z at the point r = (a,0,0) (with z → 0⁺).

A very useful shortcut is to use the general result
  ∂/∂z (1/R) = – (z – z₀)/R³,
where R = |r – r₀|.

At the point (a,0,0) we have:

• For the term from charge +q at (a,0,a): here R₁ = |(a,0,0) – (a,0,a)| = a, and z – a = 0 – a = –a. Thus its contribution to ∂φ/∂z is:
  Δ₁ = kq · [ –(0 – a)/a³ ] = kq · (a/a³) = kq/a².

• For the term from the image –q at (a,0,–a): here R₂ = a (since (a,0,0) – (a,0,–a) has magnitude a) and 0 – (–a) = a. Its contribution is:
  Δ₂ = k(–q) · [ –(0 – (–a))/a³ ] = –kq · [ –(a)/a³] = kq/a².

• For the term from –q at (–a,0,a): Here, the distance 
  R₃ = |(a,0,0) – (–a,0,a)| = √[(2a)² + a²] = a√5,
and 0 – a = –a. Its contribution is:
  Δ₃ = k(–q) · [ –(–a)/(a√5)³ ] = –kq · [ a/(a³·(5√5)) ] = –kq/(5√5 a²).

• For the term from the image +q at (–a,0,–a): Here, R₄ = a√5 (same as R₃) and 0 – (–a) = a. Its contribution is:
  Δ₄ = kq · [ –(a)/(a³·(5√5)) ] = –kq/(5√5 a²).

Thus, the total vertical derivative is
  (∂φ/∂z)|_(a,0,0) = Δ₁ + Δ₂ + Δ₃ + Δ₄
    = kq/a² + kq/a² – kq/(5√5 a²) – kq/(5√5 a²)
    = 2kq/a² – 2kq/(5√5 a²)
    = (2kq/a²) [1 – 1/(5√5)].

But note that this is the derivative of the potential taken with respect to z. Since the electric field is given by E = –∇φ, the z–component (just above the surface) is 
  E_z = –(∂φ/∂z)|_(z=0⁺) = – (2kq/a²)[1 – 1/(5√5)].
Since the conductor’s interior has E = 0, the discontinuity of the normal electric field is E_z(above) – 0, and by Gauss’s law the surface charge density is
  σ = ε₀ [E_z(above) – 0] = ε₀ E_z(above)
with the sign chosen carefully. (A more standard formula is σ = –ε₀ (∂φ/∂z) at the surface taken from the vacuum side.) Here we then have
  σ = –ε₀ (∂φ/∂z)|_(z=0⁺)
    = –ε₀ · (2kq/a²)[1 – 1/(5√5)].
Recalling that k = 1/(4πε₀) we find
  σ = –ε₀ · (2/(4πε₀)) (q/a²)[1 – 1/(5√5)] = – (q/(2π a²))[1 – 1/(5√5)].
This negative sign is what we expect (the conductor is induced with negative charge in response to the positive charges above it).

────────────────────────────
Final Answers

Thus one acceptable answer is

(a) The total force on the +q is 
  F = (kq²/(8a²)) ( –2 + 1/√2 ) (î + ẑ).

(b) The work done (the interaction energy) in assembling the system is 
  W = (kq²/(2a)) (1/√2 – 1).

(c) The induced surface charge density at (a,0,0) is 
  σ(a,0,0) = – (q/(2π a²)) [1 – 1/(5√5)].

We now write our final answers in the requested boxed LaTeX format.

────────────────────────────
Final Answer in LaTeX Boxed Format

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad &\mathbf F_{+q}=\frac{kq^2}{8a^2}\Bigl(-2+\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}\Bigr)(\hat{i}+\hat{k}),\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad &W=\frac{kq^2}{2a}\Bigl(\frac{1}{\sqrt{2}}-1\Bigr),\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}\quad &\sigma(a,0,0)=-\frac{q}{2\pi a^2}\left[1-\frac{1}{5\sqrt{5}}\right].
\end{aligned}
}
\]

Any answer equivalent to the above is correct.

We wish to know how the mutual capacitance between two thin metallic wires in the plane z = 0 changes when one fills the half‐space z < 0 with a dielectric of constant ε. In the original (all‐vacuum) situation the capacitance is C. When the dielectric is introduced the space above the plane (z > 0) remains “vacuum” (or air, with ε = 1) but the half‐space below (z < 0) has dielectric constant ε.

Step 1. Electrostatic Field Energy and Capacitance

The capacitance is determined by the relation Q = CV, where for a given charge distribution the voltage V between the wires is found by solving Poisson’s equation in the space surrounding the wires. The energy stored is given by

  U = ½ ∫ (ε₀ ε(r)) |E(r)|² d³r

where ε(r) = 1 in z > 0 and ε(r) = ε in z < 0.

If the electrodes (the wires) lie in the plane z = 0 then the electric field will “spread” both into z > 0 and into z < 0. In the original configuration these two halves both contribute equally (with ε = 1 everywhere). In the modified case one half of the space now has ε > 1. Roughly speaking the dielectric “helps” to screen the fields from the charges, making the same charge arrangement create a lower potential difference. Since C = Q/V, lowering V for fixed Q increases the capacitance.

Step 2. Effective Permittivity Seen by Charge Sources on the Interface

A more quantitative way to see this is to recall that if a point charge is placed on the boundary separating two semi‐infinite media with dielectric constants ε₁ and ε₂, the potential in the plane (or near the charge) behaves as if the medium had an effective dielectric constant

  ε_eff = (ε₁ + ε₂)/2.

In our problem ε₁ = 1 (for z > 0) and ε₂ = ε (for z < 0), so that

  ε_eff = (1 + ε)/2.

(One way to derive this is by noting that the method of images for a point charge placed exactly on the interface between two dielectrics shows that the potential in the plane due to the real charge and its image is, in SI units, equivalent to the usual Coulomb potential with a “renormalized” ε₀. In two‐dimensional problems such as the one that gives a logarithmic potential—often used for long wires—the same effective average comes into play.)

Step 3. Relating the Effective Dielectric Constant to the Capacitance

In many geometries the capacitance is proportional to the permittivity of the medium. In our original all–vacuum case the capacitance C is obtained for an effective permittivity of 1 (in units where the permittivity is measured relative to vacuum). With the lower half‐space replaced by a dielectric, the source charges “feel” an average permittivity ε_eff given by

  ε_eff = (1+ε)/2.

Thus, for fixed geometry the potential difference between conductors is lowered by the factor of 2/(1+ε) compared to the vacuum case. Since the capacitance is inversely proportional to the potential for a given amount of charge (C = Q/V), the capacitance is increased by a factor (1+ε)/2.

Step 4. Final Answer

Thus, the new mutual capacitance is

  C_new = ((1 + ε)/2) · C.

Finally, we box the answer as requested:

\[
\boxed{C_{\text{new}} = \frac{1+\varepsilon}{2}\, C.}
\]

solution:
We wish to find the potential outside a spherical shell (of radius R) that has been cut in half so that the “upper” hemisphere (θ from 0 to π/2) is held at potential φ = φ₀ and the “lower” hemisphere (θ from π/2 to π) is held at φ = 0. (Here the polar angle θ is measured from the positive z‐axis.) Because we are only interested in the potential outside the sphere (r ≥ R) and wish to keep terms that decay no faster than 1/r⁴ (i.e. we must include terms up to and including 1/r⁴), we will need the l = 0, 1, 2, and 3 terms in the Legendre expansion (note that the l = 2 term will turn out to vanish).

Step 1. General Solution for r ≥ R

Since there is azimuthal symmetry (no φ dependence), the general solution of Laplace’s equation outside the sphere is given by

  φ(r, θ) = Σₗ₌₀∞ Aₗ (R/r)^(l+1) Pₗ(cosθ).

It is convenient to write the solution in the form

  φ(r, θ) = A₀ (R/r) P₀(cosθ) + A₁ (R/r)² P₁(cosθ) + A₂ (R/r)³ P₂(cosθ) + A₃ (R/r)⁴ P₃(cosθ) + … ,

where the constants Aₗ are to be determined by the boundary condition at r = R. (The use of (R/r)^(l+1) automatically gives the appropriate 1/r^(l+1) decay at infinity.)

Step 2. Applying the Boundary Condition at r = R

At r = R the potential must equal the prescribed value on the spherical surface:
  φ(R,θ) = f(θ) where
    f(θ) = φ₀  for 0 ≤ θ < π/2   (upper hemisphere),
      = 0   for π/2 < θ ≤ π  (lower hemisphere).

Thus, at r = R we have

  Σₗ₌₀∞ Aₗ Pₗ(cosθ) = f(θ).

To determine the coefficients Aₗ we use the orthogonality of the Legendre polynomials. Multiply both sides by Pₗ(cosθ) sinθ and integrate from θ = 0 to π. However, since f(θ) is nonzero only for 0 ≤ θ ≤ π/2 we get

  ∫₀^(π) f(θ) Pₗ(cosθ) sinθ dθ = φ₀ ∫₀^(π/2) Pₗ(cosθ) sinθ dθ.
 
A change of variable u = cosθ (so that sinθ dθ = –du) converts the integral limits from θ = 0 (u = 1) and θ = π/2 (u = 0). Then

  ∫₀^(π/2) Pₗ(cosθ) sinθ dθ = ∫₁^0 Pₗ(u)(–du) = ∫₀^1 Pₗ(u) du.

On using the orthogonality relation for Legendre polynomials, we find

  Aₗ = (2l+1)/2 φ₀ ∫₀^1 Pₗ(u) du.

Step 3. Evaluating the Integrals

We now compute

  Iₗ = ∫₀^1 Pₗ(u) du

for l = 0, 1, 2, 3 using the given forms:

  P₀(u) = 1,
  P₁(u) = u,
  P₂(u) = (3/2)u² – (1/2),
  P₃(u) = (5/2)u³ – (3/2)u.

• For l = 0:
  I₀ = ∫₀^1 1 du = 1.

• For l = 1:
  I₁ = ∫₀^1 u du = ½.

• For l = 2:
  I₂ = ∫₀^1 [(3/2)u² – (1/2)] du = (3/2)(1/3) – (1/2)(1) = ½ – ½ = 0.

• For l = 3:
  I₃ = ∫₀^1 [(5/2)u³ – (3/2)u] du 
    = (5/2)(1/4) – (3/2)(1/2) 
    = (5/8) – (3/4) = (5/8) – (6/8) = –1/8.

Thus, the coefficients are

  A₀ = (1)(φ₀/2)·I₀ = φ₀/2,
  A₁ = (3 φ₀/2)·(1/2) = (3 φ₀)/4,
  A₂ = (5 φ₀/2)(0) = 0,
  A₃ = (7 φ₀/2)·(–1/8) = –(7 φ₀)/16.

Step 4. Writing the Potential Outside (r ≥ R)

Keeping terms up to l = 3, we have

  φ(r, θ) = A₀ (R/r) P₀(cosθ) + A₁ (R/r)² P₁(cosθ) + A₃ (R/r)⁴ P₃(cosθ).

Substitute the coefficients and the Legendre polynomials:

  P₀(cosθ) = 1,
  P₁(cosθ) = cosθ,
  P₃(cosθ) = (5/2) cos³θ – (3/2) cosθ.

Thus,

  φ(r, θ) = (φ₀/2)(R/r)
      + (3 φ₀/4)(R/r)² cosθ
      – (7 φ₀/16)(R/r)⁴ [(5/2) cos³θ – (3/2) cosθ].

It is sometimes preferable to write the last term with the factor of 1/2 absorbed:

  φ(r, θ) = (φ₀/2)(R/r)
      + (3 φ₀/4)(R/r)² cosθ
      – (7 φ₀/32)(R/r)⁴ [5 cos³θ – 3 cosθ].

This expansion is valid for all points outside the conductor, i.e. for r ≥ R, with terms falling off as 1/r, 1/r², and 1/r⁴.

Final Answer in LaTeX Boxed Form:

\[
\boxed{
\phi(r,\theta)=\frac{\phi_0}{2}\left(\frac{R}{r}\right)
+\frac{3\phi_0}{4}\left(\frac{R}{r}\right)^2\cos\theta
-\frac{7\phi_0}{32}\left(\frac{R}{r}\right)^4\left(5\cos^3\theta-3\cos\theta\right)
}
\]

-\frac{7\phi_0}{32}\left(\frac{R}{r}\right)^4\left(5\cos^3\theta-3\cos\theta\right)

solution:
We wish to compute the surface charge density induced on an infinite grounded (zero‐potential) conductor lying in the plane 
  z = 0
by an electric dipole

  p = P (sinθ, 0, cosθ)
located at (0, 0, z₀) (with z₀ > 0). (We have chosen our x–axis so that the in‐plane projection of p is along x; then p ⋅ e_z = P cosθ.) One very convenient method is to use the method of images. (Any answer equivalent to the answer below is correct.)

───────────────────────────── 
Step 1. Set Up the Image Problem

For a point charge q at (0,0,z₀) above a grounded conductor (z = 0) the image is a charge –q at (0,0,–z₀). For a dipole the answer is a little more complicated. One may show that if the (real) dipole has moment

  p = (p_x, 0, p_z)  with  p_x = P sinθ, p_z = P cosθ,
then one may satisfy the boundary condition φ = 0 at z = 0 (by the method of images) by placing an image dipole at (0,0,–z₀) with moment
  p′ = (–p_x, 0, p_z) = (–P sinθ, 0, P cosθ).

Thus the potential in the half‐space z ≥ 0 is given by the superposition
  φ(r) = φ_real(r) + φ_image(r)
where
  φ_real(r) = [p · (r – r₀)]⁄[4πε₀ |r – r₀|³], r₀ = (0,0,z₀),
  φ_image(r) = [p′ · (r – r′)]⁄[4πε₀ |r – r′|³], r′ = (0,0,–z₀).
One may check that on the plane z = 0 these two terms cancel so that φ(x,y,0) = 0.

───────────────────────────── 
Step 2. Finding the Induced Charge Density

Once the potential in the region z > 0 is known, the induced surface charge density on the conductor (which is a perfect metal held at zero potential) is given by
  σ(x,y) = –ε₀ [∂φ/∂z]₍z=0⁺₎,
since the (normal) electric field just above the conductor is 
  E_z = –(∂φ/∂z)
and the field inside the conductor (z < 0) is zero.

It is easiest to compute the field by “summing the fields” of the real and image dipoles. (One may also differentiate the total potential on z = 0⁺.)

For a point dipole p located at r₀ the electric field is given by
  E(r) = (1/(4πε₀)) { 3[p · R] R – p R² }⁄R⁵,
with R = r – r₀. (This formula applies to either dipole if we use the appropriate p and r₀; note that R and R² denote the vector difference and its squared magnitude.)

Let us now take the field point on the conductor r = (x, y, 0). Define
  ρ = √(x² + y²).
Then:
• For the real dipole at (0, 0, z₀) we have
  R₁ = (x, y, –z₀)  with  |R₁|² = ρ² + z₀².
Its z‐component of the field is
  Eᶻ₁ = [1/(4πε₀)] {[3(p · R₁)(–z₀) – p_z (ρ² + z₀²)]⁄(ρ²+z₀²)^(5/2)}.
Since p · R₁ = p_x x + p_z (0 – z₀) = P sinθ·x – P cosθ·z₀, we have
  Eᶻ₁ = [1/(4πε₀)] { –3P z₀ sinθ x + 3P z₀² cosθ – P cosθ (ρ² + z₀²) }⁄(ρ²+z₀²)^(5/2).

• For the image dipole at (0, 0, –z₀) with moment p′ = (–P sinθ,0,P cosθ), we similarly find
  R₂ = (x, y, z₀)  with  |R₂|² = ρ² + z₀².
Now, p′ · R₂ = (–P sinθ) x + P cosθ·z₀.
Thus,
  Eᶻ₂ = [1/(4πε₀)] { 3(p′ · R₂)(z₀) – p′_z (ρ²+z₀²) }⁄(ρ²+z₀²)^(5/2)
which works out to
  Eᶻ₂ = [1/(4πε₀)] { –3P sinθ x z₀ + 3P cosθ z₀² – P cosθ (ρ²+z₀²) }⁄(ρ²+z₀²)^(5/2).

Thus, the total z‐component is
  Eᶻ = Eᶻ₁ + Eᶻ₂ = [1/(4πε₀)] { –6 P z₀ sinθ x + 4P cosθ z₀² – 2P cosθ ρ² }⁄(ρ²+z₀²)^(5/2).

Then the induced charge density is
  σ(x,y) = –ε₀ Eᶻ
which gives
  σ(x,y) = –(ε₀/(4πε₀)) { –6 P z₀ sinθ x + 4P cosθ z₀² – 2P cosθ ρ² }⁄(ρ²+z₀²)^(5/2)
or, simplifying,
  σ(x,y) = 1/(4π) { 6 P z₀ sinθ x – 4P cosθ z₀² + 2P cosθ ρ² }⁄(ρ²+z₀²)^(5/2).

It is sometimes preferable to express the answer in polar coordinates. Writing x = ρ cosφ we have

  σ(ρ, φ) = [P/(4π)] { 6 z₀ sinθ ρ cosφ + 2 cosθ (ρ² – 2z₀²) }⁄(ρ²+z₀²)^(5/2).

───────────────────────────── 
Step 3. Final Answer

Thus one acceptable final answer is

  σ(ρ, φ) = (P/(4π)) [6 z₀ sinθ ρ cosφ + 2 cosθ (ρ² – 2z₀²)]⁄(ρ²+z₀²)^(5/2),

with ρ = √(x²+y²) and φ the polar angle in the xy‐plane.

Any answer equivalent to the boxed result below is correct.

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answer

\[
\boxed{
\sigma(\rho,\phi) = \frac{P}{4\pi}\,\frac{6z_0\,\sin\theta\,\rho\cos\phi + 2\cos\theta\,\Bigl(\rho^2 - 2z_0^2\Bigr)}{\,\bigl(\rho^2+z_0^2\bigr)^{5/2}}\quad,\quad \rho=\sqrt{x^2+y^2}\,.
}
\]

This is the induced charge density on the conducting plane.

solution:
We wish to “design” a coaxial capacitor in such a way that the energy‐density in the dielectric is constant. (By “energy density” we mean the electromagnetic energy density stored in the dielectric.) That is, if the energy density is

  u(r) = ½ ε₀ K(r) E(r)²   (1)

we require that u(r) is independent of the radius r (so that there are no internal stresses associated with a nonuniform energy distribution).

In the usual cylindrical geometry the capacitor has an inner conductor at radius a and an outer conductor at radius b. In the present problem the dielectric constant is allowed to vary with r (i.e. it is “inhomogeneous” and we write it as K(r)). When the capacitor is charged the voltage difference between the two conductors is V.

Let us proceed step by step.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Use Gauss’s law

In any dielectric the displacement field is defined by

  D(r) = ε₀ K(r) E(r).

For a cylindrical Gaussian surface of length L and radius r (with a ≤ r ≤ b) the free charge enclosed is λL where λ is the charge per unit length on the inner conductor. Gauss’s law (in integral form) then states

  ∮D·da = D(r) (2πrL) = λL,
  ⇒ D(r) = λ/(2πr).

Thus we have

  ε₀ K(r) E(r) = λ/(2πr)   (2)
  ⇒ E(r) = λ/(2π ε₀ K(r) r).

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. Write the energy density

The electromagnetic energy density in the dielectric is given by

  u(r) = (1/2) ε₀ K(r) E(r)²

Substitute the expression (2) for E(r):

  u(r) = ½ ε₀ K(r) ⋅ [λ/(2π ε₀ K(r) r)]²
     = ½ ε₀ K(r) ⋅ λ²/(4π² ε₀² K(r)² r²)
     = λ²/(8π² ε₀) ⋅ [1/(K(r) r²)].   (3)

Since we wish u(r) to be independent of r, the r–dependence must cancel in Eq. (3). That is, we require

  1/(K(r) r²) = constant   or equivalently  
  K(r) r² = constant.

It is therefore natural to define a constant C so that

  K(r) = C/r².   (4)

Then Eq. (3) becomes

  u(r) = λ²/(8π² ε₀) ⋅ r²/(C r²) = λ²/(8π² ε₀ C),
a constant independent of r.

──────────────────────────────
Step 3. Express the electric field

Now that we have found the required r–dependence of the dielectric constant, we substitute (4) for K(r) into our expression (2) for E(r):

  E(r) = λ/(2π ε₀ (C/r²) r)
     = λ/(2π ε₀) ⋅ r²/(C r)
     = λ r/(2π ε₀ C).   (5)

Thus the electric field is linear in r. (This is in contrast with the usual 1/r variation in a homogeneous capacitor.)

──────────────────────────────
Step 4. Determine the constant C in terms of the applied voltage V

The voltage difference between the inner (r = a) and outer (r = b) conductors is

  V = ∫ₐᵇ E(r) dr.

Using (5) we have

  V = ∫ₐᵇ λ r/(2π ε₀ C) dr = λ/(2π ε₀ C) ∫ₐᵇ r dr
    = λ/(2π ε₀ C) ⋅ [½ (b² – a²)]
    = λ(b² – a²)/(4π ε₀ C).   (6)

Thus, the charge per unit length is related to the voltage and constant C by

  λ = 4π ε₀ C V/(b² – a²).   (7)

We could use (7) to express other quantities (for example, the constant energy density)

  u = λ²/(8π² ε₀ C)
   = 1/(8π² ε₀ C) ⋅ [4π ε₀ C V/(b² – a²)]²
   = 2 ε₀ C V²/(b² – a²)²,
which is indeed independent of r.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

Thus, under the condition that the energy density is constant, the dielectric constant must vary as

  K(r) = C/r²,
with the constant C determined by the overall voltage via
  V = λ(b² – a²)/(4π ε₀ C).

Equivalently, if one prefers to “anchor” C by giving the value of the dielectric at the inner radius (say, K(a)), then
  C = a² K(a)
and one may also write
  K(r) = K(a) (a/r)².

Furthermore, the electric field inside the capacitor is

  E(r) = λ r/(2π ε₀ C)
or, after substituting λ from (7),
  E(r) = [4π ε₀ C V/(b² – a²)]⋅r/(2π ε₀ C)
    = (2V r)/(b² – a²).

This electric field increases linearly with r, and when used in
  u = ½ε₀K(r)E(r)²,
one easily verifies that the energy density is a constant,
  u = 2 ε₀ C V²/(b² – a²)²,
independent of r.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer in Boxed Form

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
K(r)&=\frac{C}{\,r^2} \quad \text{(or equivalently }K(r)=K(a)\Bigl(\frac{a}{r}\Bigr)^2\text{)},\\[1mm]
E(r)&=\frac{2V}{b^2-a^2}\,r,\\[1mm]
\text{with}\quad V&=\frac{\lambda\,(b^2-a^2)}{4\pi\epsilon_0\,C}\;.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

Any answer equivalent to the one given above is correct.

We wish to model the cloud as having a “dipole” charge distribution: a positive charge (+q) at the top of the cloud and a negative charge (–q) at the bottom. The bottom is 300 m above the ground and the top is 300 m above that (i.e. at 600 m). (In the following coordinates the z‐axis points upward.) It turns out that in a region where no other charges exist, the only electric field present at the ground is produced by these two charges. (Of course, the earth is a grounded conductor that responds to the cloud’s field, and that response exerts forces on the cloud. In our treatment we use the “method of images” to estimate that force.) We now describe, step by step, how one may obtain an estimate for the magnitude of the individual charges and then the net external force (its magnitude and direction) acting on the cloud.

─────────────────────────────  
STEP 1. ESTIMATE OF q FROM THE MEASURED FIELD

A vertical electric field E = 100 V/m is recorded at the ground (z = 0). (For our discussion we assume that the measured value gives the magnitude; note that there is some discussion in the literature about the “polarity”. Here, by our sign–convention the field produced by a positive charge is directed radially outward and that from a negative charge is toward the charge.) We now compute the contributions from the two charges, whose positions are:
  • Charge +q at z = 600 m.
  • Charge –q at z = 300 m.

The electric field at a field point r coming from a point charge q located at r₀ is

  E = (1 / (4πε₀)) · [q/(|r – r₀|²)] ⋅ r̂

where r̂ is the unit vector (pointing from the charge to the field point). At the ground (r = 0) the contributions are:

1. For the positive charge at z = 600 m:
  The displacement is r – r₀ = (0 – 600) ẑ = –600 ẑ.
  Thus,
   E₊ = (kq)/(600²) (–ẑ),    with k = 1/(4πε₀) ≈ 9×10⁹ N·m²/C².

2. For the negative charge at z = 300 m:
  The displacement is r – r₀ = (0 – 300) ẑ = –300 ẑ.
  Since the charge is –q the formula gives:
   E₋ = k(–q)/(300²) (–ẑ) = + kq/(300²) (ẑ).

Thus the net field at the ground is

  E_net = E₊ + E₋ = – (kq)/(600²) ẑ + (kq)/(300²) ẑ.

Notice that the two contributions are in opposite directions. Writing numbers,
  1/600² = 1/(360000)
and 1/300² = 1/(90000).
So,
  E_net = kq [1/90000 – 1/360000] ẑ = kq [ (4 – 1)/360000 ] ẑ = kq (3/360000) ẑ.
That is,
  E_net = (9×10⁹ · q · 3)/(360000) ẑ.

Evaluating the constant:
  (9×10⁹ × 3)/(360000) = (27×10⁹)/(360000) = 75000   (approximately).

Thus, we have
  E_net = 75000·q ẑ  (with q in coulombs, and E in V/m).

The measured field has a magnitude of 100 V/m so setting |E_net| = 100 V/m gives

  75000·q = 100  ⇒  q ≈ 100/75000 ≈ 1.33×10⁻³ C.

(One may note that with our sign–convention, the net field we computed points upward; whether the field measured on the ground is said to be “upward” or “downward” depends on how one defines the positive direction. Here we focus on the magnitude.)

─────────────────────────────  
STEP 2. COMPUTING THE EXTERNAL FORCE ON THE CLOUD

Even though the cloud is “electrically neutral” (the two charges sum to zero), it has a dipole moment. (In fact, the cloud’s charges are separated by 300 m so that its dipole moment is approximately p = q·300.) In a uniform field, a dipole experiences a torque but no net force. However, here the cloud is located near the earth—a grounded conductor. The charges on the cloud induce charges (or equivalently, we may trick ourselves by using the method of images). In the method of images one replaces the grounded plane by “image” charges placed below the ground. These image charges then exert forces on the real charges.

For a point charge q at a height h above a conducting plane held at zero potential, the method of images tells us that you can replace the influence of the plane by placing an “image charge” –q at the mirror location (i.e. at z = –h). The force on the real charge is then simply the Coulomb force due to its image.
The distance between the charge and its image is 2h so the magnitude of the force is

  F = k · q · | –q |/(2h)² = (kq²)/(4h²).

This force is attractive, meaning it pulls the real charge toward the plane (i.e. downward).

Now our cloud has two charges:
  (i) The top charge +q at h = 600 m, and
  (ii) The bottom charge –q at h = 300 m.

Thus, using the above expression we have:
  • On the top charge:
  F_top = kq²/(4·600²)
  • On the bottom charge:
  F_bottom = kq²/(4·300²)

Numerically:
  600² = 360000 and 300² = 90000.

Thus,
  F_top = (9×10⁹ · q²)/(4×360000),
  F_bottom = (9×10⁹ · q²)/(4×90000).

The net force on the cloud is the sum of the forces on the two charges. (Even though one of the charges is negative, note that both experience an attractive force toward the ground.) Hence,

  F_net = F_top + F_bottom = kq²/(4) [1/600² + 1/300²].

Compute the bracketed term:
  1/600² + 1/300² = 1/360000 + 1/90000 = (1 + 4)/360000 = 5/360000 = 1/72000.

Thus,
  F_net = (9×10⁹·q²)/(4) · (1/72000) = [9×10⁹/(288000)] · q².

Now we already found q ≈ 1.33×10⁻³ C. Squaring this,
  q² ≈ (1.33×10⁻³)² ≈ 1.77×10⁻⁶ C².

So,
  F_net ≈ (9×10⁹ × 1.77×10⁻⁶)/(288000).

First, compute the numerator:
  9×10⁹ ×1.77×10⁻⁶ ≈ 15.93×10³ = 15930.
Then,
  F_net ≈ 15930/288000 ≈ 0.0553 N.

The force is directed downward (i.e. toward the ground) since both charges are pulled toward their images.

─────────────────────────────  
FINAL ANSWER

The estimated magnitudes are

  q ≈ 1.3×10⁻³ C  and  F_ext ≈ 5.5×10⁻² N downward.

In boxed LaTeX format the final answer is:

\[
\boxed{q\approx1.3\times10^{-3}\,{\rm C}\quad,\quad F_{\rm ext}\approx5.5\times10^{-2}\,{\rm N}\, (\mbox{downward})}
\]

solution:
We wish to make a capacitor out of three concentric spherical shells having radii

  inner: r = a   
  intermediate: r = b  
  outer: r = d       (with a < b < d)

and we are told that the inner (r = a) and the outer (r = d) shells are connected by a fine insulated wire (with the effects of the hole neglected). In effect these two shells become one “combined conductor” which, together with the isolated intermediate shell (r = b) forms a two‐plate capacitor.

A physical picture of the situation is as follows. Writing

 – Let the one “big” conductor (the one formed by the union of the inner and outer shells) have total charge –Q_B. (This will be induced by any net charge Q_B placed on the intermediate shell so that overall charge is conserved.)  
 – The isolated intermediate shell is given a charge Q_B.

Furthermore, when two conductors are separated by an insulator the charges reside on the surfaces and the “facing” surfaces have equal and opposite charges so that the electric field in the conductor is zero. In our case a little thought shows that the configuration is equivalent to having two spherical capacitors in series:

1. A “small” spherical capacitor with inner sphere at r = a and the “inner” surface of the intermediate shell (facing the inner conductor) at r = b.
2. A “large” spherical capacitor with inner surface of the intermediate shell (facing the outer conductor) at r = b and the outer sphere (r = d).

We now explain in detail how to compute both the overall capacitance and the way in which a net charge Q_B on the intermediate shell appears on its two surfaces.

─────────────────────────────  
Step 1. (a) Finding the capacitance

For a standard spherical capacitor with inner radius r₁ and outer radius r₂ the capacitance is well known to be

  C = 4πε₀/(1/r₁ – 1/r₂) = 4πε₀ r₁r₂/(r₂ – r₁).

Thus, for our “small” capacitor we have

  C₁ = 4πε₀/(1/a – 1/b) = 4πε₀ab/(b – a),

and for the “large” capacitor

  C₂ = 4πε₀/(1/b – 1/d) = 4πε₀bd/(d – b).

Since these two capacitors are in series (with the intermediate shell acting as the common plate), the effective capacitance C_eff (which is the capacitance between the combined inner/outer spheres and the intermediate one) satisfies

  1/C_eff = 1/C₁ + 1/C₂.

That is,
  1/C_eff = (1/a – 1/b)/(4πε₀) + (1/b – 1/d)/(4πε₀)
       = [ (1/a – 1/b) + (1/b – 1/d) ]/(4πε₀)
       = (1/a – 1/d)/(4πε₀).

Inverting, we immediately obtain

  C_eff = 4πε₀/(1/a – 1/d) = 4πε₀ ad/(d – a).

Thus, the capacitance of the whole system is exactly the same as that of a spherical capacitor with inner radius a and outer radius d.

─────────────────────────────  
Step 2. (b) Distribution of a net charge Q_B on the intermediate sphere

Label the surfaces as follows:

 – On the combined conductor: the inner sphere at r = a carries a charge Q_A and the outer sphere at r = d carries a charge Q_D. Since they are connected, they must be at the same potential and they add to
   Q_A + Q_D = –Q_B     (charge conservation).

 – On the intermediate shell (r = b) the conductor is a single piece so that its two surfaces may carry different charges but the total is
   Q_B = Q_B(inner) + Q_B(outer).

Now, because the charges on facing surfaces of a capacitor are equal and opposite, the following holds:

 • In the small capacitor formed by the r = a and r = b surfaces the charge on the inner surface (that of the intermediate shell) is exactly opposite to the charge on the inner sphere. That is,
   Q_B(inner) = – Q_A.

 • In the large capacitor formed by the r = b and r = d surfaces the charge on the outer surface of the intermediate shell is opposite to that on the outer sphere. That is,
   Q_B(outer) = – Q_D.

Thus, we may write
  Q_B = Q_B(inner) + Q_B(outer) = –Q_A – Q_D.
But since Q_A + Q_D = –Q_B this is indeed consistent.

The next step is to determine how the charges Q_A and Q_D (or equivalently, Q_B(inner) and Q_B(outer)) are “divided”. This is done by noting that the potential difference from the intermediate shell to the combined conductor must be the same whether it is computed by “looking” at the inner capacitor or the outer capacitor. (That is, the middle shell is a single conductor so its potential is uniform.) If we let ΔV = V_B – V_A then

  ΔV = (charge on the capacitor)/(its capacitance).

Thus, looking at the small capacitor we have

  ΔV = Q_A/C₁           (remember that Q_A on the inner sphere is equal in magnitude to the charge induced on the intermediate shell’s inner surface).

Likewise, looking at the large capacitor we have

  ΔV = Q_D/C₂.

But since the potential difference is the same we must have

  Q_A / C₁ = Q_D / C₂        (1)

This immediately tells us that the charges on the two parts of the combined conductor (and hence the induced charges on the two faces of the intermediate shell) are in the ratio

  Q_A : Q_D = C₁ : C₂.

Since we already know that

  Q_A + Q_D = – Q_B,
it is natural to define
  Q_A = –Q_B [C₁/(C₁+C₂)]   and  Q_D = –Q_B [C₂/(C₁+C₂)].

Recalling now that the charge on the intermediate sphere is induced as

  Q_B(inner) = – Q_A = Q_B [C₁/(C₁+C₂)]
  Q_B(outer) = – Q_D = Q_B [C₂/(C₁+C₂)],

we have found the required distribution.

It is sometimes useful to write C₁ and C₂ explicitly. Recall

  C₁ = 4πε₀ab/(b – a),   C₂ = 4πε₀bd/(d – b).

Thus, one may also write
  Q_B(inner) = Q_B · [ab/(b – a)] / [ab/(b – a) + bd/(d – b)]
  Q_B(outer) = Q_B · [bd/(d – b)] / [ab/(b – a) + bd/(d – b)].

An equivalent rearrangement is to write the fractions as

  Q_B(inner) = Q_B · [a(d – b)]/[a(d – b) + d(b – a)]
  Q_B(outer) = Q_B · [d(b – a)]/[a(d – b) + d(b – a)].

These formulas express exactly how any net charge Q_B placed on the intermediate shell will split itself between its two surfaces.

─────────────────────────────  
Final Answers

(a) The capacitance of the system is

  C = 4πε₀/(1/a – 1/d) = 4πε₀ ad/(d – a).

(b) If a net charge Q_B is placed on the intermediate sphere then the charges on its inner and outer surfaces are given by

  Q_B(inner) = Q_B · [C₁/(C₁+C₂)]  and  Q_B(outer) = Q_B · [C₂/(C₁+C₂)],

where

  C₁ = 4πε₀ab/(b – a)  and  C₂ = 4πε₀bd/(d – b).

Thus, equivalently,

  Q_B(inner) = Q_B · [a(d – b)]/[a(d – b) + d(b – a)],
  Q_B(outer) = Q_B · [d(b – a)]/[a(d – b) + d(b – a)].

─────────────────────────────  
Final Answer in Latex Box

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad & C = \frac{4\pi\epsilon_0}{\frac{1}{a} - \frac{1}{d}}
= \frac{4\pi\epsilon_0\,ad}{d-a},\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad & Q_B\text{ splits as } 
\begin{cases}
Q_{B}(\text{inner}) = Q_B\,\dfrac{C_1}{C_1+C_2}
= Q_B\,\frac{a(d-b)}{a(d-b)+d(b-a)},\\[2mm]
Q_{B}(\text{outer}) = Q_B\,\dfrac{C_2}{C_1+C_2}
= Q_B\,\frac{d(b-a)}{a(d-b)+d(b-a)},
\end{cases}\\[2mm]
& \text{with } C_1=\frac{4\pi\epsilon_0\,ab}{b-a}\quad \text{and}\quad C_2=\frac{4\pi\epsilon_0\,bd}{d-b}\,.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We wish to compare the force acting on an electron (with charge –e) that is “co‐moving” with the conduction electrons of a current‐carrying wire (in the sense that its speed v equals the drift speed v₍d₎ in the wire) as seen in different inertial frames. In what follows we shall work step by step and (keeping only the lowest‐order relativistic correction) show that when one properly transforms the fields, the electron experiences the same overall four‐force though the “origin” of the spatial part (electric vs. magnetic) depends on the chosen frame.

────────────────────────────
Step (a): Force in the Lab Frame

In the lab frame the wire is at rest and carries a uniform current I in the +x direction. (Its charge neutrality means that any charge density on the wire is zero in the lab frame.) An electron moves to the right with instantaneous velocity

  v⃗ = v x̂   (with v << c).

The distance from the wire to the electron is y (say, in the ±y direction; we assume y>0 for concreteness). The magnetic field at a distance y from an infinitely long wire is

  B = (μ₀I)/(2πy)
    and its direction is determined by the right‐hand rule. For a current along +x, if the field point is above the wire (along +y) then the magnetic field is directed into the page (–ẑ).

Thus we write the magnetic field as

  B⃗ = – (μ₀I)/(2πy) ẑ.

Since the electron (charge −e) is moving with velocity v⃗ = v x̂, the magnetic force is given by

  F⃗ = (–e)(v⃗ × B⃗).

Let us compute the cross product:
  v⃗ × B⃗ = v x̂ × [–(μ₀I)/(2πy) ẑ] = – v (μ₀I)/(2πy) (x̂ × ẑ).

Recall that
  x̂ × ẑ = – ŷ .
Thus,
  v⃗ × B⃗ = – v (μ₀I)/(2πy) (– ŷ) = v (μ₀I)/(2πy) ŷ.

Therefore, the force is

  F⃗ = (–e) [ v (μ₀I)/(2πy) ŷ ] = – e v (μ₀I)/(2πy) ŷ.

That is, in the lab frame the force on the electron is downward (in the –y direction) with magnitude

  |F| = e v (μ₀I)/(2πy).

────────────────────────────
Step (b): Force in the Electron’s Rest Frame

Now boost to the electron’s frame. In this frame the electron is instantaneously at rest. (We shall be careful to include lowest‐order relativistic corrections even though v is small.)

How does the wire look in this frame? Recall that in the lab frame the wire consists of two charge “fluids”:
 • Positive ions: at rest in the lab with density n₊.
 • Conduction electrons: drifting to the right with speed v₍d₎ = v and lab density n₋.
Because the wire is neutral, n₊ = n₋ = n.

In the electron’s rest frame the conduction electrons (which in the lab move at v) are now at rest. Their proper density is higher than the density measured in the lab by the usual Lorentz factor. (To first order we have γ ≈ 1 + ½(v²/c²), but we will keep the structure of the result.) In contrast, the positive ions (which were at rest in the lab) are now seen to move to the left with speed v. Their density is increased by the Lorentz contraction, so that (to first order) their density in the electron frame is

  n₊′ = γ n.

On the other hand, the conduction electrons have laboratory density n₋ = n; but since their proper density is n_proper = γ n (because they are moving in the lab), in the electron frame (in which they are now at rest) their density becomes

  n₋′ = n_proper = γ n.

Thus the two densities are still exactly equal, and the wire remains (locally) electrically neutral in the electron frame. (This “accidental” cancellation occurs because we assumed that the electron’s speed v equals the conduction electron drift speed v₍d₎. For any other value one finds a small net charge density [and hence electric field] in the electron’s rest frame.)

Nevertheless, even though in the lab frame there was no electric field (E⃗_lab = 0) and only a magnetic field, in a boosted frame the fields mix. In fact, the Lorentz transformation (to first order in v/c) tells us that if in the lab frame E⃗_lab = 0 then in the electron frame the “new” electric field is

  E⃗′ = v⃗ × B⃗.

We already know that in the lab frame
  B⃗ = – (μ₀I)/(2πy) ẑ   and  v⃗ = v x̂.
Thus,
  E⃗′ = v x̂ × [ – (μ₀I)/(2πy) ẑ ]
      = – v (μ₀I)/(2πy) (x̂ × ẑ).

But as before, x̂ × ẑ = –ŷ, so

  E⃗′ = – v (μ₀I)/(2πy) (– ŷ) = v (μ₀I)/(2πy) ŷ.

Now the electron is at rest in this frame so the magnetic (v × B) force does not operate. Instead the force comes solely from the electric field:

  F⃗′ = (–e) E⃗′ = – e v (μ₀I)/(2πy) ŷ.

This is exactly the same as in the lab frame.

────────────────────────────
Step (c): Comparison and Comments on an Intermediate Frame

We have obtained:
 (a) In the lab frame (wire at rest, electron moving):
  F⃗_lab = – e v (μ₀I)/(2πy) ŷ  (purely magnetic force).

 (b) In the electron rest frame (electron at rest, wire moving):
  F⃗′ = – e v (μ₀I)/(2πy) ŷ  (purely electric force, arising by way of field‐mixing).

Thus the numerical force (and even its direction) is the same when properly computed in the two frames. (It is important to stress that the splitting between “electric” and “magnetic” forces is not Lorentz invariant; only the four‐force is.) In an intermediate frame – for example, one moving at v′ = v/2 with respect to the lab frame – the electron is moving with a velocity that is neither zero nor v. In that frame the electron experiences both an electric field (coming partly from the transformed magnetic field) and a magnetic field (since the electron is moving relative to the fields); the force is then given by the sum

  F⃗ = –e [ E⃗ + v′ × B⃗ ].

The partitioning between the electric and magnetic contributions depends on the frame; however, when they are added the net force will be (to the appropriate order in v/c) consistent with the invariant four‐force. In other words, while in the lab frame the force is “purely magnetic” and in the electron frame “purely electric”, in a frame moving at v/2 the force is a combination of electric and magnetic parts. (Quantitatively, small relativistic corrections of order v²/c² would appear in a careful analysis; these ensure the proper Lorentz‐covariance of the dynamics.)

────────────────────────────
Final Answer

Thus, one acceptable answer is

(a) In the lab frame, the force on the electron is 
  F⃗_lab = – e • [v (μ₀I)/(2πy)] ŷ.

(b) In the electron’s rest frame, the force is 
  F⃗′ = – e • [v (μ₀I)/(2πy)] ŷ,
 which arises from an electric field E⃗′ = v (μ₀I)/(2πy) ŷ produced by the Lorentz transformation of the magnetic field.

(c) In a frame moving at v′ = v/2 relative to the lab frame the electron (now moving at –v/2 with respect to that frame) sees both electric and magnetic fields. Although the splitting between “electric” and “magnetic” forces changes from one frame to another, the overall electromagnetic force (i.e. the four‐force) is the same. In the lab frame the force is entirely magnetic, in the electron frame it is entirely electric, and in an intermediate frame the force is a combination of both – a beautiful example of how the electric and magnetic fields are two sides of the same coin in special relativity.

────────────────────────────
Final Answer in Latex Box

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad & \mathbf{F}_{\text{lab}} = -e\,v\,\frac{\mu_0 I}{2\pi\,y}\,\hat{y}, \\
\text{(b)}\quad & \mathbf{F}' = -e\,v\,\frac{\mu_0 I}{2\pi\,y}\,\hat{y}\quad\text{(with }E' = v\times B\text{)}, \\
\text{(c)}\quad & \text{In a frame moving at }v'=\frac{v}{2}\text{ the electron sees both electric and magnetic fields,}\\
& \text{and although their individual contributions change, their sum yields the same overall force.}
\end{aligned}
}
