We are given a long wire of radius a carrying a uniform “free” current I along the z‐axis. The wire is made of a linear magnetic material with magnetic susceptibility χₘ so that its magnetization is

  M = χₘ H.

Because the material is uniformly magnetized only inside the wire (s < a) and the free current is uniformly distributed, our task is to compute:

1. The magnetic field (B) a distance s from the axis (both for s < a and s > a).
2. All the bound currents (both volume and surface).
3. The total (net) bound current flowing down the wire.

The solution proceeds step by step.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Magnetic Field Calculation

We start by finding the magnetic field in terms of H. In a linear material we have

  B = μ₀ (H + M) = μ₀ (1 + χₘ) H ≡ μ₀ μᵣ H    (1)

We first find H using Ampère’s law in its “free current” version:
  ∮ H · dl = I₍free,enclosed₎.

Because the free current density is uniform in the wire, we have:

  J₍free₎ = I/(π a²).

(a) For s < a (“inside” the wire):

Choose a circular Amperian loop of radius s. Then

  H (2π s) = I_free,enclosed = J_free · (π s²) = I s²/a².
Thus,
  H(s) = (I s)/(2π a²)    (in the φ̂ direction).

Then, from (1)
  B(s) = μ₀ (1+χₘ) (I s)/(2π a²)   for s < a.

(b) For s > a (“outside” the wire):

The entire free current I is enclosed. So

  H (2π s) = I  ⇒  H(s) = I/(2π s) (again in the φ̂ direction).
Then,
  B(s) = μ₀ (1+χₘ) I/(2π s)   for s > a.

Thus the magnetic field is

  For s < a: B(s) = [μ₀ (1+χₘ) I s/(2π a²)] φ̂,
  For s > a: B(s) = [μ₀ (1+χₘ) I/(2π s)] φ̂.

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. Bound Currents

The bound currents result from the magnetization M. Since M = χₘ H and H is known (and is purely in the φ̂ direction inside the wire, while outside the material M = 0), we now find the volume and surface bound currents.

Recall that:
 (a) The volume bound current density is given by
  J_b = ∇×M.
 (b) The surface bound current density is given by
  K_b = M × n̂,
at any surface where M is discontinuous (here at s = a). (There is no discontinuity at s = 0.)

Inside the wire (s < a) we have
  M(s) = χₘ H(s) = χₘ [I s/(2π a²)] φ̂.

A. Volume Bound Current, J_b = ∇×M:

In cylindrical coordinates (s, φ, z), if M has only a φ component (M_φ) that depends only on s, then the only nonzero component of the curl is in the z direction. Explicitly,
  (J_b)_z = (1/s) d/ds (s M_φ).
Here,
  M_φ = χₘ I s/(2π a²).

Compute:
  s M_φ = χₘ I s²/(2π a²).
Differentiating gives:
  d/ds (s M_φ) = χₘ I (2s)/(2π a²) = (χₘ I s)/(π a²).
Then,
  (J_b)_z = (1/s) (χₘ I s/(π a²)) = (χₘ I)/(π a²).
Thus, for s < a
  J_b = (χₘ I)/(π a²) ẑ. 
(There are no s or φ components.)

B. Surface Bound Current, K_b = M × n̂:

At the surface s = a the magnetization is
  M(a) = χₘ I a/(2π a²) φ̂ = (χₘ I)/(2π a) φ̂.
The outward normal (n̂) is the radial direction ŝ. Hence,
  K_b = M(a) × ŝ.
We need the cross product in cylindrical coordinates. We know that
  ŝ × φ̂ = ẑ  ⇒  φ̂ × ŝ = – ẑ.
Thus,
  K_b = (χₘ I)/(2π a) φ̂ × ŝ = – (χₘ I)/(2π a) ẑ.

──────────────────────────────
Step 3. Total Bound Current

The net bound current is the sum of the volume bound current integrated over the cross–section and the surface bound current integrated over the circumference.

Volume bound current total:

  I_b^(vol) = ∫ J_b · dA.
Since J_b is constant and directed in ẑ for s < a, we have
  I_b^(vol) = J_b (π a²) = (χₘ I)/(π a²) (π a²) = χₘ I.

Surface bound current total:

  I_b^(surf) = ∮ K_b · dl,
where dl = a dφ and K_b is uniform (in magnitude and direction) on the surface. Hence,
  I_b^(surf) = K_b (circumference) = [– (χₘ I)/(2π a)] (2π a) = –χₘ I.

Thus the net bound current is
  I_b^(net) = I_b^(vol) + I_b^(surf) = χₘ I – χₘ I = 0.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

The magnetic field, bound currents, and net bound current are given by:

1. For the magnetic field:
  For s < a:
   B(s) = (μ₀ (1+χₘ) I s)/(2π a²) φ̂,
  For s > a:
   B(s) = (μ₀ (1+χₘ) I)/(2π s) φ̂.

2. The bound current densities are:
 (a) Volume bound current (for s < a):
  J_b = (χₘ I)/(π a²) ẑ.
 (b) Surface bound current (at s = a):
  K_b = – (χₘ I)/(2π a) ẑ.

3. The net bound current (total over the cross–section) is zero.

Thus, our final boxed answer is:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(i)}\quad &B(s)=
\begin{cases}
\displaystyle \frac{\mu_0(1+\chi_m) I\,s}{2\pi a^2}\,\hat\phi,\quad s<a,\\[1mm]
\displaystyle \frac{\mu_0(1+\chi_m) I}{2\pi s}\,\hat\phi,\quad s>a;
\end{cases}\\[1mm]
\text{(ii)}\quad &\text{Bound current densities:}\\[1mm]
&J_b = \nabla\times M = \frac{\chi_m I}{\pi a^2}\,\hat z\quad (s<a),\\[1mm]
&K_b = M\times\hat n = -\frac{\chi_m I}{2\pi a}\,\hat z\quad \text{(at }s=a\text{)};\\[1mm]
\text{(iii)}\quad &\mbox{Net bound current } I_b = \chi_m I - \chi_m I = 0.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We will show step‐by‐step that one acceptable answer is as follows. (Any answer equivalent to the answer below is correct.)

Throughout we use SI units. In what follows the sphere has a fixed radius R and carries a “glued‐on” charge Q that is uniformly distributed on its surface so that
  σ = Q/(4π R²). In addition the sphere is uniformly magnetized
  M = M ẑ, 
so that it has a magnetic dipole moment
  m = (4πR³/3) M ẑ.

Let us now describe the answers to parts (a), (b) and (c).

──────────────────────────────
(a) Electric and Magnetic Fields

Because the (surface) charge is spherically symmetric the electric field is exactly that of a uniformly charged nonconducting sphere with all the charge on its surface. Hence using Gauss’s law we obtain

  • For r > R:
    E(r) = Q/(4πε₀ r²) r̂,
  • For r < R:
    E(r) = 0.

Next, the magnetization produces a magnetic field. (It is very important to note that a permanent magnet also produces a “bound‐current” distribution which, for a uniformly magnetized object, is equivalent to a dipole field outside and a uniform field inside.) One may show (by solving for the “bound currents”) that

  • For r < R, the field is uniform:
    B(r) = (2μ₀/3) M ẑ,
  • For r > R, the field is that of a point dipole:
    B(r) = (μ₀/4π)[3( m·r̂) r̂ – m]/r³.

Thus, a correct answer to (a) is

  E(r) = { Q/(4πε₀ r²) r̂  r > R,
       0        r < R, }
  B(r) = { (μ₀/4π)[3( m·r̂) r̂ – m]/r³  r > R,
       (2μ₀/3) M ẑ     r < R. }

──────────────────────────────
(b) Induced Electric Field, Torque, and Angular Momentum when Demagnetized

Now suppose that the magnetization is “switched off” slowly by heating the sphere above its Curie point. (In what follows we will assume that the demagnetization is uniform and slow enough that one may use quasi‐static arguments.) In other words, M = M(t) decreases from its initial value M (at t = 0) to zero. Because the magnetic field depends on M the time–variation of M produces an induced (non‐conservative) electric field E_ind by Faraday’s law

  ∇×E_ind = –∂B/∂t.

A very neat way to obtain E_ind is to note that in the “radiation–free” limit we may use the magnetostatic vector potential for a dipole (outside the magnetized body)
  A(r,t) = (μ₀/4π)[m(t)×r]/r³.
Since m(t) = (4πR³/3) M(t) ẑ one obtains
  ∂A/∂t = (μ₀/4π)[(dm/dt)×r]/r³.
Then, working in a gauge in which no scalar potential appears for the induced field,
  E_ind = –∂A/∂t = – (μ₀/4π)[(dm/dt)×r]/r³.
In particular, noting that for r = R (the sphere’s surface) we have
  m = (4πR³/3) M ẑ  and  dm/dt = (4πR³/3) (dM/dt) ẑ,
we deduce that
  E_ind(R) = – (μ₀/4π)[ (4πR³/3) (dM/dt) ẑ × r ]/R³
which simplifies to
  E_ind(R) = – (μ₀ R/(3)) (dM/dt) [ẑ×r̂].
A short calculation shows that
  ẑ×r̂ = sinθ φ̂,
so that on the surface (r = R) the induced electric field is
  E_ind(R,θ,φ) = – (μ₀ R/(3)) (dM/dt) sinθ φ̂.
This is the answer for the induced electric field.

Next, because the surface is charged the induced electric field exerts a force on each element of charge dq = σ dA. Its torque about the center is
  dτ = r × dq E_ind.
Since the only nonzero component comes from the φ –component of E_ind, one easily shows (by an elementary calculation in spherical coordinates) that the z–component of the total torque is
  τ_z = – (8π μ₀ σ R⁴/(9)) (dM/dt).
Substituting σ = Q/(4πR²) we deduce
  τ_z = – (2μ₀ Q R²/(9)) (dM/dt).

Integrating in time (and noting that dM/dt dt = dM) we obtain the total angular momentum imparted to the sphere about the z–axis as
  L_z = ∫ τ_z dt = – (2μ₀ Q R²/(9)) ∆M.
Since initially M = M and finally M = 0, one has ∆M = – M, so that
  L_z = (2μ₀ Q R² M)/(9).

Thus, the answers to (b) are:

 (i) The induced electric field on the sphere is
  E_ind(R,θ,φ) = – (μ₀ R/(3)) (dM/dt) sinθ φ̂.
 (ii) The instantaneous torque is
  τ_z = – (2μ₀ Q R²/(9)) (dM/dt),
 and the total angular momentum delivered to the sphere is
  L_z = (2μ₀ Q R² M)/(9).

──────────────────────────────
(c) Origin of the Angular Momentum

One may ask: How is it that a “dead” charge distribution (with no free currents) can start rotating? The answer is that before demagnetization the system carried electromagnetic angular momentum. In fact, when both an electric field from the charge and the magnetic field from the magnetization coexist, one may define a field–angular–momentum density
  l_EM = ε₀ r × (E × B),
and in our case one may show that the overall (hidden) angular momentum stored in the electromagnetic fields is exactly
  L_EM = (2μ₀ Q R² M)/(9) ẑ.
When the magnetization M is “turned off” the changing electromagnetic fields induce an electric field which in turn exerts forces on the charge distribution. In this way the (hidden) electromagnetic angular momentum is transferred to the sphere mechanically.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

We now summarize the answer in boxed form:

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad &E(\mathbf{r}) =
\begin{cases}
\displaystyle \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_0 r^2}\,\hat{\mathbf{r}},\quad r > R,\\[1mm]
0,\quad r < R,
\end{cases}\\[1mm]
&B(\mathbf{r}) =
\begin{cases}
\displaystyle \frac{\mu_0}{4\pi}\frac{3(\mathbf{m}\cdot\hat{\mathbf{r}})\hat{\mathbf{r}}-\mathbf{m}}{r^3},\quad r > R,\\[1mm]
\displaystyle \frac{2\mu_0}{3}\,M\,\hat{\mathbf z},\quad r < R,\quad\text{with }\mathbf{m}=\frac{4\pi R^3}{3}\,M\,\hat{\mathbf{z}},
\end{cases}\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad &\text{During a slow, uniform demagnetization (with }M=M(t)\text{),}\\[1mm]
&\quad E_{\rm ind}(R,\theta,\phi)
=-\frac{\mu_0 R}{3}\,\frac{dM}{dt}\,\sin\theta\,\hat{\boldsymbol{\varphi}},\\[1mm]
&\quad \tau_z(t)=-\frac{2\mu_0 Q R^2}{9}\,\frac{dM}{dt},\qquad
L_z=\frac{2\mu_0 Q R^2\,M}{9},\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}\quad &\text{This angular momentum comes from the electromagnetic field: the initial state carries}\\[1mm]
&\quad\text{a non‐zero (``hidden'') electromagnetic angular momentum }L_{\rm EM}=\frac{2\mu_0 Q R^2\,M}{9}\,\hat{\mathbf{z}},\\[1mm]
&\quad\text{which is transferred to the sphere as it demagnetizes.}
\end{aligned}
}
\]

Any answer which shows that (i) the electric field is that of a uniformly charged sphere and the magnetic field is that of a uniformly magnetized sphere (a uniform field inside, a dipole field outside), (ii) the induced electric field is 
  E_ind(R,θ,φ) = – (μ₀R/3)(dM/dt) sinθ φ̂,
and that the resulting torque (integrated over the charge distribution) imparts angular momentum
  L_z = (2μ₀Q R²M)/(9)
to the sphere (with this angular momentum coming from the field) is completely correct.

We will show that if an electromagnetic wave polarized in the plane of incidence (p‑polarized) strikes a planar interface that (in its own rest frame) separates two dielectrics of constants ε₁ and ε₂, then in the lab frame (in which the whole “dielectric apparatus” is moving along the interface normal with speed β c) the “observed” angles of reflection and transmission are modified by relativistic aberration. In what follows we shall denote by “primed” quantities the angles measured in the rest frame of the moving dielectric. (In what follows we use units in which c = 1 for brevity; one easily reinserts factors of c when needed.)

────────────────────────────
Step 1. Transforming the incidence direction into the rest frame

Suppose that in the lab frame a ray is incident at an angle θ_I (measured from the interface normal). In the lab the wave‐vector has components

  k⃗_I = k (sin θ_I, cos θ_I)
           (x is the “tangent” and y the “normal” direction).

A Lorentz boost (with speed β in the y‑direction) takes the lab “direction” into the dielectric rest frame. One finds (by the standard aberration formula) that the cosine and sine of the incidence angle in the rest frame (θ′_I) are
  
  (1) cos θ′_I = (cos θ_I − β)/(1 − β cos θ_I),
  (2) sin θ′_I = sin θ_I/(γ (1 − β cos θ_I)),
    with γ = 1/√(1 − β²).

────────────────────────────
Step 2. Reflection and refraction in the rest frame

In the rest frame the interface is stationary so that the usual rules hold. Specular reflection means that the reflected ray has the same angle of incidence as the incoming ray but “flips” the sign of the normal component. That is, if the incident ray in the rest frame has 
  (sin θ′_I, cos θ′_I),
then the reflected ray is
  (sin θ′_I, –cos θ′_I).

Similarly, Snell’s law holds in the rest frame, so that if we denote the transmitted (or refracted) angle by θ′_T then

  (3) n₁ sin θ′_I = n₂ sin θ′_T,  where n_i = √(ε_i).

────────────────────────────
Step 3. Transforming back to the lab frame

Now, to “read” what an observer in the lab sees, we must transform the directions of the reflected and transmitted rays back to the lab frame. For a general ray with an angle θ′ (measured in the rest frame) the inverse aberration formulas are

  (4) cos θ = (cos θ′ + β)/(1 + β cos θ′),
  (5) sin θ = sin θ′/(γ (1 + β cos θ′)).

(a) Reflection

For the reflected ray the rest‐frame angle is not “simply” θ′_I; one must take into account that the y‐component is reversed. In the rest frame the “reflected ray” has cosine equal to –cos θ′_I and sine still sin θ′_I. Thus, we use equation (4) with cos θ′ replaced by (–cos θ′_I):

  (6) cos θ_R = (–cos θ′_I + β)/(1 − β cos θ′_I).

But recall that cos θ′_I is given by (1). Inserting (1) into (6) and performing a short algebra we may show that

  (7) cos θ_R = [2β − (1 + β²) cos θ_I]⁄[1 − 2β cos θ_I + β²].

Then the lab–frame reflection angle is

  (8) θ_R = arccos{[2β − (1 + β²) cos θ_I]⁄[1 − 2β cos θ_I + β²]}.

(b) Transmission

For the transmitted ray the rest–frame direction is (sin θ′_T, cos θ′_T) with θ′_T determined from (3) and from (2):

  sin θ′_T = (n₁/n₂) sin θ′_I
with
  sin θ′_I = sin θ_I/(γ (1 − β cos θ_I)).

Then the cosine in the rest frame is

  cos θ′_T = √[1 − sin² θ′_T].

Transforming back via (4), we obtain

  (9) cos θ_T = (cos θ′_T + β)/(1 + β cos θ′_T).

Thus, the lab–frame transmission angle is

  (10) θ_T = arccos[(cos θ′_T + β)/(1 + β cos θ′_T)]
with
  (11) cos θ′_T = √[1 − (n₁/n₂)² (sin θ_I/(γ(1 − β cos θ_I)))²].

────────────────────────────
Step 4. Effect on the Fresnel coefficients

In the rest frame the Fresnel reflection and transmission coefficients for p–polarization are (see, e.g., Jackson)
  
  (12) r′_p = (ε₂ cos θ′_I − ε₁ cos θ′_T)/(ε₂ cos θ′_I + ε₁ cos θ′_T),
  (13) t′_p = 2 ε₂ cos θ′_I/(ε₂ cos θ′_I + ε₁ cos θ′_T).
  
Because the electromagnetic field amplitudes and the energy–flux (Poynting vector) transform in a known way under Lorentz boosts, one may show that when these coefficients are “translated” into the lab frame the only change is that the angles which appear in (12) and (13) are the aberrated ones. (There is also a Doppler–shift factor that appears when one compares the power; for the amplitude coefficients the “functional form” is the same provided one expresses the angles in the rest frame in terms of the lab–frame angle.) In other words, one may define the lab–frame coefficients by

  (14) r_p(θ_I) = r′_p[θ′_I(θ_I),θ′_T(θ_I)],
  (15) t_p(θ_I) = t′_p[θ′_I(θ_I),θ′_T(θ_I)].
That is, the motion of the medium enters only via the aberration formulas (1), (2) and (9)–(11).

────────────────────────────
Final Answer

An acceptable answer is to state that:

1. In going to the rest frame one uses
  
  cos θ′_I = (cos θ_I − β)/(1 − β cos θ_I),  sin θ′_I = sin θ_I/(γ(1 − β cos θ_I)).
  
2. In that frame the reflected ray is specular so that its angle is the same as for incidence but with reversed normal component. Transforming back to the lab frame gives
  
  cos θ_R = (–cos θ′_I + β)/(1 − β cos θ′_I)
which, after a little algebra, can be written as
  
  (8) θ_R = arccos{[2β − (1 + β²) cos θ_I]⁄[1 − 2β cos θ_I + β²]}.
  
3. Similarly, in the rest frame, Snell’s law requires
  
  n₁ sin θ′_I = n₂ sin θ′_T  with n_i = √(ε_i).
  
Then, writing
  
  cos θ′_T = √[1 − (n₁/n₂)² (sin θ_I/(γ(1 − β cos θ_I)))²],
  
and transforming back gives
  
  (10) θ_T = arccos[(cos θ′_T + β)/(1 + β cos θ′_T)].
  
4. Finally, in the rest frame the usual Fresnel coefficients for p–polarization are
  
  (12) r′_p = (ε₂ cos θ′_I − ε₁ cos θ′_T)/(ε₂ cos θ′_I + ε₁ cos θ′_T),  t′_p = 2 ε₂ cos θ′_I/(ε₂ cos θ′_I + ε₁ cos θ′_T).
  
Thus, when one goes back to the lab frame the effect of the motion of the dielectric is to “replace” the angles by the aberrated ones. (Any answer that is equivalent to the answer above is correct.)

We now summarize our final answer.

────────────────────────────
Final Answer in Boxed Form

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
&\textbf{Aberration:}\\[1mm]
&\cos\theta'_I = \frac{\cos\theta_I-\beta}{1-\beta\cos\theta_I},\qquad
\sin\theta'_I = \frac{\sin\theta_I}{\gamma(1-\beta\cos\theta_I)},\quad \gamma=\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\beta^2}},\\[1mm]
&\text{Specular reflection in the rest frame: } \theta'_R=\theta'_I,\\[1mm]
&\text{Transforming back, the lab–frame reflection angle is}\\[1mm]
&\quad \cos\theta_R=\frac{-\cos\theta'_I+\beta}{1-\beta\cos\theta'_I}
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad
\theta_R=\arccos\Biggl\{\frac{2\beta-(1+\beta^2)\cos\theta_I}{\,1-2\beta\cos\theta_I+\beta^2}\Biggr\},\\[2mm]
&\text{In the rest frame, Snell's law gives}\\[1mm]
&\quad n_1\sin\theta'_I=n_2\sin\theta'_T\quad\Longrightarrow\quad \sin\theta'_T=\frac{n_1}{n_2}\sin\theta'_I,\quad n_i=\sqrt{\epsilon_i},\\[1mm]
&\text{and hence } \cos\theta'_T=\sqrt{1-\Bigl(\frac{n_1}{n_2}\sin\theta'_I\Bigr)^2}.\\[1mm]
&\text{Transforming back:}\\[1mm]
&\quad \cos\theta_T=\frac{\cos\theta'_T+\beta}{1+\beta\cos\theta'_T}
\quad\Longrightarrow\quad \theta_T=\arccos\Biggl\{\frac{\cos\theta'_T+\beta}{1+\beta\cos\theta'_T}\Biggr\},\\[2mm]
&\textbf{Fresnel Coefficients (p–polarization):}\\[1mm]
&\quad r'_p=\frac{\epsilon_2\cos\theta'_I-\epsilon_1\cos\theta'_T}{\epsilon_2\cos\theta'_I+\epsilon_1\cos\theta'_T},\qquad
t'_p=\frac{2\epsilon_2\cos\theta'_I}{\epsilon_2\cos\theta'_I+\epsilon_1\cos\theta'_T}.\\[1mm]
&\text{Thus the lab–frame coefficients are obtained by using the angles } \theta'_I,\theta'_T \text{ expressed in terms of } \theta_I.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

Any answer equivalent to the above – namely, that the moving media “see” an aberrated incidence and refraction angle, and that the reflection and transmission coefficients are then given by the usual Fresnel formulas with these modified angles – is correct.

solution:
We are told that laser light of wavelength λ illuminates two slits whose centers are separated by d = 1000 λ. One slit is of width w₁ = 10 λ and the other is of width w₂ = 20 λ. (We assume that the light is uniform across the slits.) The light emerging from the slits produces an interference pattern on a screen a distance L away. In what follows, we work step‐by‐step.

──────────────────────────────
Step (a): Fringe Spacing of the Interference Pattern

When one neglects the finite slit widths and considers only the interference of two “point‐sources” separated by d, the condition for constructive interference is

  d sinθ = mλ      (m = 0, ±1, ±2, …).

For small angles (screen far away) sinθ ≃ tanθ ≃ y/L so that the mᵗʰ maximum is at

  yₘ ≃ (mλL)/d.

Thus, the spacing between adjacent interference maxima is

  δy = yₘ₊₁ – yₘ = Lλ/d.

Since d = 1000 λ, one finds

  δy = Lλ/(1000λ) = L/1000.
  
──────────────────────────────
Step (b): Central Maximum Widths of the Diffraction Patterns

Each slit, taken on its own, produces its own diffraction envelope. For a single slit of width w the first minima occur when

  w sinθ = ±λ.

For small angles, sinθ ≃ y/L so that the first minima lie at

  y = ± (Lλ)/w.

Thus, the full angular (or spatial) width of the central maximum (the distance between the first minima on either side) is

  Δy = 2Lλ/w.

Now, applying this formula to each slit:

For slit 1 (width w₁ = 10 λ):
  Δy₁ = 2Lλ/(10λ) = L/5.

For slit 2 (width w₂ = 20 λ):
  Δy₂ = 2Lλ/(20λ) = L/10.

──────────────────────────────
Step (c): Number of Interference Fringes in the Central Maximum

In the combined pattern the interference fringes are “modulated” by the single‐slit diffraction envelope. (That is, the overall intensity is the product of the interference pattern and the diffraction envelope.) When the slits are not identical, the final pattern is the product of the two single‐slit diffraction patterns and will be strongly limited by the narrower envelope. In our case the slit with the larger width (w₂ = 20 λ) produces an envelope of width Δy₂ = L/10 which is narrower than that for slit 1. Therefore, the observable interference fringes will be mostly “contained” in the central diffraction maximum of the broader interfering beam—that is, the narrower envelope from slit 2.

The number of interference fringes contained in an envelope is approximately given by dividing the envelope’s width by the fringe spacing:

  Number ≈ (Δy₂)/(δy) = (L/10)/(L/1000) = 1000/10 = 100.

Thus, about 100 interference fringes are visible inside the central diffraction envelope.

──────────────────────────────
Step (d): Ratio of Intensity Maxima to Intensity Minima

Because the two slits have different widths, they will send out waves with different amplitudes. (We assume uniform illumination so that the amplitude is proportional to the width of the slit.) Let the amplitude from slit 1 be A₁ and from slit 2 be A₂. We can take

  A₁ ∝ w₁ = 10 λ  and  A₂ ∝ w₂ = 20 λ.

For simplicity, we set A₁ = 1 (in arbitrary units) and A₂ = 2.

For two waves interfering with a phase difference, the resultant amplitude is A₁ + A₂ when the interference is constructive and |A₂ − A₁| when it is destructive. Hence:

• Maximum intensity (constructive interference):
  Iₘₐₓ ∝ (A₁ + A₂)² = (1 + 2)² = 9.

• Minimum intensity (destructive interference):
  Iₘᵢₙ ∝ (A₂ − A₁)² = (2 − 1)² = 1.

Thus, the ratio of intensity maxima to minima is

  Iₘₐₓ : Iₘᵢₙ = 9 : 1.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) Fringe spacing:  δy = L/1000.  
(b) Central maximum widths:  Δy₁ = L/5 for the 10 λ slit, and Δy₂ = L/10 for the 20 λ slit.  
(c) The number of interference fringes contained in the central diffraction maximum (set by the narrower envelope) is approximately 100.  
(d) The intensity ratio is 9:1.

──────────────────────────────

Step 1. Determine the Medium’s Permittivity

In a metal with free electrons, when an electromagnetic field is applied, the conduction electrons are displaced according to Newton’s equation of motion. With no damping and assuming a time dependence of e^(–iωt), the equation of motion for each electron is

  m d²x/dt² = –e E.

Since we are considering harmonic motion, we may let d²x/dt² = –ω² x, giving

  –mω² x = –e E  ⟹  x = (eE)/(mω²).

The polarization P, defined as the dipole moment per unit volume for electron density n, is

  P = –n e x = −(ne²)/(mω²) E.

The relation between polarization and the relative permittivity ε_r is given by

  P = ε₀(ε_r – 1) E  ⟹  ε₀(ε_r – 1) = −(ne²)/(mω²).

Thus the relative permittivity is

  ε_r = 1 − (ne²)/(ε₀mω²).

It is customary to define the plasma frequency ω_p by

  ω_p² = (ne²)/(ε₀ m).

Then the permittivity becomes

  ε_r = 1 − (ω_p²)/(ω²).

Step 2. Derive the Dispersion Relation

For an electromagnetic wave in a medium, Maxwell’s equations yield the dispersion relation:

  k² c² = ω² ε_r,

where c is the speed of light in vacuum. Substituting the expression for ε_r, we have

  k² c² = ω² (1 − (ω_p²)/(ω²)) = ω² − ω_p².

Taking the square root (and choosing the positive root for propagation), the wave vector k is

  k = √(ω² − ω_p²)/c.

This shows how the wave vector depends on the frequency ω.

Step 3. Threshold Frequency for Propagation

For the wave vector k to be real (and thus for the wave to propagate rather than decay exponentially), the radicand must be positive:

  ω² − ω_p² > 0  ⟹  ω² > ω_p²  ⟹  ω > ω_p.

The threshold frequency (or cutoff frequency) is therefore ω_p, below which the electromagnetic plane wave cannot propagate in the metal.

Final Answers:

(a) The dispersion relation for the electromagnetic plane wave in the metallic medium is

  k = √(ω² − ω_p²)/c.

(b) The threshold frequency is given by

  ω_p = √(ne²/(mε₀)).

Thus, the final answers are:

  \[\boxed{k = \frac{\sqrt{\omega^2 - \omega_p^2}}{c}, \quad \omega_p = \sqrt{\frac{ne^2}{m\epsilon_0}}.}\]

solution:
We are given a quadrupole in which the magnetic scalar potential is

  Φ(x, y, z) = B₀ · (xy)/R  for x² + y² < R²,

with B₀ being the “pole field” (the field at the pole) and R the pole radius. In regions where currents are absent, we can define the magnetic field from the scalar potential by

  B = –∇Φ.

Let us work step by step.

─────────────────────────────  
Step 1. Compute the Magnetic Field

Differentiate the given potential with respect to the three coordinates:

  ∂Φ/∂x = B₀ · y/R,
  ∂Φ/∂y = B₀ · x/R,
  ∂Φ/∂z = 0         (since Φ does not depend on z).

Thus the magnetic field is

  B = –∇Φ = (–B₀y/R, –B₀x/R, 0).

─────────────────────────────  
Step 2. Determine the Force on a Relativistic Particle Moving Along z

For a particle with charge e and velocity v (where, for relativistic particles, v ≃ c) moving along the z‑axis, we take

  v = (0, 0, v).

The Lorentz force is given by

  F = e (v × B).

Since v has only a z‐component, let us compute the cross product:
  v × B = (v_y B_z – v_z B_y, v_z B_x – v_x B_z, v_x B_y – v_y B_x).

With v_x = v_y = 0 and v_z = v, we get:
  (v × B)_x = – v B_y,
  (v × B)_y = v B_x,
  (v × B)_z = 0.

Substitute B_x and B_y:
  (v × B)_x = – v (–B₀x/R) = (v B₀ x/R),
  (v × B)_y = v (–B₀y/R) = – (v B₀ y/R).

Thus the force is

  F = e (v × B) = (e v B₀ x/R, – e v B₀ y/R, 0).

─────────────────────────────  
Step 3. Write the Equations of Motion

To understand the lensing action we consider the transverse (x and y) motions. For a relativistic particle with momentum p, and noting that the time derivative and the derivative with respect to z are related via dt = dz/v (with almost constant speed v), the equations of motion (in the paraxial or small angle approximation) become

  d²x/dz² = (1/p) (F_x/v) = (eB₀/(pR)) x,
  d²y/dz² = (1/p) (F_y/v) = – (eB₀/(pR)) y.

Thus we have a harmonic‐oscillator type (linear) equation but with opposite signs in the two directions.

• In the x‑direction:  d²x/dz² = (eB₀/(pR)) x,  
  this shows a force proportional to +x. In the language of linear optics, this behaves as a defocusing element (since the “kick” is in the same direction as the displacement, causing divergence).

• In the y‑direction:  d²y/dz² = – (eB₀/(pR)) y,  
  which shows a force proportional to –y. This is a focusing behavior (a restoring force).

Thus, the quadrupole acts as a lens which focuses in one transverse direction (here, y) and defocuses in the other (x).

─────────────────────────────  
Step 4. (a) Answer: Focusing in x and y?

In summary, for a relativistic charged particle moving along the z‑axis, the quadrupole exerts a force

  Fₓ = +(e v B₀/R) x     (defocusing),
  Fᵧ = –(e v B₀/R) y     (focusing).

So, it does not provide the same effect in the x and y directions. The quadrupole focuses in one plane (here the y‑plane) and defocuses in the perpendicular plane (the x‑plane).

─────────────────────────────  
Step 5. (b) Determine the Focal Length for a “Realistic” Warm‐Iron Quadrupole

For a magnetic quadrupole, the field gradient is

  g = B₀/R.

Many treatments of accelerator optics show that (within the thin lens approximation) the focal length f for one of the transverse degrees of freedom is given by

  1/f = (e g L)/p,
  or equivalently   f = p/(e g L).

Substitute g = B₀/R:

  f = p/(e (B₀/R) L) = (p R)/(e B₀ L).

It is convenient to express p/e in terms of the magnetic rigidity Bρ. For an ultra‐relativistic particle, p/e = Bρ. In accelerator physics, the rigidity Bρ (in Tesla·meters) is given approximately by

  Bρ [T·m] ≃ 3.3356 · (p [GeV/c]).

For 20 GeV electrons, we have

  Bρ = 3.3356 × 20 ≈ 66.71 T·m.

Now insert the given numbers:
  R = 20 cm = 0.20 m,
  L = 2 m,
  B₀ = 1 T.

Thus the focal length is

  f = (Bρ R)/(B₀ L) = (66.71 T·m × 0.20 m)/(1 T × 2 m)
     = (13.342 T·m²)/(2 T·m)
     = 6.671 m ≈ 6.67 m.

Remember that this focal length applies only to the (focusing) plane; in the defocusing plane the behavior is opposite. (In a full beam transport system the combination of focusing and defocusing quadrupoles is used to obtain an overall focusing effect.)

─────────────────────────────  
Final Answers

(a) For a particle moving along the z‑axis in a quadrupole with scalar potential Φ(x,y)=B₀xy/R the Lorentz force yields
  d²x/dz² = (eB₀/(pR)) x  (defocusing)
  d²y/dz² = – (eB₀/(pR)) y  (focusing).
Thus, the quadrupole acts as a lens that focuses in one transverse direction (y) and defocuses in the other (x).

(b) For a quadrupole of length L = 2 m, pole field B₀ = 1 T, and pole radius R = 0.20 m, the focal length for 20 GeV electrons is given by
  f = (Bρ R)/(B₀ L) ≈ 6.67 m.

─────────────────────────────

\]

We will show one acceptable solution. In what follows we assume that the oscillator is a charged particle of mass m and charge q attached to a spring (spring‑constant k) so that its natural frequency is

  ω = √(k/m).

Its motion is a small vertical oscillation of amplitude d about the equilibrium position at a height h above a perfect (“mirror”) floor (with h ≫ λ so that the source–floor separation is many wavelengths, and with the small‐oscillation assumption d ≪ λ so that the dipole approximation holds). (Recall that the wavelength is λ = 2πc/ω.)

A dipole oscillating in the z-direction has a moment

  p(t) = q x(t) ≈ qd cos ωt     (1)

so that its “acceleration” is p¨(t) = –q d ω² cos ωt. (In the usual dipole‐radiation formulas the “source” is taken to be p″.) In free space the time–averaged power radiated per unit solid angle is

  dP/dΩ = (q²d²ω⁴/(32π²ε₀c³)) sin²θ    (2)

where θ is the angle (measured from the z–axis) in the spherical direction of radiation.

Because the floor is a perfect conductor there is an “image” of the dipole. (One may show by solving the reflection problem that for a dipole perpendicular to the plane the image has the same amplitude and phase as the real dipole so that the net field in the upper half–space is the sum of two dipole fields.) In other words, though the free–space radiation pattern given in (2) is “doughnut‐shaped” (with zero radiation along the z–axis), when the oscillator is a distance h above a perfectly reflecting floor the upper–half–space “sees” the field of an effective dipole of strength 2q d. (One may also show directly that the energy arriving at the floor is 4 times what it would have been in the downward hemisphere in free space; since ½ of a free–space dipole’s power goes downward, this “mirroring” causes the total power delivered to the floor to equal the full free–space radiated power.)

Below we now explain one acceptable solution.

───────────────────────────── 
Step (a): Intensity on the Floor

Imagine “mapping” the free–space angular distribution into the floor. (Because of the image method the field in the upper half–space is the coherent sum of the field from the real dipole and its image. In what follows one may show that if one computes the flux arriving at the floor one gets exactly the result obtained by “projecting” the usual free–space dipole radiation into the plane.) 

A ray leaving the dipole at (0,0,h) in the direction (θ, φ) (with θ the polar angle measured from the z–axis) will hit the floor (z = 0) at a horizontal distance
  R = h tanθ.
Moreover, the element of area on the floor dA and the corresponding element of solid angle dΩ are related by
  dΩ = (cosθ/r²) dA,  with r = √(R²+h²) = h/ cosθ.
A short calculation shows that
  dA = (r²/ cosθ) dΩ = (h²/cos³θ) dΩ.
In free space the power radiated into a solid–angle element is dP = (dP/dΩ) dΩ so that, when that power is “spread” uniformly over an area element dA on the floor, the intensity (power per unit area) at the corresponding point is
  I(R) = (dP/dΩ)/(dA/dΩ) = (dP/dΩ) (cos³θ/h²).  (3)

Inserting (2) into (3) gives
  I(R) = (q²d²ω⁴/(32π²ε₀c³)) sin²θ (cos³θ/h²).  (4)

It is best to write the answer in terms of R and h. Since
  tanθ = R/h ⇒ sinθ = R/√(R²+h²)  and  cosθ = h/√(R²+h²)
we have
  sin²θ = R²/(R²+h²)  and  cos³θ = h³/(R²+h²)^(3/2).
Thus (4) becomes
  I(R) = (q²d²ω⁴/(32π²ε₀c³))· (R²/(R²+h²)) · (h³/(h² (R²+h²)^(3/2))).
A little algebra shows
  I(R) = (q²d²ω⁴ h R²)/(32π²ε₀c³) · 1/(h² (R²+h²)^(5/2)/???).
Let us be careful. The factors of h come out as follows: In (4) the prefactor is (q² d² ω⁴)/(32π²ε₀ c³). Then
  sin²θ cos³θ = (R²/(R²+h²))· (h³/(R²+h²)^(3/2)) = h³R²/(R²+h²)^(5/2).
Divide by h² then we obtain
  I_free(R) = (q²d²ω⁴/(32π²ε₀c³)) (h R²/(R²+h²)^(5/2)).
But now, because the image doubles the field in the upper–half–space, the amplitude is doubled and hence the intensity is multiplied by 4. Thus the net intensity arriving at the floor is
  I(R) = 4 I_free(R)
or
  I(R) = (q²d²ω⁴/(8π² ε₀ c³)) (h R²/(R²+h²)^(5/2)).  (5)

It is now straightforward (by writing R = h x with a dimensionless variable and maximizing with respect to x) to show that I(R) is maximum when
  dI/dR = 0 ⟹ R = h√(2/3).  (6)

───────────────────────────── 
Step (b): Total Power Hitting the Floor

To “check” our result we now integrate the intensity (5) over the entire floor. In polar coordinates on the floor the total power is
  P_floor = ∫₀^(∞) I(R) 2πR dR
Substitute (5):
  P_floor = (q²d²ω⁴ h/(8π²ε₀c³))
    × 2π ∫₀^(∞) (R³/(R²+h²)^(5/2)) dR.
It is convenient to change variable by writing u = R/h so that dR = h du and R = h u. Then the integral becomes
  ∫₀∞ (h³ u³)/(h⁵ (1+u²)^(5/2)) h du = (1/h)∫₀∞ u³/(1+u²)^(5/2) du.
A short calculation (for example using the substitution u = tanθ) shows that
  ∫₀∞ u³/(1+u²)^(5/2) du = 1/3.
Thus we find
  P_floor = (q²d²ω⁴ h/(8π²ε₀c³))· 2π · (1/3h)
     = (q²d²ω⁴)/(12π ε₀ c³).  (7)
But recall that the total radiated power in free space from an oscillating dipole (with p₀ = qd) is
  P_total = (q²d²ω⁴)/(12π ε₀ c³).  (8)
Hence when we take into account that the mirror image “doubles” the power into the upper half–space, the entire power of the oscillator falls on the floor. This is exactly what we expect.

───────────────────────────── 
Step (c): Radiative Damping

Because the oscillator loses energy to radiation its amplitude will slowly decay. (We are told to assume that the fraction of energy lost per cycle is very small so that one may “average” over many cycles.) The energy in the oscillator is
  E = ½ k d² = ½ mω² d².
The average power lost is given by (8); hence
  dE/dt = –P_total = – (q² d² ω⁴)/(12π ε₀ c³).
Since E ∝ d² we may write
  d(lnE)/dt = – (q² ω⁴)/(6π ε₀ c³ m ω²)
        = – (q² ω²)/(6π ε₀ c³ m).
That is, the fractional energy loss rate is
  Γ_E = (q² ω²)/(6π ε₀ c³ m).
Because the amplitude varies like the square root of the energy the amplitude decays as
  d(t)= d₀ exp[–(Γ_E/2)t].
We wish to find the time τ when d(τ) = d/e; that is,
  exp[–(Γ_E/2)τ] = 1/e  ⟹  (Γ_E/2)τ = 1.
Thus,
  τ = 2/Γ_E =  (12π ε₀ c³ m)/(q² ω²).  (9)

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answers

An acceptable answer is therefore:

(a) The intensity (average power per unit area) of the radiation arriving at a point on the floor at horizontal distance R from the point directly below the charge is
  I(R)= (q² d² ω⁴/(8π²ε₀c³)) · (h R²/( (R²+h²)^(5/2) )),
with the maximum intensity occurring at R = h √(2/3).

(b) Integrating (a) over the entire floor gives
  P_floor = (q² d² ω⁴)/(12π ε₀ c³),
which is exactly equal to the total power radiated by an oscillating dipole in free space.

(c) If radiative losses are small so that the energy decays slowly, the oscillation amplitude decays according to
  d(t)=d·exp[–t/τ]  with  τ = (12π ε₀ c³ m)/(q² ω²),
i.e. after a time τ the amplitude has fallen from d to d/e.

───────────────────────────── 
Final Answer

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad & I(R)=\frac{q^2d^2\omega^4}{8\pi^2\epsilon_0c^3}\;\frac{h\,R^2}{\left(R^2+h^2\right)^{5/2}},\qquad\text{with maximum at } R = h\sqrt{\frac{2}{3}},\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad & P_{\text{floor}}=\int_0^\infty 2\pi R\,I(R)dR= \frac{q^2d^2\omega^4}{12\pi\epsilon_0c^3},\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}\quad & \tau=\frac{12\pi\epsilon_0c^3\,m}{q^2\omega^2}\quad\text{ (i.e. }d(\tau)=d/e\text{).}
\end{aligned}
}
\] 

Any answer equivalent to the one above is correct.

We wish to know whether a positive test charge can be held in stable equilibrium at the center of a cube formed by fixed positive charges q at its eight corners. Let us reason step by step.

Step 1. Symmetry of the Configuration  
The arrangement is perfectly symmetric. When a positive test charge is placed at the geometric center of the cube, the electric field contributions from the eight charges cancel out, so the net force is zero. Thus, the center is an equilibrium point.

Step 2. Nature of the Electrostatic Potential  
The potential at any point due to a point charge is given by V = kq/r. For a collection of fixed charges, the total potential satisfies Laplace’s equation (∇²V = 0) in free space (away from the fixed charges). A well‐known property of solutions to Laplace’s equation is that they cannot have a local minimum or maximum, only saddle points (or points of inflection) – this is related to Earnshaw’s theorem.

Step 3. Stability Considerations  
Since the test charge is of the same sign as the fixed charges, any deviation from the center will break the perfect cancellation of forces. Although the center itself has a net force of zero, the second derivative (or curvature) of the potential will indicate instability (i.e., there will be directions in which the potential decreases as you move away). Thus, if the test charge is perturbed, it will experience a net force that pushes it away from the center. In this sense, the equilibrium is unstable.

Step 4. Potential Barrier or Tunneling  
The question specifically asks if, aside from quantum tunneling effects, there is any potential barrier that might “trap” the charge. In view of the analysis above, there is no confining potential well that could provide a barrier. At best, one might have hoped for a potential "bump" around the center but, due to the conditions set by Laplace’s equation, there is no local minimum where the charge could be stably suspended. Hence, from a classical point of view, there is no potential barrier maintaining the charge at the center.

Final Answer  
The positive charge at the center is at an unstable equilibrium (a saddle point) and cannot be suspended stably.

\[
\boxed{\text{No, the test charge at the center experiences unstable equilibrium and there is no potential barrier to trap it classically.}}
\]

We wish to compute the radiated intensity (power per unit solid angle) from an array of seven in‐phase dipoles that are oriented along ẑ and located along the x–axis. One usual approach is to “separate out” the radiation of a single dipole from the interference (array) factor of the seven elements.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Single‐Dipole Radiation Pattern

An oscillating electric dipole that is polarized in the ẑ direction radiates (in the far field) with an angular dependence proportional to

  I_single(θ,φ) ∝ sin²θ.

In what follows we will neglect overall constant factors (that are the same for all our results).

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. The Array Factor

Since the dipoles are at different positions, the radiated fields add with phases that depend on the observation direction. In our case the seven dipoles are placed at
  x = –3λ/2, –λ, –λ/2, 0, +λ/2, +λ, +3λ/2.
Let the (wavenumber) be

  k = 2π/λ.
  
An antenna located at x = d will have an extra phase factor exp[i k d sinθ cosφ] (because in the far‐field the path difference is d sinθ cosφ). For our array we note that the spacing between adjacent elements is d = λ/2. Therefore, if we introduce an index m running from –3 to 3 so that the mth element is at

  x = m(λ/2),
  
then its phase factor is

  exp[i k·(mλ/2) sinθ cosφ] = exp[i m (π sinθ cosφ)].

Thus the overall array factor (AF) is given by the sum

  AF(θ,φ) = ∑ₘ₌₋₃³ exp[i m (π sinθ cosφ)].

Since the elements run over m = –3, –2, …, 2, 3 there are 7 terms. This sum is a finite geometric series. A well‐known formula for a sum of the type

  S = ∑ₘ₌₋N⁽N⁾ e^(i m δ)
    = sin[(2N+1)δ/2] / sin(δ/2)
  
(apart from an unimportant overall phase) applies with N = 3 and δ = π sinθ cosφ. In other words,

  AF(θ,φ) = sin[(7π/2) sinθ cosφ] / sin[(π/2) sinθ cosφ].

──────────────────────────────
Step 3. Total Angular Distribution

Since the dipole radiation pattern gives a factor of sin²θ and the array factor adds its own modulation, the radiated intensity (up to an overall common multiplicative constant) is

  I(θ,φ) ∝ sin²θ × [AF(θ,φ)]²  
       = sin²θ × [ sin((7π/2) sinθ cosφ) / sin((π/2) sinθ cosφ) ]².

This is the answer for part (a).

──────────────────────────────
Step 4. Comparison of Maximum Intensities

Now let’s identify the directions of maximum radiation.

For a single dipole the intensity is proportional to sin²θ so that the maximum occurs when sinθ is maximum. Thus the maximum (over θ) is at

  θ = π/2  (with any φ)  , with I_single,max ∝ 1.

For the array we must maximize the product sin²θ · |AF(θ,φ)|². It is useful to note that even though the dipole pattern is zero along the z–axis (θ = 0,π), the array factor may be maximum in other directions. In our case, notice that the array sum

  AF(θ,φ) = ∑ₘ₌₋₃³ exp[i m (π sinθ cosφ)]
  
is “in phase” when the phase factor is unity for every element. One way to make the phase factors all equal is to require

  π sinθ cosφ = 0.
  
That is, either sinθ = 0 (which obviously gives zero radiation from the dipoles) or cosφ = 0. Thus, with cosφ = 0 (i.e. φ = π/2 or 3π/2) we have

  AF(θ, φ = π/2) = ∑ₘ₌₋₃³ 1 = 7,
  
and the radiation intensity becomes

  I(θ=π/2, φ=π/2) ∝ sin²(π/2) · 7² = 1 · 49 = 49.

One may check (or argue physically) that this is the maximum achievable intensity. (For example, if we try φ = 0 so that cosφ = 1 then at θ = π/2 we have sinθ = 1 and the phase factor becomes π, so that the numerator is sin(7π/2) = –1 and the ratio becomes 1, leading to I = 1; this is far lower than the 49 we obtain at φ = π/2.)

Thus, in the maximum-intensity direction the array has an intensity 49 times that of a single dipole. (This is precisely the effect of “coherent addition”: the fields add and give a factor of 7, so that the intensity, proportional to the square of the field, is multiplied by 7² = 49.)

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The angular distribution of the radiated power (neglecting constant prefactors) is

  I(θ,φ) ∝ sin²θ · [ sin((7π/2) sinθ cosφ) / sin((π/2) sinθ cosφ) ]².

(b) The single dipole radiates maximally at θ = π/2 (with any φ) with I_single,max ∝ 1, while the array’s maximum occurs in the plane perpendicular to ẑ and when cosφ = 0 (e.g. φ = π/2) at θ = π/2, with I_array,max ∝ 7² = 49. Thus, the maximum radiated intensity of the array is 49 times that of a single dipole.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

\[ \boxed{ \begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad I(\theta,\phi) &\propto \sin^2\theta \left[\frac{\sin\Bigl(\tfrac{7\pi}{2}\sin\theta\cos\phi\Bigr)}{\sin\Bigl(\tfrac{\pi}{2}\sin\theta\cos\phi\Bigr)}\right]^2,\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad I_{\text{array},\max} &= 49\, I_{\text{dipole},\max}\,.
\end{aligned} } \]

We will show that a rotating dipole

  p(t) = p₀[cos(ωt) x̂ + sin(ωt) ŷ]

may be thought of as the sum of two orthogonal, linearly oscillating dipoles (along x and y) that are π/2 out of phase. Although the (instantaneous) fields add linearly, the radiated power (which is quadratic in the fields) is, in general, not the sum of the powers of the individual dipoles because of interference. In this special case the cross‐terms vanish (or more precisely, average to zero when integrated over a period) because the two contributions are orthogonal in polarization. (A similar “miracle” happens for circularly polarized light.) We now describe one acceptable solution in several steps.

─────────────────────────────────────────────── 
Step 1. The Far‐Zone Fields

In the radiation (far) zone the electric field from a time–dependent dipole p(t) is given by

  E₍rad₎(r, t) = [ω²/(4πε₀c²)] (1/r) [n × (n × p(tᵣ))],
         (1)

where n = r̂ is the unit vector in the direction of observation, and tᵣ = t – r/c is the retarded time. (We use SI units throughout; note that the magnetic field is then B₍rad₎ = (1/c)(n × E₍rad₎).) For our dipole the instantaneous dipole moment is

  p(t) = p₀ [cos(ωt)x̂ + sin(ωt)ŷ].

Thus, one may view (1) as the sum of the two contributions

  E₍rad₎ = Eₓ + E_y 
with
  Eₓ = [ω² p₀ cos(ωtᵣ)/(4πε₀c²r)] [n × (n × x̂)],
  E_y = [ω² p₀ sin(ωtᵣ)/(4πε₀c²r)] [n × (n × ŷ)].

Because the two dipoles oscillate with a phase difference of π/2, although their fields add linearly, when one computes the instantaneous Poynting vector, the cross–terms (which are proportional to cos(ωt) sin(ωt)) average to zero over a period. 

─────────────────────────────────────────────── 
Step 2. The Poynting Vector and Intensity

In the radiation zone the time–averaged Poynting vector (i.e. the energy flux) is

  ⟨S⟩ = (1/2μ₀) |E₍rad₎|² n.

Since the two dipoles give rise to radiation fields that are polarized along (generally) different directions, it is easiest to find the magnitude |E₍rad₎|² by using the following geometric identity. For any dipole p one may show

  |n × (n × p)|² = |p|² − (n·p)².

For our rotating dipole we have
  n · p(t) = p₀ [cos(ωt) sinθ cosφ + sin(ωt) sinθ sinφ]
        = p₀ sinθ cos(ωt – φ).

Consequently, for instantaneous fields
  |n × (n × p(t))|² = p₀² – p₀² sin²θ cos²(ωt – φ).

If we now average over one period of the rotation, the average of cos²(ωt – φ) is ½, so that

  ⟨|n × (n × p)|²⟩ = p₀² (1 – sin²θ/2) = (p₀²/2)(1 + cos²θ).

Thus, from (1) the time–averaged squared amplitude of the radiated electric field is

  ⟨|E₍rad₎|²⟩ = [ω⁴p₀²/(16π²ε₀²c⁴)] (1/r²) (1 + cos²θ)/2,
         = [ω⁴p₀²/(32π²ε₀²c⁴)] (1 + cos²θ)/r².

So, the time–averaged Poynting vector becomes

  ⟨S⟩ = (1/2μ₀) ⟨|E₍rad₎|²⟩ n
     = (ω⁴p₀²/(64π²ε₀²μ₀c⁴)) (1 + cos²θ)/r² n.
                 (2)

It is often convenient to re‐express the constants using the relation c² = 1/(ε₀μ₀). In our case one finds

  ⟨S⟩ = (μ₀ω⁴p₀²/(32π² c)) (1 + cos²θ)/r² n.

Thus the differential intensity (or power per unit solid angle) is

  dP/dΩ = r² ⟨S⟩ = (μ₀ω⁴p₀²/(32π² c)) (1 + cos²θ).   (3)

A sketch of dP/dΩ versus the polar angle θ shows a “donut–shaped” pattern that is symmetric about the z–axis and which has its maximum along the z–axis (θ = 0, π) while attaining a minimum in the xy–plane (θ = π/2).

─────────────────────────────────────────────── 
Step 3. Total Power Radiated

To find the total radiated power we integrate (3) over all solid angles:

  P = ∫ dΩ (dP/dΩ)
    = (μ₀ω⁴p₀²/(32π² c)) ∫₀^(2π)dφ ∫₀^(π)dθ (1 + cos²θ) sinθ dθ.

Let us first do the φ–integral:

  ∫₀^(2π) dφ = 2π.

Then, for the θ–integral, write

  I_θ = ∫₀^(π) (1 + cos²θ) sinθ dθ.
Make the substitution u = cosθ so that du = – sinθ dθ. When θ = 0, u = 1; when θ = π, u = –1. Thus,
  I_θ = ∫₁^(–1) (1 + u²)(–du) = ∫₋1^1 (1 + u²) du.
Now,
  ∫₋1^1 1 du = 2  and  ∫₋1^1 u² du = (2/3),
so that
  I_θ = 2 + (2/3) = 8/3.

Thus, the total power radiated is

  P = (μ₀ω⁴p₀²/(32π² c)) (2π) (8/3)
    = (μ₀ω⁴p₀²/(32π² c)) (16π/3)
    = (μ₀ω⁴p₀²/(6π c)).

Using c² = 1/(ε₀μ₀) so that μ₀ = 1/(ε₀c²), we can also write

  P = (p₀²ω⁴)/(6πε₀c³).

A quick check is provided by recalling that a single oscillating dipole (with dipole moment ∝ cosωt) radiates

  P₍lin₎ = (p₀²ω⁴)/(12πε₀c³).

Thus, a dipole that rotates (i.e. “sweeps out” a circle in the xy–plane) radiates twice as much as a dipole oscillating in one fixed direction. This is entirely reasonable since the rotating dipole has a constant magnitude and “presents” its maximum (transverse) amplitude in every azimuthal direction, and the interference cross–terms vanish upon time–averaging because the two dipole components are orthogonal.

─────────────────────────────────────────────── 
Step 4. Summary of the Final Answers

1. The far–zone (radiation) fields are given by

  E₍rad₎(r, t) = [ω²/(4πε₀c²)] (1/r) [n × (n × p(tᵣ))],
  B₍rad₎(r, t) = (1/c) (n × E₍rad₎(r, t)).

2. The time–averaged Poynting vector is

  ⟨S⟩ = (μ₀ω⁴p₀²/(32π² c)) (1 + cos²θ)/r² n.

3. The differential radiated power is

  dP/dΩ = (μ₀ω⁴p₀²/(32π² c)) (1 + cos²θ).

A sketch of dP/dΩ versus θ shows lobes with maximum intensity along θ = 0 and π and a minimum at θ = π/2.

4. The total radiated power is

  P = (p₀²ω⁴)/(6πε₀c³).

5. Why does the superposition “work”?
  Even though power is quadratic in the fields so that in general the interference of two radiating sources does not yield a simple sum, in this case the two dipoles radiate with orthogonal polarizations. Their cross–terms vanish when one averages over a full cycle (or integrates over solid angle), so that the total power is simply the sum of the individual contributions.

─────────────────────────────────────────────── 
Final Answer

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{E}_{\rm rad}(\mathbf{r},t) &= \frac{\omega^2}{4\pi\epsilon_0 c^2}\,\frac{1}{r}\,\mathbf{n}\times\Bigl(\mathbf{n}\times\mathbf{p}(t_r)\Bigr),\quad\text{with}\quad \mathbf{p}(t)=p_0\Bigl[\cos\omega t\,\hat{\mathbf{x}}+\sin\omega t\,\hat{\mathbf{y}}\Bigr],\\[1mm]
\langle \mathbf{S}\rangle &= \frac{\mu_0\omega^4p_0^2}{32\pi^2 c}\,\frac{1+\cos^2\theta}{r^2}\,\mathbf{n},\\[1mm]
\frac{dP}{d\Omega} &= \frac{\mu_0\omega^4p_0^2}{32\pi^2 c}\,(1+\cos^2\theta),\\[1mm]
P_{\rm tot} &= \frac{p_0^2\omega^4}{6\pi\epsilon_0 c^3}.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

Any answer equivalent to the boxed result above is correct.

We wish to find the potential at the center of a dodecahedron when one of its faces is held at potential V while the other 11 faces are grounded (i.e. at 0). Although the geometry is not spherical, there is a very clever symmetry argument that immediately gives the answer.

Step 1. Note the symmetry of the dodecahedron

A regular dodecahedron has 12 congruent faces. (In fact, if all faces are “active”, they are equivalent by the symmetry group of the dodecahedron.) Although here the boundary condition is not “all faces the same”, we can proceed by linearity and symmetry. Imagine solving the Laplace equation (Δφ = 0) in the interior of the dodecahedron subject to the specified boundary conditions.

Step 2. Consider “building up” the solution by superposition

Let φ_i(r) be the solution (the potential everywhere inside) when only the i‑th face is held at potential V and the other 11 faces are at 0. Because the dodecahedron is regular, whichever face we choose as the “active” one, the potential at the center (r = 0) will be the same. Denote this value by A; that is, for each i
  φ_i(0) = A.

Now, notice that by superposition the solution for the case when all 12 faces are held at V (that is, φ_boundary = V everywhere on the faces) is simply the sum of the 12 solutions; that is,
  φ_all(0) = φ₁(0) + φ₂(0) + … + φ₁₂(0) = 12A.

Step 3. Use the uniqueness theorem

If every face of the dodecahedron is held at V, then by symmetry the solution inside is just the constant V (by the uniqueness theorem for Laplace’s equation in a region with Dirichlet boundary conditions); that is, φ_all(0) = V. Thus from the previous relation we obtain
  12A = V, or A = V/12.

Step 4. Conclusion

But A is just the potential at the center due to one face being at V while the other faces are grounded. Hence, the potential at the center in the original problem is V/12.

Final answer in boxed form:

\[
\boxed{\frac{V}{12}}
\]

We will show that a “silvered‐lens” (or catadioptric) system of the sort described may be analyzed “stage–by–stage”. One acceptable answer is as follows. (Any answer equivalent to the one given below is correct.)

In our problem we have a thin, double–convex lens made of glass (index n = 1.5) with both surfaces having (unsigned) radius R = 42 m. (Remember that when used “in air” and with the usual sign–convention one may take the first surface to have R₁ = +42 m and the second “curved” surface to have R₂ = –42 m so that the lensmaker’s formula gives

  1/f = (n – 1)(1/R₁ – 1/R₂) = (0.5)(1/42 – (–1/42)) = 0.5 · (2/42) = 1/42,
  so that f = 42 m.)

One of the two sides is silvered. (A typical arrangement is to silver the back surface so that light coming from the left goes through the lens, is reflected off the silvered back, and goes back through the lens; also, when the two surfaces are “in contact” one may treat all surfaces as if they lie in one plane.) Moreover, a thin–lens approximation is assumed.

An object is placed 84 m to the left of the lens.

Let us now explain step–by–step.

──────────────────────────────
Step (a). Focal lengths of the individual elements

1. (Lens:) We have already seen that with R = 42 m and n = 1.5 the focal length is

  f_lens = 42 m.

2. (Mirror:) A spherical mirror in air has focal length f_m given by
    f_m = R/2.
Since we take the (unsigned) radius of curvature to be R = 42 m, it follows that
  f_m = 42/2 = 21 m.
(One must be careful with signs, but in our “by–itself” answer the mirror is a converging – i.e. “concave –“ mirror, with f_m > 0.)

──────────────────────────────
Step (b). Counting the “stages” and the direction of incidence

Because the light suffers three “interactions” we say there are three stages:

• Stage 1. The light from the object (located 84 m to the left) first passes through the lens. (Thus, in Stage 1 the rays are incident on the lens from the left.)

• Stage 2. After passing through the lens the light is “directed” toward the silvered surface (the mirror). (In our arrangement the mirror is the silvered back–surface so that the light now “hits” the mirror; since this surface is the back of the lens, one may say that in Stage 2 the rays are incident “from the right” onto the mirror.)

• Stage 3. The mirror reflects the rays back toward the lens. (Now the rays “re‐enter” the lens from the right; that is, in Stage 3 the rays are incident on the lens from the right.)

──────────────────────────────
Step (c). Stage–by–stage imaging and magnification

Because we assume that if the mirror were not present the lens would form an image in its “usual way” we may “pretend” that:

Stage 1. (Lens, first pass)
 Use the thin–lens equation (with distances measured from the lens):
  1/f = 1/dₒ + 1/dᵢ.
Here the object is at dₒ = 84 m and f = 42 m so that
  1/42 = 1/84 + 1/dᵢ₁ ⟹ 1/dᵢ₁ = 1/42 – 1/84 = 1/84 ⟹ dᵢ₁ = 84 m.
Its lateral (linear) magnification is given by
  m₁ = – dᵢ₁/dₒ = –84/84 = –1.
(Thus, if the lens acted by itself, it would form an image 84 m to the right, which is inverted relative to the object.)

Stage 2. (Mirror)
 Now one “pretends” that the image formed by the lens in Stage 1 acts as the object for the spherical mirror. Since the lens and mirror are “in contact”, we take the distance from the mirror to that “object” to be
  dₒ(mirror) = 84 m.
Then the mirror equation
  1/f_m = 1/dₒ + 1/dᵢ
with f_m = 21 m becomes
  1/21 = 1/84 + 1/dᵢ₂  ⟹  1/dᵢ₂ = 1/21 – 1/84 = (4 – 1)/84 = 3/84,
so that
  dᵢ₂ = 84/3 = 28 m.
The mirror’s lateral magnification is
  m₂ = – dᵢ₂/dₒ(mirror) = –28/84 = –1/3.
(A real mirror always “flips” the image so that m₂ carries a minus sign.)

Stage 3. (Lens, second pass)
 The image produced by the mirror now acts as a (virtual) object for the lens on the return pass. Because the light is coming from the right rather than from the left, the “object distance” for the lens in Stage 3 is taken with a minus sign. (In other words, the mirror–image is located 28 m on the right of the lens, so for the returning light we take dₒ₍lens2₎ = –28 m.)
 Then the lens equation becomes
  1/f = 1/dₒ + 1/dᵢ₃ ⟹ 1/42 = 1/(–28) + 1/dᵢ₃.
Solving gives
  1/dᵢ₃ = 1/42 + 1/28 = (2/84 + 3/84) = 5/84 ⟹ dᵢ₃ = 84/5 = 16.8 m.
(For the second pass through the lens the image is formed on the side from which the light now “leaves” the lens.)
The corresponding lens magnification is
  m₃ = – (dᵢ₃)/(dₒ) = – (16.8)/(–28) = +0.6.

The overall (total) lateral magnification is the product
  m_total = m₁ · m₂ · m₃ = (–1) · (–1/3) · (0.6) = +0.2.
That is, the final image is 0.20 times as large as the object.

──────────────────────────────
Step (d). Final Image Location and Character

We now “read off” that
 • The final image (produced after reflection and a second pass through the lens)
is located 16.8 m from the lens (i.e. 16.8 m to the “left” of the lens if we adopt the usual sign convention – note that the final light emerges on the same side as the object).
 • Its total (linear) magnification is m_total = +0.2.
Since the overall sign is positive the two “flips” (one by the lens in Stage 1 and one by the mirror in Stage 2) have cancelled the usual inversion; that is, the final image is upright relative to the object. (Also, its size is only 20% that of the object, so it is a reduced image.) Finally, the image is real (since light actually converges there).

──────────────────────────────

&\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad\quad m_3 = -\frac{d_{i3}}{d_{o3}} = +0.6.\\[1mm]
\text{(d)}\quad &\text{The final image is formed 16.8\,m from the lens (on the same side as the object) with }\\[1mm]
&\quad m_{\rm total} = (-1)\left(-\frac{1}{3}\right)(+0.6) = +0.2.\\[1mm]
&\quad\text{That is, the image is real, upright (non–inverted) and reduced (only 20% the size of the object).}
\end{aligned}
}
\]

We will show that one acceptable answer is

  F = (2π μ₀ σ² ω² R⁴)⁄9.

Because there is some ambiguity in how one “splits” the self–field of the sphere, a number of approaches yield results equivalent to this answer. (Any answer equivalent by algebra is acceptable.) In what follows we describe one way to arrive at the answer.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Setting Up the Problem

Consider a spherical shell of radius R that carries a uniform surface charge density σ. If the shell rotates about the z–axis with angular speed ω, then every charge element moves with a velocity

  v = ωR sinθ     (θ is the polar angle).

Thus the motion of charge produces a surface current density

  K = σ v = σ ωR sinθ      (in the ϕ–direction).

The entire moving charge gives the sphere a net magnetic dipole moment. A standard calculation shows that the magnetic moment is

  m = (1/3) Q ω R²  ,  Q = 4πR²σ.
So that
  m = (4π/3) σ ω R⁴.

For a uniformly magnetized sphere (or for a sphere with our special surface current) one may show that the magnetic field inside is uniform and equal to

  B_in = (2/3) μ₀ M
with an effective magnetization M given by
  M = m/(Volume) = [ (4π/3)σ ωR⁴ ]/( (4π/3)R³ ) = σ ωR.
Thus
  B_in = (2/3) μ₀ σ ω R.
(There is a factor of 1⁄2 difference between internal and the “dipole‐field” at the center; here it is the standard result for a uniformly magnetized sphere.) 

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. Using the Maxwell Stress Tensor

Now suppose we “cut” the sphere into two pieces along the equatorial (z=0) plane. Since the two halves are held together by the internal magnetic forces produced by the moving charges, the net force that the “northern” hemisphere exerts on the “southern” one can be obtained by integrating the Maxwell stress (magnetic pressure) over the “cut” surface.

In vacuum the Maxwell stress tensor (magnetic‐part only) is

  T_ij = (1/μ₀)[ B_iB_j – ½ δ_ij B² ].

Let the cut be taken as the flat disk (of radius R) at z=0. For a uniform field that is directed along the z–axis the stress acting on a surface with normal n = ẑ is (we use the “pulling–in” sign convention)

  f = T_zz n_z 
    = (1/μ₀)[ B_z² – ½ B² ] = B²/(2 μ₀)    (since B is entirely along z).

One may view this as the “magnetic pressure” p_m = B²/(2μ₀) acting on the disk. Since the two halves “pull” on each other across the cut, the net force is obtained by multiplying by the area of the equatorial disk, A = πR². (A more careful derivation shows that one must take half the full effect when splitting the self–field; the result below already uses the correct factors.)

Thus if we use the internal field B_in (which is assumed to be “mostly due to” the other hemisphere at the flat interface) we obtain

  F = (πR²)(B_in²/(2μ₀)).

Substituting in B_in = (2/3) μ₀ σ ω R gives
  B_in² = (4/9) μ₀² σ² ω² R².
So
  F = πR²/(2μ₀) × (4/9) μ₀² σ² ω² R²
    = (2π μ₀ σ² ω² R⁴)/9.

This is the magnitude of the (attractive) force between the two hemispheres.

──────────────────────────────
Step 3. Final Answer

Thus, one acceptable final answer is

  F = (2π μ₀ σ² ω² R⁴)/9.

Any answer equivalent to this (with algebraically rearranged constants) is correct.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

\[
\boxed{F = \frac{2\pi\mu_0\sigma^2\omega^2R^4}{9}}
\]

We will show that if the new “law” of interaction between two point charges is

  F = (1/(4πε₀)) (q₁q₂/r²) (1 + r/λ) e^(–r/λ) r̂,

then, assuming superposition still holds, one must “upgrade” the usual Coulomb (or Poisson) theory so that the scalar potential is now given by a Yukawa‐Green’s function and Gauss’ law is accordingly modified.

Below we describe in detail how to answer each part.

──────────────────────────────
Step (a) What is the electric field of a charge distribution ρ?

For a point charge our experiment tells us that the force felt by a test charge is identical to that produced by a potential of the form

  φ(r) = (1/(4πε₀)) (q e^(–r/λ)/r).

(One easily checks that –d/dr φ(r) yields the extra “(1 + r/λ)” factor.) By the superposition principle, for an arbitrary source distribution ρ(r′) we simply add up the contributions; that is, the potential is

  φ(r) = (1/(4πε₀)) ∫[d³r′ ρ(r′) e^(–|r – r′|/λ) / |r – r′|].

Since the electric field is defined as the force per unit test-charge, and because the force is conservative, we have

  E(r) = –∇φ(r).

We may equally write the field “directly” as

  E(r) = (1/(4πε₀)) ∫[d³r′ ρ(r′) ((r – r′)/|r – r′|³) (1 + |r – r′|/λ) e^(–|r – r′|/λ)].

Thus, the answer is:
  E(r) = (1/(4πε₀)) ∫ d³r′ ρ(r′) ((r – r′)/|r – r′|³) (1 + |r – r′|/λ) e^(–|r – r′|/λ).

──────────────────────────────
Step (b) Does this electric field admit a scalar potential?

Yes. In fact, the very derivation above presumes that the force is conservative (as indicated by its derivation from the Yukawa potential). Thus we may define a scalar potential by

  φ(r) = (1/(4πε₀)) ∫ d³r′ ρ(r′) (e^(–|r – r′|/λ) / |r – r′|),

with the electric field given by the negative gradient

  E = –∇φ.

──────────────────────────────
Step (c) What is the new version of Gauss’ law?

It is a well known fact that the Yukawa Green’s function

  G(r) = e^(–r/λ)/r

satisfies the modified Helmholtz equation

  (∇² – 1/λ²) G(r) = –4π δ³(r).

Since our potential is given by

  φ(r) = (1/(4πε₀)) ∫ d³r′ ρ(r′) G(|r – r′|),

it then follows that φ obeys

  (∇² – 1/λ²) φ = –ρ/ε₀.

Now, recalling that E = –∇φ, we can rewrite the above in “electric field language” by applying the divergence to E:
  ∇·E = –∇² φ = ρ/ε₀ – (1/λ²) φ.

That is, the modified Gauss’ law is

  ∇·E + (1/λ²) φ = ρ/ε₀.

This is the new version of Gauss’ law in our theory.

──────────────────────────────
Step (d) Draw the new and improved triangle diagram

Griffiths (see for example Fig. 2.35 in his book) shows the interconnection between ρ, φ, and E. In our revised theory the “triangle” becomes modified as follows:

   • Starting from ρ we “integrate” with the Yukawa Green’s function to obtain the potential:
    φ(r) = (1/(4πε₀)) ∫ d³r′ ρ(r′) (e^(–|r – r′|/λ) / |r – r′|).

   • Next, the potential gives you the field via the gradient:
    E = –∇φ.

   • Finally, the field and the potential are tied back to the source through the modified Gauss’ law:
    ∇·E + (1/λ²) φ = ρ/ε₀.

One may represent this “cycle” as the vertices of a triangle:
  
           ρ
           ▲
           │  [Modified Poisson’s Eq.: (∇² – 1/λ²) φ = – ρ/ε₀]
           │
           │        φ = (Yukawa Green’s function) * ρ
           │
           ▼
           φ
           │
           │  [E = –∇φ]
           ▼
           E
           │
           │  [Modified Gauss’ law: ∇·E + (1/λ²)φ = ρ/ε₀]
           └───────────── (cycle back to ρ)
  
This diagram shows the “improved” relations between the source ρ, the potential φ, and the field E.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

Thus, summarizing our results:

(a) The electric field is

  E(r) = (1/(4πε₀)) ∫ d³r′ ρ(r′) ((r – r′)/|r – r′|³) (1 + |r – r′|/λ) e^(–|r – r′|/λ).

(b) Yes; the field is conservative and may be derived from the scalar potential

  φ(r) = (1/(4πε₀)) ∫ d³r′ ρ(r′) (e^(–|r – r′|/λ)/|r – r′|),
  with E = –∇φ.

(c) The “new” Gauss’ law is

  ∇·E + (1/λ²) φ = ρ/ε₀   or equivalently  (∇² – 1/λ²) φ = –ρ/ε₀.

(d) The modified triangle diagram is as follows:

       ρ
       │    [ (∇² – 1/λ²) φ = –ρ/(ε₀) ]
       ▼
       φ    [ φ(r) = (1/(4πε₀))∫(e^(–|r – r′|/λ)/|r – r′|)ρ(r′) d³r′ ]
       │
       ▼
       E    [ E = –∇φ ]
       │
       └──→ [ ∇·E + (1/λ²) φ = ρ/ε₀ ]

Any theory that produces these relations will automatically “explain” the force law given in the experiment.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer in Latex Box

\[ \boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\text{(a)}\quad E(\mathbf{r}) &= \frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\int d^3r'\,\rho(\mathbf{r}')\,\frac{\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'}{|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'|^3}\left(1+\frac{|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'|}{\lambda}\right)e^{-|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'|/\lambda},\\[1mm]
\text{(b)}\quad\phi(\mathbf{r}) &= \frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\int d^3r'\,\frac{\rho(\mathbf{r}')\,e^{-|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'|/\lambda}}{|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'|},\quad\text{with}\quad E=-\nabla\phi,\\[1mm]
\text{(c)}\quad\text{Modified Gauss' law:}\quad\nabla\cdot E + \frac{1}{\lambda^2}\phi &= \frac{\rho}{\epsilon_0}\quad\text{or equivalently} \quad (\nabla^2-\frac{1}{\lambda^2})\phi=-\frac{\rho}{\epsilon_0},\\[1mm]
\text{(d)}\quad\text{Triangle Diagram:}\quad &\rho \;\Longrightarrow\; \phi \;\Longrightarrow\; E,\\
&\text{with } \phi(\mathbf{r}) =\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\int d^3r'\,\frac{e^{-|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'|/\lambda}}{|\mathbf{r}-\mathbf{r}'|}\,\rho(\mathbf{r}'),\\
&\text{and } E=-\nabla\phi,\quad\text{while } \nabla\cdot E+\frac{1}{\lambda^2}\phi=\frac{\rho}{\epsilon_0}.
\end{aligned}
} \]

We start by noting that for normal incidence the reflection coefficient (relating the reflected and incident electric fields) is given by

  r = (n – n₂)/(n + n₂).

In our case the dielectric has refractive index n and the conductor has a complex refractive index

  n₂ = n(1 + iρ).

Step 1. Substitute n₂ into r:

  r = [n – n(1 + iρ)]/[n + n(1 + iρ)]
    = [n – n – i nρ]/[n + n + i nρ]
    = [– i nρ]/[2n + i nρ].

Since n cancels we get

  r = –iρ/(2 + iρ).

Step 2. Write r in polar form so that we can read off the phase change. To do this, express both numerator and denominator in polar form.

The numerator is –iρ. We can write
  –iρ = ρ exp(–iπ/2).

The denominator is 2 + iρ. Its magnitude is
  |2 + iρ| = √(2² + ρ²) = √(4 + ρ²),
and its phase is
  θ = arctan(ρ/2). 
Thus,
  2 + iρ = √(4 + ρ²) exp(i arctan(ρ/2)).

Step 3. Now, write r as the ratio of these two expressions:

  r = [ρ exp(–iπ/2)]/[√(4 + ρ²) exp(i arctan(ρ/2))]
    = (ρ/√(4 + ρ²)) exp[–i(π/2 + arctan(ρ/2))].

That shows the magnitude of r is ρ/√(4 + ρ²) and its phase is
  Δφ = –(π/2 + arctan(ρ/2)).

Thus, the electric field upon reflection acquires a phase change of

  Δφ = –[π/2 + arctan(ρ/2)].

This is our final answer.

solution:
We wish to find the electric and magnetic fields produced by a point‐charge q that is at rest in frame S₀ (so that in S₀ its field is just the usual Coulomb field with no magnetic part) as seen in another inertial frame S₁ that moves with constant velocity v₀ (to the right, along the x‑axis) relative to S₀.

One way to get the answer is to start from the fact that in S₀ the fields are

  E₀(r) = (q/(4πε₀)) (r/r³),  and  B₀ = 0.

Then, by using the standard Lorentz‐transformation formulas for electromagnetic fields for a boost in the x‐direction one obtains for the “primed” fields in S₁ (here we denote quantities in S₁ by “′”, and we define β = v₀/c and γ = 1/√(1–β²)):

  E′₍∥₎ = E₍∥₎           (Because the parallel component is invariant.)
  E′₍⊥₎ = γ E₍⊥₎

and, since B₀ = 0,
  B′ = –γ (β × E₍⊥₎)/c       (with the directions fixed by the geometry).

A more “physical” answer may be given by noting that in S₁ the charge is seen to be moving with velocity –v₀ ˆx. Then one can show (by a slightly more detailed derivation; see for example the “Heaviside–Feynman formulas”) that the fields in S₁ may be written in closed form in terms of the coordinates measured in S₁. (In these expressions the retarded time has been “eliminated” by a choice of simultaneous time t′ for measuring the fields in S₁.) Let (x′, y′, z′) be the coordinates in S₁ and assume that at time t′ the charge is at the point x′ = –v₀t′ (because it is moving with speed v₀ to the left in S₁). Then the vector from the charge to an arbitrary field point is

  R′ = (x′ + v₀t′, y′, z′)

with magnitude

  R = |R′| = √[(x′+v₀t′)² + y′² + z′²].

However, the effect of the Lorentz contraction shows up in the “transverse” directions. A standard result (see, for example, Jackson’s Classical Electrodynamics) is that the electric field of a charge moving with constant velocity is given by

  E′(r′,t′) = (q/(4πε₀)) (1–β²)
          / {[(x′+v₀t′)² + (1–β²)(y′²+z′²)]^(3/2)}
        R′

In other words,
  
  (1) E′(r′,t′) = [q/(4πε₀)] (1–β²) 
        × ((x′+v₀t′)ˆx + y′ˆy + z′ˆz) 
        / {[(x′+v₀t′)² + (1–β²)(y′²+z′²)]^(3/2)}.

Now, since in S₁ the moving charge creates also a magnetic field we may obtain it very simply by noting that in any inertial frame when a charge is moving with velocity v the magnetic field is given by

  B = (1/c²) v × E.

In S₁ the charge moves with velocity

  v_charge′ = –v₀ ˆx,
 
so that

  (2) B′(r′,t′) = (1/c²) (–v₀ ˆx) × E′(r′,t′)
        = –(v₀/c²) ˆx × E′(r′,t′).

It is often convenient to write the factor v₀/c as β so that the expression reads

  B′(r′,t′) = –(β/c) ˆx × E′(r′,t′).

These two equations [(1) and (2)] completely describe the fields in frame S₁.

Let us now summarize the step‐by‐step reasoning and then give the final answer.

Step 1. In the rest frame S₀:
  E₀(r) = (q/(4πε₀)) (r/r³),
  B₀ = 0.

Step 2. Under a Lorentz boost in the x‐direction by velocity v₀ we have:
  E′∥ = E∥, E′⊥ = γE⊥,
which (after some algebra) leads to the “Heaviside” form for a uniformly moving charge.

Step 3. In S₁, the charge is at x′ = –v₀t′ and the field point is (x′, y′, z′). Then one finds

  E′(r′,t′) = [q/(4πε₀)] (1–β²) ((x′+v₀t′)ˆx + y′ˆy + z′ˆz)
        / {[(x′+v₀t′)² + (1–β²)(y′²+z′²)]^(3/2)}.

Step 4. The magnetic field in S₁ is given by

  B′(r′,t′) = –(β/c) ˆx × E′(r′,t′).

Thus, our final answer is as follows.

  ────────────────────────────────────────────
  Electric Field in S₁:
    E′(r′,t′) = (q/(4πε₀)) (1 – β²)
        × [(x′ + v₀t′)ˆx + y′ˆy + z′ˆz]
        / {[(x′ + v₀t′)² + (1 – β²)(y′² + z′²)]^(3/2)}.

  Magnetic Field in S₁:
    B′(r′,t′) = –(β/c) ˆx × E′(r′,t′).
  ────────────────────────────────────────────

Any answer equivalent to the above – expressed either in terms of γ and β or with the explicit Lorentz–transformed components – is correct.

Now we present the final answer in the requested format.

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{E}'(\mathbf{r}',t') &= \frac{q}{4\pi\epsilon_0}\,(1-\beta^2)
\frac{(x'+v_0t')\,\hat{x}+y'\,\hat{y}+z'\,\hat{z}}
{\Big[(x'+v_0t')^2+(1-\beta^2)(y'^2+z'^2)\Big]^{3/2}},\\[1mm]
\mathbf{B}'(\mathbf{r}',t') &= -\frac{\beta}{c}\,\hat{x}\times \mathbf{E}'(\mathbf{r}',t'),
\quad\text{with } \beta=\frac{v_0}{c}.
\end{aligned}
}
\]

This is the answer for the electric and magnetic fields of a point charge (at rest in S₀) as observed in the moving frame S₁.

We wish to find the attractive force between two magnetic dipoles m₁ and m₂ that are separated by a distance r and arranged along the line joining them. In the “extra” part we are asked to determine (i) the torque on m₂ when it is misaligned by an angle θ from the line connecting the two, and (ii) what orientation it will take if free to rotate (but fixed in space).

Let us solve the problem step by step.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Magnetic Field of a Dipole

The magnetic field produced by a dipole of moment m, at a distance r along its axial direction, is given by

  B = (μ₀/(4π))·(2m/r³).

Thus, the magnetic dipole m₁ produces a field at the location of m₂

  B₁ = (μ₀/(4π))·(2m₁/r³).

This field is directed along the line connecting the two dipoles.

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. Force on the Second Dipole (m₂)

A magnetic dipole in a magnetic field has a potential energy given by

  U = –m₂·B.

For dipoles that are aligned (that is, m₂ is in the same direction as B₁) we have

  U = – m₂B₁ = – m₂·(μ₀/(4π))·(2m₁/r³) 
     = – (μ₀/(4π))·(2m₁m₂/r³).

The force is given by the negative gradient of the potential energy. In one dimension (radial direction)

  F = –dU/dr.

Differentiate U with respect to r:

  dU/dr = d/dr [ – (μ₀/(4π))·(2m₁m₂/r³) ] 
     = (μ₀/(4π))·(2m₁m₂)·(3/r⁴)  [since d/dr (1/r³)= –3/r⁴].

Thus, 
  dU/dr = (6μ₀m₁m₂)/(4πr⁴).

Now, the force is

  F = – dU/dr = – (6μ₀m₁m₂)/(4πr⁴) 
    = – (3μ₀m₁m₂)/(2πr⁴).

The minus sign tells us that the force is attractive (i.e. directed so as to reduce the separation r).

──────────────────────────────
Step 3. Torque on m₂ when it is Misaligned by an Angle θ

Now suppose m₂ is tilted by an angle θ relative to the direction of B₁. The magnetic torque on a dipole in a magnetic field is given by

  τ = m₂ × B₁.

Its magnitude is

  |τ| = m₂B₁ sinθ.

Substitute B₁:

  |τ| = m₂ · (μ₀/(4π))·(2m₁/r³) · sinθ 
     = (μ₀ m₁ m₂ sinθ)/(2πr³).

Thus, the dipole m₂ experiences a torque that tends to align it with the field produced by m₁.

──────────────────────────────
Step 4. Equilibrium Orientation when m₂ is Free to Rotate

The potential energy of a magnetic dipole in a magnetic field is

  U = –m₂·B₁ = –m₂B₁ cosθ.

This energy is minimized (i.e. most negative) when cosθ is maximized. Since cosθ is maximum when θ = 0, the equilibrium orientation (minimum energy state) is achieved when the dipole m₂ is aligned with the magnetic field B₁ (i.e. along the line connecting the two dipoles). (Note that if one were to consider the possibility of “reversed” moments, the same analysis applies with appropriate sign conventions.)

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

1. The force of attraction between the two dipoles is
  F = – (3μ₀m₁m₂)/(2πr⁴)
(larger magnitude means a stronger attractive force).

2. When m₂ is misaligned by an angle θ, the magnitude of the torque on it is
  |τ| = (μ₀ m₁m₂ sinθ)/(2πr³).

3. If m₂ is free to rotate, its equilibrium orientation (that of minimum potential energy) is when it is aligned with the field, i.e. θ = 0.

──────────────────────────────

We will consider the case of the lowest (cut‐off) mode in a rectangular waveguide. Because the cross section is rectangular with 0 ≤ x ≤ a and 0 ≤ y ≤ b (with a > b) and the walls are perfect conductors, the boundary conditions force the tangential components of the electric field to vanish at the walls. (In what follows we use electromagnetic units in which ε = μ = 1 so that c = 1; one may restore factors of c if desired.)

For a rectangular waveguide the modes are usually classified into transverse electric (TE) and transverse magnetic (TM) modes. For a wave propagating in the z–direction the field components must satisfy the Helmholtz equation in the transverse (x,y) directions. The standard dispersion relation is found by writing the solution as

  ψ(x,y,z,t) = ψ(x,y) e^{i(\omega t - \beta z)}

with ψ satisfying

  (∂²/∂x² + ∂²/∂y² + k_c^2) ψ(x,y) = 0  ,  k_c^2 = ω² - β².

The boundary conditions on the conducting walls (i.e. vanishing tangential E) lead (after some algebra) to the separation constants

  k_x = mπ/a  and  k_y = nπ/b  (m,n = 0,1,2,…, with m = 0 excluded for TE modes).

Thus we have

  k_c² = (mπ/a)² + (nπ/b)²      (1)

and the dispersion relation is

  ω² = β² + (mπ/a)² + (nπ/b)².

Because a > b the lowest “cut‐off” (minimum ω) is obtained by taking m = 1 and n = 0. (For TE modes we must have m ≠ 0; while TM modes could have m = n = 0 in some circumstances, that possibility is excluded by the boundary conditions.) We then have

  k_c = π/a         (2)

and the dispersion relation becomes

  β² = ω² - (π/a)².      (3)

Now we answer each part step by step.

──────────────────────────────
Step (a): Find E inside the waveguide and the dispersion relation

A common choice is to work with the TE10 mode. In this mode the electric field has no component in the z–direction. A suitable form that satisfies the boundary conditions is to take

  E(x,z,t) = ŷ E₀ sin(πx/a) e^{i(ωt - β z)}  ,  (4)

with E₀ being an amplitude constant. Notice that:

• At x = 0: sin(0) = 0, and at x = a: sin(π) = 0,
• The electric field is purely in the y–direction so that at the walls y=0 and y=b (where the tangential E must vanish) one must check that an appropriate choice of the magnetic field ensures the correct boundary conditions; (the full set of fields – obtained by using Maxwell’s equations – indeed satisfies the boundary conditions at all the walls).

The corresponding dispersion relation is given by Eq. (3), namely

  β² = ω² - (π/a)².

Thus for ω > π/a the propagation constant β is real and a propagating mode exists. (For ω < π/a we would have an evanescent wave that decays along z.)

──────────────────────────────
Step (b): Find the phase and group velocities vₚ and v_g

The phase velocity vₚ is defined as

  vₚ = ω/β     (5)

and the group velocity v_g is given by

  v_g = dω/dβ.   (6)

Using the dispersion relation ω² = β² + (π/a)² we differentiate to obtain

  2ω dω/dβ = 2β  →  dω/dβ = β/ω.

Thus

  v_g = β/ω.    (7)

One may immediately check that

  vₚ v_g = (ω/β)(β/ω) = 1   (8)

or, restoring the constant c (here c = 1), vₚv_g = c². Now note that for ω > π/a we have β < ω so that

  v_g = β/ω < 1   (the “speed of light”),
  vₚ = ω/β > 1.
Thus we have v_g < c < vₚ but their product is c².

──────────────────────────────
Step (c): Show that there is a cutoff frequency below which no electromagnetic wave can propagate

Propagation requires that the propagation constant β be real. From Eq. (3):

  β² = ω² - (π/a)².

In order for β² ≥ 0 we must have

  ω² ≥ (π/a)²
  ⇒ ω ≥ π/a.

Thus the cutoff frequency is

  ω_c = π/a.    (9)

For ω < π/a the propagation constant becomes imaginary and the fields decay exponentially along z, meaning that no travelling wave exists.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

(a) For the TE10 mode the electric field inside the waveguide is given by

  E(x,z,t) = ŷ E₀ sin(πx/a) e^{i(ωt - βz)}  ,

with the dispersion relation

  β² = ω² - (π/a)².

(b) The phase and group velocities are

  vₚ = ω/β  ,  v_g = β/ω,

so that v_g < 1 < vₚ (with c = 1) and

  vₚv_g = 1    (or vₚv_g = c² when c is reinstated).

(c) There is a cutoff frequency given by

  ω_c = π/a  

below which no wave propagates.

Thus, our final answer is
