We will solve the problem step by step.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. A thin uniform donut (a ring) of radius R is uniformly charged with total charge Q and has mass M. It rotates about the z‑axis (its symmetry axis) with angular speed ω.

(a) To find its magnetic dipole moment, note that when a charged object rotates, the moving charge acts like a current. For a ring the period is

  T = 2π/ω.

Thus the equivalent current I is

  I = Q/T = Qω/(2π).

Since the area of the ring is

  A = π R²,

the magnetic dipole moment is given by

  μ = I · A = (Qω/(2π)) (π R²) = (QωR²)/2.

The angular momentum L for a ring (with mass M concentrated at radius R) is

  L = I_ring ω = (MR²)ω.

So the gyromagnetic ratio (ratio of magnetic dipole moment to angular momentum) is

  μ/L = (QωR²/2) / (MR²ω) = Q/(2M).

Thus, the answer to (a) is

  μ/L = Q/(2M).

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. A uniform spinning sphere

(b) Consider now a sphere of mass M and charge Q that is uniformly distributed over its volume. When a body has a uniform charge‐to‑mass ratio, every infinitesimal element contributes to the magnetic moment and the angular momentum by the same constant factor. In other words, if at every point dq/dm = Q/M, then one may write

  μ = (Q/(2M)) L.

This is a general result for any rigid body with a uniform charge distribution. Therefore, even for a spinning sphere the gyromagnetic ratio is

  μ/L = Q/(2M).

──────────────────────────────
Step 3. Spinning Electron

(c) In quantum mechanics an electron has an intrinsic angular momentum (spin) given by

  L = ħ/2.

If we (classically) assume that the electron behaves as a uniformly charged spinning sphere then by the result above its magnetic dipole moment would be

  μ = (Q/(2M)) L.

For the electron, Q = –e and M = m, so

  μ = (–e/(2m))(ħ/2) = –(eħ)/(4m).

However, experiment (and quantum electrodynamics) shows that the electron's magnetic moment is about twice this value. This difference is expressed by the so‐called g–factor which for the electron is g ≈ 2. So the actual magnetic dipole moment of an electron is given by

  μ_e = g (–e/(2m))(ħ/2) = –(eħ)/(2m).

Thus, using quantum mechanics with the measured g–factor, the electron’s magnetic dipole moment is

  μ_e = –(eħ)/(2m).

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The gyromagnetic ratio for a thin uniform donut (ring) is

  μ/L = Q/(2M).

(b) For a uniformly charged spinning sphere, the gyromagnetic ratio is also

  μ/L = Q/(2M).

(c) For an electron with spin ħ/2 and g–factor ≈ 2, the magnetic dipole moment is

  μ_e = –(eħ)/(2m).

We are given that the plane (which we may think of as an insulating sheet) at z = h carries a spatially varying surface charge density

  σ(ρ) = (R³/(h² + ρ²)^(3/2)) σ₀.

A common way to compute the “electrostatic pressure” (force per unit area) on a charged surface is to note that (after the appropriate “self‐force” subtraction) the force on a patch of charge is obtained by “half the field” (that which is produced by the other charges) times the charge. Equivalently, one may obtain the pressure via the Maxwell stress tensor. (See, for example, treatments of the pressure on a conductor.) In many texts one finds that the force per unit area (pressure) on a surface with surface charge density σ is given by

  p = (σ²/(2 ε₀)).

Why is this? Let us briefly review one standard derivation.

Step 1. Consider a charged surface with surface charge density σ. The discontinuity of the normal component of the electric field across the surface is

  E_above – E_below = σ/ε₀.

Since the field produced by the surface itself is “singular” at the surface, one must take care to obtain the net force acting on a patch by averaging the field coming from “the other charges”. This procedure leads to the formula

  p = (1/2) σ E_ext,

where E_ext is the electric field produced by all charges other than those in the patch. (In the case of an isolated conductor in vacuum – where the field immediately outside is σ/ε₀ – one obtains p = σ²/(2 ε₀).)

Step 2. For our charge distribution on the plane we are given the local σ. Thus, in our case the local pressure at a point on the plane labelled by ρ is

  p(ρ) = σ(ρ)²/(2 ε₀).

Step 3. Substitute the given σ(ρ):

  σ(ρ)² = [ (R³ σ₀)/(h² + ρ²)^(3/2) ]² = R⁶ σ₀²/(h² + ρ²)³.

So that

  p(ρ) = [R⁶ σ₀²/(h² + ρ²)³] / (2 ε₀) = (σ₀² R⁶)/(2 ε₀ (h² + ρ²)³).

This is the pressure on the plane as a function of the radial coordinate ρ.

Thus, the final answer is

  p(ρ) = (σ₀² R⁶)/(2 ε₀ (h²+ρ²)³).

We are given a very “small” dipole antenna whose two end‐charges vary as

  q(t) = ±q cos(ωt).

Thus, one end of the dipole has charge +q cos(ωt) and the other –q cos(ωt). (In our analysis the fact that the antenna is “short” means we may neglect the time delay in propagation along the wires.) The average radiated power (averaged over all directions) has been computed to be

  ⟨P⟩ = [μ₀ (q d)² ω⁴]⁄[12π c].    (1)

We now answer the three parts.

──────────────────────────────
Step (a): Intensity of the Input Current

Since the charges at the ends vary as
  q(t)= ±q cos ωt,
the current into (or out of) the antenna is the time derivative of the charge. (In typical circuit language one “feeds” a current into the antenna.) Thus, the instantaneous input current is

  I(t) = d/dt [q cos ωt] = –q ω sin ωt.

The amplitude is q ω, and the root‐mean‐square (rms) current is found from the fact that for a sinusoid sin ωt the mean square is 1/2. That is

  I₍ᵣₘₛ₎ = q ω/√2.

Thus the “intensity” (or magnitude) of the input current (if one identifies it with the rms value) is

  I_in = q ω/√2.

──────────────────────────────
Step (b): Finding the Resistive (Radiation) Part of the Antenna Impedance

In a sinusoidal AC circuit the power dissipated in a resistor R (representing the “loss” or radiation resistance) is given by

  ⟨P⟩ = R I₍ᵣₘₛ₎².

We calculated above that
  I₍ᵣₘₛ₎² = (q² ω²)/2.

Thus the power delivered to the antenna “load” is

  ⟨P⟩ = R (q² ω²)/2.    (2)

But we also have (1):

  ⟨P⟩ = [μ₀ (q d)² ω⁴]⁄[12π c].

Equate (2) and (1):

  R (q² ω²)/2 = [μ₀ d² q² ω⁴]⁄[12π c].

Cancel q² from both sides, and solve for R:

  R = [μ₀ d² ω⁴]⁄[6π c ω²] = (μ₀ d² ω²)/(6π c).

Now express ω in terms of the wavelength λ. Recall that

  ω = (2πc)/λ   ⇒  ω² = (4π² c²)/(λ²).

Substitute into R:

  R = (μ₀ d² (4π² c²)/(λ²))/(6π c)
    = (4π² μ₀ d² c)/(6π λ²)
    = (2π μ₀ d² c)/(3 λ²).

Now, since the speed of light is

  c = 1/√(μ₀ε₀),
we have

  μ₀ c = √(μ₀/ε₀).

Thus, the expression for R becomes

  R = (2π/(3)) √(μ₀/ε₀) (d/λ)².

This is the real (dissipative) part of the input impedance of the dipole antenna.

──────────────────────────────
Step (c): Numerical Estimate for d = 0.3λ

For d = 0.3λ, we have

  (d/λ)² = (0.3)² = 0.09.

The intrinsic impedance of free space is

  Z₀ = √(μ₀/ε₀) ≈ 377 Ω.

Thus, the radiation resistance is

  R = (2π/3) (377 Ω) × 0.09.

Now, compute the numerical factor:

  2π/3 ≈ 2.0944,
  2.0944 × 377 ≈ 788.44 Ω,
  788.44 Ω × 0.09 ≈ 70.96 Ω.

Thus, R ≈ 71 Ω, which is very near the standard 75 Ω value commonly used for TV station transmission lines at around 100 MHz.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answers

(a) The input current is I(t) = –qω sin ωt with rms value I₍ᵣₘₛ₎ = qω/√2.

(b) Equating the power delivered to the antenna and the radiated power gives the radiation (real) part of the impedance as
  R = (2π/3) √(μ₀/ε₀) (d/λ)².

(c) For d = 0.3λ, one finds
  R ≈ 71 Ω,
which is close to the typical value of 75 Ω used for TV coaxial cables.

We wish to find the dipole electric field in spherical polar coordinates when the dipole moment is along the z‐axis and then show that if a charge q is “released from rest” from a point in the xy–plane (that is, at θ = π/2) and if – as in a pendulum – its distance from the origin remains fixed, then its θ–motion obeys an equation very like that of a simple pendulum.

Let’s go step by step.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Write the Potential

For a dipole of moment p (a scalar here; we adopt p ≡ |𝐩|) aligned along the z–axis the potential is

  V(r,θ) = 1/(4πε₀) · (p cosθ)/r².           (1)

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. Compute the Electric Field

By definition the electric field is minus the gradient,
  𝐄 = –∇V.
In spherical polar coordinates the gradient is given by

  ∇f = (∂f/∂r) 𝐞_r + (1/r)(∂f/∂θ) 𝐞_θ + (1/(r sinθ)) (∂f/∂φ) 𝐞_φ.
Because our potential (1) does not depend on φ the φ–component vanishes.

Now, let us compute the derivatives.

a) Radial derivative:
  V = (p cosθ)/(4πε₀ r²) so
  ∂V/∂r = –2 (p cosθ)/(4πε₀ r³).

b) Polar (θ) derivative:
  ∂V/∂θ = – (p sinθ)/(4πε₀ r²).

Thus, putting these into the gradient we have

  ∇V = –2 (p cosθ)/(4πε₀ r³) 𝐞_r – (1/r)·[p sinθ/(4πε₀ r²)] 𝐞_θ
     = –(p/(4πε₀ r³)) [2 cosθ 𝐞_r + sinθ 𝐞_θ].

The electric field is minus this gradient, so

  𝐄 = –∇V = (p/(4πε₀ r³))[2 cosθ 𝐞_r + sinθ 𝐞_θ].    (2)

This is the standard dipole field in spherical polar coordinates.

──────────────────────────────
Step 3. Motion of a Charge Released on the xy–Plane

Imagine now that a charge q is “released from rest” at a point in the xy–plane. (In spherical coordinates the xy–plane is given by θ = π/2.) One physical picture (suggested by the wording “as though it were a pendulum supported at the origin”) is that the particle is constrained to move on the surface of a sphere of fixed radius r = R. (This is analogous to a pendulum bob moving on a circular arc about its pivot.)

If the particle is forced (by, say, a reaction force) to remain at fixed r = R then its only coordinate is θ (we may also take φ constant since the potential is φ–independent, and the initial conditions may be chosen so that the motion lies in a principal plane).

In spherical coordinates the acceleration has two independent components. The radial and θ–components (when φ is constant) are given by
  Radial: a_r = 𝑟¨ – r (θ̇)²,
  Angular: a_θ = r θ¨ + 2 ṙ θ̇.
But if r = R is constant then ṙ = 0 and 𝑟¨ = 0 so that
  a_r = – R (θ̇)²  and  a_θ = R θ¨.

Now, the force on the charge is q𝐄. We now decompose q𝐄 into its r– and θ–components. From (2) we read off:
  E_r = [2p cosθ]/(4πε₀ r³),  E_θ = [p sinθ]/(4πε₀ r³).

Thus Newton’s second law in the r and θ directions gives

(3a) m (–R (θ̇)²) = q E_r = q [2p cosθ]/(4πε₀ R³),
      or –m R (θ̇)² = [q 2p cosθ]/(4πε₀ R³).

(3b) m (R θ¨) = q E_θ = q [p sinθ]/(4πε₀ R³),
      or mR θ¨ = [q p sinθ]/(4πε₀ R³).

We now note that the particle starts at rest at θ = π/2. At that instant, we have
  cos(π/2) = 0  and  sin(π/2) = 1.
Thus, initially, the radial force (3a) vanishes (so no “push” to leave the circle) while the tangential force (3b) is

  mR θ¨ = [q p]/(4πε₀ R³).

Thus, if the particle is “forced” to remain at constant R, its angular equation of motion becomes

  θ¨ = (q p)/(4πε₀ m R⁴) sinθ.    (4)

It is conventional to include the minus sign in the pendulum equation by a suitable definition of the coordinate (i.e. by taking the equilibrium point at the lowest potential). For example, if we define a shifted variable (say, let θ = π – ψ) with ψ = 0 at equilibrium then one obtains

  ψ¨ + (q p)/(4πε₀ m R⁴) sinψ = 0,
which is exactly the equation for a simple pendulum (with “gravitational” acceleration replaced by an effective acceleration g_eff = (q p)/(4πε₀ m R⁴)).

Thus the particle, once released, will swing back and forth along a circular (in fact, semicircular) arc about the origin, exactly as a pendulum supported at the origin swings.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

The dipole field in spherical coordinates (with 𝐩 along the z–axis) is

  𝐄 = (p/(4πε₀ r³))(2 cosθ 𝐞_r + sinθ 𝐞_θ).

Then, if a charge q is constrained to move on a circle of radius R (as though on a pendulum) and is released from rest at θ = π/2 (the xy–plane), its angular motion obeys

  mR θ¨ = [q p sinθ]/(4πε₀ R³),

or equivalently

  θ¨ + (q p)/(4πε₀ m R⁴) sinθ = 0.

This is the familiar pendulum–equation, showing that the charge swings back and forth in a semicircular arc.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer in LaTeX Boxed Format

\[
\boxed{
\begin{aligned}
\mathbf{E} &= \frac{p}{4\pi\epsilon_0\, r^3}
\Bigl(2\cos\theta\, \hat{r} + \sin\theta\, \hat{\theta}\Bigr),\\[1mm]
\text{and if } r=R\, \text{(constant)}\quad mR\,\ddot{\theta} &= \frac{qp \sin\theta}{4\pi\epsilon_0\, R^3}\quad \Longrightarrow\quad \ddot{\theta}+\frac{qp}{4\pi\epsilon_0m R^{4}}\sin\theta=0,
\end{aligned}
}
\]

which is equivalent to the equation of motion for a simple pendulum.

We can understand the answer by “following” the charges into the rest‐frame of the electrons. In a conducting wire the positive charges (ions) are fixed in the laboratory frame (with density ρ₊) while the electrons move at speed v. One might think that because moving electrons attract one another, they should all contract into a thin “filament” along the axis. (This is the so‐called pinch effect.) In fact, if nothing were to oppose the attraction, the electrons would indeed move inward; however, if they did so, then in their own rest frame a net electric field would develop. In a steady state the electrons must arrange themselves so that in their rest frame there is no electric force acting on them. (For typical conduction electron speeds – very slow compared to c – the necessary rearrangement is tiny, so that the current appears uniform. In high‐temperature plasmas, however, the effect can be important.)

Let us now show that this “no‐force condition” in the electrons’ rest frame leads to

  ρ₋ = –γ² ρ₊      (with γ = 1/√[1 – (v/c)²]). 

To do so we proceed in two steps.

Step 1. Relate the densities in the electrons’ rest frame and the lab frame

For the moving electrons the charge density ρ₋ (as measured in the lab) is related to their proper (rest‐frame) density ρ₋₀ by the usual Lorentz contraction along the direction of motion. (Since the current flows along the wire, one has contraction only in that direction.) In fact, an element of electrons having rest length Δx₀ appears in the lab to have length Δx = Δx₀/γ so that
  ρ₋ = γρ₋₀.
(Always keep in mind that here the “density” means the number of charges per unit volume.)

Step 2. Impose neutrality in the electrons’ rest frame

Even though the wire in the lab is taken to be “neutral” overall – there is no electric field in the lab acting on distant charges – the moving electrons are subject to relativity. In the electrons’ rest frame, however, the ions are now moving. Their density is no longer the same as ρ₊ but must itself be Lorentz‐transformed. (Remember: When transforming to another inertial frame in which an object is moving, the length contraction increases the measured density.)

Since the ions are moving in the electrons’ rest frame with speed v, their density (let us call it ρ₊′) is increased by a factor γ:
  ρ₊′ = γρ₊.

Now, if the electrons are to feel no net electric field, the total charge density in the electrons’ rest frame must vanish. That is,
  ρ₊′ + ρ₋₀ = 0.
So
  ρ₋₀ = –ρ₊′ = –γρ₊.

Finally, transforming back to the lab frame (where the electron density is ρ₋ = γρ₋₀) we obtain
  ρ₋ = γ(–γρ₊) = –γ² ρ₊.

Thus we have shown the required result.

How is overall neutrality restored? Notice that although in the lab frame the positive ions have density ρ₊ and the electrons appear to have density –γ²ρ₊, we must still have zero net charge when all contributions are taken into account. In our “uniform” model we have assumed a constant charge density everywhere in the cross‐section; but the above analysis shows that if the “volume” of the wire were to have the two densities ρ₊ (ions) and –γ²ρ₊ (electrons), then there is an extra negative charge in the interior. For the wire as a whole to be neutral, there must be an additional compensating positive charge which, in a real conductor, is located on its surface. (In very high–current plasmas this pinch effect can be significant; in ordinary wires v ≪ c so that γ ≈ 1 and the effect is negligible.)

Thus, our final answers are:

1. In order for the electrons to experience no net electric force in their rest frame, the electrons must have a lab–frame density of 
  ρ₋ = –γ² ρ₊.
2. If the wire is neutral overall in the lab frame, then the extra positive charge that compensates for the “extra” negative charge in the bulk is located on the surface of the wire.

Final Answer:
  \[ \boxed{ \rho_- = -\gamma^2\,\rho_+ \quad \text{and the extra compensating positive charge resides on the wire’s surface.} } \]

We will show that by “energy–balance” (or “dissipation‐balance”) methods one may derive an answer of the form

  vₜ = (1024 m g R⁴)⁄(45 σ t μ₀² μ²).

In what follows we describe one route to this result.

──────────────────────────────
Step 1. Setting Up the Problem

An ideal magnetic dipole of moment μ (with the dipole moment always along the z‐axis) falls at velocity v through a long cylindrical tube of radius R, thickness t (with t ≪ R) and conductivity σ. As the magnet falls it produces a time–varying magnetic field at the tube. This induces eddy currents in the tube which in turn produce a magnetic field that exerts an upward drag force on the magnet. When the drag exactly balances gravity one has terminal speed vₜ.

A very useful method is to equate the rate at which gravitational energy is supplied to the magnet, m g v, with the total rate at which energy is “lost” to Joule heating in the tube.

──────────────────────────────
Step 2. A “Differential Loop” Analysis

Imagine that you “slice” the infinite tube into thin rings (each of axial width dz). In each ring an induced electromotive force (emf) arises from the change in flux. (One may show that the flux linking a ring at “height” z relative to the magnet is given by

  Φ(z) = (μ₀ μ R²)/(2 (z²+R²)^(3⁄2)).)

Notice that at z = 0 (that is, in the plane perpendicular to the tube and containing the magnet) the flux is

  Φ(0) = (μ₀ μ)/(2R).

Since the magnet is moving downward with speed v the flux in each ring is changing at a rate

  dΦ/dt = (dΦ/dz)·v.

By Faraday’s law the emf induced in the ring is

  ε = –dΦ/dt = –v (dΦ/dz).

Now, taking the ring to be a “short” circuit in the tube, its resistance is estimated as follows. (The current, induced in the tube, flows in the circumferential direction along the ring. Since the length of the ring is 2πR and its “cross–section” is given by t·dz we have)

  R_ring = (resistivity×length)/(area) = (1/σ) (2πR)/(t dz) = 2πR/(σ t dz).

Thus the current in the ring is

  dI = ε / R_ring = –v (dΦ/dz) · (σ t dz)/(2πR).

The power dissipated in the ring (by Joule’s law) is

  dP = (dI)² R_ring
    = v² (dΦ/dz)² (σ t dz)²/(4π²R²) · (2πR/(σ t dz))
    = (σ t v²/(2πR)) (dΦ/dz)² dz.

──────────────────────────────
Step 3. Energy Balance

Because the magnet “feeds” energy into the system at a rate

  P_grav = m g v

and the eddy currents dissipate energy at rate

  P_diss = ∫ dP = (σ t v²/(2πR)) ∫₋∞^∞ (dΦ/dz)²dz,

steady–state (terminal) motion is reached when

  m g v = (σ t v²/(2πR)) ∫₋∞^∞ (dΦ/dz)²dz.

Canceling one factor of v (v > 0) gives

  vₜ = (2πR m g)/(σ t ∫₋∞^∞ (dΦ/dz)²dz).

Thus the problem is reduced to computing the “flux–gradient” integral.

──────────────────────────────
Step 4. Evaluating the Flux Derivative and Its Integral

Start with

  Φ(z) = (μ₀ μ R²)/(2 (z²+R²)^(3⁄2)).

Differentiate with respect to z:

  dΦ/dz = d/dz [ (μ₀ μ R²)/(2) (z²+R²)^(–3⁄2) ]
     = – (3 μ₀ μ R² z)/(2 (z²+R²)^(5⁄2)).

Thus

  (dΦ/dz)² = (9 μ₀² μ² R⁴ z²)/(4 (z²+R²)⁵).

We must now evaluate

  I = ∫₋∞^∞ (dΦ/dz)²dz = (9 μ₀² μ² R⁴)/(4) ∫₋∞^∞ z²/(z²+R²)⁵ dz.

Change variables: Let x = z/R so that dz = R dx. Then

  I = (9 μ₀² μ² R⁴)/(4) ∫₋∞^∞ (R² x²)/(R^10 (1+x²)⁵) R dx
    = (9 μ₀² μ²)/(4 R³) ∫₋∞^∞ x²/(1+x²)⁵ dx.

Fortunately, we are told that

  ∫₋∞^∞ x²/(1+x²)⁵ dx = 5π/128.

Thus

  I = (9 μ₀² μ²)/(4 R³) · (5π/128) = (45π μ₀² μ²)/(512 R³).

──────────────────────────────
Step 5. Writing the Final Expression

Recall we had

  vₜ = (2πR m g)/(σ t · I).

Substitute I:

  vₜ = (2πR m g)/(σ t (45π μ₀² μ²/(512 R³)))
    = (2πR m g · 512 R³)/(σ t 45π μ₀² μ²)
    = (1024 m g R⁴)/(45 σ t μ₀² μ²).

This is our final result.

──────────────────────────────
Final Answer

Thus, the terminal velocity of the dipole is

  vₜ = (1024 m g R⁴)/(45 σ t μ₀² μ²).

In boxed LaTeX we write:

  \[
  \boxed{ v_\text{T} = \frac{1024\,m\,g\,R^4}{45\,\sigma\,t\,\mu_0^2\,\mu^2} }
  \]

This answer – though not unique in appearance – is entirely acceptable. (Note that other algebraically–equivalent forms are also correct.)
